PUB-DATE: April 18, 1999

SECTION: Section 1; Page 37; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front

LENGTH: 1285 words

HEADLINE: Despite Deregulation, Utilities Avoid New York

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 17

 BODY:
For years, officials here and in other state capitals have hailed competition as a way to lower electricity bills, and New York is one of just five states that have actually begun letting some customers choose their supplier of power.
But the price framework the Pataki administration has created provides very little room for competition, less than in almost any other state that has begun the process. Customers are learning that they cannot find a price much lower, or even slightly lower, than the one being offered by their old, familiar utilities. 
 As a result, most of the nation's major energy retailers have stayed out of New York, although they are competing aggressively for customers in several other states.
"We are not about to jump into the New York market and lose money," said Howard Fromer, director of government affairs in New York for Enron Corporation of Houston. "I can't believe any outside marketer is making money in the New York market."
Even some officials at the Public Service Commission, the state agency that regulates utilities, concede privately that there is far less competition than they had hoped for. It was the commission, whose members are appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki, that designed the system for competition.
But the commission's chairwoman, Maureen Helmer, said that while New York might have less robust competition than some states have now, it has laid the groundwork for more competition in the future. "I think when you look in one or two years, you're going to see a very different picture," she said.
New York has some of the highest electricity rates in the country, about 50 percent above the national average. Business groups say that makes the state less competitive economically, and they have long pushed for a freer energy market.
Environmentalists, too, have high hopes for competition. They predict that companies marketing "green power," power generated by the cleanest sources, will find ready takers even if the companies charge a little more for electricity, a theory borne out in other states. Power plants, particularly older ones burning coal and oil, are a major source of air pollution and acid rain.
"People are going to realize that the choice of an energy provider is the single most important environmental decision they can make," said Ralph Kavanagh, energy program co-director for the Natural Resources Defense Council.
But if the rate structure does not leave room for the biggest energy marketers to turn a profit in New York, smaller companies offering green power say they stand even less of a chance.
"New York's setup is just not supportive of competition," said Julie Blunden, vice president of Green Mountain Energy of South Burlington, Vt., a leading seller of green power that has shunned New York. "We don't market ourselves as being cheaper, but price competition helps us because it means people are out shopping for a new supplier."
Industry officials and analysts say they believe that New York's regulators wanted to shield the state's seven established regional utilities, including Consolidated Edison, from the pressures of competition. But some also contend that in making trade-offs, the Public Service Commission believed that it had no choice but to restrict competition.
As part of a five-year transition from the traditional monopolies to a competitive market, New York's utilities are being radically reorganized. They are selling their power plants and each one is splitting into two companies, one to own and maintain the transmission and distribution system, and the other to sell power to consumers. The commission was never sure that it had the legal authority to order such changes -- the utilities threatened to tie the state up in litigation for years if it tried -- so it negotiated the transition with the utilities, reaching agreements with them in 1997 and 1998.
At the same time, the Pataki administration was determined to begin the process with across-the-board rate reductions, which turned out to be 10 percent in Con Edison's territory and less in other parts of the state.
"To get the utilities to agree to restructuring and rate cuts, they settled for less competition than they might have gotten," said Larry Shapiro, staff attorney at the New York Public Interest Research Group.
Ms. Helmer said New York has been more aggressive than other states in getting utilities to sell their power plants. That, she said, will mean vigorous wholesale competition among power producers, which will eventually translate into retail competition and lower prices. The result, she said, will be "more sustainable benefits for New Yorkers than they may get in other states."
Advocates of competition laud the sale of the power plants, but they say the price structure the state set still poses a long-term problem.
Competition in New York began last year in Con Edison's territory, New York City and Westchester County, where about one-fifth of the market has been opened up to competitive bidding.
Consumers snapped up that power as soon as it was available, but it is unclear how much real competition that reflects. Retailers were able to offer only a very small savings over Con Edison's rates, based mostly on a tax loophole that the administration has warned it will close this year. And many of the consumers who took advantage of the competition did not sign up with an outside retailer, but with Con Edison's own new, competitive subsidiary.
Even after states introduce competition, the old utilities still hold monopoly control of the system that distributes power and delivers it to homes and businesses. So a portion of every customer's bill will continue to go to the utility, even if the customer buys electricity elsewhere.
In a highly subjective process, state regulators look at the old, monopoly-style utility bill and decide which charges represent those services the utilities will continue to provide and which reflect the actual price of electricity. The electricity portion of the bill is known as a "shopping credit" or a "back-out rate," meaning that consumers can stay with the utility, for now, at that price, or shop for a better deal.
The lower the shopping credit, the higher the guaranteed revenue for the established utility, and the harder it becomes for any company to undercut the utility's price.
Among four of the five states where competition has begun -- New York, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island -- as well as a few others that have set their price structures but have not yet ushered in competition, New York allows the least room for competition by setting the lowest shopping credits. The fifth state, California, is an anomaly in that regulators did not set specific shopping credits, letting them fluctuate instead, and its system effectively leaves even less of a margin for competition than New York's does.
The rate structure the Public Service Commission created for Con Edison allows a shopping credit averaging about 3.5 cents a kilowatt-hour out of a total bill of about 15 cents per kilowatt-hour, though both figures can vary widely. The credits are smaller, often less than 3 cents, for customers of upstate utilities like Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.
By comparison, most residents and businesses in Pennsylvania have shopping credits of 4 to 5 cents per kilowatt-hour; the credits are scheduled to rise over the next few years until the average is above 5 cents. New Jersey, which is scheduled to begin some competition on June 1, has decided on a framework with shopping credits generally above 5 cents. In Rhode Island and Massachusetts, the average shopping credit is about 3.5 cents.

HEADLINE: Do Computers Help the Economy?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The techno-pessimists you quote (front page, April 14) don't foresee productivity gains in knowledge work. They fail to understand the nature of most knowledge work. 
 Sure, we create and manipulate information. But very little of our work is truly original. Someone else has written the same contract clause, advertising plan or procedures manual. We recreate existing information only because it would be more costly to find and appropriate what has already been created elsewhere. That will change.
The "elsewheres" are rapidly becoming part of a global network. The World Wide Web is still in its infancy, yet most knowledge workers already turn to it first for information gathering. Our productivity improvements may be impossible to measure, but they are real and they are accelerating.
 
KIT SIMS TAYLOR
Bellevue, Wash., April 14, 1999
 
The writer is an economics instructor at Bellevue Community College.

HEADLINE: It's Not Just the Rich Who Are Getting Richer

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Victimless Income Gap?" (Op-Ed, April 12): One problem is that house prices have been driven up because of their location in good school districts, which are good because the wealthiest 1 percent of people have chosen to live there. 
 Unfortunately for Robert H. Frank's argument, this gives excellent support to the Pareto criterion, which holds that a change in circumstances must be counted as a good thing if it makes at least some people better off without harming any others. In fact, those middle- and lower-income families who live in the better districts have better schools precisely beause the rich have become richer.
The real problem is that "the quality of public schools is closely linked to local property taxes." The solutions are more efficient management of public schools and a more equitable way to finance them.
 
CHARLES CANTER
Amherst, Mass., April 12, 1999

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS;
Statements of United States' policy on Kosovo:

 BODY:
"In the event of conflict in Kosovo caused by Serbian action, the United States will be prepared to employ military force against the Serbians in Kosovo and in Serbia proper." President George Bush in a letter to Slobodan Milosevic, then Serbian President, Dec. 25, 1992.
 "We remain prepared to respond against the Serbians in the event of a conflict in Kosovo caused by Serbian action." Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Feb. 13, 1993 
 "U.S. policy has not changed." Robert Gelbard, U.S. special representative for the Balkans, March 4, 1998, when asked if Bush's "Christmas Warning" was still in effect.
 "The time to stop the killing is now, before it spreads. The way to do that is to take immediate action against the regime in Belgrade." Mrs. Albright, March 8, 1998, in Bonn.
 "I am determined to do all I can to stop a repeat of the human carnage in Bosnia and the 'ethnic cleansing.' And I have authorized, and I am supporting, an accelerated planning process for NATO." President Bill Clinton, June 9, 1998, in Washington.
 "While no decision has been made regarding the use of force, all options -- including robust military intervention in Kosovo -- remain on the table. NATO planning is on track and Milosevic understands that this is no idle threat." Mr. Gelbard, July 23, 1998, to the House International Relations Committee.
 "I believe that the credibility of NATO really is on the line, that one can not continue to prepare for possible military action or indeed threaten military action unless one is prepared to carry it out." Secretary of Defense William Cohen, Sept. 29, 1998, news conference at NATO Defense Ministers' meeting, Vilamoura, Portugal.
 "NATO is prepared to act if President Milosevic fails to honor the United Nations resolutions. The stakes are high. The time is now to end the violence in Kosovo." President Clinton, Oct. 6, 1998, opening the International Monetary Fund/World Bank annual meeting.
 "I think that the threshold has been crossed ... I do not believe that we ought to have to have thousands more people slaughtered and buried in open soccer fields before we do something." President Clinton, March 19, 1999, in Washington, after peace talks ended with only the Albanians signing the proffered agreement on Kosovo.
 "I don't intend to put our troops in Kosovo to fight a war." Mr. Clinton, March 24, 1999, announcing the start of air strikes that he said were designed to prevent a wider war.

HEADLINE: Best Herb;
This Bulb's Life

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill
<BLB>Shunned for centuries, garlic triumphs again. 

 BODY:
<DC>Hail garlic. The stinking rose, subject of ancient poetry and medical texts, has returned to glory.
For thousands of years, garlic, the most pungent member of the lily family (which includes chives, leeks and onions), had been esteemed by many cultures. The ancient Egyptians, who tucked garlic bulbs into their kings' tombs, swore oaths on the herb -- just as moderns do on the Bible. The sacrificial lambs of China were seasoned with garlic. Hippocrates prescribed raw garlic for an infected lung. And in the first half of this millennium, foods -- and cultures -- lacking in garlic were generally considered backward. By the 1700's, however, especially in Britain and America, the bloom was off the bulb. The smell of garlic had become synonymous with promiscuous, poor and superstitious peasant cultures. Garlic's fall was great -- but its resurrection, over the past half century, has been even greater. 
 At the turn of the current millennium, herbalism flourished, as did the notion of food as medicine. As the Church grew, however, ecclesiastical and medical considerations became more intertwined, especially at the dinner table. Six hundred years later, there was a growing tendency toward milder food -- an early attempt, some food historians suggest, at a holier-than-thou cuisine. Other historians consider this new blandness a reaction against the traditional use of boisterous aromatics, including garlic, to mask the taste of spoiled food.
And thus, over time, garlic became declasse in certain circles. The pro- and anti-garlic camps were largely divided along religious lines, with the mighty bulb more popular within the Mediterranean-based Catholic Church than in the less mystical churches of Northern Europe. During the Elizabethan era, cleanliness was increasingly equated with godliness, and strong scents were associated with lustiness and the Devil himself. In "Measure for Measure," Shakespeare points up the herb's low status when he has Lucio denounce the Duke as a man who "would eat mutton on Fridays" and "would mouth with a beggar, though she smelt of brown bread and garlic."
Nor was garlic favored in the young American republic, especially in polite society. Though it was used occasionally for medicinal purposes, it was generally off-limits in the culinary realm -- unless you were poor or a recent immigrant. Isabella Beeton, in her influential "Book of Household Management" (1861), wrote that "the smell of this plant is generally considered offensive."
But garlic's reputation was about to change. Waverley Root, in his dictionary "Food," wrote that when he left America for France in 1927, you were looked down upon if you ate garlic, and when he returned in 1940, you were looked down upon if you didn't. French cooking -- particularly the provincial style, which made liberal use of the herb -- had become a measure of gastronomic sophistication. As First Lady, Eleanor Roosevelt religiously chewed raw garlic to improve her memory.
These changes, however, occurred far from middle America. When I was growing up, in Columbus, Ohio, during the 1950's, there were two pariahs on the playground: the kids with B.O. and those who stank of garlic. I am embarrassed to recall the slurs we came up with for the Italian Catholics who sweated garlic.
But by the mid-1960's, even in my home economics class in Columbus, garlic had been declared the magical ingredient that would bring us all closer to Julia Child. Though my mother remained unimpressed, I, along with an entire generation, was perfumed by garlic right down to my Birkenstocks. This was a renaissance fueled by both taste and rebellion. Within counterculture circles, garlic became a staple of vegetarian cooking; and because ours was a generation that distrusted authority figures, particularly traditional doctors, garlic also became a darling of countless folk cures, some of which had roots reaching back thousands of years. By the 1990's, garlic had worked its way into the self-cure trinity, along with vitamin C and zinc.
And it looks as if garlic is here to stay. No other ingredient is featured as prominently in today's fashionable peasant cooking, to say nothing of the Mediterranean diet, which, with its emphasis on bread and garlic, bears a strong resemblance to the fare of the pyramid builders. (The recipe for bread-and-garlic sauce below is based on accounts of a mixture that was fed to Egyptian laborers and, later, to Roman soldiers. The recipe for garlic-and-almond soup is garlic grower Chester Aarons's interpretation of the Ur-gazpacho. The chicken recipe is based on a dish that a young fashion model consumed frequently and with great gusto, according to "Garlic and a Lady," an essay by Ford Madox Ford in his book "Provence." And the recipe for mashed potatoes proves that we've become comfortable enough with garlic to use it in the quintessential comfort food.)
By industry estimates, Americans eat more than 250 million pounds of garlic a year, more than four times the amount consumed in the 1970's. Most of it, some 90 percent, is grown around Gilroy, Calif., the only town in America, as Will Rogers said, where you can marinate a steak by hanging it out on a clothesline. Around the country, garlic festivals are booming; in gourmet circles, garlic snobbery runs rampant. Restaurants like Chez Panisse in Berkeley are creating seasonal dishes from green garlic, garlic shoots and bulbil caps (secondary, budlike cloves). Sophisticated epicures are fluent in the distinctions between various garlics: German Red is spicy, Spanish Roja intensely piquant and particularly pure; Inchelium Red, grown in Washington State, gets sharp with age, while Russian Red is faintly sweet. Grocery-store garlic is considered fit for only the unenlightened masses, and garlic salt and powder are beneath contempt. Then there are the debates over cooked garlic versus raw, and the various merits of mincing, chopping or using it whole.
It is safe to say that garlic has become a fetish. While there are no recent accounts of bulbs being tucked into the caskets of deceased heads of state, I do have a friend who rubbed garlic juice on the lips of his firstborn. Baby princes in 14th- and 15th-century England bore the same assault. My friend could not tell me if his act was meant to ward off vampires, or merely to rebel against the the antiseptic hospital room. He thought of it as a religious ritual, he said, although he has no religion. He is a man who trusts his own knowledge of herbal and homeopathic cures more than he does modern medicine. He is close to garlic, reassured by garlic; in his do-it-yourself pharmacopeia -- as well as in his kitchen -- garlic is god.
 
Garlic-and-Bread Sauce With Thyme
 
 4 ounces (about 6 slices) white bread, crusts removed, diced
 1/4 cup olive oil
 2 tablespoons red wine vinegar
 2 cloves garlic, minced
 3/4 teaspoon kosher salt
 A few grinds black pepper
 1/2 cup water
 2 teaspoons chopped thyme.
Combine all the ingredients except the thyme in a blender and process until fairly smooth (do not overprocess or the sauce will become gummy). Transfer to a bowl and stir in the thyme. Serve at room temperature or heat very gently over low heat. Serve as a sauce with grilled or roast meat or fish, or cold poached fish or chicken.
Yield: About 1 cup.
 
White Almond-Garlic Soup with Grapes
(Adapted from "The Great Garlic Book," by Chester Aaron, Ten Speed Press, 1997)
 
 1 3/4 cups (about 8 ounces) blanched, ground almonds
 3 slices white bread, crusts removed, diced
 10 cloves garlic, peeled
 6 cups milk
 2 teaspoons sherry vinegar
 2 cups extra-virgin olive oil
 Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 36 white seedless grapes, halved, for garnish.
1. In a large bowl, combine the almonds, bread, garlic, milk and vinegar. Working in three batches, transfer about a third of the mixture to a blender and process until smooth. With the motor running, slowly pour in 1/4 cup of olive oil. Strain the soup through a fine mesh sieve into a bowl. Repeat process with the remaining mixture.
2. Season the soup to taste with salt and pepper and chill for several hours. Before serving, taste the soup; if it tastes too strongly of either garlic or vinegar, add a bit of water. Serve the soup garnished with grape halves.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
A Young Lady's Poulet
 
 1 cup olive oil
 1 large roasting chicken, 4 to 5 pounds
 Kosher salt and pepper
 1 pound garlic (12 to 15 bulbs)
 4 large baking potatoes.
1. Preheat the oven to 325 degrees. Put a large pot of lightly salted water on to boil. On another burner, place a large ovenproof casserole over medium heat with 1/2 cup of olive oil.
2. Truss the chicken and season it all over with salt and freshly ground black pepper. When the oil is hot, gently slide the chicken, breast-down, into the casserole. Brown the chicken carefully on all sides. You will need to move the chicken around every two to three minutes so that the skin doesn't stick. The entire procedure will take about 20 minutes.
3. While the chicken is browning, break the garlic into individual cloves, but do not peel them. When the water boils, blanch the garlic for 2 minutes, drain immediately, refresh under cold running water and set aside. Peel the potatoes, cut each into six pieces and set aside.
4. When the chicken is brown on all sides, remove it from the casserole and push a quarter of the blanched garlic into the cavity and set aside. Discard the used olive oil; wipe the casserole. Add 1/4cup of new olive oil to the bottom of the casserole. Add the remaining garlic cloves and toss so that the cloves are lightly covered in olive oil. Add the chicken and baste it with 2 tablespoons of olive oil.
5. Place another skillet over high heat; add the remaining 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. When the oil is hot, quickly brown the potatoes. Discard the oil and arrange the potatoes around the chicken. Cover the casserole, put in the oven and bake for 90 minutes. Allow the chicken to rest at room temperature for 10 minutes before serving.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
Garlic-and-Herb Mashed Potatoes
 
 4 pounds (about 6) baking potatoes, peeled and quartered
 8 cloves garlic, peeled
 3 tablespoons unsalted butter
 3/4 cup milk or heavy cream, or a combination of both
 Kosher salt and freshly ground white pepper to taste
 1/2 cup chopped parsley
 2 tablespoons chopped herbs (any combination basil, thyme, chervil or chives).
1. Place the potatoes and garlic in a large saucepan and cover them with cold, salted water. Place over high heat and bring to a boil. Lower the heat and simmer until the potatoes are tender when pierced with a fork, about 20 minutes. Drain.
2. While they are still warm, pass the potatoes and garlic through a ricer or mash with a potato masher. Return the potatoes to the pan and stir in the milk or cream and the butter. (Add more milk or cream if they seem too stiff.) Stir in the parsley and herbs. Season to taste with salt and pepper and serve.
Yield: 6 servings.

HEADLINE: The Best of the First Millennium;
The Ice Age Cometh

BYLINE: By Felipe Fernandez-Armesto
<BLB>When China ruled, Islam rose and a lost sailor glimpsed America.; Felipe Fernandez-Armesto is the author of "Millennium," which is being made into a TV series for CNN.

 BODY:
<DC>Imagine a museum exhibition planned for 10,000 years in the future. The Galactic Museum will inaugurate its special millennium retrospectives on planet Earth with a show called "First Millennium, Christian Era: The Greatest Hits."
Across an immense distance of time and space, the Galactic curators will enjoy a perspective that allows the world to be seen whole. The impact will be paradoxical: refreshingly destructive. Our myths about the past will vanish. 
 The millennium before ours will be remembered not for the events that fill our textbooks -- the triumphs of barbarism and religion over "classical" civilizations -- but for the fact that for the first time cultures reached out and touched or almost touched. The Thule Inuit crossed the American Arctic, while in the opposite direction, the Norse navigated the Atlantic. Polynesians fanned across the Pacific. The Indian Ocean was crisscrossed with cultural contacts. The ideas and inventions of China spread west along developing trade routes. The heat of Arab imperialism forged the Middle East we know today. Indian missionaries and colonists spilled beyond the subcontinent. In Europe, heavy plows threatened the environment, and the stirrup transformed war.
Highlights in the Galactic Museum's retrospective will be genuine extracts from authentic documents -- surviving voices -- of the millennium. Here are some of them.
<DC>Exhibit #0964. From the prison-cell poetry of Boethius, a former secretary of state, awaiting execution for treason in the Ostrogothic kingdom of Italy, A.D. 524.
God's powerful love
Is undenied to all
Who in their search for goodness strove
Back: to the spring from whence they first did fall.
No worldly strain
Can linger without death
Unless love bring it back again a
Back to the source which first inspired its breath.
There were no new departures in the use of the mind -- in the first millennium A.D. or the next. So the main intellectual achievement of the millennium was the transmission of ancient traditions. Humankind relied on the old philosophies of Confucius, Lao-tzu, Buddha, Plato and Aristotle, the Upanishads and the Jewish Scriptures. The last of these inspired the two big, new religions of the period: Christianity and Islam.
Civilization depended on a few sages and monks who understood the ancient wisdom and passed it on. Their work was vital because of the strategic fragility of civilized life: literacy and scientific progress were threatened with extinction during this period in Europe and America. The scribes who kept tradition alive in the New World are unknown by name, but Boethius was one of the heroes of continuity in Europe. He helped to make Christianity an appealing fusion of Jewish and Greek traditions about God. In particular, he helped revive a reasoning method of Aristotle's, called "logic," although this was immensely overrated for the next millennium and a half.
<DC>Exhibit #1247. From the diary of Ibn Wahab, seeker of wisdom, traveler to China from Iraq, A.D. 872.
When I was received by the emperor, he called for a box of scrolls and had them spread before us. Recognizing the portraits of the prophets, I said, "Here is Noah with his ark, which saved him when the earth was drowned. . . ."
At these words the emperor laughed and said: "You have identified Noah correctly, but as for the flood, we do not believe it. It did not reach China or India."
"There is Moses," I said.
"Yes," said the emperor. "But he was unimportant, and his people were few."
"There," I said, "is Jesus surrounded by apostles?"
"Yes," said the emperor. "He lived only a short time. His mission lasted only thirty months."
Then I saw the Prophet on a camel . . . and I was moved to tears.
"Why do you weep?" asked the emperor. "His people founded a glorious empire, though he did not live to see it completed."
China was the millennium's greatest civilization and its greatest state. For most of the history of the human species, the world's best data banks were in China. From the library of the Tang emperors (A.D. 618 to 907), scholars could behold the rest of the world with a degree of objectivity and skepticism almost worthy of Galactic curators. People at the other end of Eurasia, in the west, thought they possessed "the fairest part of the earth and the most civilized portion of mankind." In reality, China had the most advanced technology, the most scientific mind-set, the most cohesive state, the largest population, the most effective imperial vocation.
China was also remarkable for its endurance. Other civilizations stagnated or were overwhelmed. Rome -- China's nearest rival in scale, productivity and inventiveness -- succumbed to barbarians and Christians. The Persian empire fell to barbarians and Muslims. The Maya gave up the struggle to maintain cities in the rain forest. The great monuments of the Ethiopian empire -- at the time, the tallest monoliths ever -- toppled and were never resurrected.
Most history is a path picked across ruins. But in the Galactic Museum, we display the human phase of life on Earth as a mainly Chinese story. Of course, there were moments when the power of one human community to influence the rest passed to other hands. In the last couple of centuries of the millennium, which ended in A.D. 2000, Europeans forced their influence on the world. Their former colonies in America became the world's only superpower. But such moments were an aberration, for history normally unfolded from east to west.
<DC>Exhibit #1368. Paraphrase from a Persian sea captain's "Book of the Wonders of India," c. A.D. 950.
Abhara of Kirman was the age's leading navigator. He sailed to China and back seven times. On one occasion, we found him alone in the Sea of Tonkin, with a skinful of water, in a flat calm. Thinking to rescue him, we invited him aboard our ship. But he refused, except for 1,000 dinars, saying, "Your situation is worse than mine."
We said: "Our ship has much merchandise and many people. It will do us no harm to have Abhara's advice for 1,000 dinars."
So we made the bargain. Declaring, "We have no time to waste," Abhara made us discard heavy merchandise, jettison the mainmast and cut the anchor cables to lighten the ship. A cloud like a minaret then appeared -- the sign of a typhoon. Not only did we survive its onslaught, but Abhara got us profitably to China and, on the way back, steered us to the exact place where some of our lost anchors could be retrieved from barely visible rocks, where, but for him, we should surely have perished.
The first millennium's greatest economic achievement was the conquest of the Indian Ocean. Explorers created trade routes that united the monsoon belt of the world, from the Pacific Rim to Arabia and East Africa. The ocean became the planet's richest arena of wealth and culture. Its eastern half was colonized by Indian ideas and esthetics. Indian cosmogony and myth were carved in the stones of Angkor in Cambodia and Borobodur in Java. Abhara's own religion spread from the west: it was founded in the early seventh century by an Arabian bandit chief who became a holy man and received revelations from an angel.
<DC>Exhibit #2000. An incident recalled in an Icelandic saga, c. A.D. 987.
The fair wind failed. Northern winds and fogs set in. And for many days they had no idea what their course was. After that they saw the sun again and were able to get their bearings. They hoisted sail and after a day's sailing they sighted land. They discussed among themselves what country this might be.
Although its effects were long delayed, the first millennium's best error was the discovery of a way from Europe to America. It happened by accident, when, decades before Leif Eriksson, a Norwegian trader named Bjarni Herjolfsson tried to sail from Iceland to Greenland by a route unknown to his crew. He got lost and sighted a strange land. This small mistake was a sign that two of the most powerful long-term trends on the planet were about to be reversed, however briefly. First, Western Europe -- formerly a stay-at-home civilization -- began to look outward. Secondly, the evolution of life forms on sundered continents, which had been diverging for millions of years, now were on the verge of being brought together by transoceanic commerce -- with prospects of contact and perils of contagion.
Nearly a millennium after Bjarni's blunder, the Atlantic replaced the Indian Ocean as the world's biggest axis of commerce. The period of Atlantic dominance was brief, for by the year 2000 the Pacific carried more traffic. Meanwhile, exploration opened up new routes -- some airborne, some below the ocean's surface -- across the planet's remaining underexploited sea. The Arctic would eventually become the world's most influential arena of activity. At the beginning of their third millennium, the people on Earth thought their planet was warming up. Little did they realize that Earth was destined to enter a new kind of Ice Age, an era dominated and shaped by a frozen ocean.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1334 words

HEADLINE: Despite a Passion for the Net, Many On-LineVolunteers Want Pay

BYLINE: By LISA NAPOLI 

 BODY:
David Mann has played piano and written arrangements for Frank Sinatra, serenaded President Truman on his yacht and written popular music like the song "In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning."
More recently, from his home in Kinnelon, N.J., he sits at a different keyboard, talking about classical music with the members of a chat room on America Online. By his estimate, he puts in at least five hours a week as a volunteer, moderating a weekly chat session, answering E-mail and filling out an on-line report about his duties. 
 In exchange, he and more than 10,000 other people who perform similar tasks for the on-line service get a free account and the designation "community leader." What they do not get is a paycheck, which is fine with Mr. Mann.
"I am not too concerned with being remunerated, since my purpose was to fulfill an obligation to my art -- my Muse, as it were. I merely believe that I owe it to the cause of good music to steer less knowledgeable people in the right direction," said Mr. Mann, 82, in an E-mail interview. "I deem it not only an obligation for me to do so, but a privilege."
While Mr. Mann considers his role a privilege, some former volunteers for America Online view it as work and have filed complaints with the Labor Department. They say volunteers at the company are treated like employees and perform functions that are integral to the on-line service's mission and should be paid.
In asking the Labor Department to investigate their claims, they have raised two decidedly Internet-age questions: When does taking part in and enjoying a community transcend hobby status and become work? And what does an Internet company owe to the people who give it life, not to mention high valuations on the stock market?
While the Labor Department will not comment on the complaints against America Online or any action it is taking, the industry and the volunteers themselves are looking on with interest. If the department does find America Online in violation of laws like the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act, it could change the on-line landscape, since America Online is not the only company that relies on the passions and goodwill of people like Mr. Mann.
Dozens of other Internet businesses, including Prodigy Communications, iVillage and Geocities, are built on the foundation of a virtual community, where volunteer participants establish, lead and police discussion areas. In turn, the businesses proudly boast about the number of members who take part in their communities, and trade on those numbers to attract advertisers and make multimillion-dollar business deals. Without their contributions, company executives acknowledge that their services would be virtual ghost towns.
"They're the core foundation of our business," said Bruce Zanca, a spokesman for Geocities, a Web community where he says four million people have built free home pages. Mr. Zanca said 1,800 volunteers contributed their time to the management of the on-line community, hosting chat rooms and enforcing community standards, among other tasks. In exchange, they get Geo-Points they can use to buy products and services on Geocities.
"The monetary exchange probably wouldn't be an inducement," Mr. Zanca said. "These people are the cyber equivalent of scout leaders and P.T.A. members and the Rotary and Kiwanis Clubs. Why do people participate in these programs? It's the same reason I coach Little League on Saturday mornings. It's something people do for their own personal reasons."
The local Little League is a different proposition, however, than Geocities, a publicly traded company with 300 paid employees that was bought in January by Yahoo in a stock deal worth about $3.6 billion.
The notion of volunteering for a for-profit corporation is an unusual one, so there is little precedent by which to judge these relationships.
But one question the Labor Department might be asking as it looks into the complaints about American Online is whether the volunteer force is providing a service that the company would have to pay for if volunteers did not exist, said Jeffrey Chamberlain, an employment lawyer based in Albany.
"It's the difference between volunteering at I.B.M. to assemble computers and volunteering at the I.B.M. soup kitchen," Mr. Chamberlain said. "The difference between doing good and making computers is relatively conceptually easy to understand."
In the digital age, the lines between volunteering and working without pay are less clear. Many of the people who volunteer on line say they do the work for personal reasons -- not for the corporation.
Terri Bass spends, by her estimation, 20 to 30 hours a week in her home in Middleton, Wis., as a supervisor in the pet care forum on America Online.
She says she loves her virtual, unpaid job: hosting chat sessions, checking bulletin boards for inappropriate comments, responding to E-mail from those who visit the area. Sure, she said, she would like to be paid. "Who wouldn't love that?" she said. But even without financial compensation, she derives great satisfaction from her work.
"We are a close-knit family here," she said. "Most of my best friends are here."
It may seem peculiar to the uninitiated that so many people would give so much time, without financial compensation, to a company with $2.6 billion in revenue last year and a stock market valuation of $130 billion. Perhaps even more peculiar is the notion that volunteers would be so personally invested in the work they do. But it is a phenomenon that is part of an on-line tradition.
"Like sex, it looks funny from the outside," said Howard Rheingold, author of the book "The Virtual Community" (Addison-Wesley, 1993). "Any virtual community that works, works because people put in some time."
But in exchange, he said, what the members of virtual communities need and want is respect. Many Internet businesses, in the frenzied rush to capitalize on industry buzzwords, have used the word "community" in their marketing, but not necessarily in deed.
Mr. Rheingold said he suspected this was the case with the management at America Online.
Scott Kurnit, founder of the Mining Company, a guide to the Internet, chose a different strategy to compensate the people who manage various topics within the company's directory, like "pregnancy" or "Southern food." Mr. Kurnit said he knew when he started the company that he would need a large group of guides to fulfill his promise of a "human-powered" search engine, but that the economics of hiring a large staff were unrealistic for a start-up operation. Instead, he pays the guides a combination of a monthly stipend and a cut of the net revenues generated by advertising on their sections. Mr. Kurnit says the guides, who now number 692, earn between $500 and $11,000 a month, depending on the popularity of the section.
In addition, he said, he issued 200,000 shares of stock to the guides, which is now worth a total of about $10 million. (The company went public last month, making Mr. Kurnit, on paper, worth more than $50 million.)
In exchange, the guides sign over the rights to the sites they create, and agree not to work for other on-line services in a similar capacity.
While for guides who have less trafficked sites, the compensation might not equal a living wage, Mr. Kurnit feels his program offers a fair reward, and that the company benefits more than it would if he relied on volunteers.
"My view is entrepreneurs are the best workers -- they work tirelessly," Mr. Kurnit said. "Volunteers are unreliable, and have an expectation that you owe them something."
However, Mr. Zanca of Geocities disagrees that the quality of work he gets from his volunteers is less than if he were to pay them. He also said he was not concerned that the Labor Department inquiry might affect the way his company is structured.
"We think the Net has a new dynamic," he said, "and in new dynamics, laws and regulations need to be re-evaluated."

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
So Many Programs, So Few Bodies

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
In an earlier time of broadcast news, marked by far-flung correspondents and high-roller budgets, individual news programs fought for turf, for talent and for money. A correspondent for the NBC "Nightly News" would not be assigned to do a report for, say, a news magazine, nor would a CBS News domestic reporter be sent to cover a war.
For that matter, no one would have dreamed of asking Diane Sawyer to combine her prestigious work as a prime-time news magazine anchor on ABC's "20/20" with a five-day-a-week stint in the folksy world of breakfast-show television. But there she is now, the co-anchor of "Good Morning America" with Charles Gibson -- and, by all accounts, happy to do so. 
 The hierarchies and fiefs of television news are breaking down a bit, driven by the networks' needs to cut costs and by new management philosophies that see a need for broadcast news reports to distinguish themselves from the reporting found on 24-hour cable news networks, radio and the Internet.
Increasingly, correspondents are contributing reports to several programs, not just the one to which they are assigned. Programs are becoming less territorial about stories and staff.
The war in Yugoslavia is providing many examples.
ABC News assembled a team to report on the Kosovar refugees, including a senior foreign correspondent from London (Jim Wooten), a Los Angeles-based domestic reporter (Jane Clayson), a "20/20" correspondent (John Quinones) and Mr. Gibson, co-anchor of "Good Morning America." The result was an hour report for "20/20," the prime-time news magazine, as well as reports for other programs on the network, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company.
The NBC foreign correspondents Ron Allen and Jim Maceda, who have been in Yugoslavia since the war began, have reported for "Nightly News," the morning program "Today," the prime-time magazine "Dateline," the CNBC business-news cable network and the MSNBC all-news cable network and World Wide Web site, which are jointly owned by NBC's parent, the General Electric Company, and the Microsoft Corporation.
Thalia Assuras, a reporter for "CBS This Morning," that network's breakfast-hour news program, began reporting from Tirana, Albania, last week on the refugee crisis, and filed a report for the "CBS Evening News" as well.
Even Dan Rather, the "Evening News" anchor who traveled to Belgrade last week, has contributed reports since then to his own 6:30 "Evening News," "CBS This Morning," the magazine program "48 Hours" and the CBS News Web site as well as six to eight reports daily for the CBS Radio network.
"In today's economic world," said Andrew Heyward, president of CBS News, "we've made it very clear to our correspondents that, with the possible exception of prime-time correspondents, we're asking all our hard news correspondents to contribute to all of our broadcasts and to radio."
Although economics may have kicked off this trend, other reasons played a role.
"We have not just 24-hour cable news, but Internet news, local news, radio news, pager news and everything else," said David Westin, president of ABC News. "In that world, giving people raw data is no longer a way of competing. We need to focus on explanation, on putting things in context, on deeper analysis and meaning."
That means pooling the fact-gathering resources of ABC News with the expertise of producers and correspondents, he said, then directing the results to whichever programs may best serve viewers.
For example, Mr. Quinones of "20/20" and Chris Bury, one of two "Nightline" correspondents, are reporting separate pieces for "World News Tonight," something that would have been unthinkable a few years ago.
"We're working toward a situation where ABC News reports the news, rather than an individual program reports the news," Mr. Westin said. "Does it have cost effects? Of course. But sometimes economic pressures cause us to do what we should be doing."
NBC News, for example, decided the audience for the morning "Today" show was news-savvy enough that the network's two White House correspondents, David Bloom and Claire Shipman, were divided equally between that program and the "NBC Nightly News." They alternate weeks of reporting for each.
NBC News paved the way in this new multitasking world three years ago with the creation of the MSNBC cable network and Web site. Since then, NBC News correspondents and producers have contributed to all programs on all those outlets.
"Viewers benefit from this in getting Tom Brokaw or Brian Williams on the little cable network," said Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press in Washington. "It's good when the resources of the premier news shows can be brought to bear on smaller shows or on cable."
But, Mr. Kohut cautioned, "working journalists aren't as sanguine about this as the executives are," partly because some feel they are being stretched too thin.
Lawrence K. Grossman, a former president of NBC News who is now a media consultant and a columnist for the Columbia Journalism Review, said there are fewer specialists in network news, which "isn't the end of the world, but it has changed what's reported."
"Basic news gathering is farmed out to news agencies, stringers and freelancers," he said, a major event like the war in Yugoslavia being an exception.
"If a major story develops, the networks will parachute in one of their mainstream correspondents from a bureau," who will do a professional but less expert job, he contended.
But such methods do save money. Last year all three broadcast news divisions had to shrink their costs.
The CBS Corporation gave pink slips to about 120 people in the fall, about 7 percent of the CBS News staff, though none of those dismissed were correspondents. ABC News and NBC News made similar reductions, without setting percentage quotas or publicizing precise layoff figures.
ABC News achieved some savings last year by not renewing contracts of five correspondents, though it has also hired two new correspondents this year.
For example, ABC News told George Strait, a longtime medical correspondent for "World News Tonight," that his contract would not be renewed. In part, this was because Dr. Tim Johnson and Dr. Nancy Snyderman were contributing reports to all programs, enough that news executives felt that beat was adequately covered without Mr. Strait.
Similarly, ABC News did not renew the contract of Tim O'Brien, who has covered the Supreme Court for "World News Tonight" for 22 years, choosing to rely on its recently formed law and justice unit, whose correspondents are John Miller and Terry Moran, formerly of Court TV.

HEADLINE: The Net's Real Business Happens .Com to.Com;
A Market That Dwarfs Retail E-Sales

BYLINE: By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
Each month, Patricia Ruszkay, a purchasing agent for BOC Gases, a global distributor of industrial gases with American headquarters in Murray Hill, N.J., pulls a chair up to a computer, logs on to the Internet, and looks for a bargain.
In this case, the bargain involves not only the price of the product, but an entire cost-saving process set in motion when the on-screen "order" button is clicked. 
 Nearly 7,000 miles away from New Jersey, in a Japanese gas processing plant, a BOC supplier receives the million-dollar order for tungsten hexafluoride, a highly toxic gas used in semiconductor manufacturing, among other purposes. And within minutes, some 2,500 miles miles from Murray Hill, a BOC distribution center in San Diego receives electronic notice from Japan that the shipment is on the way.
No multilingual phone calls or faxes required. No written purchase orders, invoices or shipping notices to lose. And, because the entire process takes place on the World Wide Web, there are no extra charges for handling the order over a special long-distance data network -- which until a few years ago would have been the only way to conduct business electronically.
BOC makes some $20 million worth of purchases from the Japanese supplier a year, and BOC officials say the Internet will save the company several hundred thousand dollars annually.
There may be more headlines about retailers selling books and compact disks on line, or consumers Web-auctioning the contents of their attics to one another. But in terms of dollars and impact, the real electronic-commerce action these days is the business-to-business transactions quietly taking place among companies like BOC and its suppliers and customers.
In 1998, American companies had $43 billion worth of sales to one another over the Internet, five times the consumer retail total, according to Forrester Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass. Within four years, Forrester says business-to-business sales on line will reach $1.3 trillion, or 9.4 percent of corporate America's purchases.
Another research firm, the Aberdeen Group, is even more exuberant in its calculations of business-to-business E-commerce, estimating that the market may now be 10 or more times larger than the on-line consumer arena, and hold at that level.
Word early this year of strong on-line Christmas sales "put visions of sugar plum fairies into people's heads," said David Alschuler, a vice president at Aberdeen, which is based in Boston. "But the fact is, business on the Internet is cutting significant costs out of the supply chain, with better procurement and resource planning," Mr. Alschuler said. In the long run, "that will have a far bigger impact than what you buy from Amazon.com," he added.
While computer companies like Cisco Systems and Dell Computer have been the notable leaders in business-to-business E-commerce organizations in other lines of business have also joined the parade.
Harley-Davidson, Mobil Oil and Los Angeles County are among the disparate cases cited by Alyse Terhune, an analyst with the Gartner Group, a research firm in Stamford, Conn., as evidence that business-to-business E-commerce "is absolutely proliferating beyond the high-tech companies now, into just about everything."
Mobil, for instance, recently implemented an Internet ordering system for its roughly 300 lubricant distributors, saving the company $100,000 a year in ordering costs, and cutting the error rate for such orders from 30 percent to virtually none, Ms. Terhune said.
Certainly, E-commerce has brought fundamental change to businesses like BOC Gases. Its British parent, the BOC Group, has been pushing for on-line supplier and customer transactions throughout its multinational operations, which include a wide variety of warehousing, distribution and cargo-handling services. And the benefits transcend mere back-office efficiency.
Alex Cahill, a BOC purchasing manager in Murray Hill, cites the example of tungsten hexafluoride. The company sells the gas in six-foot steel cylinders that are worth $10,000 each when filled, making for an unwieldy, expensive inventory.
"In previous years, our stock has been bloated to accommodate for miscommunication, upturn in demand, returns or problems with quality," Mr. Cahill said. "So it was typical to have three months of inventory in the system -- which could be between 50 and 60 cylinders, with a bunch en route."
The primary reason for such "blind stocking," as Mr. Cahill put it, was the inefficiency of the order fulfillment process. "We have quite a lot of people interested in each purchase order," he said. "All that communication was handled through faxes, E-mails or the phone, one on one -- which is great until someone goes on vacation or sick leave, or they leave the office for a few hours, or transcribe something incorrectly."
Under the system, which the San Diego site put in place in March 1998, BOC negotiates a bulk purchase with suppliers for a year's worth of gas, and posts the information on a restricted-access Web site. This site, or "extranet," is accessible only to select BOC suppliers and customers, and to BOC employees like Ms. Ruszkay who place orders by choosing from an on-line catalogue of gases that has been screened for price and selection, based on the bulk purchase agreement.
As the order progresses through delivery, both the supplier and BOC will update the Internet order page, noting the shipping dates, quantity, and shipping method. This gives key personnel instant access to the order's status, which cuts down the need for correspondence, slashes the amount of time spent processing purchase orders and greatly reduces the opportunities for human error.
Perhaps more significantly, Mr. Cahill said the system's precision had enabled the company to reduce substantially the number of filled cylinders it keeps in stock, saving his division "several hundred thousand" dollars in annual inventory costs.
Fulton Wilcox, BOC's director of technical business development, conceded that the estimated $60 million worth of business the company transacted last year on the Internet represents but a tiny portion of BOC's annual revenue of $1.2 billion. But because the buyers using the system tend to be the biggest and most valued of BOC Gases' customers, dollar volumes tell only part of the story, he said.
"Even if we had the hard numbers of exactly how much in sales we do on the Internet," Mr. Wilcox said, "it's still chump change compared to what it's doing to deepen the customer relationship and reduce the overall cost of ownership." He was referring to the costs a customer incurs not only in buying gas from BOC, but in storing and tracking it.
That seems to be the case with the military contractor Raytheon Systems, one of BOC's key customers. In 1997 BOC approached what was then the Hughes Aircraft Company (Raytheon merged with Hughes later that year) and offered to put its catalog of gases on an extranet and let the company order around the clock, if necessary. The customer accepted, and now orders as many as 30 cylinders of gases each week for its El Segundo, Calif., plant, for use in research and development.
Despite such headway, there are speed limits on the growth of corporate E-commerce.
While the overall size of the business-to-business market dwarfs the consumer market, the rate of E-commerce adoption among corporations has been -- and will continue to be -- much slower, says Chris Davis, a vice president CSC Inc., an information technology consulting concern.
"The business-to-business space is just a lot more complex," Mr. Davis said. "And organizations don't always behave like consumers."
With layers of bureaucracy to navigate, and with procurement and sales methods ingrained in the corporate culture, he said, those who champion E-commerce within corporations must be prepared to move slowly.
Indeed, "the sun and the moon and the stars have to line up to make this work," said Mr. Wilcox, of BOC. "We're so intertwined with a customer and their processes, we can't just do things suddenly without re-engineering the whole process. That's why business-to-business E-commerce will have a more organic growth than the flash growth on the retail side."
And unlike consumer-oriented E-commerce, there are no ready-made software programs sophisticated enough to quickly apply to most business situations. Analysts and industry executives note that the requisite business-to-business software tends to be expensive -- often more than $1 million for the initial software license, from vendors like Ariba Technologies Inc. and Spaceworks Inc. And making the system fit the specific needs of a particular company, not to mention keeping it in tune, typically requires an internal support staff as well as continued consultation with the software vendor.
"For every dollar that businesses will spend on the packaged application, they'll spend $5 to $50 on system development and integration," said Ms. Terhune, the Gartner Group analyst.
BOC was pulled into E-commerce by a longtime customer, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which has been buying gases from the company since 1989 for use in science experiments and other purposes. Four years ago, seeing the Internet's potential for more efficient business practices, M.I.T. persuaded BOC and another of the university's big vendors, Office Depot, to offer their products for sale in virtual catalogues. Like BOC, Office Depot gave it a try, liked what it saw and has since become an E-commerce evangelist.
BOC hired I.B.M. in early 1996 to custom-design its extranet. But the system also includes a large amount of software written by BOC's own engineers, which helped keep the initial outlay below $1 million, according to Mr. Wilcox, who said annual maintenance now ran around $150,000.
Beyond money, though, companies embarking on E-commerce must also become accustomed to doling out ample portions of trust. BOC, for example, gives its suppliers unprecedented access to its own inventory data, in order to keep its stockpiles replenished. And BOC customers like M.I.T. give BOC access to their cost accounting systems, to avoid having to re-enter data as an order works its way through the process.
Such trust is a departure from traditional business practices, Mr. Wilcox conceded. "But somebody's got to be willing to do something a little differently for this to work."

HEADLINE: Patents;
New thrills from New Zealand: Strapped down and harnessed, piloting a 60-horsepower aircraft.

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
STRUNG across a valley in Queenstown, New Zealand, is an amusement park ride that makes bungee-jumping look tame. It combines bungee features with elements of trapeze and aircraft flight, allowing thrill-seekers to swing through the air at the end of a tethered cable at speeds up to 120 miles an hour, piloting a one-man craft shaped like a B-movie rocket ship in any direction they want.
Neil Harrap invented and built the ride he calls Fly by Wire. Now he has won a United States patent for his daring toy and is scouting locations in this country. 
 Stringing it across the Las Vegas Strip, he says, would be a good place to start.
Mr. Harrap, a property developer in Wellington, New Zealand, got the idea for his ride in the middle of the night a few years ago. "I woke up at 4 in the morning with the idea for a swing that would move in figure-eights," he said while in New York last week. "It was a swing that could change directions in the air, and out of that came the seed of an idea."
That seed grew into a design for a narrow, missile-shaped plane with a cutout for a pilot and powered by a 60-horsepower aircraft engine. A single pilot, lying on his stomach, is strapped into the craft with a five-point harness and ankle clips. His arms extended in front of him, and he controls steering and acceleration with his hands.
In New Zealand, the aircraft is suspended above ground from a cable tethered to a line strung across a canyon. In the United States, Mr. Harrap plans to anchor that line from towers.
"It's 1,400 feet across and 340 feet from the ground," he said. "A single wire, three-eighths of an inch in diameter, comes down from that, and it carries the weight of the plane and pilot and takes care of the additional G-forces generated, because it can pull up to three times gravity during the middle of the flight."
"There's sufficient strength in the steel cable to accommodate that," he continued. "We're running the cable at 10 percent of its load capacity. There's no single load path so there's no single path to break and be catastrophic."
The craft has a conventional-shaped tail for stabilization, a five-bladed rear-mounted propeller inside a circular drum that looks like a giant fan, and a four-stroke aircraft engine. At the beginning of the ride, a winch lifts the plane seven or eight feet off the ground.
"It pulls the plane backward the same way you'd pull a child back on a swing, up to the desired height for launch," Mr. Harrap said. "At any point on the way up, the pilot can release. He can get a little way up and think it's scary and release from there, giving it as much acceleration as he wants. The steering is controlled with both hands, pretty much the way you steer a bike."
The winch can lift a the craft clear of its launch deck and a cautious pilot can simply "give it a bit of gas and fly in a circle, backward, forward or wherever he wants to go," Mr. Harrap said. More daring pilots who let the winch retract to maximum will be released at a 200-degree angle.
"Away he goes, all downhill and up the other side," said Mr. Harrap, who has ridden his own ride. "Lots of people go slowly at the start, but within a minute or two they're flying as fast as they can as they gain confidence."
Pilots can then swish through the air in figure-eights, loops, arcs or wild swings. Mr. Harrap is careful to point out that his ride "doesn't fly; it's a powered swinging device."
"Because of the design, the worst that can happen if you don't pilot it well is it will go slow," Mr. Harrap said. "We believe it is completely idiot-proof. No matter what you do, you can't hit yourself, anyone else or any object. It's not powerful enough to go up and strike the support cables."
Mr. Harrap says none of his passengers in New Zealand have "gotten sick, taken a fit, or passed out" on the six-minute ride, which costs about $70.
He was in the United States to scout locations in Las Vegas, Texas and California and to talk to tower construction companies. "The first in the U.S. will be in year-round locations," he said. He has a Web site at www.flybywire.co.nz featuring a short snippet of video of the New Zealand ride. He also holds patent 5,782,699.
 
Insurance For Trade Secrets
In a nod to the growing value of intellectual property as a business asset, the CNA Financial Corporation of Chicago has announced that it is offering what it says is the first insurance policy to cover financial losses from the theft of trade secrets.
"The secrets must be owned by the company and be in a recorded form, either formulas, patterns, compilations, programs, devices, methods, techniques or processes," CNA said. "The policy includes coverage for ideas designed for commercial use, which have economic value because they are not being generally known."
The plan could pay benefits up to $10 million.
 Patents may be viewed on the Web at www.uspto.gov or may be ordered through the mail, by patent number, for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

HEADLINE: Santo Domingo Memo;
Caribbean Unity? Bananas Are Getting in the Way

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 18

 BODY:
Venezuela's New President, Hugo Chavez Frias, was supposed to deliver a closing thank you speech at this weekend's Caribbean summit meeting here, but speaking with the candor of the recently elected, he grumbled that he had already attended six meetings of heads of state in only 73 days in office.
"We go from summit to summit, and our people go from abyss to abyss," he said, telling the 24 other leaders of the Association of Caribbean States meeting here on Saturday that they shared the "same drama of terrible underdevelopment." 
 "What is the central core of all these summits?" he asked. "What is the nucleus? I think we are a little disorganized. I think we should review all these summits to be more efficient."
The one-day session here was called to come up with a plan of action for the next century. Leaders of countries with a Caribbean coastline, including Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico, Fidel Castro of Cuba and Andres Pastrana of Colombia, signed a declaration declaring tourism the industry that can best increase employment and income in the region.
The declaration also condemned the transport of nuclear waste shipments through the Caribbean and committed the members to pursue bilateral pacts and tariff concessions for regional trade and investment.
But even though these countries have been striving for unity to cope with economic globalization, the gathering failed to reach consensus on some issues, underscoring the diversity of the countries involved.
Among the most divisive issues was the recent World Trade Organization ruling allowing the United States to impose sanctions against European-made goods in retaliation for the European Union's trade preferences for bananas grown in its former colonies.
The banana dispute pits small eastern Caribbean islands like St. Vincent and the Grenadines against Central American countries, where Chiquita Brands and other American companies are major banana growers that contend they will be hurt by the European Union's quota system.
The issue was a hot topic in a closed-door session here in which Mr. Castro railed against the trade group, which regulates international trade, as "a fearful instrument of re-colonization and exploitation of the world," the Cuban Government news media reported today.
Since the Association of Caribbean States represents countries on both sides of the banana dispute, it was up to the eastern Caribbean islands that oppose the ruling to issue their first formal statement on the decision. They did today, under the aegis of another regional group, the Caribbean Community.
Their statement called the ruling "the single most dangerous threat to the economies of the Caribbean banana exporting countries" and warned that putting it into effect "without consideration of the vulnerability of the Caribbean banana industry would lead to severe social and economic dislocations."
Speaking at the opening of the meeting in the National Theater here Friday night, President Jules A. Wijdenbosch of Suriname used the banana dispute to call for increased concerted action by Caribbean states. He said that the battle was being fought by two major economic powers, the European Union and the United States, without direct involvement by the smaller countries most affected.
One of the association's goals is for members, who represent 200 million people and a gross domestic product of $500 billion, to coalesce in a trading bloc that would be one of the largest in the world.
"More than ever it's our responsibility to demonstrate our presence in international and regional organizations and demand that our concerns are an integral part of the agenda, the debate and the general solutions," Mr. Wijdenbosch said.
But Presidents also used the summit meeting, the second held by the five-year-old group, to seek cooperation on more individual matters. President Armando Calderon Sol of El Salvador petitioned Mr. Castro "for clemency in the name of the families and all Salvadorans" for two Salvadorans who face the death penalty in terrorist bombings in Havana.
Presidents Pastrana and Chavez, who have had differences over Mr. Chavez's sympathy for Colombian guerrillas, also held a private meeting.
And the Dominican President, Leonel Fernandez, has clearly solidified the Dominican Republic's new stature as an international player after years of isolation under a strongman, Joaquin Balaguer.
Because of the presence of so many world leaders, parts of the city were turned into maximum security areas, with armed military police along many streets and with metal detectors at hotel entrances.
Mr. Castro, as usual, drew special attention even though he kept a low profile and made no public speeches. He signed the meeting's joint declaration even though it included a provision to "reaffirm our commitment to preserve, consolidate and strengthen democracy, political pluralism and a state of law as the privileged backdrop that allows respect, defense and promotion of human rights."
But the declaration also urged the United States to end the Helms-Burton law, which toughened the American trade embargo against Cuba, and it endorsed the principles of sovereignty and nonintervention "and the right of each country to build its own political system in peace, stability and justice."
The Foreign Ministry here restricted a news conference after the signing of the "Declaration of Santo Domingo" Saturday night to allow not more than two questions of any leader, apparently to keep someone like Mr. Castro from monopolizing the spotlight.
But in the end, Mr. Castro bowed out of the news conference, the only leader to do so. He cited "unavoidable commitments," standing up two reporters -- one of them from the exile press in Miami -- who were assigned the two questions for him.

HEADLINE: Ben S. Stephansky, 85, Dies; Former Ambassador to Bolivia

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Ben S. Stephansky, President John F. Kennedy's Ambassador to Bolivia at a complex time in its history, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 85.
Dr. Stephansky, whose Ph.D. was in economics from the University of Wisconsin, was labor attache at the United States Embassy in Mexico City in the mid-1950's. President Adolfo Lopez Mateos later remembered him as "the one American who really understood Mexico." 
 Dr. Stephansky became a career Foreign Service officer in 1956 and was labor adviser in the State Department's Bureau of Inter-American Affairs from 1957 to 1960.
After Kennedy took office in 1961, "able young career men were promoted to Ambassador, such as Stephansky in Bolivia," a close Kennedy aide, Theodore C. Sorensen, wrote later.
By then Bolivia was in the 10th year of the period that has been called the Bolivian National Revolution. It followed a rebellion in 1952 touched off by the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement, the first party in the country's history to gain widespread popular backing. At that time, the party was a broad alliance and it had left and right wings.
The 1952 rebels, including miners and national policemen, got the Bolivian Army to surrender after three days of fighting, and the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement leader Victor Paz Estenssoro became President for four years. Mr. Paz Estenssoro was at first a neutral force between his party's wings.
An American political scientist, James M. Malloy, wrote in his book, "Bolivia: The Uncompleted Revolution," (Books on Demand, 1970) that in the Kennedy Administration, there was "a positive aim to make Bolivia a showcase of guided 'democratic revolutionary' change.' "
"Previously high aid commitments were increased and broadened," Mr. Malloy wrote, "and a pro-revolution Ambassador, Benjamin Stephansky, was sent to La Paz," Bolivia's capital.
With that, President Paz Estenssoro, who was re-elected President in 1960, came to believe that Kennedy would be unstinting in giving aid to Bolivia. As Mr. Malloy put it, "Paz then decided to go all the way with the United States and to shape his regime in close accordance with the expectations of the Alliance for Progress," the aid program for Latin America that the Kennedy Administration began in 1961.
In May 1961, on the day before Kennedy formally nominated Dr. Stephansky to be Ambassador, the White House announced that the United States had offered, and Bolivia had accepted, nearly $10 million in immediate economic aid and relief.
In addition, President Paz Estenssoro, Washington and Bonn approved a plan under which the Inter-American Development Bank, the United States and West Germany would make capital and technical expertise available, and Bolivia would reduce and discipline its work force.
But in August 1963, the Bolivian Cabinet resigned in a crisis brought on by the Paz Government's inability to put into effect a plan to rehabilitate Bolivia's large and vital tin-mining industry. The plan entailed dismissing 2,000 workers. Confrontations between the Bolivian Government and tin miners continued. By late 1963 things began to get out of control.
By then it had also been announced that Dr. Stephansky would not stay on as Ambassador past the end of 1963 and would return to Washington because of his wife's health. Then, in 1964, the Bolivian military overthrew the Bolivian Government, and a junta controlled by Gen. Rene Barrientos Ortuno took power.
Dr. Stephansky went on to become, in 1963 and 1964, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State in the Bureau of Inter-American Affairs. He was executive secretary of the United States-Puerto Rico Commission on the Status on Puerto Rico from 1964 to 1966 and Deputy United States Representative to the Organization of American States with the personal rank of Ambassador in 1967 and 1968. Later, he held various posts in foundations and other fields.
Dr. Stephansky was born in what is now the Ukraine and was brought to the United States in 1915. He received a bachelor's degree from the University of Wisconsin in 1939 and his doctorate in 1950.
He is survived by his wife, Anne; two sons, Evan of Alexandria, Va., and Tom of Denver; a daughter, Kate Stephansky of Olney, Md.; and two grandchildren.
