HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE BOMBING;
NATO Said to Focus Raids on Serb Elite's Property

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT and STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
In listing its bombing targets in Yugoslavia, NATO has generally described them as installations that feed Slobodan Milosevic's war machine. What the alliance does not usually say is that some of the refineries and factories have also been chosen as targets because they are run by close cronies of the Yugoslav President.
The idea, according to senior NATO and Pentagon officials, is to undermine Mr. Milosevic's control by chipping away at his system of political and economic patronage. 
 "He doesn't care if his soldiers die in Kosovo, as long as he stays in power," one senior military officer said of Mr. Milosevic. "But if you blow up some things near and dear to him -- or to somebody close to him -- then that could have an effect."
While NATO's bombing seems to have solidified popular support for Mr. Milosevic, the officials said they hope the attacks against some of the targets will turn loyal supporters against him by destroying their own sources of wealth and power.
The bombing continued this weekend, with 500 sorties flown on Saturday afternoon and overnight in what NATO said were its most active 24 hours yet of the war.
 Yugoslav media reported several powerful detonations around Novi Sad, Serbia's second-largest city, early Monday, according to The Associated Press. There were no reports of casualties, but the damage was described as "great," including a missile strike on the provincial government building. Tanjug, the state-run news agency, also reported attacks on the capital, Belgrade, and in the towns of Paracin, Kraljevo and Sremska Mitrovica.
Yugoslavia's oil and gas industry has suffered enormously under NATO's strikes. While the stated aim of those attacks has been to choke off fuel to the armed forces operating in Kosovo, the strikes must also be a blow to Dragan Tomic, the director of Yugo Petrol, who as Speaker of the federal parliament in Belgrade is a close ally of Mr. Milosevic.
On April 9, a missile strike destroyed the Zastava automotive plant in Kragujevac. Its director, Milan Beko, has served under Mr. Milosevic as Minister of Privatization.
Four days earlier, NATO struck a tobacco factory and warehouse in Nis, and damage to tobacco plants has been reported in other cities. According to American intelligence reports, a major player in Yugoslavia's tobacco distribution is Mr. Milosevic's son, Marko.
So far, economic and industrial targets have made up a small portion of NATO's targets. Of the roughly 200 targets attacked since the air war began on March 24, a dozen have been strictly industrial sites, like factories. That percentage grows when those targets are combined with fuel storage and ammunition factories.
As NATO presses on with bombing that has done little to stop the purging of ethnic Albanians from Kosovo, some NATO and Pentagon military leaders have advocated striking still more economic and industrial targets, the officials said.
These commanders, including the alliance's supreme commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, believe that NATO has to intensify its efforts to undermine Mr. Milosevic's 11-year grip on power.
"If we continue sustaining this air campaign and intensifying it in a way that he sees he is slowly but surely starting to lose those instruments of power that keep him in power, then he's going to have to make a decision," Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen testified on Capitol Hill last week.
The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, disclosed that NATO's political leaders had not yet approved a select group of targets for heavy attack. He said NATO warplanes could begin striking such targets "in a few days."
General Shelton declined to identify those targets, but the highly classified list includes additional industrial and economic sites, according to a senior Administration official. Attacking those targets would carry a much higher risk of civilian casualties and cause the kind of profound disruption of life for ordinary Yugoslavs that NATO has so far sought to avoid, that official said.
Such strikes could also undercut NATO's stated rationale for its bombing: to weaken the military and police forces involved in the killings in Kosovo rather than wage war on the people of Yugoslavia.
Nevertheless, the Pentagon and NATO are looking for ways to intensify pressure on Mr. Milosevic's Government.
"We're trying to make the price higher and higher," a senior military official said.
While not aiming directly for Mr. Milosevic, American and NATO officials say they are hitting what they call his four pillars of power: the political machine, the communications media, military and security forces, and the economic system.
A senior American military officer said the targets on NATO's list included strikes at "the things that keep him afloat." The idea, the officer said, is to instill fear in those whose economic standing depends on Mr. Milosevic, to make them think, "We didn't bargain for this."
"If you can achieve that mindset, then who knows what will happen?" the officer said.
Allied planes and missiles have struck half a dozen targets thought to be part of the "national command authority," several of them in and around Belgrade. These include headquarters and bunkers believed to be used by political and military leaders, although it was unclear whether anyone was killed or injured.
In Yugoslavia's state-run economy, virtually any industrial or economic activity can be linked to Mr. Milosevic's Government. Ever since the former Yugoslavia collapsed into its rump state today, and the economy was hit by comprehensive sanctions from 1992 to 1995, Mr. Milosevic, a former banker and Communist bureaucrat, has been able to tighten his control of the little business left. Agriculture, fuel, manufacturing and exports and imports are operated by Mr. Milosevic's cronies virtually as private fiefs, American officials say.
Mr. Milosevic has used funds gained from industry and his cronies mostly to finance an effective security apparatus to maintain political control, according to experts and intelligence estimates.
But his family and associates also have benefited, living far better than most Yugoslavs, whose standard of living has fallen sharply since the country began to disintegrate in 1991.
Britain's Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, challenged Mr. Milosevic last week to admit to his people that he has bought three villas in Greece. European news reports also have spoken of funds funneled to Swiss banks through French accounts held by Mr. Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic.
The holdings of the couple's son, Marko, are believed to include a discotheque and a tobacco distribution network. Before the war, Yugoslav media reported that he had announced plans to open a Disney-style theme park, called Bambiland.
Yugoslav officials have estimated damage from the bombing as high as $100 billion, including damage to roads, destroyed bridges and railways, which has the ripple effect of disrupting commerce. But there are no signs that Mr. Milosevic has lost the backing of his key supporters.
One American Government official familiar with the Yugoslav economy said the prospects were slim that Mr. Milosevic's cronies, however battered, would turn on him. "A scenario that would involve these guys acting as a group seems fairly unlikely," the official said. "They don't have anywhere to turn besides Milosevic."
Mr. Milosevic appoints the executives of each of the country's monopolies, many of whom also serve as Government ministers. Dejan Kovacevic, the Minister of Construction, also heads Mastrogradnje, one of the country's largest construction firms. Zivota Kosic, the Minister of Energy and Mining, also heads a natural resources concern called Duvanksa Industrija Nis. Nis is southern Serbia's largest city, and has been a repeated target of NATO bombs.
Another state-run industry that has been severely disrupted is ammunition production, which is overseen by an umbrella organization headed by Maj. Gen. Jovan Cekovic.
Although the industry has a clear military function, it has also historically provided Yugoslavia with hard currency, and the destruction of the plants has crippled another source of profits for people close to Mr. Milosevic, officials say.
Pentagon and NATO officials declined to provide a list of economic or industrial targets that have been struck. But Yugoslav news agencies have reported strikes against several, including a small-plane manufacturer in Pancevo, a construction-equipment plant in Krusevac and a plastics factory in Pristina.
NATO has repeatedly struck a plant in Cacak that Yugoslav officials portrayed as an appliance factory. Reporters allowed to tour the scene described seeing wrecked vacuum cleaners. Western officials say the plant also included an underground ammunition section.
NATO's targets are chosen by military aides to General Clark in the alliance's headquarters in Brussels, as well as in Germany and Italy. These officers work closely with a little-known cell within the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the Pentagon, called J-2T, where officers consider a range of technical aspects, including the most effective weapon and where exactly to aim it.
The planners weigh the military value of a target against the drawbacks, including the risk to pilots if the target is in a heavily defended area and the risk to civilians if it is in a heavily populated area.
Lawyers at the Pentagon and at NATO's headquarters review each target carefully to justify striking it. Hitting industrial and economic sites requires walking a fine line, the officials said.
Mr. Cohen said President Clinton, like leaders of other major NATO countries, review the target list.
NATO officials insist the bombing is taking a toll, wearing down Yugoslav supplies and resolve. But the political process has kept some targets off the list. General Clark has sought approval -- so far unsuccessfully -- to attack another of the pillars of Mr. Milosevic's support: the communications industry. Control of radio and television has been a mainstay of the Yugoslav leader's 11 years in power. One radio station is owned by his daughter, Marija.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Bush's Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
In our last episode, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas reluctantly began to expound on his foreign-policy mindset. To continue:
On our involvement in Kosovo: "NATO has to be confident in its capacity to help preserve the peace in Europe. So I think it is in America's strategic interest in this case, that once we are in the position we got into, that Mr. Milosevic be taught a lesson." 
 On refusing to use trade as a lever to influence China on human rights or global behavior: "I think it is to the advantage of U.S. producers and to the country to have admitted China to the World Trade Organization. . . . Unilateral sanctions often don't work."
(Some of us in what Bill Clinton derides as "the anti-China crowd" think Bush may be Peking too soon.) But now to Russia:
Should the International Monetary Fund lend more money to Moscow? "No." Why not? "Because I don't think we ought to be throwing good money after bad. Russia needs to convince lenders, both private and public," says Bush, "that money is secure within Russia, that the rule of law matters, that corruption has been held in check. I think we should have learned our lesson."
Should we get tougher with Russia on its aid to Iran on nuclear development? "Yes. I think that we ought to be firmer about the distribution of weaponry around the globe, whether they come from China or Russia. This ought to be a high priority for a President."
In light of talk about moderation in Teheran, do you favor a rapprochement with Iran? "I am not prepared to talk about that. I will at some point in time."
What about missile defense? "I think that we ought to move aggressively forward with the development of the capacity to deploy an intermediate- and long-range anti-ballistic-missile system. You bet."
And with China positioning missile batteries across the Taiwan Strait, would you make a missile defense available to our ally? "Well, I have not made up my mind yet. I think it is hard to make it available to Taiwan until it is available to the United States."
How would you handle the Russian claim that our 1972 ABM treaty precludes a missile defense? "I think we need to move aggressively forward, and if that means eventually renegotiating the treaty with the Russians, we ought to do so."
But when they don't want to renegotiate it? "I know they don't. We ought to give them first the opportunity to renegotiate and if they don't, then move forward with abrogation." (Score one for hawkish adviser Richard Perle.)
On Iraq, do you think President Clinton is doing enough to stop Saddam Hussein from developing weapons of mass destruction? "My gut tells me no, but I do not have enough facts to be able to back that up with a statement."
On North Korea, would you continue to supply Pyongyang with oil, food and nuclear power plants while it refused inspection? "Now we are going to inspect them after we have given them six months' warning. I am worried about that. So should our friends in the Far East be worried about it."
The foreign-policy split in the G.O.P.? "There are some very powerful constituencies in both parties that advocate isolationism and protectionism. It may surface to the point it becomes a wildfire or it may not. I believe that rhetoric and policies that would isolate us would be a mistake for our country . . . America is too great to withdraw."
Then why hasn't he been speaking out on foreign affairs at such a crucial moment? "I am thinking about it, but if and when I criticize this Administration, I intend to do so when people are paying attention."
But many already are. Nettled by the suggestion in that last question that he is manipulatively sitting on his lead, he leaned forward and volunteered:
"I am a candidate and I am going to be the nominee. I think I am going to be the President. I have got strong principles and values, and I am surrounding myself with good, smart people who understand my principles and with whom I am going to become more knowledgeable. I am going to understand specific areas better and better as time goes on."

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1100 words

HEADLINE: With Smoked Salmon and Beer, Berlin Greets Parliament

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, April 19

 BODY:
With solemnity but little pomp, and with Europe at war in the Balkans, Germany returned its Parliament to the Reichstag today, 66 years after a fire there ushered in Hitler's dictatorship.
The first session in the renovated Reichstag, now topped with a glass dome to symbolize the political transparency on which Germany has based its postwar revival, marked the dawn of the "Berlin Republic," a phrase dear to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, but one he insists will bring no fundamental changes in German policy. 
 Addressing the Parliament today, Mr. Schroder, a Social Democrat, said that to equate the word "Reich," or "empire," with "Reichstag" would be "as senseless as equating Berlin with Prussian glory and German centralism."
He went on, "The federative model of German politics is well-established and in no way endangered."
With its many ghosts -- of imperialism, fascism, communism and division -- Berlin has stirred some old fears that its periods as a German capital are synonymous with disaster. The Chancellor appeared concerned to allay any such concerns, saying it was the success of "Bonn democracy" that "makes the Berlin Republic possible."
Mr. Schroder spoke in a 669-member chamber of striking informality, evidently intended to counter any imperial nostalgia that the massive stone edifice begun under Bismarck might kindle.
Gray carpets, simple mauve seats, low public galleries, and the glass cupola and big windows give a feeling of accessible ordinariness. Hovering over the proceedings is the pudgy eagle known affectionately as "the fat hen" that adorned the Parliament in Bonn, retained after several leaner models more suggestive of Prussian virility were rejected.
No national anthem was played, and no thumping rhetoric delivered, as speaker after speaker emphasized that the westward-looking democratic values that have anchored Germany's postwar rebirth and then unification in 1990 would remain strong.
Sensitivity about the move back to Berlin has been heightened by the fact that the first session in a building touched by so many of this century's conflicts took place as war raged in the Balkans with German planes taking part in NATO attacks on Serbia.
Mr. Schroder did not directly refer to the violence, but said he was convinced that a united Germany, assuming new political responsibilities after its long postwar tutelage, must be prepared to fight for "a Europe of human rights that does not exclude anybody on our continent."
To applause, he quoted the Albanian writer, Ismail Kadare: "The Balkans is the yard of the European house, and in no house can peace prevail so long as people kill each other in its yard."
But Ludger Volmer, a Deputy Foreign Minister, echoed growing uneasiness in his environmentalist Green Party, the junior member of Mr. Schroder's governing coalition. "We are initiiating our Berlin Republic in the midst of a European war," he said, "and I am one of the people responsible for a policy that leaves me no reason to be optimistic or happy."
Referring to the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, Mr. Volmer added: "We failed in our first goal of bombing Milosevic back to the negotiating table within two or three days, and we failed to stop a genocide in Kosovo. Now we must persevere, but the outlook is not encouraging."
On Sunday, Gila Altmann, a Green and a Deputy Environment Minister, added her signature to a petition for a cease-fire already signed by about 1,000 Green Party members. These divisions in the party are putting pressure on Joschka Fischer, the Green Foreign Minister, although his support in the country has risen since the bombing began.
Despite the crisis in the Balkans, the overriding symbolism today was of European and German reconciliation. The first sitting came almost exactly a decade after the fall of the Berlin wall, which the Reichstag abutted during its long postwar hibernation.
Accepting a symbolic key to the Reichstag, Wolfgang Thierse, the Speaker of the Parliament and a man who grew up in Communist East Germany, stood in bright sunshine beneath the old inscription "Dem Deutschen Volke"' -- "To the German People."
He said the words, betrayed by those who repeatedly trampled the democratic aspirations of Germany in this century, symbolized the grave responsibilities of every member of Parliament on a day when "all doubts are set aside, all resistance overcome, all problems solved."
Mr. Schroder took a somewhat more somber view, noting that every sixth Berliner is unemployed and suggesting that the special role of Berlin would lie in overcoming the lingering mistrust between the eastern and western parts of the country and so completing the unification of Germany
"Just as Bonn stands for the western part of the republic, Berlin symbolizes a united Germany," he said. He accused "a sheltered generation" of westerners of arrogance in criticizing easterners without asking, "What would we have done under similar conditions?"
Growing support from the eastern part of the country was critical to Mr. Schroder's victory in elections last year, and he has made the struggle against high unemployment in formerly Communist areas a central plank of his Government's program. Up to now, results have been modest.
The Reichstag, which was completed in 1894, was a center of war propaganda during World War I, the Parliament of the Weimar Republic and the site of a Nazi exhibition in 1938 on "The Eternal Jew." After the war, the border between the British- and Soviet-occupied sectors ran through its damaged masonry.
It has been restored at a cost of about $330 million by the British architect Sir Norman Foster, who said today that the "openness, fairness and resolution" with which the project was completed said much about the qualities of German society.
Many of the major architectural projects in Berlin have been entrusted to foreign architects, causing some grumbling here. The decision clearly reflects the great sensitivity of architecture in a city where Hitler's architect, Albert Speer, laid out elaborate plans for "Germania," the planned capital of the 1000-year Reich.
After the inaugural session, the members of Parliament and Mr. Schroder moved upstairs for a jolly reception, at which an oompah band performed as meatballs, smoked salmon sandwiches and beer were consumed with evident relish.
The scene was extremely relaxed and low key, very much Prussia-lite. "Behind its monstrous dress, what we now have inside the Reichstag is a rather modest woman," remarked Michael Naumann, the State Minister for Culture.

HEADLINE: The One Place NATO Could Turn for Help

BYLINE: By Jack F. Matlock; Jack F. Matlock, a professor at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, is a former Ambassador to the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia.

 BODY:
There cannot be security and stability in the world without Russia.
NATO intensifies its bombing of Serbia to the cheers of a fair portion of the Western political and intellectual elite. The bombing has rallied Serbs behind their dictator, Slobodan Milosevic, who is using the air strikes as a cover and pretext for mass expulsions, massacres and hostage taking. As NATO bombing continues, outrages against the Kosovars seem certain to continue. The weapons used against the Kosovars are not easily countered from the air. 
 The air war is clearly making things worse on the ground -- much worse, in fact, so pressures build to use ground troops. If they had been available for intervention from the start of the bombing, they might well have served both as a deterrent to Mr. Milosevic and as real protection for the Kosovars if that deterrence failed.
But they were not available, and it will be weeks before they could be, even if NATO governments decide today to accept the political risk of sending them. By the time a few hundred thousand troops could be assembled to invade, Kosovo would probably be emptied of civilian Kosovars, except for those forced to become human shields for Serbian forces dug into a rugged terrain.
The Clinton Administration seems unwilling to admit the obvious: that NATO bombing has been an unmitigated disaster for all the parties we set out to protect. So far, the only gainers have been Mr. Milosevic and his henchmen, whose support in Serbia, once wobbly, is now solid.
Will that change if bombing continues, on and on and on? Perhaps. But don't count on it. So long as Mr. Milosevic can pose as the ultimate barrier to the loss of the sacred ground of Kosovo, a Serbian patriot set upon by more powerful foreign bullies, few Serbs will take the risk of opposing him.
Any successful strategy for peace depends on splitting the Serbian people from Mr. Milosevic's leadership. Waging war against Serbia as a whole has the opposite effect.
The negative reaction in Russia to NATO's attack was predictable. After all, we had assured Russia during the debate on NATO enlargement that there was nothing to fear. NATO, we said, was a purely defensive alliance, constitutionally incapable of undertaking offensive military action. (We had earlier given Mikhail Gorbachev to understand that NATO's borders would not be moved further east if Germany were allowed to unite and stay in NATO.)
Now Russians are asking, Who's next? Will Moscow be bombed if the war heats up again in Chechnya?
The antics of those Russian politicians talking irresponsibly of military support for Serbia, or a union of Serbia, Belarus and Russia, can be dismissed as lunatic ravings. They are symptoms of a feeling of weakness and humiliation, the irresponsible rhetoric of politicians who need issues in the coming election to distract public attention from their failures to deliver on campaign promises.
Nevertheless, while such posturing may have no practical effect on military operations in the Balkans, the emotions it exploits will complicate and delay the development of democratic institutions and economic reforms in Russia. It also increases Russian resistance to further reduction of nuclear weapons.
Russian official policy, as distinct from the emotional rhetoric that now poisons the air, has actually been moderate and responsible.
Russia was willing to join others in a diplomatic effort to deter ethnic cleansing in Kosovo, but held fast throughout to three positions: 1. That the threat of NATO bombing was unlikely to cause Mr. Milosevic to accept the Rambouillet agreement. 2. That bombing would not solve the Kosovo problem but make it worse. 3. That military action should not be taken against a sovereign country without United Nations sanction.
The first two points have proved absolutely correct. The third should give the United States and its NATO allies serious pause. Are we willing to concede to other military alliances a right to intervene at will outside their borders? To do so would seem exceedingly unwise.
But unless we do, how can we expect countries outside NATO to accept it as prosecutor, judge, juror and policeman of Europe? Is that its purpose? It would be different, of course, if the United Nations Security Council or the General Assembly had asked NATO to enforce a decision it had made.
Once again, we are finding that it is much easier to start a war than to end it. So much damage has already been done that any feasible solution now will be significantly worse than what might have been obtained by diplomacy without threats to bomb, or by diplomacy backed up with a credible threat to invade. But we cannot make effective policy on the basis of what might have been. We also cannot make effective policy if we are blinded by rage and frustration, however justified.
The United States must find the wisdom and will to lead the alliance away from the tragic quagmire that looms ahead if it stays on the current course of war against Serbia. So long as we make Serbia the enemy, rather than Slobodan Milosevic, the Kosovo problem will not be solved. Neither partition nor independence nor indefinite foreign occupation will work in the long run without the acquiescence of the Serbian people.
It should also be clear by now that there is no way to restore stability to the Balkans without Russian cooperation. President Boris Yeltsin's pledge yesterday not to intervene militarily gives us an opening to discuss the shape of a settlement and Russia's participation in it.
 Other non-NATO countries can also be helpful: President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine recently made proposals that should be taken seriously and explored. If the Kosovar refugees are to return and life is to be restored to the rubble, policing by outsiders will certainly be required. NATO alone is not capable of imposing a settlement that will last.
Stability in the Balkans must be treated as a problem for all of Europe and countries as important as Russia and Ukraine made part of the solution, not forced to be part of the problem.
Why not declare victory (we have seriously degraded Mr. Milosevic's military potential, as we set out to do), end the bombing and welcome active Russian participation in reaching a settlement? Given what has happened, it certainly will not be easy, but let's face it: bombing Serbia is not working.

HEADLINE: F-15's Attack Iraq Defenses, U.S. Reports

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, April 19

 BODY:
United States fighter planes attacked defense sites in northern Iraq today, after Iraqi radar had locked on them, American officials said.
Air Force F-15E's dropped laser-guided bombs near Mosul, according to a statement from Incirlik Air Base in southern Turkey, the American base 250 miles north of Baghdad. The statement said that damage was being assessed and that all aircraft left the area safely. 
 A statement by the Iraqi armed forces said the bombing was directed against "service installations and heroic weapons sites." The statement, carried by the official Iraqi News Agency, did not mention damage or casualties.
It was the second time since March 15 that American or British aircraft had struck northern Iraq. On Saturday, the Iraqi armed forces said, four civilians died and one was injured when American jets struck military sites in the area. British and American planes have focused on defense sites in northern and southern Iraq since December, when Iraq started challenging allied planes that enforce the no-flight zones.
Baghdad does not recognize the legitimacy of the zones and has pledged to oppose them. The zones were set up after the Persian Gulf war in 1991 to prevent Iraqi planes from threatening rebels.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
'Oil for Food' Fund Soars
 UNITED NATIONS, April 19 (Reuters) -- Iraqi oil revenues are up sharply since oil prices began surging two months ago, but are still short of needs, a spokesman for the United Nations "oil for food" program said today. The revenues, intended to ease hardships under United Nations economic sanctions, are projected at $3.7 billion for the first half of the year, $700 million above the amount projected in February, the spokesman, John Mills, said.
The program overseers said in their weekly report that Iraqi exports dipped, to 1.77 million barrels a day last week from an average of 1.9 million in the previous four weeks. Exports would have to rise to 2.1 million barrels a day if Iraq is to export all it has contracted to sell by the end of the current phase of the program, which ends late next month. Barrels of oil have 42 gallons.
But even if it meets its targets and oil prices stay high, the revenue, which buys food, medicine and other exceptions to the embargo, will still be far short of needs, Mr. Mills said. The Security Council raised the production limit. But decrepit equipment can produce only two million barrels. Of the money raised through exports, one-third is deducted for war reparations, victims' payments and United Nations costs.
France, Russia and others say foreign investment should be allowed to repair the equipment. But the United States and Britain have blocked that. The allied bombing, in retaliation for the expulsion of United Nations weapons inspectors, has over five months hit a major refinery and its two main pipelines.
The United Nations said yesterday that Iraqi pipeline flow and ports were not disrupted last week. The United Nations said it approved contracts last week for a total of 5.6 million barrels of crude.

HEADLINE: A Real-World Economist;
Krueger And Empiricists Challenge Theorists

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
As he pulled up the charts one after another on his office computer, Alan B. Krueger grew enthusiastic. Children do better all through their schooling, he declared, if by fourth grade they have spent just one year in a class of only 15 students. The tall green bars and rising red lines on Mr. Krueger's charts told the story in simple-to-understand detail. Poor children in particular are helped by early attention from a teacher.
"Small classes later on may have less impact," Mr. Krueger said, rehearsing the punch line of a speech he would give a few days later. "I infer that very young children become socialized in a small class. They learn how to behave in school. They are more likely to take the S.A.T. exams in high school, and to earn more later as workers." 
 Empirical economists talk that way, as if each finding is a nugget of fresh, significant insight. Many are. No group within the profession is challenging accepted wisdom more vigorously. But Mr. Krueger does so rather cautiously. For all his enthusiasm, he is reluctant to prescribe small classes as national policy without more research.
There is a reason for his hesitation. Empirical economists may be increasingly pressing theorists, but abstract thinkers still dominate academic economics with their explanations of how people and markets behave. Theory, for example, says that employment should fall when the minimum wage rises, but empiricists have uncovered exceptions. And for all the profession's emphasis on education as the key to higher earnings, economic theory fails to provide a blueprint for improving learning. Empiricists are trying to fill the breach with studies like Mr. Krueger's.
Many are less than a decade out of graduate school, which makes Mr. Krueger, a 38-year-old Princeton University professor and the editor of the prestigious Journal of Economic Perspectives, already an elder statesman of the growing empirical movement. It is bringing to economics what amounts to a reality check.
"Theory is being forced to be much more specific," said George Akerlof, a theorist at the Brookings Institution who, like some others of similar bent, is now doing more empirical work. "The whole intention of empirical economics is to force theory down to earth."
And the profession is paying heed. The John Bates Clark Medal, awarded by the American Economic Association every two years to an outstanding economist in his 30's, has gone to empirical economists the last two times. In 1995, the winner was David Card, a frequent collaborator of Mr. Krueger's, and in 1997 to Kevin Murphy at the University of Chicago.
Mr. Krueger is frequently mentioned as a candidate for this year's award, to be selected this month. So is Andrei Shleifer of Harvard, a Russian-born empiricist, whose specialty is the study of financial markets operating in different legal and political settings. There are other possibilities as well for perhaps the most prestigious award in economics short of the Nobel.
Empirical economists test a theory or a belief by coming up with just the right data or observations. Mr. Krueger likens the process to medical research, where a drug is the equivalent of a theory or belief and the empirical work is the testing among thousands of people, some of whom get the drug and some a placebo. He came to his conclusions about class size after tapping into a Tennessee study of 11,600 children who had been placed randomly in small or large classes.
Public schools might work just fine if tax money were channeled to the right programs, like small classes for very young students, says Mr. Krueger, whose mother and wife are public school teachers, and whose two children attend a public elementary school here. So why doesn't he campaign for such reforms?
"If you ask, 'Why am I cautious,' there are two reasons," he said, talking across the wide, curved desk in his sunny office. "The strength of a researcher is not in being an advocate, but in making scientific judgments based on the evidence. And empirical research teaches us that nothing is known with certainty -- even the class-size results, which seem so definitive."
That reluctance is at odds with Mr. Krueger's public profile. A Democrat, he served as chief economist at the Labor Department in 1994 and 1995. The journal he edits has a circulation of 25,500, making it the most widely read in the profession. He pumps out half-a-dozen research papers a year, a considerable pace in economics, and travels every other week to seminars and conferences. "What I like to do is give the data its own voice," he said.
Inevitably, however, Mr. Krueger is asked for recommendations. What, his audiences want to know, should be done? That's when he balks. He is not in the business of making value judgments, he insists. Once economists get caught up in value judgments, they become reluctant to accept the findings of their own research when the findings contradict their beliefs. "Astronomy was plagued until the 16th century," he said, "by value judgments about the centrality of man."
So he declines to advocate President Clinton's proposal to spend $12 billion to reduce class size nationwide. Convincing as it seems, the Tennessee experiment, started in 1986, is not sufficient, he says. Further research is needed involving at least 12 states.
"Economics has to construct theory very slowly, block by block," he said. "There is no other choice."
Mr. Krueger's cautiousness represents one strong faction of empirical economics. Edward Leamer, at the University of California at Los Angeles, belongs to another, less diffident group. He insists that theory and findings be yoked together, early on.
Mr. Leamer studies the impact of trade on American wages. His thesis is that there is an impact, one broader and more complicated than standard theory has acknowledged. An apparel worker, for example, driven from his job by cheap imports, may seek work as a waiter or warehouse hand, perhaps driving down wages in those fields. A few years later, apparel imports decline, but Japanese machinery imports rise and machinery workers accept a wage freeze. The impact on wages continues, with different evidence.
"Economics is so theory-driven," Mr. Leamer said, "that until you have a theory that explains your findings, people will retain the old theory. You need new theory to drive out old theory."
Mr. Krueger resists that lesson, but he is still reeling from it. So is Mr. Card, now at the University of California at Berkeley. A minimum-wage study they did in the early 1990's, while Mr. Card was at Princeton, has brought them much more notoriety than they ever anticipated. They found an eye-catching exception to the theory that employment falls when the minimum wage rises.
The study was very much in character for Mr. Krueger, who has a knack for spotting what empiricists call "natural experiments," where chance circumstances usually create the experimental variables. (In laboratories, in contrast, scientists can control the variables much more precisely.) Mr. Card, for instance, now wants to study what happens when affirmative action is eliminated, as it has been at the University of California. Mr. Krueger came up with a question that can be answered empirically: What are the best black students doing, turning to universities elsewhere or still enrolling in California?
"If you look at my curriculum vitae, you will find more papers that no one has read than in Alan's, 10 to 1," Mr. Card said. "He does not waste time on research he does not consider important and practical."
Their minimum-wage research, initiated in the late 1980's, soon after Mr. Krueger got his Ph.D. at Harvard and came to Princeton as an assistant professor, seemed important to both of them. Their first studies involved California. But when New Jersey in 1992 raised its minimum to $5.05 an hour from $4.25, they jumped at the opportunity for a natural experiment.
Entrenched theory holds that supply and demand tend to balance each other. When the minimum wage rises enough, as it did in New Jersey, then demand among employers for minimum-wage workers declines. So when Mr. Krueger and Mr. Card surveyed fast-food restaurants in New Jersey, compared them with nearby Pennsylvania, where the minimum was unchanged, and found no impact on employment, there was an uproar.
They published their study in 1994, just as Mr. Krueger started at the Labor Department, where his boss, Robert B. Reich, was pushing for an increase in the minimum wage, later enacted. Card-Krueger, as they came to be known, were accused by some economists of shoddy research for a political goal and blithe disregard for theory.
"They don't root their findings in existing theory and research," says James J. Heckman, a University of Chicago labor economist and empiricist. "That is where I really deviate from these people. Each day you can wake up with a brand new world, not plugged into the previous literature."
Mr. Krueger and Mr. Card have reaffirmed their minimum-wage findings. They insist that what happened in New Jersey could be explained without upending supply-and-demand theory. Special circumstances played a role. The New Jersey minimum had been unusually low. Employers found they could fill vacancies more easily at the higher wage, and employee turnover fell, two cost savings. Another wage increase might indeed reduce employment, Mr. Krueger says.
But for all his caution, standard theory is no longer the same in his eyes. "We tested the supply-and-demand curve," he said, "and it needs to be amended."
Empirical economics blossomed in the mid-20th century, feeding on the growing quantities of economic data the Government collected and the new polls that explored consumer attitudes and behavior. "There was this outpouring of data in the 50's and 60's, and then it became dangerous, all these numbers and not enough theory to organize them," Mr. Heckman said.
Theory, with its emphasis on abstract, mathematical modeling, took command by the 1960's. Only in the last decade has empirical economics gradually regained a footing, first in labor economics and then in finance, education and trade. Computers make the data easier to process.
By the early 1990's, nearly half the articles in economics journals dealt with empirical research, up from 27 percent in 1960, one study showed.
Mr. Krueger grew up in Livingston, N.J., where his father, an accountant, still practices. His mother taught first grade in nearby East Orange. "The Worldly Philosophers," Robert Heilbroner's tales of the great economists, first aroused his interest. But he followed his sister, Barbara, to Cornell and enrolled in its School of Industrial and Labor Relations, thinking he would become a lawyer. "It seemed like what people went into," he said, "and I had seen the movie 'Norma Rae.' "
His goal soon changed. As research for a paper, he found himself analyzing data on productivity and wages, a typical empirical inquiry. He took to the statistical detective work. From Cornell he went on to Harvard, earning a doctorate in economics in 1987. Within weeks of graduation, he had landed at Princeton, thanks to a chance encounter with Orley Ashenfelter, a Princeton labor economist.
There he soon fell in with Mr. Card, forming one of the more enduring collaborations in economics. It is a collaboration, as Mr. Ashenfelter put it, that "reports results neither man had anticipated beforehand."

HEADLINE: 2-State Dispute Over Shipping Lines' Lease Clouds Port Authority Future

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The intense political wrangling to keep two large shipping companies from leaving New York Harbor for Baltimore has opened a larger struggle between New York and New Jersey that threatens to tear apart the Port Authority, the agency created 78 years ago to prevent such squabbling.
The first casualty could be the loss of Sea-Land Service and Maersk Line, which together handle a quarter of the container cargo moving through the harbor and are to decide in less than two weeks whether to expand operations here or move to Baltimore. 
 Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is eager to sign new leases with Sea-Land and Maersk, which employ 1,000 workers at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal in New Jersey and have a $100 million payroll. But New York's Governor, George E. Pataki, has refused to sign new leases until Mrs. Whitman agrees to an overhaul of the authority that would give New York what it says is a fairer share of its revenue.
Fifty-one days after Sea-Land's lease expired in Elizabeth, the two states remain deadlocked. Last Tuesday, Sea-Land accepted a jury-rigged final proposal that includes $120 million in state funds from New Jersey, knowing that Governor Pataki could veto the deal at any moment. The dispute is delaying action on billions of dollars in Port Authority projects at the three airports it operates.
"We haven't seen this level of brinksmanship before," said James Hughes, dean of the School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "If we lose these shipping companies we may well come to the breaking point. But I don't know how you'd disentangle. I can imagine years and years of wrangling over the Port Authority's assets."
Organized in 1921, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was established to bring order to the chaotic movement of cargo between ships and the region's railroads. To bolster the regional economy during the Depression, the agency built the Holland Tunnel and the George Washington Bridge. Later it took over the three major airports in New York City and Newark and built the container port in Elizabeth.
Assessing whether the Port Authority has helped New York or New Jersey more depends on the period under discussion and the standard used for judgment.
In the last 10 years, the agency invested $2.8 billion on projects in New York and $1.7 billion on those in New Jersey. But Charles A. Gargano, vice chairman of the Port Authority and Governor Pataki's chief negotiator, contended that money earned was more important than money spent.
Mr. Gargano said that Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports and the World Trade Center had generated net income of more than $2 billion since 1980. During that same period, the PATH trains and the Port Authority Bus Terminal, which Mr. Gargano described as New Jersey assets, lost $2.8 billion. Newark International Airport, however, contributed net income of $775 million.
Mr. Gargano argued that the proposed lease for Sea-Land and Maersk would entail $600 million in subsidies over its 29 years. "The major problem is the tremendous drain that New Jersey facilities have on Port Authority results," he said.
Calculating that the Sea-Land lease provides the best opportunity to wrest financial control of the Port Authority from New Jersey, Mr. Pataki is demanding a reorganization that would give each state control of assets on its own land. Shared assets like bridges and tunnels "would be subject to our mutual agreement on what is fair."
Rejecting that ultimatum, Governor Whitman has said that she is willing to explore reorganization and a more equitable division of revenue. New Jersey officials say New York fails to recognize that the agency provides regional benefits, like public transportation that makes it easier to get to Manhattan and reduces vehicle congestion. Sea-Land and Maersk, they say, are keystones in a $20 billion industry whose 166,500 employees are evenly divided between New York and New Jersey.
In any event, apportioning the benefits from some shared assets may be impossible. The World Trade Center, for example, was built in Manhattan for $1.6 billion in a deal that created the PATH system for New Jersey. Its value is predicated, at least in part, on the subways and PATH trains beneath it.
"The kinds of assets the Port Authority has historically been able to provide benefit people in the entire region," said Rick Mroz, special counsel to Mrs. Whitman.
The squabbling is marked by posturing. Mrs. Whitman's call for regional cooperation belies her administration's continual efforts to lure the New York Stock Exchange, the New York Yankees and dozens of companies to her state, a process that has cost New York billions of dollars in corporate tax breaks and cash.
And although Governor Pataki bemoans the subsidies that New Jersey is so willing to provide Sea-Land and Maersk, he never questioned the multimillion-dollar subsidies he and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani provided Reuters in Times Square, or International Business Machines Corporation in Westchester County.
The two governors did agree on paring the work force by 25 percent on a payroll they agreed was fat and ineffective. And last year, the Port Authority's gross revenues rose to $2.4 billion and net income to $167 million.
The two states have different versions of when the current dispute started and who started it.
In New York's version, the spark came not with the Sea-Land and Maersk negotiation but with two large airport projects: Continental Airlines' renovation of two terminals at Newark and American Airlines' proposal to build a new $1 billion terminal at Kennedy. At the agency's December board meeting, Louis Eisenberg, the chairman of the Port Authority and Governor Whitman's principal negotiator, raised questions about the American deal, as did one New York commissioner.
There was no rancor, but afterward, Mr. Gargano said New Jersey had suddenly linked the American Airlines deal to the harbor deal. Mr. Gargano said Mr. Eisenberg had told him New Jersey "would not take action on any other project unless the deal with Sea-Land-Maersk was approved."
"I was appalled," Mr. Gargano said.
New Jersey officials deny that account. If there was a serious rift between the governors it was not apparent for another month, as the two sides continued to work on a new lease proposal for Sea-Land and Maersk.
In January, Mayor Giuliani reiterated his intention to seize control of Kennedy and La Guardia when the Port Authority's lease with the city expires in 2015. Governor Whitman responded, "It would make no sense for the Port Authority to make any new investments in the New York airports until their future is determined."
Rather than retaliating, Mr. Gargano sided with New Jersey several weeks later when he said Mr. Giuliani's interference was jeopardizing work at Kennedy. At the time, Mr. Gargano said that agency's record had improved in recent years, citing more than $4 billion in projects for new terminals, rail links and road work at Kennedy.
On Feb. 16, Mr. Gargano began secret negotiations with Mr. Eisenberg at his office on the Upper East Side over a "global settlement" of disputes between the two states. The executives quickly agreed to sweeten the shipping deal by $120 million and secure a new lease with the companies and sell the World Trade Center. New York, in turn, would get a special allocation of $120 million for New York projects.
But the agreement disintegrated shortly before the Port Authority's Feb. 25 board meeting, when Mr. Gargano told Mr. Eisenberg that Governor Pataki would not approve the deal. Governor Whitman then ordered Mr. Eisenberg "to pull everything" on the agency's agenda, three New Jersey officials said. The agency's staff was ordered out of the room as New York and New Jersey commissioners exchanged heated complaints.
It was immediately clear that the agency would not be able to conclude a new deal with Sea-Land by the time the company's lease ran out on Feb. 28 and that there would be no action on the American and Continental airport projects. The stalemate continued through the March board meeting. The agency failed to deliver a long-promised lease proposal to Sea-Land on March 11, allowing Baltimore to continue to add more incentives to its offer.
Since then, Mr. Gargano said, Governor Pataki reviewed the operating results at the Port Authority and the demand to overhaul the agency came to the fore. New York raised the ante for the special allocation to $400 million for New York projects, to offset port investments on the Jersey side of the river.
In letters to Governor Pataki on March 29 and April 6, Governor Whitman offered $250 million, saying that although she was willing to discuss restructuring the agency and raising PATH fares, the Sea-Land lease must be concluded first.
"I think we can both agree," Mrs. Whitman wrote in the April 6 letter, that the loss of jobs, "if Sea-Land-Maersk were not retained in the port, would be unacceptable to both of us as well as the people of the region."
To meet a Sea-Land deadline, Governor Whitman added the $120 million to an earlier lease proposal that the companies had rejected. But the continuing viability of the offer is dependent on the two states overcoming their differences.
"Sea-Land and Maersk retreated under cover of a New Jersey offer," a Port Authority executive said. "They'll hold off on their decision as long as possible. But I don't know if we're going to make it."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Latest Banana Squabble: Retroactivity of Sanctions

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, April 19

 BODY:
The United States received the World Trade Organization's formal approval today to impose $191.4 million in punitive tariffs on European goods in a protracted fight over European banana imports. But the effective date of the sanctions was still in dispute.
This was the first time in the four years the world trade group has been in existence that such retaliation had been approved, and only the second such retaliatory step going back to its predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. 
 The United States has maintained for six years that the European Union unfairly discriminates against bananas from Latin American countries, which are exported by United States companies, in favor of those grown and exported from former European colonies, mostly in the Caribbean. The trade group agreed with the American complaint earlier this month, although it reduced the amount of damages sought from an original $500 million.
On Friday, the European Trade Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, said that the European Union would not appeal. But today, the Europeans' delegate here, Roderick Abbott, disputed the effective date of the sanctions, arguing that they were not retroactive to March 3, the date the United States contended.
"It is normal that a decision applies from the day that it was taken," Mr. Abbott said.
Rita Hayes, the American representative to the World Trade Organization, disagreed and said that notice of the tariffs was to be posted in today's Federal Register.
Tariffs of 100 percent will be levied on a range of products that includes lithographs, bed linens, German coffee makers, French plastic handbags, cardboard packing material and lead-acid storage batteries. The sanctions effectively double the price of the imports and make them much harder, if not impossible, to sell in the United States.
European and American officials will meet Wednesday in an attempt to negotiate an effective date for the sanctions, but a compromise could be difficult. Mr. Abbott noted that the interests of the two sides "are diametrically opposed."
If the two sides cannot agree on a date, the matter would be referred to the W.T.O.'s dispute-resolution process. But Mrs. Hayes said the United States and the Europeans could settle the matter themselves.
The retaliatory sanctions were the first to be imposed since 1952, when the Netherlands acted against the United States in a dispute over dairy products. The victorious Dutch got approval to reduce the number of tons of American ground wheat flour they imported.
In addition to approving the American sanctions today, a three-member arbitration panel reaffirmed the illegality of the European Union's banana-import policy.
It is unclear how or even when the Europeans will amend that policy, but Mr. Abbott said today that any changes soon were unlikely because of European Parliament elections in June and the likelihood that a new executive agency would not be in place in Brussels until the fall.
Mrs. Hayes said the "only deadline is compliance," leaving the European Union presumably in the position of paying the tariffs until it makes its import policy acceptable.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Rally throughout Asia buoys hopes that the economic crisis has bottomed out.

BYLINE: By Mark Landler 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
STOCK markets from Seoul to Singapore soared yesterday, extending a rally that many analysts here say is proof that foreign investors are returning in large numbers to the recession-ravaged economies of Asia.
"Something fundamental is happening," said Miron Mushkat, the head of global economics and strategy at Indocam Asia Asset Management in Hong Kong. "The markets are telling us that the Asian crisis is over. We are moving from deeply dark territory into the land of the light." 
 The euphoria was most pronounced in Jakarta, where shares jumped 6 percent. But the gains were impressive throughout the region: 5.7 percent in Seoul, 5.5 percent in Manila, 4.1 percent in Singapore, 2.7 percent in Kuala Lumpur and 2.2 percent in Hong Kong. The Nikkei index in Tokyo was the only exception, falling 1.1 percent after a string of powerful gains last week.
Beyond the general sense of a better tomorrow, analysts said several factors were driving the rally. Asia governments have aggressively cut interest rates; yesterday the Philippines cut rates for the 10th time this year. Foreign fund managers are steering more money to the region, in part because technology stocks in the United States have lost some of their appeal after troubles at the Compaq Computer Corporation.
"When people shift out of technology stocks, they tend to look at cyclical stocks and overseas opportunities," said Marc Faber, the managing director of Marc Faber Ltd., an investment firm in Hong Kong. "People do feel that the crisis in emerging economies worldwide is over."
The rally in Asian stock markets is all the more remarkable because it bears no relation to the underlying health of the economies. In Hong Kong, for example, the Government announced yesterday that unemployment reached a record rate of 6.2 percent in the three months from January through March.
Undaunted, the Hang Seng index roared past the 13,000 level before closing at 12,766. The Hang Seng, which has risen 17 percent just this month, has regained all the ground lost since it crashed in October 1997.
Some investors said they were alarmed by this performance because it could lull Government officials and business executives into thinking the hard times were over. With money pouring into Asia, some analysts predict that efforts toward fundamental economic changes could bog down in Indonesia, Thailand and elsewhere.
"This was a once-in-a-blue-moon opportunity to sort out Asia," said Bill Kaye, the senior managing director of the Pacific Group, an asset management firm in Hong Kong. "But here we are, back to the races."
Mr. Faber said, "The big problem with falling interest rates and surging liquidity is that it lessens the incentives to pursue deep reforms."
Although Indonesia recently took steps to clean up its insolvent banking system, the restructuring process has been extremely slow in Malaysia and Thailand. In Hong Kong, the robust market belies an economy that has failed to reduce costs, despite a reduction in costs of rival economies like Singapore.
Analysts said that shares in Seoul rose yesterday because of hopes that South Korea's largest conglomerates were finally reducing their bloated operations. The leaders of LG Group and Hyundai Group, for example, met yesterday to discuss plans for a subsidiary of Hyundai to acquire LG's electronics unit, LG Semicon.
Investors are not alone in expressing optimism that the worst is over in Asia. The Asian Development Bank said yesterday that the economic downturn had hit bottom and predicted that the region would return to economic growth this year.
In its annual report issued in Manila, the president of the bank, Tadao Chino, said: "I believe the worst of the financial crisis is over. This gives us reason to expect that 1999 will see notable improvements in economic performance." The development bank predicted that Asia, excluding Japan, would grow at an average annual rate of 4.4 percent in 1999 and 5.1 percent in 2000. That compares with 2.6 percent in 1998.
Though the performance of Asian stock markets is impressive, analysts pointed out two caveats.
First, the volume of trading on some markets -- notably Jakarta -- is much smaller than it was before the crisis. So a relatively small infusion of capital can cause a large percentage increase.
Second, investors are aggressively buying shares in major public companies like HSBC Holdings, the parent of the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, which hit an all-time high of $284 (Hong Kong), or $36.64 (United States), before closing at $280 (Hong Kong), or $36.12 (United States). But that does not mean that money is flowing to the small and medium-size companies, the backbone of many Asian countries.
"There is this disconnect between the large-cap stocks and the carnage of small companies down below," said John D. Pinkel, a partner at Shaw, Kwei & Partners Ltd., a Hong Kong fund that invests in smaller companies.
For all the caveats, forecasters do not see an end to the rally soon. As the sentiment about Asia improves, more fund managers in the United States and Europe are expected to divert capital to these markets.
"It's very difficult to predict anything when we make these qualitative leaps," Mr. Mushkat said. "Our year-end target for the Hang Seng was 12,000, which seems rather irrelevant right now."

HEADLINE: Reinventing Compaq:Tasks for Next Chief

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
As the Compaq Computer Corporation begins its search for a new chief executive, it is clear that the prospective leader's first challenge will be to chart a course from the brick-and-mortar retailers that have been the company's lifeblood to the direct-sales model that is increasingly defining the industry's future, analysts and consultants said yesterday.
Eckhard Pfeiffer, 57, was dismissed over the weekend by Compaq's board, led by a company co-founder and its chairman, Benjamin M. Rosen. Earl L. Mason, the chief financial officer, also resigned to become chief executive at an unidentified company. The announcement came nine days after Compaq warned its first-quarter income would be about half what analysts had expected. 
 Compaq's problems stem from a strategy that has appeared to pull the company in opposite directions at the same time.
On one hand, it has struggled to compete in the personal computer market with the Dell Computer Corporation, which sells directly to buyers, avoiding the dealer channel and its markup, and builds each machine to order, keeping inventories and costs at a minimum. At the same time, Compaq, though its acquisitions of the Digital Equipment Corporation last year and Tandem Computer in 1997, has tried to become a major systems company, like the International Business Machines Corporation and Hewlett-Packard.
"It seems to me that Compaq's strategy has been unraveling for quite a few years now," said Regis McKenna, president of the McKenna Group, a management consulting firm based in Palo Alto, Calif. "They're caught between the low end and the high end, and that's why you see them constantly changing their mind. The first thing they have to do is figure out what they want to be when they grow up."
Mr. Pfeiffer succeeded Compaq's first chief executive, another co-founder, Rod Canion, in 1991, in a coup also led by Mr. Rosen. He aggressively lowered Compaq's cost structure to meet the challenge of new competition, and the reduced costs allowed the Houston-based company to gain the computer industry's leading market share while maintaining decent profit margins. But by the late 1990's, as Compaq embraced the sub-$1,000 PC, its growth came at the expense of profit margins.
About 18 months ago, Compaq announced that it was moving to a build-to-order business model, similar to Dell's, but that it would retain its traditional distribution through the dealer channel, as well. Although Compaq did reduce internal inventory levels, it has never matched Dell's operating efficiency, and it has continued to lag behind Dell in growth. Dell has systematically sought out Compaq's strongest markets, first in laptops, then in servers and work stations, and has gained market share in each.
Like Mr. Canion, who made an unsuccessful attempt to acquire Silicon Graphics in the late 80's, Mr. Pfeiffer looked to the high end of the market to differentiate Compaq. The Tandem and Digital acquisitions were meant to transform Compaq from the world's largest PC company into a fully integrated computer systems maker. Just as it had hassed I.B.M. in PC sales, so Compaq would come to lead the systems business, Mr. Pfeiffer predicted.
"The kind of goals he had sounded good to shareholders -- like being a $50 billion company by the year 2000, or to beat I.B.M. -- but they didn't have anything to do with customers," said Mark Anderson, president of Strategic News Service, a research firm based in Friday Harbor, Wash. "The new C.E.O. should look at everything Eckhard acquired and ask: did the customer benefit from that. If the answer isn't yes, they should get rid of it."
Mr. Anderson said he was not necessarily advocating the sale of Digital, Tandem or any of the smaller companies Compaq acquired in recent years, only their integration into a coherent strategy. "If you think of the Internet as the all-embracing future, as Ben Rosen seems to suggest from his statements, it's not hard to see how the parts of Compaq fit into that," he said. "The new C.E.O. should have a clear focus on a single business plan."
Perhaps the biggest challenge facing Compaq's next leader is how to differentiate the company's products at a time when the value of brands has been diminished and personal computers sell almost exclusively on the basis of price. While Apple Computer can command a small premium based on the ease of use or on the attractive design of its products, and Sun Microsystems flourishes as a high-end technology company identified with the Internet, most computer makers struggle to add value to a commodity product.
"The business has been assiduously destroying pricing and profitability, bent on self-immolation," said Seymour Merrin, president of Merrin Information Services, a consulting firm based in Palo Alto. "Compaq, more than any other vendor, has the opportunity to do what Robert Crandall at American Airlines did when he said, 'The time has come to stop killing ourselves.' The customer, if he perceives value, is willing to pay. What all the companies have failed to do, with Compaq right at the front, is to differentiate."
Dell prospers by offering performance at a price, rather than just a low price, and by making the purchasing process more pleasant, Mr. Merrin said. But he said he did not believe that Compaq should emulate Dell by eliminating the dealer channel.
"Compaq can't do that," Mr. Merrin said. "They have better distribution than anyone else. A good percentage of their customers are buying through dealers because they want to. What they should do is set up a totally separate business unit" for direct sales..
Tim Bajarin, president of Creative Strategies, a consulting firm in Cupertino, Calif., agreed. "I don't think you can cut the channel off, but what you have to do is take off the price protection you give dealers," he said, referring to the common practice of reimbursing dealers for price cuts affecting current inventory. "It's a new world and a new economy."
The new chief executive Mr. Bajarin said, "has to build a model that says no matter what the customer wants to buy, no matter where they want to buy it -- on the Internet, by telephone, in a superstore -- Compaq has to make it available."
On a day of widespread losses among technology stocks, Compaq's shares closed yesterday at $22.75, down 87.5 cents, on trading of more than 38 million shares.

HEADLINE: David, 71, and Joan McCall, 57, Die in Crash

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
David B. McCall and Joan Mills McCall, who excelled separately in the worlds of advertising, philanthropy and the arts and together as fiercely dedicated advocates for the world's displaced people, died in a car accident Sunday while on an aid mission in Albania.
Mr. McCall was 71. His wife was 57. The couple lived in Manhattan and Bridgehampton, N.Y. 
 Mr. and Mrs. McCall, together with Yvette Pierpaoli, a well-known French aid worker, and their driver, were on their way from Tirana, the Albanian capital, to the northern town of Kukes, where tens of thousands of refugees who have poured out of Kosovo have congregated in recent weeks. The four were driving in heavy rain when their car missed a turn on a winding mountain road and plunged several hundred feet into a ravine, said Dennis Grace, a vice president of Refugees International, where both Mr. and Mrs. McCall served on the board. All four were killed.
Mr. Grace said that the McCalls were among their nation's most generous financial supporters of refugee aid. During their eight years of involvement with Refugees International, they participated in numerous missions to, among other places, Thailand, Cambodia, Somalia and Eritrea. They had traveled to Albania to explore the possibility of setting up a satellite radio network that would help refugee families separated by the chaos in Kosovo.
"The initial reports referred to them as two American aid workers," said Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States special envoy to the Balkans, who is chairman of Refugees International and was to be succeeded in that post by Mr. McCall later this year. "They would have liked that. They were highly successful financially and socially. They could have lived a comfortable life in New York with their family and friends. Instead, they repeatedly risked their lives in Southeast Asia, Africa and the Balkans to increase public awareness of the plight of people in need."
Mr. McCall was born in New York, attended the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn., and briefly attended Yale before serving in the armed forces during the Korean War. He began his career in advertising in the mail room at Young & Rubicam in 1951.
From there, he joined Ogilvy & Mather, where he eventually was hand-picked by David Ogilvy, the agency's legendary founder, to succeed him as chief copywriter. At Ogilvy & Mather, Mr. McCall worked on campaigns for Sears, Roebuck & Company, Hathaway Shirts and Maxwell House coffee, for which he wrote the tag line "Coffee that tastes as good as it smells."
In 1961, Mr. McCall left Ogilvy to become co-founder of an agency, McCaffrey & McCall Inc. There, he helped create campaigns for a variety of companies, including Exxon, Tiffany and Mercedes-Benz. One particularly memorable television commercial created by Mr. McCall for Norelco showed Santa Claus sledding down a hill on one of the company's electric shavers.
"David really supported the creative side tremendously, often times to the exclusion of the account managers," said Tom Yohe, who was a creative director at the agency in the 1970's.
But it was McCaffrey & McCall's work for Mercedes-Benz that was probably most influential, setting the standard for how luxury cars are marketed in the United States.
The agency was acquired by Saatchi & Saatchi in 1983. Mr. McCall left five years later, eventually becoming a partner in the Sawyer-Miller Group, a political and corporate communications consulting firm in New York. At the time of his death, he was chairman of Shepardson Stern & Kaminsky, a communications, consulting and advertising firm based in New York that he helped found six years ago.
Throughout his career, Mr. McCall exhibited a strong passion for politics, education and human rights. In the 1960's, he served on the boards of the New York Urban League and the Congress for Racial Equality. Later, he was a founding member of the Central Park Conservancy and of Meals on Wheels.
He also used advertising to promote social causes. Mr. McCall helped organize agencies around the country to create ads opposing the war in Vietnam, a campaign called "Unsell the War." He created anti-tobacco advertising.
But he took most pride in "Schoolhouse Rock," an Emmy award-winning series of animated educational segments aimed at children that was shown on the ABC television network on Saturday and Sunday mornings from 1973 to 1985 and again in 1993.
Mr. McCall was married three times and is survived by six sons from his first marriage, John P. McCall, Peter Cortelyou McCall, and David Bruce McCall, Jr., all of New York City, and William Dudley McCall of Atlanta, Robert McCall of Seattle and Thomas Clement McCall of Easton, Md.; a sister, Margaret G. Wasley of Niantic, Conn., and six grandchildren.
He met his third wife at a party in Bridgehampton, and they were married in 1978. Born Joan Partridge Mills, and known as Penny, Mrs. McCall was born into wealth. Her mother was a member of the Ordway family, which helped found the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, or 3M.
Mrs. McCall grew up in Greenwich, Conn., and attended the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury. In addition to her refugee work, she devoted much of her life to collecting art and supporting artists. She served on the board of the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan and established the Penny McCall Foundation to support contemporary artists, especially women and minorities.
She was also a supporter of the Abyssinian Development Corporation in Harlem and at the time of her death was working on an economic develop project in Harlem to set up an urban fashion design and manufacturing company in association with the Thurgood Marshall Academy.
Mrs. McCall is survived by her mother, Dorothy O. Mills of Greenwich; a daughter from a previous marriage, Jennifer McSweeney Reuss of Rowayton, Conn.; and two brothers, George P. Mills of New York City, and Sam Mills of San Francisco.
In recent years, the McCalls had focused much of their attention on the problem of land mines, which kill and maim thousands of refugees around the world each year.
Only a few months ago, the couple were instrumental in starting a new organization called the Independent Demining Assessment Center. Its aim is to bring new mine detection and removal technology to the areas of the world that need it, said Mr. Grace of Refugees International, which is helping to organize the center.

HEADLINE: Case Has Loss In First Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: RACINE, Wis., April 19

 BODY:
The Case Corporation, the No. 2 United States maker of farm equipment behind Deere & Company, said today that it had a first-quarter loss, as slumping crop prices forced farmers to curb spending on tractors and machinery.
Case had a loss of $48 million, or 68 cents a share, compared with profit a year earlier of $69 million, or 88 cents. The loss was much narrower than the 85-cent-loss average estimate of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation, and investors responded by sending its shares up $1.375, to $34.3125. 
 Recessions last year, particularly in Brazil and Asia, left farmers with less money to spend on agricultural equipment. Farmers' revenues were also hurt by bumper harvests for wheat and other crops, pushing commodities prices to their lowest levels in two decades. "The lower year-over-year earnings for the first quarter reflect significant sales declines in high-margin, large agricultural equipment," Case said in a statement. Revenue fell to $1.20 billion from $1.38 billion.
"Unfavorable economic conditions in Brazil" reduced earnings by $15 million, or 16 cents a share, Case said. It said Latin American demand for small tractors is projected to fall 10 percent to 15 percent in 1999. Financing for equipment purchases in emerging markets is expected to remain difficult to obtain, and worldwide sales of agricultural equipment will be down about 8 percent to 10 percent in 1999, Case said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Globalution Game

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
A few years ago I was interviewing a dissident Indonesian news editor who was telling me how he managed to get critical things about the corrupt Suharto family into the heavily controlled Indonesian press. He said that when President Suharto's son was being given government subsidies for a wacky idea he had for building an Indonesian car industry, the local press was reluctant to come out openly against this nepotism. What the Indonesian press did instead was wait for the World Trade Organization to bring a case against Suharto's son for unfair trade practices and then splash that on the front pages. The message was, "Gosh, we would never say anything bad about the President's son, but these folks at the W.T.O. sure think he's up to no good."
This Indonesian use of the W.T.O. is not an isolated case. Actually, it is an example of a new political phenomenon you can see in many developing countries today, which I call "globalution." Globalution happens when reformers understand that revolution from below may be too explosive, and revolution from above is never going to happen, so they choose revolution from beyond.
Their strategy is to plug their country into every possible global rules-based organization they can find -- from the World Trade Organization to the PriceWaterhouseCoopers accounting firm to Conservation International -- in hopes of importing rule-of-law systems from beyond. 
 This is how one should look at the issue of whether the U.S. should support China's entry into the W.T.O. -- something that President Clinton balked at when China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, visited last week, but that Mr. Clinton is reconsidering and renegotiating with the Chinese.
That China's joining the W.T.O. -- on American terms -- is so manifestly in our economic interest is not even worth debating. America's markets are largely open. China's joining the W.T.O. will not have much impact on China's exports to the U.S. But it will have a huge impact on American access to China's market, because it will force China to open up to foreigners on a defined schedule with set rules overseen by a multinational organization -- replacing the arbitrary, closed system the Chinese have now. There is this notion out there that letting China into the W.T.O. is somehow a giveaway. Well, it is, sort of. It's a giveaway to the U.S. economy.
But there's more going on here. Zhu Rongji is a closet globalutionary. He knows that this deal would help force more transparency, global standards and outside reviews on what is now a highly secretive system of trade laws in China, in which individual bureaucrats have huge discretion and therefore huge opportunities to rip off both foreigners and Chinese. China's entry into the W.T.O. would also help open the interior of China to foreign investors in the fields of Internet service, telephones, faxes and banking, which in turn would help to raise living standards and to develop parts of China that China itself cannot afford to develop. Right now foreign companies cannot own telecommunications companies in China. If China enters the W.T.O., Sprint, AOL and AT&T will all be able to buy into companies there, and that can only contribute to China's being more wired into the world. Lastly, Chinese entrepreneurs, who today have to do their importing through state trading companies, will now be able to import and export directly, which can only help strengthen the private sector in China.
In other words, Mr. Zhu clearly sees the W.T.O. as a way to force his own economic and political reforms on the bloated, inert and corrupt Chinese system. But we should have no illusions. Opponents of this deal within China will fight an intense rearguard action against it if China signs. Implementation will not be easy.
"My sense is that the biggest opposition in China is coming from elements in China's national defense area who are saying to Zhu, 'You are putting us into a globalized world and we are going to lose control,' " says Michael Oksenberg, a Stanford University China scholar.
China is not going to be remade overnight, by this or any other globalution deal. But China's joining the W.T.O. would be a huge step in the protracted process of opening up the Middle Kingdom and easing its wrenching transition from Communism. It would be a grievous error to miss this opportunity.
