HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
STOCK MARKET HITAS INVESTORS FLEE TECHNOLOGY AREA

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON and KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
In a stunning reversal, investors piled out of technology stocks and other market darlings yesterday, pummeling the very shares that propelled the broad market averages to records last week.
After rising 271.8 points, or 2.6 percent, during the morning, the Dow Jones industrial average ran out of steam shortly after noon and ended the day down 53.36 points, or a half-percent, at 10,440.53. 
 The Nasdaq market started the day in negative territory and never climbed out as investors fled the computer, Internet and telecommunications stocks they had been favoring. Amazon.com lost 16 percent, Dell Computer declined 7.3 percent, and Microsoft fell 6.5 percent.
The Nasdaq composite index, home to most of the nation's technology companies, fell 138.43 points, or about 5.6 percent, to close at 2,345.61.
That was the composite's second- biggest fall in points but only its seventh in percentage terms. Its largest point decline took place on Aug. 31, at the height of the Russian economic crisis.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded 1.21 billion shares, the second-heaviest trading day in the exchange's history. Nasdaq trading volume was also brisk, at 1.198 billion shares.
Early in the day, investors took refuge in stocks whose fortunes closely track the performance of the economy, but even those shares began to sputter at the close. "This kind of a sharp and dramatic reversal is not just business as usual," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "There's a message here. The message is everything finally began to sell off from sheer exhaustion."
Though oil prices rose in the morning, traders said this alone was not enough to kill the rally in the Dow. The shift away from the glamour stocks of technology, health care, Internet and telecommunications companies began last week and it simply gained momentum. The Standard & Poor's/Barra Growth stock index -- a collection of companies with high growth rates and lofty stock valuations -- has fallen 10 percent in the last five trading sessions.
Some of the biggest losers yesterday were stocks that had previously seemed to levitate. Even after yesterday's collapse, these shares are trading at high prices based on their earnings and are well above their lows. America Online, for example, fell 23 7/8 a share, to 115 7/8. That is down more than 30 percent from its high of April 6, but the shares are now where they were just about a month ago.
Likewise, the Charles Schwab Corporation, a brokerage concern that is a favorite Internet play because of its on-line trading services, closed down 32 percent from its high of one week ago. Still, it is up 81 percent since the start of the year. Reflecting the damage done to Internet stocks, the American Stock Exchange's Internet index is down 18 percent from its high set last Tuesday.
Proving once again that the market's leadership can change on a dime, investors last week began to realize that excessive valuations in stocks posed more risk than they could comfortably accept. Rather than flee stocks entirely, they shifted to shares of some companies that had been left for dead. Previously unglamorous companies such as Allied Signal,, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing and Smurfit-Stone Container registered impressive gains.
"Investors had the idea that it's a new economy and a new stock market and that meant you don't have to worry about the old rules of diversification and quality," said Alan F. Skrainka, chief market strageist at Edward Jones in St. Louis.
No longer.
The move away from growth stocks with high valuations and into companies that are viewed as cheaper began last week. Market strategists pointed to two events that gave investors pause. The first was the European Central Bank's move on April 8 to cut interest rates, a signal that policy makers are committed to keeping the world on a path to economic growth by jumpstarting Europe's economies.
When economic growth around the world is scarce, as it has been recently, investors retreat to stocks they know can produce good earnings in spite of any malaise -- these are shares with hefty and reliable profits, so-called growth stocks. Indeed, these investors are willing to pay premiums for these profits. But when growth is plentiful, a broader group of companies benefits and investors can find improving profits in less expensive stocks.
The second scare for growth-stock investors came last Monday when Compaq Computer warned that its quarterly earnings would be half what analysts had been expecting. This reminded traders that technology, for all its promise, can also disappoint.
Adding to investor concern about growth stocks in general, and technology stocks in particular, was the news on Friday that Robert Stansky, the manager of Fidelity Investments' Magellan fund, had sold large positions in many hot technology stocks that had been among his biggest holdings. Mr. Stansky moved into "value stocks," more mundane shares that were trading at lower premiums to their earnings growth rates.
Traders noted yesterday that there were so few buyers for many falling stocks that sellers could get out only if they accepted prices well below the prevailing market. Some fell sharply even though relatively few shares exchanged hands.
Companies waiting in the wings to offer their shares to the public for the first time were likely losers in yesterday's market decline as well. Three Internet concerns, Net Perceptions Inc., Proxicom Inc. and Launch Media Inc., had planned initial public offerings this week. Until investors become more hospitable to companies like these, such offerings are likely to remain on hold.
Strategists pointed to the effect that hordes of rapid-fire day traders -- many of whom are relative newcomers to stocks and have yet to experience a severe, protracted decline in stock prices -- could have on the market. In recent months, these traders have created momentum and profits as they piled into stocks. If they are now piling out, they may create tidal waves of selling.
"This is a case where a lot of these stocks have some unreasonable gains," said Laszlo Birinyi, who heads his own stock research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "Now people are starting to lock in the gains when they can. As these stocks decline from their highs, the movement feeds on itself."
Longtime traders worry that a flood of calls from brokerage firms will go out to stock investors on Tuesday for more funds to prop up diminished portfolios that they have borrowed against to buy more stocks. Customers must meet these requests, known as margin calls, with fresh money or with cash raised by selling stocks. If shares are sold, the market decline could accelerate.
A spokeswoman for Ameritrade, a large discount brokerage firm, said that it had slightly higher margin calls than normal, adding that it had no discernible problems with trading. She also said that the brokerage firm had previously imposed higher borrowing limits, presumably lessening the number of margin calls that would go out to customers.
Of course, investors could jump back into their former stock darlings if they judge the selling to be overdone. Such a strategy has served them well in the last five years and was especially shrewd when the market rebounded from its correction in October. Microsoft, for example announces its earnings today. Investors may like what they see and bid the stock back up again.
Still, Mr. Wien of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said that the United States stock market remains overvalued and that the broad market averages will experience a correction, defined by traders as a decline of 20 percent. "What you're seeing is a resolution of excessive valuation in the market. I expect the indexes to decline further, but I don't think we're in a bear market."

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Bloomberg News)
 Bond prices snapped a four-session slide and posted their best day since April 8 as stocks fell, increasing the appeal of less risky Treasury securities.
The price of the 30-year benchmark bond rose 2 8/32 , to 96 8/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.51 percent from 5.57 percent on Friday. Yields on two-year notes, the most actively traded Treasuries and among those considered the safest, fell 6 basis points, to 4.93 percent.

HEADLINE: Bradley Takes Early Party Prize: He Goes One-on-One With Gore

SERIES: THE CONTENDERS: Running Toward 2000

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
Former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey likes to tell audiences that in 1988 he looked at himself in the mirror and said, "You're not ready." He decided not to run for President.
Four years later, he says, "there was something inside me that said, 'No, don't do this.' " 
 By last fall, he recalls, he looked in the mirror again and told himself: "I'm at the top of my game. I'm going to run for President of the United States."
Only months ago, many Democrats questioned Mr. Bradley's timing. They argued that he passed up his best chance in 1992, and that trying to triumph over an incumbent Vice President was a quixotic, even foolhardy, exercise.
But now, largely because of circumstances that Mr. Bradley had nothing to do with, few political professionals dismiss his prospects outright, even as they concede that Vice President Al Gore remains the heavy favorite for the nomination. That is because Mr. Bradley has already captured the prize for which nearly a dozen contenders on the Republican side are arduously competing: to emerge as the alternative should the leading candidate falter.
The parade of other Democrats who had planned to take on Mr. Gore has evaporated, leaving a simple dynamic. If Mr. Gore does not get the nomination, Mr. Bradley does. Never before in modern American politics, in a contest for an open White House, has the competition for a nomination been distilled to two people so early.
"It's Al Gore and I, one-on-one, for 11 months," said Mr. Bradley, who is as much known as a basketball star at Princeton University and for the New York Knicks as for his 18 years in the Senate.
As the only apparent alternative to Mr. Gore, Mr. Bradley is in a much more potent position than he would have been had other Democrats, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, not bailed out. He will automatically draw all of the anti-Gore and, in some cases, anti-Clinton, vote.
And Mr. Bradley will command far more attention from the press, and from voters. On Tuesday, for instance, he plans to highlight his long interest in race relations with a speech in New York that will in part address the case of Amadou Diallo, the unarmed West African immigrant who was shot to death by four white police officers.
It is the latest effort by Mr. Bradley to promote so-called "big ideas" to contrast with bite-sized initiatives advanced by Mr. Gore, like combating local traffic congestion.
Senator Bob Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat who decided not to challenge Mr. Gore, said Mr. Bradley had the potential to win the nomination.
"Any time there's only two people in the race there's a possibility," Mr. Kerrey said. "Bradley has two things people like: He was a good basketball player and he's smart. If he adds a third one, that he's a leader, he'll be tough."
It is an enviable political perch: as the early favorite, Mr. Gore faces pressure not only to prevail in the early contests but also to win overwhelmingly. Even if Mr. Bradley tallies a respectable percentage of the vote, but ultimately loses, he could still win plaudits as a dragon slayer who came close to toppling an incumbent Vice President.
Still, Mr. Bradley has yet to prove that he is the best candidate to make the most of the one-on-one dynamic. The reality is that Mr. Gore's weaknesses are not necessarily Mr. Bradley's strengths. Both are known as more cerebral, even shy, than back-slapping politicians. Both are often less-than-compelling orators. And it is difficult to decipher any momentous issue differences between the two, beyond that Mr. Bradley opposed the Administration's welfare reform measure. He feared that it would force mothers to abandon their children for jobs.
Mr. Bradley's reputation as somewhat plodding is sometimes evident in his campaign speeches. In a talk to contributors in Palm Beach, Fla., recently, he hardly sounded convincing when he said: "Now, the question is, 'Can you win?' And the answer is, 'Absolutely.' "
Yet Mr. Bradley came alive at a Democratic Party convention in Manchester, N.H., this month when he delighted the audience, and underscored his appeal as a celebrity, with tales from his basketball days. He also puts forth a personal side. Everywhere he goes, he says he is thankful that he did not run in 1992 because his wife, Ernestine, had breast cancer diagnosed that year and has since recovered.
Though at 6-foot-5 Mr. Bradley looks a bit awkward loping about, mingling with voters, his admirers at those events often walk away from him with the same response: He is more charming than they expected, and would offer a clean break from the scandal of the Clinton years.
In an interview, Mr. Bradley said he doubted that those who questioned his campaigning skills "have ever been out with me."
"I've been on the road for 30 years," he said, "and all those years I've either been performing in short pants, campaigning for people or earning money on the road. Now I'm out campaigning for the Presidency, and it's the ultimate exhilaration."
Insisting that the contest was serious business for him, Mr. Bradley said, "I don't get into it unless I can see my way through to 270, which are the electoral votes needed to be President."
Mr. Bradley's most pointed arguments for why voters should turn to him are that he has had a more varied life experience than Mr. Gore, who was the son of a Senator, and that he has had more ambitious ideas. "I had a life before I got into politics," he tells audiences.
His supporters also emphasize that Mr. Bradley has a long established reputation as championing campaign reform, and that his ethics have never been questioned. That, they say, would make a pointed contrast to the scandals of the Clinton years and the questions surrounding Mr. Gore's raising money for the 1996 campaign.
Even so, Mr. Bradley, who retired from the Senate in 1996, has resisted requests to put forward many specifics about what he would do as President. He has been reluctant, for example, to spell out how the Administration should be handling the most pressing matter of the day: the crisis in Kosovo.
Mr. Gore's advisers, already devising arguments to undermine their competitor, say that it is disingenuous for Mr. Bradley, who is 55, to cast himself as a Washington outsider because he was a Senator a decade longer than the Vice President.
But Gore advisers were clearly unnerved that Mr. Bradley collected $4.3 million in the first three months of the year, an impressive sum even though it did not approach the $8.9 million amassed by Mr. Gore in that period. The fact that Mr. Gore has an opponent has also prompted him to display his political might by taking steps like staging a formal endorsement with Mr. Gephardt.
Mr. Bradley has nowhere near the endorsements or the vast staff of the Gore organization. Not one member of Congress, not even from New Jersey, has publicly signed on to his campaign.
Yet Mr. Bradley has assembled a skilled staff, including many longtime advisers, although they still seem to be struggling with the unexpectedly intense and early demands placed upon the second candidate in a two-person matchup.
Insisting that he was well aware of, but unfazed by, Mr. Gore's institutional advantages, Mr. Bradley offers a sweeping, yet rather vague, explanation for how he can prevail: "Ultimately, the people decide these elections and they decide them on the basis of who's speaking to their lives and who do they feel is speaking most clearly about the future of the country."
Mr. Bradley's unexpected position as an underdog to be reckoned with is in part an outgrowth of Mr. Gore's miscalculations. Though the Vice President shrewdly scared off potential rivals who were intimidated by his seeming invincibility, he did not take Mr. Bradley's intentions as seriously as he did the others.
Mr. Bradley's image is also helped by early polls showing that Mr. Gore's support is quite shallow. Those surveys have found that Mr. Bradley has gained significant ground in polls in recent weeks, though he remains far behind Mr. Gore.
The Bradley strategy is founded on the premise that voters in the two most pivotal early contests, the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary, sometimes pride themselves on being contrary and do not always reward the expected winner. Mr. Bradley hopes he will emerge in one or both of those early contests. He is also wooing independent voters and even Republicans, with some success, judging by the turnout at some of his events.
Bernie Schnitzer, a New Jersey resident who calls himself a snowbird who spends winters in Florida, said at a Bradley event in Palm Beach that he opposed Mr. Gore because "he's a little too much in the Clinton image." But, Mr. Schnitzer said, he is worried that beyond the Mid-Atlantic States, Mr. Bradley may strike voters as "too Eastern, too liberal, too intellectual."
Mr. Gore's advisers dismiss Mr. Bradley as the Gary Hart of 2000. In the 1984 Democratic primaries, Mr. Hart, then a Colorado Senator, emerged as the alternative to former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, and, like Mr. Bradley, portrayed himself as the thoughtful candidate with big ideas.
Mr. Hart jolted the Democratic Party by winning the New Hampshire primary. Mr. Mondale then recovered with a heavy advertising and organizational campaign, and by posing this question about Mr. Hart's vaunted ideas: "Where's the beef?"
But Mr. Bradley's advisers argue that because of the newly compressed primary schedule in 2000, a victory in Iowa or New Hampshire would make him unstoppable as the race turns quickly to big states like California and New York.
"If Gore maintains his standing, Bradley probably can't do anything," said John Haskell, a professor of political science at Drake University in Des Moines. "But if the economy went bad, or if you get lucky in some primary -- Gore makes a stupid mistake -- it can really snowball because of the front-loaded primaries."
Though Mr. Gore has far more extensive organizations, Mr. Bradley has the advantage of being able to campaign full time, and without being captive to Air Force Two and other trappings, which can be important in early states where one-on-one contact with voters is crucial.
"The difficulty Gore faces now in Iowa and New Hampshire is that these are both states where he has never really campaigned on his own behalf before, and there's an inherent need in those constituencies to see him up closer in a more retail way," said William Carrick, a veteran Democratic strategist. "Obviously, that's easier for Bradley to do than for Gore."
The hard part, Mr. Carrick noted, is advancing from No. 1 alternative to the nominee.
"We have a history of the process producing significant and serious challenges to the established front-runner," he said. "But it's a 50-50 thing whether they win or not."
More than a year ago, over lunch in Palo Alto, Calif., where Mr. Bradley was a fellow at Stanford University, he recalled what he did not miss about his old job: "Who needed to be stroked? Who needed to be called? Who needed to be reasoned with? Who in the press were our allies? Who were our enemies? How do we convince four or five people on the other side you need to have to make something really go. It's just a different time."
Asked in that interview whether he had the stomach or endurance to dive back into the most competitive political arena of all, he shrugged and said, "Who knows? Who knows?"
This is the first in a series of profiles of major Presidential candidates.

HEADLINE: Despite Intense Criticism, US Airways Increases Fares in New York

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, April 18

 BODY:
The only airline with jet service within New York State quietly raised ticket prices over the weekend, pushing fares as much as 67 percent higher than a year ago. The airline, US Airways, is already under intense criticism from corporate and political leaders for charging high fares within the state.
At the same time, the airline is cutting one daily flight and ending all jet service between La Guardia Airport and Syracuse, instead using smaller turboprop planes starting May 4, Richard Weintraub, an airline spokesman, confirmed. 
 US Airways increased last-minute business fares between New York City and Albany to $450 for a round trip, $60, or 15.4 percent, higher than the price a year ago. That raises the cost to $1.65 per mile. US Airways reports that it breaks even when its revenue is about 12 cents per mile for each seat on its planes.
US Airways' round-trip business fares from New York City are now $458 to Buffalo, $416 to Rochester and $436 to Syracuse.
The biggest percentage increases were on the cheapest advance-purchase tickets, which are nonrefundable and require a Saturday night stay. The round-trip fare between La Guardia Airport and Rochester, for example, was raised on Friday to $224 from May through August. The same ticket cost $134 for the comparable season a year ago, an increase of 67 percent. That fare rise was cut back slightly Saturday to $204, a 52 percent increase.
Even before the latest fare increases, Rochester had the nation's fourth-highest fares, United States Department of Transportation data show, while Buffalo and Syracuse had among the 20 most expensive.
Lawrence M. Nagin, general counsel for US Airways, said the increases were part of an industry-wide rise in fares last week. "No one market was targeted," he said, but he declined to discuss fares for specific cities. Over all, the airline industry has raised business fares about 3 percent this year and leisure fares 7 percent.
The fare increases were denounced by political figures and business leaders. United States Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said US Airways "is pushing the envelope when it comes to abusing their monopoly status" and that its fares "are throttling the economy upstate."
Anthony M. Masiello, the Mayor of Buffalo, said, "punitively high air fares are causing serious economic problems for upstate New York, and its decline will seriously affect the whole state, and make us less competitive."

HEADLINE: Reading and Commerce

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You ask "When No One Read, Who Started to Write?" (April 6). 
 My speculation is that someone needed to keep a unambiguous record, given the fallibility of human memory. Perhaps a merchant or a ruler who wanted a written record for himself. He had to develop the symbols and once that was done, he could convey the ability to read them to an employee. Next step: a contract or bill of sale, which now required an outsider to learn to read. The precursor to the spread of reading must have been trade and the evolution of the merchant. Still, it seems surprising how recently writing and reading began.
 
JOHN T. BENNETT
Alexandria, Va.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Rutgers Named in Suit Over Alumni Ad Dispute

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey sued Rutgers University yesterday in an effort to force the alumni magazine to publish an advertisement by a group opposed to what it considers the university's emphasis on big-time athletics.
An alumni group known as Rutgers 1000 sought to publish the advertisement in May, but the magazine, Rutgers Alumni, rejected the ad, said David Rocah, a staff lawyer for the civil rights organization. 
 The advertisement quoted the Nobel Prize-winning economist Milton Friedman, a member of the alumni group, as saying, "Universities exist to transmit knowledge and understanding of ideas and values to students, not to provide entertainment for spectators or employment for athletes."
The suit, filed in State Superior Court in New Brunswick, charges that the magazine denied the alumni group its right to free speech under the New Jersey and United States Constitutions.
Unlike private newspapers and other media, which have the right to publish what they see fit, Mr. Rocah said, a magazine published by a public institution is an extension of government, and cannot censor ideas contained in its advertising.
The university released a statement saying that based on a preliminary review of the lawsuit, "the constitutional arguments raised by the A.C.L.U. are without merit."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1432 words

HEADLINE: Giuliani to Propose Some Height Limits On City Skyscrapers

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Moving to overhaul New York City's zoning laws for the first time in 40 years, the Giuliani administration today will propose the city's first broad limits on the height of skyscrapers. The rules would curtail a longstanding practice that permits developers to build higher buildings in exchange for creating plazas or other public amenities at ground level.
The changes are among several in the planned zoning revisions. Some changes would open manufacturing areas to more medical and social service complexes. Others would greatly increase the number of parking spaces allowed in new residential buildings and impose more restrictions on the large billboard-type signs that are common in the city. 
 But perhaps the most significant changes involve building size, with the new proposals aimed at setting maximum heights for buildings in most parts of a city that is synonymous with its skyscrapers. City officials say the height limits have yet to be determined, but added that the permissible height of new buildings would probably be similar to that of the tallest existing structure in any particular neighborhood.
The most congested parts of midtown and downtown would be excluded from the new height rules, Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, said in an interview. The idea, Mr. Rose explained, is not to protect those two most densely developed parts of Manhattan from more dense development, but to prevent other areas of the city from being overdeveloped.
The proposed restrictions are intended to address the challenges posed by a strong economy and a resulting building boom that has tested limits on the height and scale of new construction.
For instance, Donald J. Trump is proceeding with plans for a 90-story apartment building on a residential East Side block, a project he has been able to push by obtaining development rights from several nearby properties.
The Trump plan would have been blocked if the proposed zoning changes had been in effect a year ago when it was awaiting city approval, Mr. Rose said. He would not give other examples of buildings, either existing or proposed, that would be disqualified.
Calling the existing rules that allowed for such projects cumbersome and obsolete, city officials say developers should no longer be allowed to exploit such development rights -- and use outdated city incentives -- to build ever-higher towers.
At the same time, they said, the city should find ways to accommodate projects that meet the needs of its growing economy.
"We have a city that has been built to its borders, but is still growing and changing as rapidly as any other," said Mr. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, who is scheduled to describe the proposed zoning changes to an invited group of planners, community advocates and elected officials in a City Hall address today. He said the height limits would vary according to the existing scale of city neighborhoods.
Referring to the city's complex 900-page zoning law that was first written in 1916 and last amended in 1961, Mr. Rose said he feared what he called "a Pandora's box" of conflicting demands from developers, environmentalists and others if the entire zoning statute were opened for revision. The solution, he said, was to institute a limited number of "dramatic modifications."
The proposed changes face a battery of tests, including public hearings, environmental review and a City Council vote. The administration hopes to have the rules in place by the time Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani leaves office; the last time such major changes were proposed, in the 1950's, the revisions were not enacted for nearly a decade.
Those rules have helped shape the city landscape by encouraging the creation of small plazas that surround huge structures, or allowing for skyscrapers that tower over surrounding blocks of low-rise buildings.
In the case of Mr. Trump's planned East Side tower, the developer bought development rights, or "air rights," over several other buildings on the block of his building site, between 47th Street and 48th Street, and incorporated setbacks and public plazas into the design. That allowed him to receive city approval to erect a tower far taller than anything close by; by contrast, the nearby United Nations is 39 stories, slightly more than half as high.
"For 40 years, we have been guided by the Tower in the Park concept of zoning," said Mr. Rose, invoking a term coined in praise of tall, narrow buildings that allowed light and air on the street, and often on public plazas built for the exclusive use of their residents above street level.
Since the 1960's, planners have condemned such building design as a form of architectural division between urban residents and the traditional vibrancy of their streets. And for developers and city officials, it has created a byzantine regulatory framework.
"The zoning law has become crowded with incentives, but the form it creates is inconsistent with what is good for the city," Mr. Rose said. Although the use of such incentives as air rights, which developers have used for scores of buildings in Manhattan, and plaza bonuses would not be eliminated, he said, they would no longer enable developers to build beyond city-mandated height limits.
The proposals provoked a mixture of enthusiasm and skepticism among civic groups and builders. Developers, while warning of determined resistance to the proposed height limits if they undercut potential profits, said they were heartened by the separate proposal outlined by Mr. Rose that would liberalize the city's restrictions on new parking spaces.
That zoning change would eliminate the current limit of one parking space for every five apartments in large new residential developments. Mr. Rose said that that rule had created a severe shortage of parking and that the zoning proposal would probably double the allowable number of spaces in new buildings.
Absolute height restrictions are not common in big cities, said Bill Morrish, director of the design center for American Urban Landscape, a research organization at the University of Minnesota. Most large cities use zoning restrictions that are similar to the ones New York is seeking to replace.
Absolute restriction are more common in smaller cities, like Santa Monica, Calif., and in resort areas.
Should the New York rules pass, they could be the Giuliani administration's most enduring imprint on the physical shape of the city. Mr. Rose suggested that the announcement of the proposal was timed to allow for a thorough review of them before the Mayor leaves office.
"I think that is one of the most brilliant things I've heard proposed in city zoning," said Mr. Trump, who described his First Avenue tower as "grandfathered in and totally on schedule" despite lawsuits by community residents.
He said the new height limits proposed by Mr. Rose "would only be a bad thing if they limit creativity of architects and developers."
Mr. Rose said the proposed height limits, while setting varying standards across the city, would not be absolute. In rare instances, he said, builders might win exceptions based on the quality of their architecture.
Steven Spinola, the president of the Real Estate Board of New York, which represents builders, said yesterday that industry executives would "argue over how high is too high." But he added that Mr. Rose's proposals could lead to a "much simplified zoning process" that would be embraced by the industry.
At the Municipal Art Society, a group that was instrumental in creating the city's first zoning law in 1916, Philip K. Howard, the group's chairman, said yesterday that Mr. Rose's proposals had "finally attacked the premise of zoning that has for too long been corroding the vitality of the city."
"The 1961 zoning law was like a meteor that happened to strike in the middle of New York City," Mr. Howard said, adding that the proposed height limits would provide a "useful technique for bringing development into a pattern that is consistent with neighborhoods."
While providing only sketchy details, Mr. Rose said the element of the proposed zoning changes that would liberalize rules in industrial areas was intended to relieve pressure on residential areas that are overburdened by medical clinics, drug treatment centers and other public service complexes.
He said the proposed restrictions on signs would make it more difficult to erect large signs on the sides of buildings and were not aimed at those placed on the front of stores and theater marquees.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 21, 1999, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about proposed zoning regulations for New York City omitted the context for a quotation from Donald J. Trump. In saying, "I think that is one of the most brilliant things I've heard proposed in city zoning," he was referring to one aspect -- an increase in the number of parking spaces allowed in large residential developments -- not to the overall proposal.

LENGTH: 1533 words

HEADLINE: They're Building a Lot More Than Their Collections

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Asoaring structure, resembling a bird taking flight, is rising on Lake Michigan's shores, where it is soon to be a wing of the Milwaukee Art Museum. The erstwhile Home for Needy Confederate Women in Richmond was just rechristened as the education center of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts. The Old Main Library in San Francisco and an abandoned Nabisco factory in Beacon, N.Y., are about to be converted, respectively, into the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco and a branch of the Dia Center for the Arts.
Then there is a trio of gallery pavilions that will "float" above a reflecting pond as the new Museum of Modern Art of Fort Worth; a sculpture garden dug into the Washington Mall for the National Gallery of Art; an old May Company department store morphing into space for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art; a disused multiplex discount cinema that is now the Scottsdale Museum of Contemporary Art in Arizona, and the Museum of Modern Art's $650 million plan to transform its block of West 53d Street in New York. 
 There is even 130,000 square feet of new floor space at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, created by slicing two-story galleries into separate floors and by taking over air shafts and vacated offices.
Any which way they can, American art museums are expanding. Play the proverbial dart game with a map of the United States and, chances are, you'll land near a city whose museum has expanded, is expanding or plans to expand.
Though no one keeps a master list, a wide but by no means complete survey by The New York Times discovered nearly 60 museums that are enlarging their quarters, to the tune of several billion dollars. That does not include recent projects, like the stunning new branch of the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, the sprawling new Getty Center in Los Angeles and the fledgling Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., that made their entrances before 1998.
Where growth plans do not yet exist on paper, they often dance in the heads of museum directors and trustees. The Philadelphia Museum of Art, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, the Cleveland Museum of Art, the St. Louis Art Museum and the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, for example, are writing strategic plans bound to involve additional square footage.
"It's just dreams at this point, but we will have something to say soon," said Malcolm Rogers, the director of the Boston museum. "If you're not changing or expanding, you're standing still."
The broadest, grandest, most ambitious art museum boom in American history depends, of course, on one fact: If ever there was a good time for raising cash, it is now. Thanks to the second-longest economic expansion of this century and a 10,000-point Dow Jones Industrial Average, the United States is rich with, well, the wealthy. The monied classes enjoy being art patrons, with the recognition, gilt by association and confirmation of taste that giving confers.
And donors generally prefer to give money for buildings, rather than operations, a trend that dovetails with museums' primal need for more space -- their version of Manifest Destiny -- to show ever-growing collections. "A museum that considers itself finished is dead," said Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Some museums say they are at the breaking point: They own art that ought to be on display but isn't, and yet donors of new gifts want to see them out in the open. Gail Harrity, the chief operating officer at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, voiced a common complaint: "We've already expanded into every possible inch that we can."
But there may be more going on here than the museum world's perpetual quest for marble and mortar. To some observers, the expansion blitz signals that museums occupy a more imposing position in the community than they have in the past, socially and economically as well as culturally.
"Art museums have shaped their outlook and their activities to be more in sync with society's needs and the aspirations of the community," said Robert P. Bergman, the director of the Cleveland Museum of Art. "More people look to cultural institutions to serve a wider, rather than narrow, band of our citizenry, and museums have vastly diversified their activities and programs."
Mr. Bergman and others cite classrooms, media laboratories, interactive displays, libraries, "event" rooms, auditoriums, performing arts spaces and, of course, shops, coffee bars and restaurants. With so many activities available under one roof, the museum becomes a gathering place, especially if it has added evening hours and live music.
Andrea Rich, the president of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, calls today's museum "the new town square" in some communities, the exceptions being, perhaps, major metropolitan areas.
Art museums have certainly insinuated themselves into local economies by attracting tourists. "Every city has to have an art museum," said Witold Rybczynski, the author of "City Life: Urban Expectations in a New World" (Simon & Schuster) and a professor of urbanism at the University of Pennsylvania. "The feeling is, if you get one, along with a sports team and an aquarium, that will somehow fix you up."
In Philadelphia, for example, the museum has drawn huge numbers of tourists to its retrospectives of Cezanne and Delacroix. "The art museum, once considered the icing on the cake, is suddenly the cake," Mr. Rybczynski said. Indeed, a 1998 study commissioned by the Travel Industry Association of America found that a quarter of adult travelers in the United States had visited a museum the previous year.
J. Mark Schuster, an associate professor of urban studies and planning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said: "Museums are part of urban development strategy. Communities are saying, 'We have to have one to compete.' "
The cultural position of art museums is changing, too, as they have transformed the nature of their collections. "The museum canon has broadened quite a lot," said Neil Harris, a history professor and expert on museums at the University of Chicago, "partly as a function of scholarship, partly in response to audiences."
Thus museums are adding art that reflects their region's ethnic makeup -- Latin American art in Texas, for example. But some go beyond that now, adding, say, Tibetan art as well as contemporary art in more forms, like photography, film, video, multimedia art and so on. (And 20th-century art casts what Mr. Harris called a long shadow, and "takes more space.")
For all these reasons, along with better marketing, increased frequency of blockbuster exhibitions and a more educated public, attendance is up at most museums. In Houston, for example, the Museum of Fine Arts is doubling its space partly to accommodate a visitor tally that jumped more than 50 percent in the last five years to 1.3 million in 1998. The Government reported last year that 68 million adult Americans visited art museums in 1997, resulting in 225 million visits. (Children's visits would increase the total sharply.)
BECAUSE of changes in methods, experts say, these figures cannot be compared with those from previous surveys. So it is hard to say whether a greater proportion of the population is visiting museums, or the population increased, and the same people are visiting museums more often. But Monnie Peters, a consultant in Washington who once headed the Government's arts participation survey, said: "You do have concrete evidence of the increased desire of the American public to go to art museums. They're saying they're going more, and I think you can believe it."
It helps, Mr. Harris said, that people have more money to spend on cultural activities and that the nation's population in cities, where the museums are, is growing. The proliferation of art images on the Internet is also whetting the appetites of many who now want to see the real thing, he said.
The more visitors museums have, the more space they need for amenities like bathrooms, parking areas and restaurants, which enlarge the expansions. Some experts, however, worry that museums are over-building, leaving themselves open to deficits if attendance drops.
Still, museum attendance has been rising for decades. "There is nothing inherently unsustainable" about high attendance, Mr. Harris said. "But it is expensive to sustain," he added. "A large number of people will go to certain exhibitions, but not others. Then there is pressure on museums to mount exhibitions that draw."
None of this seems to be particularly worrisome in the museum world, where the prevailing mood is boundless optimism. Consider the International Glass Museum in Tacoma, Wash., which exists only on paper. The group trying to build this showcase for studio glass has found firm commitments for just half of the $11 million needed.
In February, though, a letter from its headquarters announced that the yet unbuilt museum was expanding. To house "the extensive programs as well as preserve the overall beauty and attractiveness of the museum," trustees decided to boost the plan from 55,000 square feet to 59,300. Their new capital goal is $16.4 million.

HEADLINE: A Region Pins Hopes To the Backs of Fish

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI

 BODY:
WITH a cultural trove containing more than a dozen museums, several amusement parks and professional football and baseball teams, this port city would seem to have more than enough attractions for every visitor.
Indeed, a respectable 4.6 million visitors came to this area last year, spending $3.1 billion on everything from art appreciation -- the Cincinnati Art Museum is the first general art museum to be built west of the Alleghenies -- to a day at one of the nation's leading zoos. 
 Why, then, has the scheduled opening of an aquarium next month in Newport, Ky., less than a half-mile across the Ohio River, made Cincinnati tourism officials positively euphoric?
The answer is more: more attractions to entice more people into more frequent and longer stays, which government and business leaders hope will generate more money and more jobs.
Aquariums have become the bright stars in the museum world, as a number of cities -- Baltimore, Chattanooga, Tenn., and Corpus Christi, Tex., among them -- have discovered their value as cornerstones for economic development in formerly blighted urban areas. Cincinnati, already committed to helping build two new sports stadiums and other costly civic projects, drew the line at helping to finance an aquarium; Newport was willing. But even Cincinnati has recognized the benefits that an aquarium -- albeit one in the next state -- can provide.
"All of us have something to gain from it," said Gayle Harden-Renfro, a spokeswoman for the Greater Cincinnati Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Visitors don't look at city or state boundaries; to them it's the same area. So we are embracing the fact that these are invisible boundaries, and we are training ourselves not to say, 'This side of the river, that side of the river.' "
Because raising the entertainment quotient can increase profits, Cincinnati is sprucing up its waterfront with new football and baseball stadiums, and it is planning a multimillion-dollar National Underground Railroad Freedom Museum. The museum will focus on stories of courage and cooperation among fugitive slaves and those who helped them reach free states or Canada via a loosely organized system that existed before the Civil War.
Boosting tourism is also why Las Vegas, Nev., for example, is offering Nascar and shopping malls as well as gambling, and why Orlando, Fla., with its theme parks, is also touting its many (if little-known) cultural treasures, including its art museums, symphony orchestra and ballet. As the Greater Cincinnati Convention and Visitors Bureau noted in its 1998 annual report: "Increasing total room nights is a major annual goal, because a visitor or convention delegate who stays one or more nights in a hotel room (versus visiting for the day and then leaving) always generates more revenues for the host city."
The benefits to the region as a whole were spelled out in a 1996 economic impact study of the aquarium by the University of Cincinnati, which forecast that "83 percent of hotel expenditures would occur in Ohio," as would the lion's share of expenditures on food, drink and retail sales. That explains why photographs of the Newport Aquarium appear in tourist brochures and vacation packages offered by the Cincinnati visitors bureau. It also suggests why tourist brochures for the three Kentucky counties directly across from Cincinnati (Campbell, Kenton and Boone) proclaim "Northern Kentucky, the Southern Side of Cincinnati."
"People come here from Louisville, Columbus and Indianapolis to see a ball game or to go to amusement parks," said Barbara Dozier, the vice president of sales and marketing for the Northern Kentucky Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Our focus groups showed that few had ever been to an aquarium, because the closest are in Chattanooga and Chicago. So we hope to generate people who haven't been here before, and to get people who do visit the aquarium to stay over that second night."
Danny Fore, the executive director of the Tri-County Economic Development Corporation in nearby Covington, added: "The mutual cooperation makes sense, because we are joined at the hip with Cincinnati." The attachment extends to the Cincinnati-Northern Kentucky International Airport, which is a dozen miles from Cincinnati in Boone County, Kentucky.
But it is Newport that is looking to the aquarium to work a kind of magic. For all of the city's charm, including its historic district and riverfront restaurants with a front-row view of Cincinnati's bright lights and sleek high-rises, the 10-acre aquarium site was, until recently, a seedy "adult entertainment" district of strip clubs and pornography shops that earned Newport the sobriquet "sin city."
"Newport," said Patricia Wingo, the city's economic development director, "was Las Vegas before there was a Las Vegas."
Five local business executives originally proposed building the aquarium in Cincinnati, but the city was already wrestling with where to build its stadiums, and the Cincinnati Zoo decided it did not want to finance or operate an aquarium. Covington, Ky., the next most likely contender, wanted the aquarium, but hesitated because of the high cost of preparing a riverfront site.
Newport, however, offered to spend $10 million to acquire and prepare a suitable location. It didn't hurt that the aquarium's owners would benefit from a Kentucky law that provides tax incentives for tourist attractions expected to draw at least 25 percent of their visitors from out of state.
A recent tour of the two-level aquarium, while the sharks, moray eels, alligators and piranhas were completing quarantine in a nearby annex, demonstrated why local leaders believe that this attraction can generate a sea change in the regional tourism industry.
The aquarium itself is average in size (100,000 square feet with 1 million gallons of water). But its 380,000-gallon, open-air shark exhibit is one of the nation's biggest. Its 11,000 salt- and fresh-water animals comprise 600 species and include 50 sharks and 16 king penguins, whose purchase from an aquarium in Shirahama, Japan, accounted for about half of the aquarium's $600,000 total budget for animals.
EACH of the aquarium's five tunnels, totaling 200 feet, consists of a continuous piece of two-and-one-half-inch acrylic, thin enough for alligators and sharks to eyeball visitors up close from above or below, but thick enough to thwart the most determined predator.
Rising alongside the aquarium is a complex of restaurants, stores, an IMAX theater and a 21-screen megaplex, the biggest theater complex in the Greater Cincinnati area. A local developer who had a 73,000-pound bell cast in France (and claims it is the world's biggest) said he plans to ship it to Newport this summer to be mounted on a 1,000-foot-high "millennium monument." The notion is that the bell will be used to ring in 2000.
With financing for the multimillion-dollar tower still in question, not many revelers are likely to beat a path to Newport to witness the turn of the century. But as with the aquarium, city officials have high hopes.
"For years we provided entertainment for lots of people, but it was the wrong kind," said Ms. Wingo, Newport's economic director. "Now with the aquarium and our other attractions, we're going to provide entertainment you can talk about in public."
 
A Big Boom Underwater
THEY'RE not just fish tanks anymore. Aquariums have come a long way in recent years, in number, attendance and mission.
Thirty-one aquariums are members of the American Zoo and Aquarium Association, in Bethesda, Md., up from 17 in 1989, and aquarium attendance during the last decade has soared to 36.6 million from 23 million. There are also aquariums in Miami, Minneapolis, San Francisco and at least seven other cities that are not affiliated with the association. Aquariums are under construction or in the planning stages in about a dozen more cities, including Atlanta and Charleston, S.C.
What has sparked the recent interest is the ability of aquariums to attract visitor dollars and their importance in helping to regenerate rundown or abandoned urban areas.
Moreover, aquariums, like zoos, have benefited not only from visitor curiosity about sea creatures, but also from the growing interest in wildlife conservation and the environment. No longer just collections of fish, mammals or other marine life in tanks, modern aquariums often offer the aquatic equivalent of petting zoos, as well as interactive musical entertainment, seminars for adults, story times for children, movies and slide shows, intern programs and posted feeding times.
California has the largest number of aquariums belonging to the association (six), while Living Seas at Disney's Epcot Center in Orlando, Fla., draws the most people -- six million in 1997. The Monterey Bay Aquarium in Monterey, Calif., offers the biggest population of marine life outside the ocean -- more than 305,500 animals and plants at last count, representing 563 species of fish, mammals, birds, invertebrates, reptiles and plants. It also claims to have the world's biggest window: 54 feet wide, 15 feet tall, 13 inches thick and weighing 78,000 pounds.
The $118 million Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach, Calif., which opened last year, is the most expensive built in the United States, and the newest. The oldest is the New York Aquarium in Coney Island, Brooklyn. Built in 1896, it has the biggest aquarium-based marine research laboratory in the nation.

HEADLINE: FOOD STUFF

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant 

 BODY:

Now, Organic Produce With the Morning Paper
For some time Manhattanites have been able to get weekly deliveries of milk, juice, soft drinks, bottled water and even bagels and bread along with their morning paper. Now, organic fruits and vegetables are on the grocery list. Mitchell's News has started distributing produce from Eco-Organics in Jersey City each Thursday. Choices range from a generous array of vegetables suitable for salads for $28 to around 35 pounds of produce for $55, including delivery. 
 The economy assortment, for $35, contained excellent broccoli, carrots, garlic, celery, tiny tomatoes, mesclun and good red romaine, citrus, apples and a pineapple. The very fresh spinach included was mature, more suited for braising than a salad, and the string beans were not as young as they could have been, but both were acceptable.
Orders for delivery by Mitchell's should be placed directly with Eco-Organics, either at (888) 326-6742 or, better still, at its Web site (www.ecoorganics.com), which provides a complete listing of the week's offerings. On the Internet you can add or subtract from the standard assortments, customizing your needs from week to week.
Mitchell's delivers only to buildings with 24-hour attendants. Eco-Organics will deliver to any building by United Parcel Service for a dollar or so more than Mitchell's service.
 
A Sale on (Fine) Chocolates
Excellent Michel Cluizel Chocolates, made in France, have just been introduced at Sutton Place Gourmet and Hay Day stores on Long Island and in Westchester and Connecticut, as well as in the Washington area. Fillings encased in silken bittersweet and milk chocolate include praline with a bit of crunch, fragrant pistachio cream, and dense coffee and citrus-scented ganaches. As high-end chocolates go, these are well priced. Until the end of May, they will be $24.99 a pound, instead of $29.99, when selected from 28 varieties on display. Prepacked gift boxes cost more: $39.99 for a pound, $24.99 for a half pound.
The stores will soon be selling Michel Cluizel ice cream, too.
 
Dean Waters
Alice Waters, who throughout her restaurant career has mostly stayed close to her home base in Berkeley, Calif., is adding New York to her itinerary. She has been appointed a visiting dean at the French Culinary Institute, 462 Broadway (Grand Street). It is a departure for a school whose philosophy is extremely French, but a way of increasing the visibility of women on the male-dominated faculty, said Sue Huffman, the director of marketing. Starting next month, Ms. Waters will give lectures to each new class in the six-month program.
 
Ginger by the Drop
Ginger root now seems to be indispensable to serious cooks, but it's difficult to keep it fresh and moist. Grating it or producing juice, if that's what a recipe requires, is tedious. Royal Pacific's new bottled ginger juice is a handy alternative, to use by the droplet or the spoonful, to add a bit of gingery heat to tea, fruit salads, dressings, sauces and cocktails. Minced fresh ginger and fresh ginger juice are a trifle spicier, so you might want to use a little more of the bottled kind, which has citric acid and an emulsifier. Once opened, it should be kept in the refrigerator.
Royal Pacific Ginger Juice is about $4 for five ounces at Aphrodisia, 264 Bleecker Street (Cornelia Street); Garden of Eden, 162 West 23d Street, and Zabar's, 80th Street and Broadway. Soon, it will be sold at Food Emporium and Kings Super Markets.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
Law of Gravity Applies to Bordeaux Prices

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
FOR the first time in four years, the prices of Bordeaux wines are beginning to fall, in some instances significantly below last year's levels. Among some of the better-known chateaus, Margaux is down 14 percent, Cos d'Estournel 25 percent, Ducru-Beaucaillou 16 percent and Gloria 11 percent.
But don't rush to your local wine store looking for a bargain just yet. The price drop refers to the 1998 vintage, which is maturing in chateau cellars and whose wines will not be sold in the United States until 2000 or 2001. The 1997 Bordeaux, whose prices set off a debate among those in the wine trade, will begin to arrive this year. More about them later. 
 The price drop was welcomed by the Bordeaux Wine Council, a trade group, which announced it officially in Paris last week. As always, the five most famous chateaus -- Haut-Brion, Lafite-Rothschild, Latour, Margaux and Mouton-Rothschild -- were the first to announce their prices, which are called opening prices. As the wine passes through the hands of brokers, shippers, importers, distributors and retailers, that opening price can increase by 50 to 100 percent.
Bordeaux is France's biggest wine exporting region, so what goes on there is closely watched by wine experts around the world. They had been predicting a drop in French wine prices because of the Asian financial crisis, declining Japanese demand and growing competition from wines elsewhere in the world.
To other wine players, greed on the part of Bordeaux producers also had a part. They point out that the 1997 vintage, a relatively mediocre one, was offered for sale at prices well above the 1996, a very good vintage, as producers tried to make the most of a hot market.
Preliminary judgments of the 1998 vintage put it considerably above the 1997 in quality, which means that the 1998's are being offered at lower prices than the less-good 1997's.
But where did the astoundingly high prices for Bordeaux wines of the last few years come from anyway? After a succession of indifferent years -- 1991, 1992, 1993 and 1994 -- worldwide demand for a good wine was great. The 1995 vintage was excellent, and anticipating the demand for it, Bordeaux producers set their opening price 35 percent over 1994. Even so, demand was so strong that prices were pushed up 50 percent more. Growers were encouraged to offer the 1996 vintage at even higher prices -- in some cases, 55 or 60 percent higher than what they had asked for the 1995's.
"Up to this point, there was some logic to all this," said Anthony Barton, owner of Chateau Leoville-Barton in St.-Julien, in Bordeaux wine country. That is, good wines sold in a buoyant market in a generally expanding world economy. "When things ceased to make sense was when the 1997 vintage was put on the market," he added. Although that year produced some excellent wines, few would say they were equal to, let alone better than, 1995 or 1996. Yet prices went up again.
Mr. Barton said it was "a grave error" for producers to think that there was a true demand for the 1997 vintage at this high price. "Now, the 1998 campaign is under way, and it has caused producers quite a problem," he said.
Eric Dulong, vice president of the Bordeaux Wine Council, defended the 1997 vintage as "overly criticized," but promised "a significant effort" to lower prices for the vintage, much of which remains unsold.
In New York, Abdallah Simon, chairman of the Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, an important Bordeaux importer, said he was not worried about selling the 1997's but criticized the Bordelais for pushing the 1997 prices so high.
In Bordeaux, Paul Pontallier, manager of Chateau Margaux, said of 1997: "We did what we had to do -- perhaps we went a bit too high."
He added: "Pricing is out of our hands. The market makes the prices. Our job is to make the very best wine we can."
Will a measure of logic return to a market driven by ego and tradition, as well as economic realities? Mr. Barton, whose family has made wine in Bordeaux since 1822, is cautiously optimistic. "With luck and a small measure of good judgment," he said, "the 1998 vintage will be sold at about the right price." He added, "I look forward to returning to the old-fashioned formula of increasing prices in good years and decreasing them in lesser years."
 
Tastings
A Robust Red
 
Gallo Zinfandel, Alexander Valley, Barrelli Creek Vineyard, Sonoma County, Calif., 1995. About $14.
 
ANOTHER of Gallo's single-vineyard Sonoma County wines, this is a blend of 82 percent zinfandel and 18 percent petite sirah, both from Barrelli Creek vines. The two grape varieties were fermented separately, blended, then aged for almost 14 months, mostly in American oak barrels. The result is a rich, full-bodied wine with a beautiful bouquet and a surprisingly long finish. It might benefit from a few years' extra aging, but it's perfectly ready to drink now. The alcohol level is high, 14.4 percent, but that's not uncommon in zinfandels these days, and it gives them the robust quality we've come to expect. Not exactly a summer wine, it would be ideal for use with red meats, game and some assertive cheeses.

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 1; Museums 

LENGTH: 1936 words

HEADLINE: Culture's Power Houses;
The Museum Becomes An Engine of Urban Redesign

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
I want to hold on to the moment after I checked into my hotel in Bilbao, Spain, dropped off my bags in the room and rushed out to walk around the city's new Guggenheim Museum. By chance, I ran into the museum's architect, Frank Gehry, outside the hotel, and he asked if I wanted to go look at the building with him.
That was not what I'd had in mind. I love to arrive in a new town and just walk around, letting impressions sink in, before heading off to inspect a new building. But this was an occasion to let the unexpected happen: the designer of this museum, a building already celebrated months before it opened, also walking around by himself, checking the impressions his work made from different parts of the city -- streets, angles, distances. 
 Anyway, how do you answer a question like that? Look at the building? What building? Oh, no, I came to Bilbao because somebody recommended the local variety of blood sausage, or because I'm interested in Basque separatism.
Seventy-five years ago, the subject of this article might have been the opening of a shipyard, but it is the late 90's, so I was there for the opening of a museum. Bilbao was once a shipbuilding town, but that industry has dried up locally, leaving the city high and dry. The solution has been to fill the void with culture: a museum, a concert hall, a sports arena and, of course, the architecture in which these enterprises are housed.
This pattern has been repeated in Paris, Barcelona, Helsinki, San Francisco, Cleveland and countless smaller cities, like North Adams, Mass., where the sprawling Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art will open next month in the one-time factory buildings of the Sprague Electrical Company. These cities have ceased to be centers for industry and have become domains of culture. Along with financial management and tourism, culture is now a leading urban industry.
No longer merely the ornament of power, culture is a power in its own right. Of course, museums are not the only engines of this transformation -- theaters, commercial galleries, jazz clubs and other varieties of night life, book fairs, music festivals, loft conversions, architectural walking tours and, not least, computer software firms are also driving the industrialization of culture. But the museum occupies a privileged place in the hierarchical scheme of things. It symbolizes the civilized idea that cultural and material values are not the same.
Frank Gehry led me over to a street a block or two away that runs perpendicular to the Nervion River and leads straight to the museum's entrance. Photographs of the building framed by the view down this street have been widely published, but are misleading, for they emphasize the difference between Mr. Gehry's titanium-clad structure and the masonry vernacular of Bilbao's streets. But when seeing the museum firsthand, you are struck by how uncommonly sympathetic it is to the tough riverside surroundings of this decayed town.
"I see all the mistakes," Mr. Gehry said, and he pointed out what he considered to be one of them, a skylight that pokes through the metal skin of the roof. It didn't look like a mistake to me, but then I wondered, should I be looking for mistakes? Later on, as we rounded the side of the museum, I thought, well, maybe I don't like the convex curves that frame the window of that big rectilinear piece that shoots up in the air. They're so refined.
But who cares? This was magic time, an adventure in goosebumps. My hair would have been standing on end if it hadn't been plastered down with so much mousse. Architecture will never be the same. Cities will never be the same. And it all came out of the brains of two people, Frank Gehry and his patron, Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim's director. People will like the building, or they won't, they'll come to see it, or they won't. The point is that an idea has been expressed here about the function of the museum in the contemporary city, and the idea, to give it a name, is Subjective Truth.
No one can prove that something is or is not good architecture. There are no scientific tests to determine the quality of art, no rules for declaring such-and-such work to be a masterpiece. These are matters of judgment. But that does not mean that the concept of truth has no relevance to these questions; it is possible to discriminate in a relativistic universe -- that is what museums are about, and cities, and critics, too. The lack of objective standards is what makes culture so dynamic.
Museums, industrial cities and newspapers are fundamentally 19th-century institutions. The present century has been largely one of transition, a bridge that extends from the great industrial cities of the past to the global information network to which the older urban centers must now adjust.
The announcement, earlier this year, that Levi Strauss was shutting down 11 factories in the United States is a good illustration of this transition. It was unsettling to learn that Levi's jeans, a venerable American icon, would henceforth be produced on foreign soil. But the news was not surprising. In the last three decades, manufacturing has been overwhelmingly exported to countries that offer cheap labor.
Still, if the United States would no longer produce Levi's, it would nonetheless continue to produce images of Levi's. In advertising campaigns, movies, television programs, music videos and fashion magazines, Levi's would figure as signs of youthfulness, sexuality, informality, the great American style. The archetypal American uniform had shifted categories, in other words. It had left the field of industrial manufacturing and entered the sphere of culture.
This development has changed more than the physical landscape of the city, or its social demographics. The proliferation of museums partly reflects the uncertainty many people feel about the future of the city. And a museum is, among other things, a school that trains us to live with uncertainty in creative ways.
In the subatomic realm, the distinction between objectivity and subjectivity begins to break down. Depending on the method used to perceive it, light will register as either particles or waves. Some argue that since such phenomena are not experienced outside sophisticated laboratory settings, they have no bearing on ordinary life, that the laws of classical (Newtonian) physics remain valid. The point is, however, that since Heisenberg formulated the Uncertainty Principle, it has no longer been possible to equate science exclusively with objectivity. Science itself has placed limits on that equation.
I think that the modern museum, and the contemporary city as a whole, extend a similar message throughout everyday life: Truth cannot be equated exclusively with objectivity. Museums stand for the idea that some things are culturally more valuable than others; hierarchies do exist.
This idea cannot be proved, nor can esthetic judgments be verified by time or popular referendum. Tastes change, and intelligent people disagree. This complexity is a truth of the urban condition.
FURTHER adventures in the goosebumps trade, three shows whose intelligence still inspires me:
1. "Willem de Kooning in East Hampton," Guggenheim Museum, New York City, 1977. Few people will come out and say that Frank Lloyd Wright's rotunda is the ideal place to display paintings. Also, this period of de Kooning's work -- semi-abstractions suggesting summer days at the beach, with sea, sky, sunlight, gulls, women, waves -- is not considered the artist's best. (One critic said the canvases looked painted in mayonnaise.) But there can be a chemistry between building and painting that makes the entire experience soar.
Wright compared the ramp to an unbroken ocean wave; and sometimes the sound of murmuring visitors, percolating upward through the tall space, creates an aquatic or marine effect, like bubbles effervescing through surf. The show was like a collaboration between two old men splashing around together in the fountain of youth.
2. "Wonderblock," Museum of Contemporary Art, Vienna, 1989. In honor of some anniversary or other having to do with Freud, Vienna staged several shows on psychological themes. Wonderblock, the German term for those self-erasing sketch pads children use, featured 18th- and 19th-century mechanical contraptions designed to diagnose and treat mental disorders. These were exhibited with paintings that plumbed dream states, by artists like Fuseli and Goya.
The labels were in German, and there was no English catalogue, but not knowing precisely what I was looking at made these medical machines seem all the more hilarious: chairs equipped with gears, pullies and elaborate gauges of copper and brass; padded booths with helmets and arm clamps; pneumatic couches. These Rube Goldberg devices were stunningly handsome, and each reverberated with the authority of science. But they looked far more psychotic than any of the maladies they were intended to cure -- vapors, hysterias, unbalanced humors, moral degenerations.
3. "La Ville," the Georges Pompidou Center, Paris, 1992. A blockbuster show of 20th-century urban visions, half of them by painters, the others by architects: paintings, renderings, photographs and, in the final segment, a battery of video monitors showing architects and artists commenting on the city's future.
This epic display, mounted on the museum's top floor, was accompanied by three smaller shows that explored different facets of urban culture. A ground-floor gallery draped in black velvet presented a heartbreaking array of black-and-white photographs of libraries, mosques, office towers and other buildings in Sarajevo that had been reduced to ruins in the outbreak of Balkan hostilities in the early 90's.
In the basement galleries, a retrospective of the work of Ettore Sottsass clearly demonstrated this designer's cosmopolitan esthetic, with objects that synthesized a broad range of Mediterranean, Indian, Japanese, American and other global influences. A fourth gallery honored the work of Walter Benjamin, the German philosopher, literary critic and student of city life. Street signs, stereopticons, photographs of shopping arcades and amusement parks, and other visual artifacts helped to evoke the mind of one of this century's most gifted urban thinkers.
There was a fifth exhibition: the city of Paris, laid out like a panorama as visitors went up or down the Pompidou's glass-enclosed escalator, a city that, after viewing these shows, could never look the same.
LIKE Frank Gehry's design for Bilbao, exhibitions like these collapse the psychological wall between subjective perception and objective reality, allowing the two to momentarily fuse. The effect can be powerfully visceral.
In his book "Understanding the Present: Science and the Soul of Modern Man" (Doubleday), the British science writer Bryan Appleyard attacks the cultural impact of scientific rationalism. "Science works, but is it the truth?" Mr. Appleyard rhetorically asks. Though not explicitly written as such, his book can be read as a manifesto for the 21st-century urban project. With its functionalist architecture, rational planning, synchronized work force and sociological models, the industrial city was governed by scientifically ordered measurements, quantities, statistics. The challenge of the post-industrial city is to realize that subjectivity and objectivity are not opposites, but two sides of one coin in the inherently unstable currency of culture. One looks to the museum for leadership in that direction.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk
