HEADLINE: Preservation Chic: Tables With a View of the Past

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
GRAY KUNZ, the four-star chef without portfolio, has generated nearly as much talk about his search for a space for his own restaurant as he did while cooking at Lespinasse. Finally, he is hoping to open in Lever House, the landmark office building on Park Avenue.
Many obstacles remain between him and a sure deal on the former employee cafeteria and terrace of Lever House, a 1952 edifice with a glass-curtain facade that changed office building design forever. Will there be enough room for the kitchen he needs, after the million-dollar extravaganza he was accustomed to at Lespinasse? Will the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission allow him to cut a door into the side of the building to allow direct access to the dining room? 
 Mr. Kunz said he knows there is "added-on difficulty with a landmarked building, but there's a lot of character and cachet."
"In a landmark space, the rewards are so much better," he said. "You have a facade, an exterior so wonderful it attracts a certain clientele that has an eye for that."
If the negotiations succeed, Mr. Kunz will join a growing contingent of New York restaurateurs who have discovered the advantages of recyling grand old spaces into culinary pleasure palaces. David Rockwell, the architect who designed Michael Jordan's: The Steak House in the landmark Grand Central Terminal, summed up the allure: "There is something about a space revealing its layers that is a richer, more exciting experience" than working in a raw space, he said. "You are trading off being able to throw up Sheetrock wherever you want for an incredible sense of quality of what was there before. There is a shortage of spaces where the space itself is the draw."
The recycling trend began two years ago when Le Cirque 2000 opened in the landmark rooms of the Henry Villard Houses, built in 1887 and now part of the New York Palace Hotel. Adam Tihany's ultramodern design was controversial. But Jennifer J. Raab, the landmarks commission's chairwoman, said: "Le Cirque did one of the best preservation jobs in the city. The new things they brought in are all temporary, and when Adam Tihany's designs are no longer the rage, a new set of designs will come."
In the last eight months, more and more owners have realized that one way to stand out in the blizzard of new restaurants with similar menus is to be in a landmark building. Tabla and Eleven Madison Park, for instance, made news in the Art Deco Metropolitan Life Building, at Madison Avenue and 24th Street; Bayard's opened in India House, the former home to the New York Cotton Exchange, built in 1851.
And more are on the way. After years of delay, construction has finally begun under the Queensboro Bridge on a project that will include two restaurants. Pier A, the Victorian building near Battery Park City whose reclamation has been in the works for 10 years, is to open in the fall as a restaurant with incomparable views of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. A private apartment in Grand Central is becoming a lounge.
Buildings like these, at "the monumental end of the spectrum," are particularly suited to restaurants, said Dr. James Marston Fitch, the founder of the Columbia University graduate program in historic preservation and a partner in Beyer Blinder Belle, the architectural firm that oversaw the restoration of Grand Central and Ellis Island. "It is new wine for old bottles," he said.
At the same time, developers have had a change of heart and finally understand that there are substantial tax credits for restoring landmarks. For landlords, a retail establishment can help pay for a restoration. "You can breathe new life into old buildings by creating a new economic engine," Mr. Rockwell said.
And the landmarks commission looks with particular favor on restaurants. "One of the great things about restaurants is that they don't call for a lot of division of space, so they keep the open feeling," Ms. Raab said. "Restaurants often prize the same features preservationists appreciate, like the ceiling."
As Mr. Kunz has discovered, even a relatively new landmark has irresistible allure. For 50 years, Dr. Fitch said, "the policy was all old buildings are bad buildings, all new buildings are good. But in the last 10 years the public hostility to old buildings has turned to enthusiastic support."
At the same time, the preservation movement has grown beyond a fringe element. New York City's 33-year-old landmark law, passed after the razing of the old Pennsylvania Station, is one of the strongest in the country, said Peg Breen, the president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy, a nonprofit group that gives financial and technical help to owners of landmark properties. "Now there is more emphasis on buildings that are 30, 40 and 50 years old," like Lever House and the Four Seasons Restaurant, she said. "In many instances there is a sense of prestige to own a landmark or to live in a historic district, and people have seen their property values maintained."
The commission has designated 1,400 exteriors and 102 interiors as landmarks.
AS businesses consolidate, particularly banks, more and more grand spaces have become available. "The large turn-of-the-century buildings are perfect for restaurants because volume is a luxury" in Manhattan, said Tony Goldman, whose company, Goldman Properties, specializes in restoration. He has opened Wall Street Kitchen and Bar in the 1907 neo-classical American Bank Note Company building at 70 Broad Street in the financial district. "When you have space that is 20 or 25 feet high, there's an aura. There's value in the artistic quality -- the fabulously carved and elaborate ceilings, grand columns and craftsmanship that is not available today."
Two of the most notable new-old restaurants are in one landmark, the Metropolitan Life Building. While Tabla has Indian accents, Eleven Madison Park has retained Art Deco characteristics. The latter project "took six months extra and cost 30 percent more than had been budgeted," said Richard Coraine, the director of operations for Danny Meyer's restaurants, including these. "The whole rich history of landmarked buildings is another story to tell, and there is a certain amount of pride that the building is important for other reasons."
Bayard's, in India House at One Hanover Square, is an even more sensitive re-creation of an original space. The building, in the Italianate palazzo design, has been a private club since 1914. The club continues to operate at lunchtime, but Harry Poulakakos, who owns Harry's at Hanover Square downstairs, and his son, Peter, have restored the interior, peeling back layers of paint to reveal the magnificent architecture and mahogany double staircase, and removing the acoustical tile from the ceilings and linoleum from the floors.
Dining there is transporting, out of turn-of-the-millennium Manhattan: you almost hear the rustle of silk damask gowns and feel the warm glow from the candelabra.
Farther uptown, in TriBeCa, Henry Meer has opened City Hall in a landmark 1861 Italianate building on Duane Street that used to house a dry-goods wholesaler and was once Public School 10. The creamy yellow exterior sparkles in sunlight; inside, the dining room, with its two-story ceilings, has the original cast-iron columns and support beams, enhanced by historic photographs of New York lining the walls.
"I wasn't really looking for another restaurant," said Mr. Meer, who also owns the Cub Room in SoHo. "But being a passionate New Yorker, I always wanted a restaurant to be reflective of New York and have a New York experience."
On New York Harbor, Pier A is expected to be open by year's end with a restaurant and banquet rooms; Levy Restaurants of Chicago, which operates the highly rated Spiaggia there, is negotiating to operate them. Pier A began life in 1886 as the headquarters of the docks and ferries department and was a fireboat station before it was set for demolition to make way for Battery Park City. The metal and glass structure became a landmark in 1977, saving it, but the project, which was to take six years, is now in its 10th year. The budget has ballooned from $18 million to $26 million.
At Grand Central, the Campbell Apartment, a hidden jewel of a Florentine palazzo, is being renovated as a cocktail lounge by Mark Grossich, who calls it "a one-of-a-kind space in a one-of-a-kind space." From the 1920's to the 40's, it was the office of a wealthy businessman, John W. Campbell. The apartment, where he and his wife entertained guests, had a pipe organ and grand piano. "It gives you a sense of how large a swashbuckling tycoon lived at the time," said Mr. Grossich, who also owns Bar and Books.
The organ and piano are gone, but the rest of the apartment is being restored to its former grandeur, with painted beamed ceilings, a huge stone fireplace, an enormous leaded-glass window, even gargoyles. Mr. Grossich hopes to open by the end of spring.
The landmark revival is also renewing activity at the long-stalled Bridgemarket, the vaulted space beneath the Queensboro Bridge, leased by the London-based Conran Holdings and Joel Kissin, the owner of Guastavino's Inc., which will run two glass-front restaurants and two Conran stores. After 22 years of delays, workmen are finally cleaning the tiled ceiling, which soars 37 feet.
The restaurants are scheduled to open by year's end. One of them, Guastavino, at ground level, will be like Conran's Quaglino restaurant in London, a grill with rotisserie food. The other, Club Guastavino, a more luxurious French-accented version of Bibendum, also in London, will be on a mezzanine, where a party of two could easily leave behind $200. The names honor the architect Rafael Guastavino, a 19th-century Spanish immigrant who invented vaulted tiled ceilings, one of which can be seen in the Oyster Bar at Grand Central.
"When you go into these landmarked spaces, you get a definite sense of place, of continuity with the past," said Ms. Breen, of the Landmarks Conservancy. "Places that give you a sense of the past, and an understanding that there have been generations before you help to ground you and help to make you feel a part of New York."
 
Imbibing History, Modest and Grand
 NEW YORKERS never seem to look up. (Maybe they're afraid to appear like tourists.) But if they did, they would notice the wonderful landmarks they are often dining in.
Probably the most celebrated is Gage & Tollner, a landmark inside and out, in an Italianate 1875 building on Fulton Mall in downtown Brooklyn. A restaurant since 1892, the original goldish-bronze walls of lincrusta (the poor man's stamped leather) were restored along with the gaslights when Joe Chirico bought it in 1995.
Capsouto Freres, on Washington and Watts Streets in TriBeCa, opened in 1978 in an 1891 Flemish-style building, a former shoe factory.
Indochine, on Lafayette Place, is in a row of 1832 Greek Revival buildings, but its French planter-style interior bears no relation to the exterior, with its columns and laurel wreaths. "This was once the grandest address in all New York," said Peg Breen, the president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy.
Landmarks aren't always grand. Bridge Cafe, in a small 1801 wooden building on Water and Dover Streets, on the Manhattan side of the Brooklyn Bridge, has been a restaurant since 1826, but the interior looks Victorian, with tin ceilings and a mahogany bar.
The Ear Inn, at 326 Spring Street near Washington Street, is in a wooden building with a brick front that was built in 1817 by James Brown, an African-American aide to George Washington. And Tennessee Mountain, on Spring and Wooster Streets in SoHo, and Paolucci's, on Mulberry Street in Little Italy, are also wooden reminders of New York's past. MARIAN BURROS

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
True North takes the lead in aiding agencies and media owned by members of minorities.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
EFFORTS to increase the consideration given to multicultural consumers are gaining momentum as one of the 10 largest agency companies, True North Communications in Chicago, takes two big steps to embrace media outlets and agencies specializing in advertising aimed at members of minorities.
True North, the world's No. 7 agency company, with billings estimated at $11.6 billion, is scheduled to announce the steps at a news conference this morning in Washington under the aegis of the American Advertising Federation. Officials of the federation are among the industry figures accelerating the search for ways to increase diversity in response to intensifying pressure from activist organizations and the Clinton Administration. 
 "The leadership of True North shows us that the greatest music is made with many voices," Vice President Al Gore said in a statement released before the news conference. "I encourage other companies to follow suit and sign on."
Executives of True North are to announce their endorsement of a voluntary code of conduct to insure that agencies and media owned by minorities get what is deemed their fair share of attention when ad dollars are spent. True North, which owns agencies like Foote, Cone & Belding and Bozell Worldwide, would become the first large agency company to endorse the equal opportunities code, known as the Kennard Principles for Fairness in Communications after William E. Kennard, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.
Mr. Kennard has taken an active role in this issue since the commission released a study in January concluding that radio stations with black and Spanish-speaking audiences drew less ad revenue per listener than mainstream stations -- even in markets where they enjoyed higher ratings.
"I'm delighted to see the advertising industry moving to address these issues," Mr. Kennard said in an interview last week. "It's a great first step."
The commission has called for additional research on advertiser spending patterns in radio because the study did not specify the origin of the revenue discrepancies between stations. But owners of stations with programming aimed at members of minorities complained about what they termed "dictates" to agencies from clients calling for "minority discounts" -- paying lower rates for commercials on their stations -- and the avoidance of stations with Spanish-language or "urban" -- black -- formats.
"Those practices are pernicious," Mr. Kennard said, "based on misinformation and stereotypes. The way to solve such problems is to shine a light on them."
True North's endorsement of the code is important, Mr. Kennard said, because it represents self-regulation rather than Government intervention.
"We want to work with them," he said, referring to agencies and advertisers, "as opposed to dictating to them."
Wally Snyder, president and chief executive of the federation in Washington, agreed with Mr. Kennard.
"This is a marketplace solution," Mr. Snyder said in an interview last week, "not a Government solution. Clients are going to act on their own best financial interests, not on a political agenda."
Mr. Snyder also praised True North, whose agencies create campaigns for advertisers like the BankAmerica Corporation, the DaimlerChrysler Corporation, Levi Strauss & Company and S. C. Johnson & Son.
"This is the turning point we've been waiting for," Mr. Snyder said, adding: "We've been encouraging agencies and clients to really go after this multicultural audience because it is one with a great deal of economic clout. Now I think other agencies will follow True North."
The True North executives also plan to announce the formation of a media services agency dedicated to helping mainstream advertisers with planning and buying ad space in ethnic publications and commercial time on ethnic television and radio networks and stations.
"It's right for the times," said David Bell, who was recently named chairman and chief executive at True North. "We have a tapestry in America, and marketing needs to address that."
The media services initiative, to be called New America Media Group, will represent a partnership between two units of True North based in New York: TN Media, which handles media planning and buying for accounts with billings estimated at more than $2.6 billion, and New America Strategies Group, which offers multicultural marketing consulting services.
"This market has reached critical mass, with buying power greater than ever," said Mike Drexler, chairman at TN Media. "It can no longer be ignored or given short shrift."
"We believe we can make a big contribution to helping advertisers analyze multicultural markets for their products and services," he added, "and then to place their ads to reach those markets in the most effective way."
The new media group will be led by three media directors from agencies under the New America Strategies umbrella: LaTanya Junior, 35, at Stedman Graham & Partners, specializing in campaigns aimed at black consumers; Caleb Windover, 34, at Siboney USA, for Hispanic consumers, and Khanh Kach, 28, at a True North affiliate, Imada Wong Communications, for Asian-American consumers.
"Ethnic media have always been the extra guest at the party," said Al Schreiber, managing partner at New America Strategies. "Now they'll be the guest of honor as advertisers move from token budgets to budgets that reflect the reality of today's marketplace, where multicultural consumers are the growth market."

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Resuming Sale of Land

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 20

 BODY:
The Hong Kong government held its first land auction in almost a year today and raised about 20 percent more money than analysts expected.
The government, which had suspended land sales last June in an effort to stem a sharp decline in property prices, sold three sites for a total of $1.49 billion (Hong Kong), or $192 million (United States). 
 By resuming land sales, the government has revived one of its main sources of revenue. In a city where seven of 10 companies invest in real estate, an increase in property prices may lift the stock market, too.
"It was like the first day at the races," Nicholas Brooke, chairman of Brooke International Ltd., a real estate consulting firm, said of today's bidding. "Property prices are going to rise 15 to 20 percent in the short term."
Stocks, though, fell today, hurt by speculation that companies would take advantage of the market's recent surge to issue more shares, diluting the value of investors' current holdings. The benchmark Hang Seng index, which had risen nearly 17 percent this month until today, fell 2.8 percent, or 356.66 points, to 12,409.78.
Hong Kong's three biggest developers, Cheung Kong Holdings Ltd., Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd. and the Henderson Land Development Company, did not bid at today's auction. "It's much cheaper for the big developers to pay to convert agricultural land to residential use than to buy at auction," said Robert Hart, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Asia.
Still, one of the three, Henderson Land, said it planned to start raising property prices gradually, based on the results of the auction.
Mr. Brooke, the consultant, warned that a quick rebound in prices might hurt Hong Kong's competitiveness by detracting from efforts to diversify the economy away from real estate development toward high technology. "The increase isn't supported by economic fundamentals," he said. "Unemployment is still high and people are still worried about their jobs."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
2 U.S. Auto Makers Delay New Factories in Brazil

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 20

 BODY:
Citing the pressure from other priorities on his state's finances, an opposition Governor in southern Brazil has disrupted plans by General Motors and the Ford Motor Company to build two car factories regarded as prototypes for automobile manufacturing of the future.
G.M. has delayed by at least six months its plans to produce compact cars at a plant code-named the "Blue Macaw" project in Rio Grande do Sul, the southernmost state. The delay could affect the auto maker's plans for similar plants in the United States and elsewhere. Ford has put on hold plans to build a plant for its "Project Amazon," also intended to produce inexpensive small cars. 
 Roughly 10,000 jobs related to the factories and more than $1 billion in investment are at stake as the two leading auto makers, already frustrated by a plunge in car sales as Brazil struggles with recession, seek an agreement with Olivio Dutra, the outspoken Workers Party governor of Rio Grande do Sul, an industrial state of 10 million.
Mr. Dutra, who took office in January, suspended an accord that his predecessor had made with G.M. and Ford to provide the two companies with about $280 million of financing and infrastructure in exchange for their decision to build the factories near Porto Alegre, the state capital.
One of the rising stars of the Workers Party, the main organized opposition to President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's Government, Mr. Dutra contends that his state needs the money previously designated for the factories to finance programs in education, health care and housing.
The president of G.M.'s Brazilian subsidiary, Frederick Henderson, said in an interview that "there are certain things we need like gas, waste-water treatment, roads and electricity, to proceed." Without the Government's help in finishing these projects, the G.M. factory will not be ready to produce cars until mid-2000 -- about six months later than expected, Mr. Henderson said.
The conflict between the car producers and Mr. Dutra is part of a wider argument, in which several Brazilian states have resorted to unorthodox measures to shore up their finances. Another Governor, Itamar Franco of Minas Gerais in central Brazil, declared a moratorium on his state's debt payments to the federal Government at the beginning of the year, a decision that contributed to a market panic and a currency crisis.
Mr. Dutra also threatened default, but backed off after pressure from President Cardoso, and has since refocused his energy on G.M. and Ford.
The Governor's conflict with the auto makers is complicating what until recently were plans for the two advanced factories, which have been closely followed by world car makers. G.M.'s Blue Macaw plant is designed to function as a "factory condominium," as described by Mr. Henderson, in which 16 suppliers operate on the same site. G.M. has hoped to produce as many as 150,000 compact cars annually at the plant.
At the nearby site for the Ford factory, where only the ground has been prepared for construction, suppliers are also expected to be more involved in production. The plant was scheduled to start production in 2001, with annual output of 150,000 cars. Since the factory is in such an early stage, representatives from the state government have said there is a possibility that Ford may switch the location to another state. Officials from Ford's Brazilian subsidiary declined to comment.
Mr. Dutra has explained his actions by saying that the incentives granted by the previous Governor, Antonio Britto, were unrealistic, given Rio Grande do Sul's need to improve basic services. In addition, the state government faces a budget deficit of roughly $60 million a month.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Scandal Inquiry Hurts Brazilian Markets

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 20

 BODY:
Nervousness over a legislative inquiry into reported irregularities during a Government bailout of two banks earlier this year unsettled Brazilian financial markets today, cutting some recent gains.
The currency, the real, fell in New York to a rate of 1.7125 to the dollar, from 1.6775 on Monday, while the benchmark Bovespa stock index gave up 4 percent before recuperating to close at 10,989.42, down 207.18 points, or 1.85 percent. 
 The declines were spurred by concern that an investigation into accusations of a central bank-orchestrated bailout in January of two investment banks might damage the credibility of some high-ranking Government officials.
The bailout was organized by Francisco Lopes, who has since been replaced as head of the central bank by Arminio Fraga. Mr. Lopes, now a consultant in Rio de Janeiro, cited emotional pressure in a request to delay testimony before a congressional panel investigating the allegations, which include bribery and trading on inside information.
There has been some speculation that Mr. Lopes might disclose incriminating details of the bank rescue. But some financial analysts said that concern about the scandal was overdone. "This happened under previous bank management, lessening the fallout," said Tulio Vera, a Latin American sovereign debt analyst at ABN Amro Bank.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Continues to Balloon, Hitting $19.4 Billion

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit jumped unexpectedly to previously unheard of levels in February as consumers bought growing quantities of imports and declining demand from abroad hurt exporters, the Government reported today.
The deficit in goods and services in February surged to a new monthly high of $19.4 billion, the Commerce Department said, $2.6 billion more than January's deficit of $16.8 billion, which itself had been a record. Economists had expected February's deficit to be around $16.7 billion. The figures are adjusted to smooth out seasonal variations in trade patterns. 
 Imports in February rose by $2.1 billion, to $96 billion. Exports declined by $500 million, to $76.6 billion.
The figures reflected the persistent and in some ways increasing gap between the economic strength of the United States and the downturns plaguing nearly all of its trading partners, from Asia to Europe to Latin America.
Alone among the world's major countries, the United States is a magnet for imports of goods and services, helping to avert even deeper global economic problems. With unemployment low and stock prices up sharply since the beginning of the year, American consumers have been spending freely, and they are finding bargains in imports.
But because demand for American-made goods has been diminished by weakness in other countries, the growing trade deficit is hurting many manufacturers and farmers in the United States and slowing growth. Economists said declining exports appear to have slowed the economy's expansion to about a 3 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year from twice that in last year's fourth quarter.
The growth in the deficit after a year and a half of economic upheaval around the world added to an escalating debate over how willing the United States should be to leave its markets open to other countries that do not fully reciprocate.
Groups like farmers, steelworkers and textile makers are already howling about unfair competition from abroad, and making their influence felt in Washington. The next major flash point is likely to come in a few months, when the Clinton Administration is expected to complete a deal to bring China into the World Trade Organization and seek approval from a deeply divided Congress.
President Clinton used the figures today to bolster his call for an overhaul of the world's financial system in the wake of the turmoil that sped from Asia to Russia and Latin America in the last year.
"Though our economy has continued to grow, we have been affected by the Asian financial crisis as you can see by our trade figures, by what has happened in steel and by the loss of markets by our farmers," Mr. Clinton said in a speech at the White House.
Saying that this was "not a moment for complacency," Mr. Clinton outlined a series of principles he said the United States would advance in coming months as the major industrial nations consider how to overhaul the financial system and avert future international economic upheaval. They include tighter bank lending rules and encouraging developing nations to rely less on short-term loans.
Advocates of free trade have become increasingly worried about what they see as growing protectionist pressures. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, denounced protectionism in a speech on Friday and made a case that while dropping trade barriers can be painful it ultimately adds to the nation's prosperity.
But organized labor and companies in the industries being hit hardest continue to argue that fair trade rather than free trade should be the nation's goal. John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., called today's trade figures "cause for real alarm," and said the worst may not yet be past for American workers.
"In the last year we lost over 350,000 manufacturing jobs," Mr. Sweeney said in a speech in Chicago. "And no one knows how long we can survive as an island of prosperity in a sea of trouble."
With Japan still mired in recession, growth in Western Europe slowing and Latin America struggling, some economists and business groups said they expected demand for exports to be tepid for the rest of the year. Rising oil prices could also make the deficit look bigger in coming months.
The trade deficit, said Gordon Richards, an economist at the National Association of Manufacturers, "won't improve substantially until the world economy recovers, and that is still some time away."
Other economists, however, said there were signs that the decline in export demand had bottomed out and that manufacturing was ready to rebound. Among the signs they cited was a rise in export orders tallied by the National Association of Purchasing Management in February and March, suggesting that shipments to foreign customers could pick up in coming months.
February marked the fourth consecutive month of declining exports, and the figures showed weakening demand in February from most of the country's major trading partners. The deficit of trade in goods with Mexico increased to $1.8 billion from $1.4 billion, using figures that are not seasonally adjusted. The goods deficit with Japan increased to $5.3 billion for the month from $4.7 billion in January. Demand from Western Europe dropped sharply, sending the monthly deficit in trade of goods to $2.2 billion from $1.4 billion.
Much of the decline in exports was in agricultural products, including soybeans, and in commercial aircraft, a notoriously volatile component of the figures that is almost totally dependent on the Boeing Company's delivery schedule for sales to foreign airlines.
The rise in imports was concentrated in consumer goods, including clothing, toys and sporting goods, with a surge as well in the number of imported cars.
One of the few relative bright spots was a slight decline in the deficit with China. The goods deficit with China declined to $4.6 billion in February from $4.9 billion in January. But over the last few years, the deficit with China has grown to the point that it rivals the deficit with Japan as the biggest two-way trade gap.
But with the Administration about to make a push to seal a trade deal with China, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said Beijing still had to prove that it was willing to play by international rules and drop the barriers that have kept companies from the United States and other countries out of its markets.
"If China wants to be a true global trading partner and a member of the World Trade Organization," Mr. Daley told reporters today, "the Chinese Government must promptly agree to open her markets to foreign goods and services."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
The inflation rate is likely to rise this year. But why worry.

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
THE rate of inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, is likely to jump this year, from the exceedingly comfortable 1.6 percent of last year to more than 2 percent.
That would not constitute a surge. But the rate of increase has shrunk for three straight years. And in annual terms, the inflation rate has risen only twice in the last eight years. 
 If oil prices continue to gather steam, though, the monthly data could even prompt headlines about inflation rising at an annual rate approaching 3 percent.
The possibility that such numbers might upset the stock and bond markets on the days they are reported led Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, to warn her clients recently that investors in the coming months should be wary of the "noise" in the C.P.I. and the related Producer Price Index.
Still, there is no reason to worry too much about these numbers. The main culprit is higher oil prices, and the inflation projections are based on the assumption that these prices will stick, not a sure thing. Even if they do, neither the Federal Reserve nor the bond market will get too upset if that's the only problem, as it is not considered big enough to alter the long-term outlook for inflation.
In fact, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned Congress in February that several one-time factors that depressed inflation in 1998 -- including low oil prices -- would not be present this year.
But he added that "recent experience does seem to suggest that the economy has become less inflation-prone than in the past, so that the chances of an inflationary breakout arguably are, at least for now, less than they would have been under similar conditions in earlier cycles."
The March consumer price data seemed to prove him right. Although the energy index jumped 1.6 percent -- its first increase since October -- the overall index rose just two-tenths of 1 percent, resulting in a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.5 percent for the first three months of the year.
Another positive sign: other commodity prices remain generally low. Though the Bridge/Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities has jumped 4 percent from the 24-year low it set at the end of February, the index is virtually unchanged for the year -- even with oil included.
Oil prices, which have added to their gains in the last week, are up 48 percent this year, and scrap metal prices have risen 3 percent. But the prices of raw industrial materials are down 2.6 percent and food prices are off 4.7 percent.
Prices paid for imports have also slid, in part because of the dollar's growing strength this year, a rally many forecasters did not expect. In March, prices of imports other than fuel fell four-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest drop in seven months.
Surprising gains in worker productivity, especially this late in an economic cycle, are also restraining inflation by partly offsetting the increase in wages. And the pace of wage increases themselves, despite the lowest unemployment rate in 29 years, is slowing.
All these positive forces have led many forecasters to dismiss concerns about a change in the inflationary climate, even if rising oil prices push the overall C.P.I. number higher. In fact, a move toward 2 percent would only bring the index in line with the "core C.P.I.," the index without the volatile food and energy components. Last year, this core index rose 2.3 percent from 1997. So the only element being lost is the extra bit of help that the C.P.I. got last year from plunging oil prices.
The bond market seems to share that view. Investors did push interest rates sharply higher in January when it became clear that 1999 economic growth would be much stronger than had been expected. But by the time oil prices began to take off in late February, the yield on the 30-year bond had already risen to 5.70 percent. And now with the price of a barrel of oil just shy of $18, the yield on the 30-year bond has retreated to 5.50 percent.
In their February meeting, Fed policy makers said that "a somewhat less favorable inflation performance was viewed as likely over the year ahead," according to minutes of the meeting. But they concluded that this would not result in "any substantial deterioration in the inflation climate."
What could alter the climate? Oil prices could keep rising. But more threatening would be a revival in other commodity prices. That would signal a significant rebound in world economic growth, which in turn would increase wage and inflationary pressures here.
But with no new inflationary pressures now -- outside of oil -- it's too early to worry.

HEADLINE: Chase Posts 61% Rise in Net Earnings

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Several of the nation's big banks reported sharply higher earnings yesterday, with one of the biggest, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, posting robust trading gains comparable to the outsized results already turned in by most of the country's big trading houses.
Benefiting from an unusually strong trading season spurred by a rebound from the global financial crisis of last fall, Chase said first-quarter net earnings leaped 61 percent, to $1.17 billion, or $1.32 a share, from $725 million, or 80 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1998. 
 Chase's operating income, a more accurate reflection of the company's core earnings strength than net income, rose a more modest 11 percent, to $1.17 billion from $1.05 billion. Net income in the comparable quarter a year earlier included a reorganization charge of $521 million.
Although Chase, the country's third-largest bank by assets, beat analysts' expectations of $1.25 a share, the stock was sharply lower yesterday as investors appeared to be concerned about the unpredictability of such big trading returns and Chase's ability to maintain its earnings momentum. The shares, which have more than doubled in the last year, fell $2, to $83.
"Given how everyone has been blowing through their numbers, I think there were higher expectations for Chase," said Sally Pope Davis, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But nobody should complain about these numbers, because they're very strong."
Chase's revenue in the quarter rose 11 percent, to $5.14 billion, from $4.62 billion in last year's first quarter. Revenue from the New York bank's global corporate business, Chase's most important segment and the one that includes trading, rose 8 percent, to $2.6 billion, while profits in the unit rose 11 percent, to $882 million. Trading revenue rose 21 percent, to a record $837 million. But investment banking fees fell 12 percent, to $317 million, on weakness in the leveraged-finance business.
The consumer unit, Chase's other main business, saw sales climb 12 percent, to $2.16 billion. But that business is much less profitable than Chase's corporate business, generating earnings of $350 million.
The Bank One Corporation, the fourth-largest bank in the country and the product of last year's merger of Bank One and the First Chicago NBD Corporation, also reported strong earnings yesterday. It said profits jumped 23 percent, to $1.15 billion, or 96 cents a share, from $933 million, or 78 cents a share, in the first quarter last year. The Chicago-based bank said that on an operating basis, earnings rose nearly 16 percent, to $1.05 billion, or 88 cents a share, from $909 million, or 76 cents, meeting analysts' expectations.
But the shares slipped 25 cents, to $59, yesterday as investors' confidence in the bank weakened.
Bank One's stock was severly battered in the wake of last year's merger as questions arose about the company's ability to rein in expenses and still increase revenue, although it has recovered smartly in recent months. But while yesterday's results showed renewed expense discipline, Bank One still reported numbers that in Wall Street parlance were "noisy." The results included $360 million of one-time gains offset by merger and restructuring charges of $204 million.
The bank also posted a big increase in nonperforming assets, a harbinger of possible lending problems. It had $1.15 billion in nonperforming assets in the quarter, up from $819 million at the end of last year and far above the $670 million at the end of 1997. Bank One said the recent surge was a result of $302 million of problem loans to financial services and energy companies.
Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco, the seventh-largest bank in the country, said its first-quarter earnings rose 29 percent, to $884 million, or 53 cents a share, from $684 million, or 41 cents a share in the comparable quarter last year.
The results exceeded analysts' expectations of 50 cents a share, sending the bank's shares up $1.25 yesterday, to $42.375. Wells attributed its strong performance to solid growth in mortgage lending and returns from venture capital investments.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Warns Global Economy Could Slow This Year and Next

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund warned today that global economic growth could slow in 1999 and perhaps into 2000, hurt by weakness in Russia, Asia, Brazil and some regions of Europe, notably those ravaged by the Kosovo conflict.
The group's latest world economic outlook said that "several hurdles could prevent global growth from returning to potential within two or three years." 
 The lending agency's assessment was issued at the beginning of a weeklong meeting in Washington by officials of the I.M.F. and the World Bank. Its cautious tone followed the I.M.F.'s conspicuous failure to foresee the 1997 economic crash in Southeast Asia and its havoc on financial markets around the world, the subsequent financial crisis in Russia and parts of Eastern Europe or the more recent economic tremors in Brazil, Latin America's largest economy.
C. Fred Bergsten, who runs the Institute for International Economics here, said the I.M.F. caution also reflected its desire to fight complacency that could come in weakened economies if they show signs of improvement.
"The fund is afraid that if recovery starts, the countries of Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe will back off from the deep structural economic reforms the recent crises showed they must make," he said.
The I.M.F. predicted a 2.3 percent global economic growth rate this year, down from 2.5 percent in 1998 and 4.2 percent in 1997.
It predicted a 3.4 percent growth rate in 2000. That projection assumed a steady improvement in the emerging-market economies, a gradual slowing of the American economy to a more sustainable pace, resilience in Europe and an end to the Japanese recession. But the I.M.F. said the weakness this year in Brazil, China and Russia, as well as the possibility that Japan's recession could worsen, could lead to "a distinct possibility of a less favorable scenario developing."
It also said economic activity in the former Communist countries of southeastern Europe would be affected by the Kosovo crisis.

HEADLINE: High Seas, Higher Costs;
As Imports Swamp Exports, Shipping Lines Try to Cope

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 20

 BODY:
Come May 1, the ocean-shipping business will be largely deregulated, setting off a scramble among shipping lines to lure customers with discounts. The same day, however, virtually all ships carrying goods from Asia to the United States plan to raise their rates by the same, mutually agreed, amount.
If this sounds contradictory, it is. But the state of affairs reflects the forces buffeting the shipping business, which is now going through some of the biggest changes in its tradition-bound history. 
 Under the partial deregulation, container shipping lines for the first time will be able to sign individual, confidential contracts with importers and exporters. The competition to sign up such customers is expected to greatly loosen the grip of the cartels that have legally set rates for ocean shipping for more than a century.
But the shipping industry's unusual immunity from Federal antitrust laws -- something it has enjoyed almost ever since there were antitrust laws -- is not being eliminated. So even as they enter a less regulated era, the shipping lines, reeling from low profits and overcapacity, are collectively raising rates on imports from Asia by 30 percent or more.
The result is a clash between the old and new ways of doing business, and no one is quite sure how it will turn out.
Many analysts expect that eventually container shipping will follow the paths of airlines, trucking and railroads, which began their deregulation two decades ago. There will be lower prices and better service over all, but also a brutal period of mergers and bankruptcies among the competitors.
Others say that the continued right to set rates collectively will blunt these effects. "It isn't going to be airlines," said Ashley Craig, a consultant at Rodriguez & Associates, a Washington law firm that represents small importers and exporters. "It isn't going to be rail or trucks."
Regardless of which way shipping costs move, consumers might not notice much difference because for most goods, such as imported sneakers or videocassette recorders, shipping costs contribute only a tiny amount to the final price.
Still, with more than $400 billion in goods entering or leaving the United States each year on container ships, even little changes mount up. Moreover, shipping lines, pressed to cut costs further, might make even more demands for concessions from taxpayer-supported ports. Sea-Land Service, a unit of the CSX Corporation, and Maersk Inc. of Copenhagen, a subsidiary of the A.P. Moller Group, are now making such demands of the ports of New York and New Jersey and Baltimore, which are vying for the lines' business, with jobs and income at stake.
The last thing many shipping executives want right now is more competition. The economic downturn in Asia, which has led to record trade deficits for the United States, has also caused serious imbalances for their lines. And the situation may well continue: The Commerce Department reported today that the nation's trade deficit jumped to a new monthly high of $19.4 billion in February, largely on the strength of imports and the weakening demand for exports.
Ships bringing imports to the United States from East Asia, the largest trade route in the world, are stuffed to capacity, but the ships going back to Asia are half-empty. Shipping lines say they need revenue on both legs to make a profit. And that is why they are raising rates in the busy direction.
"I've been in the business 30 years and the imbalance has never been that bad," said Albert A. Pierce, chairman and executive director of the Transpacific Stabilization Agreement, the group of carriers that decided on the May 1 rate increase.
The bulging trade deficit can be seen in the form of empty shipping containers stacked four high on the piers at the adjacent ports of Long Beach and Los Angeles, which together handle about a third of the nation's container traffic. For many months last year, as exports to Asia dried up, more empty containers were being sent back to Asia than full ones.
"Our No. 1 export was empty containers," said Harold J. Hilliard, marketing manager for the Port of Long Beach, the nation's largest. In the last few months, amid some signs of recovery in Asia, loaded containers heading to Asia have slightly outnumbered the empties.
Meanwhile, imports have been unusually strong early this year as importers ship early to beat the May 1 increase and a possible strike by longshoremen this summer. They also fear a repeat of the delays that occurred last year, when not enough ships and containers were available to handle all the imports from Asia that had suddenly become cheaper for Americans when Asian currencies were devalued.
"Quite a few of our Christmas decorations arrived too late for the season," said John Carrier, import traffic manager of World Bazaar Inc., a housewares importer based in City of Commerce, Calif. The per-container price he paid rose from $1,400 to as much as $3,000.
Many executives expect the same thing to happen this summer. "The big issue this year is 'I don't care what it costs, just get me on a ship,' " said Tom Craig, head of the LTD Shippers Association, which represents 500 small importers and exporters.
Taking advantage of the seller's market, the shipping lines said they would raise rates by $900 for a 40-foot container coming to the West Coast from Asia, with an additional $300 surcharge from June through November, the peak season. That represents an increase of 30 percent to 100 percent over current rates, which range from $1,100 to more than $3,000, depending on the merchandise and the route.
Robert Camarena, vice president for operations and global logistics for Vans Inc., a footwear company, said that shipping contributed about 35 cents to 50 cents to the cost of a pair of shoes; the rate increase, he said, would add 15 cents to 20 cents to that. An executive at another footwear company cited even lower costs.
Still, while consumers might not notice, even pennies matter to corporate profit margins. Retailers "won't even take a 15-cent hit," Mr. Camarena said, worried that his company might have to absorb the increase on millions of pairs of shoes.
A major question, however, is whether such a coordinated rate increase will hold under the new Ocean Shipping Reform Act, enacted in October by Congress. These changes, the first in 15 years, will allow importers and exporters to sign confidential contracts with a shipping company. Big importers -- the Wal-Marts and Nikes of the world -- are expected to obtain hefty discounts.
Until now container shipping lines have been "common carriers" like the phone company, accepting all customers at published rates. Most rates have been set by cartels known as conferences. Importers and exporters could negotiate their own contracts, often with the entire conference, sometimes with an individual shipping line. The terms of such contracts were public and other importers or exporters had the right to demand the same rate.
The conference system has already started to fray in anticipation of May 1. The Asia North America Eastbound Rate Agreement, known as Anera, which sets rates for containers heading from Asia to the United States, will disband on April 30, as will its westbound counterpart. Somewhat similar changes are occurring on the Atlantic Ocean.
Still, Anera is being replaced by the Transpacific Stabilization Agreement, a "discussion group" that is housed in the same office in San Francisco. Such groups will not have legally binding rate-setting authority, as the conferences do. But that has not stopped members of the group from "voluntarily" agreeing to raise rates.
Shipping is one of the few industries -- others include Major League Baseball and farm cooperatives -- to enjoy some immunity from antitrust laws. First granted in 1916, immunity was apparently rationalized as a way to prevent price wars and bankruptcies that could lead to a shortage of shipping capacity. It applies to regularly scheduled shipping lines, not to oil tankers and bulk commodity carriers, which are not regulated and thus not affected by the new law.
The container shipping lines fought successfully to retain the antitrust exemption in October's legislation, arguing that the United States had to be in accord with other nations, which allow collective rate-setting. An argument was also made that American shipping lines, which are more easily subject to prosecution by the Justice Department than foreign companies, would be at a disadvantage if immunity ended -- even though few American lines remain.
Deregulation was pushed most strongly by big importers and exporters, which wanted not only lower rates but also the more tailored service they could get through contracts with a single shipping line. While these companies wanted to eliminate the antitrust immunity, they compromised with the shipping lines to get the bill passed. Peter Gatti, director of policy for the National Industrial Transportation League, which represents major importers and exporters, said that in an era of individual contracts, collective rate-setting would not be as important as before anyway.
Even without deregulation, the shipping conferences have been the cartels that couldn't shoot straight. Companies added so many new ships that overcapacity resulted, driving down prices. Some major shipping companies, such as Taiwan's Evergreen Line, never joined.
"We've been much less successful than even OPEC," said Torey Presti, vice president of regulatory affairs for APL Ltd., a major shipping line based in Oakland, Calif. Neptune Orient Lines of Singapore, which acquired APL in 1997, lost $263 million last year.
APL's sale left Sea-Land Service as the only American shipping line among the 10 largest global carriers serving the United States -- this despite Government subsidies of about $2 million a year to ships with American flags and crews that can be turned over to the Pentagon in times of war.
Sea-Land's operating profits, after growing for several years, dropped by half in 1998 and there are rumors that CSX might sell all or part of the shipping line.
John P. Clancey, chief executive of Sea-Land, predicted that deregulation would actually lead to higher profits for the best shipping lines, which would be able to develop closer relationships with key customers.
Companies like Sea-Land and APL hope to offer global contracts, rather than ocean by ocean, and to provide more sophisticated services, such as coordinating a customer's entire supply network. APL, for instance, is managing the shipments of parts to a General Motors factory in Thailand, even the shipments over land.
To speed cargo movements and cut costs, APL has also invested heavily in cargo terminals like the one here in Los Angeles, where 200 trucks come and go each hour, picking up or dropping off containers that are assigned spaces by a computer in a vast parking lot.
Changes to the business might be gradual, but jarring just the same.
"Maritime finds it harder to change than almost anybody because it's steeped in tradition," said Jil Morley, transportation manager for Blue Diamond Growers, a cooperative of almond growers. But with deregulation, she said, "I'm expecting it to get more like the real world, like the rest of the world."

HEADLINE: Budget Panel Irks Mayor With Proposed Cap on Stadium Subsidies

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
City tax subsidies for stadium projects for the Yankees and Mets should be limited to a maximum of $46.2 million annually, a nonpartisan watchdog group said yesterday.
In a letter to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Citizens Budget Commission said its study found that teams playing in new or renovated facilities would generate enough economic activity in the city to justify yearly subsidies of $23.1 million per team. If used to pay off 25-year bonds, the subsidies could total $636 million. 
 "We're not suggesting that he spend to the limit," said Charles Brecher, executive vice president of the commission. "If he commits the maximum, that would be a C minus. If he commits more, he'd take too much from the economy."
The commission said the city could rationalize paying the subsidies because each team would generate an estimated $29.5 million a year for the city's economy if they played in new or renovated facilities. The suggested subsidy figure is lower because it deducts projected costs of maintenance and other expenses.
Although the study appears to support Mr. Giuliani's staunch belief that new stadiums can spur economic development, he said yesterday that the commission was "dead wrong" in its assessment of the benefits.
"Actually, the city makes more from a single World Series, by a lot," he said, rejecting the study's economic benefit figure of $29.5 million. "But thank goodness the Citizens Budget Commission isn't running the budget."
He added, "If I took their advice on baseball stadiums, I would make a terrible, terrible mistake. The baseball teams generate a tremendous amount for our local economy. They generate a lot more than many other businesses, and that's how they have to be treated, in a proportionate way."
The City Comptroller's office issued a report during last year's World Series estimating that the Yankees generated $251 million for the city's economy during the regular season, and $67 million more during the postseason, including $31 million for two World Series games.
The commission's figure was based on spending by out-of-towners on tickets, parking, concessions, and meals, plus the city taxes paid in those areas. Spending by city residents was excluded because, the commission said, they would spend money on other entertainment if a team moved.
The Comptroller's figure was based on the much broader universe of game-related spending by all fans, as well as team media revenues and stadium advertising sales, plus local bar and restaurant receipts.
Last year, a study released by the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, pegged the Yankees' economic impact on the city at $30 million annually, and he suggested that the city should provide $175 million to pay for a $525 million redevelopment of the stadium and its environs into a Yankee Village.
Still, any plan awaits a decision from George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the principal owner of the Yankees, about keeping his team at Yankee Stadium, where its lease expires in 2002. Last week, he displayed a willingness to remain there if there is a plan to revitalize the South Bronx. He has pushed for a ballpark over the West Side rail yards of Manhattan or in New Jersey, but the viability of both options has faded.
The cost of a new or renovated stadium for the Yankees has been estimated as high as $1 billion, while a stadium with a retractable dome for the Mets, which is being planned for completion in 2003, would cost about $500 million.
The study again raises the feasibility of government financing of stadiums for profitable private businesses, like the Yankees and Mets. The commission said each team's potential economic impact in new facilities is a "significant stimulus" worthy of a subsidy.
But Mark S. Rosentraub, an expert on sports economics who is an associate dean in the School of Public and Environmental Affairs at Indiana University, said, "We already know sports is too small to be thought of as an economic development tool. As a percentage of New York City's economy, team sports is minuscule."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Plans $157 Million In Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will propose $157 million in new tax cuts when he unveils his budget plan tomorrow, including a tax credit that would benefit 600,000 low-income families, his aides said yesterday.
The tax cut proposals were the latest in a series that city officials have put forth in recent months as the local economy has thrived and city coffers have overflowed. In January, Mr. Giuliani proposed $248 million in tax reductions as part of his $35.4 billion preliminary budget. And in March, City Council leaders called for tax cuts worth $700 million. 
 While the Giuliani administration and the Council both expect squabbling over which taxes to cut during the budget negotiations, they say that discussion will be a pleasant change from last year's battle over the Mayor's plan to build a new Yankee Stadium in Manhattan.
"We have turned the corner in our fiscal world to the point where the most important thing that we can do for New Yorkers is debate tax cuts," said Joseph J. Lhota, the Deputy Mayor for Operations. "The debate is going to be about how many taxes to cut, what kind of taxes to cut and how deep they get cut."
The most significant of the 10 proposals yesterday is a city earned income tax credit for the working poor, similar to those available at the state and Federal levels. Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone has proposed a similar credit, but his version would provide a larger tax break for fewer families.
Mr. Vallone says his proposal would give 450,000 low-income families an average tax credit of $360 and cost the city $190 million a year. Mr. Giuliani's version would provide 600,000 families with an average credit of $80 and cost $48 million a year.
In both cases, the city would cover only a small amount of the cut; the bulk would be paid out of surplus Federal welfare money available because of the drop in welfare rolls.
The proposals announced yesterday were recommended by a commission that Mr. Giuliani appointed in January to identify unreasonable taxes. They include eliminating the city sales tax on books, which adds up to $25 million a year; eliminating a tax that car owners pay when they register their vehicles, which would cost the city $15 million a year, and a reduction in the sales tax on building materials, which would mean a loss of $48 million a year.
Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that his tax cut proposals were justified because the city has "one of the largest surpluses in history" for the third year in a row. He estimated in January that the budget surplus was $1.6 billion, but his aides said yesterday that he would release a larger figure tomorrow.
Council leaders insist that the surplus is at least $2.1 billion, which is why they want more substantial tax cuts of $700 million as against Mr. Giuliani's $405 million.

HEADLINE: Report Finds Power Plants Dirtier in '98

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Air pollution from 21 aging power plants across New York State rose significantly last year, according to a report released yesterday by several private environmental, health, and consumer groups.
Although New York State environmental officials did not dispute the findings on these plants, they said that the state had reduced overall power-plant pollution by half from the level in 1990. 
 At the plants, which use decades-old technology and burn mainly oil or coal, there was a 21 percent rise last year in emissions of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain and respiratory problems, and a 12 percent rise in releases of nitrogen oxides, which cause acid rain and smog, according to the report.
The study said that the persistent problems at these plants, the state's most polluting, could cause health problems for communities downwind in New York and New England, which receives some of New York's pollution along with the flow from more highly polluting plants in the Midwest.
The plants cited in the report are scattered across the state, from Port Jefferson on Long Island and Astoria, Queens, to the Hudson Valley and Niagara County. They were highlighted because they all produce at least 100 tons more nitrogen oxides annually than the Federal standard allowed for new plants burning coal, said Cori Traub, an author of the report and director of air and energy projects for Environmental Advocates, a private lobbying group in Albany. The other organizations publishing the study were the New York Public Interest Research Group and the New York chapter of the American Lung Association. The data were provided by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.
New York State environmental officials said the state was a national leader at cutting power-plant pollution, by focusing efforts on newer plants, where major improvements can be made at a low cost, instead of forcing expensive improvements at old plants. Samuel Thernstrom, a spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Conservation, said that the drop in the state's total emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides since 1990 was due mainly to a shift to cleaner fuels, like natural gas, and improved pollution-capturing gear for smokestacks.
He added that by far the biggest air problem for New York still lay to the west. In fact, he said, some individual coal-fired power plants in the Ohio River Valley produce more sulfur and nitrogen pollution than all New York's industries combined. This pollution drifts east, damaging forests and lakes and causing health problems like asthma.
Nonetheless, the authors of the report said that more must be done to clean up what they called the dirty 21. The 21 plants are responsible for half the total emission of the nitrogen oxides and sulfur dioxide released by all industries in the state, according to the analysis.
If they are not forced to clean up to the same standard as other plants, Ms. Traub said, they will have a competitive advantage over newer plants that are required to install costly pollution-control gear. "With deregulation happening," Ms. Traub said, "it's unfair that these plants have this competitive advantage, that they're able to run more cheaply under outdated standards."
But Mr. Thernstrom said that if New York clamped down too hard on its dirtiest plants, utility companies might simply close them and buy power from even dirtier ones in the Midwest.
The study comes as most of the state's plants are being sold off by utilities like Consolidated Edison and Niagara Mohawk under new state regulations aimed at ending monopolies in the power industry.
Carol Murphy, the executive director of the Independent Power Producers Association of New York, said that the rise in emissions last year was unlikely to be repeated, because many of the new owners are planning to modernize the plants, either switching to a cleaner fuel, natural gas, or installing more efficient equipment that reduces pollution.
Also in the background is an intensifying fight between the Midwest and the Northeast over cutting pollution from old plants that rely on coal and oil. Several bills that would curtail pollution, sponsored by legislators from eastern states, are making the rounds in Congress.
But environmental groups say that New York could spur improvements by passing a state law requiring that any electricity sold in the state, whether it is generated here or elsewhere, be produced at plants using the cleanest standard, said Ashok Gupta, an economist who conducted a similar study two years ago for the Natural Resources Defense Council.

HEADLINE: New Zoning Leaves Room For Skyline Of the Future

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
Joseph B. Rose wants to make New York safe for architecture once again.
That is one clear point that emerged in a wide-ranging speech on the reform of zoning policy that Mr. Rose, the Giuliani administration's Planning Commission chairman, delivered yesterday at City Hall. Speaking to an audience that included planners, urban designers and community activists, Mr. Rose declared, "We are not Colonial Williamsburg, and the world's greatest and most dynamic city should be a hospitable environment for bold new structures." 
 But how is this estimable goal to be attained? Not everyone will be pleased with the answer.
In part, Mr. Rose hopes to discourage remakes of past mistakes by restricting the height of buildings outside of the midtown and downtown business districts. At the same time, he wants to encourage excellence by exempting some buildings from those same limits on height.
"The public process should be able to grant waivers from some regulations on the basis of exceptional design," he stated. "To that end, I am convening an advisory body to help us figure out how we can prudently introduce such values into our zoning."
In a city as economically dependent on real estate development as New York, Mr. Rose's call for height restrictions may be the splashiest of his proposals. In a sense, it may also be the easiest to accomplish. For the city's architectural community, however, his most significant goal was that city government recognize that it has a legitimate role to play in raising the standards of architectural quality in New York. Referring to the stringent laws on landmark preservation now in place, Mr. Rose said, "If we can bend over backward on behalf of great old buildings, I am confident we can figure out how to do so for great new ones, too."
That's the really hard part. Mr. Rose's plan is a welcome opportunity. But given the slim chance of a sudden civic rage for innovative design, can New York seize it?
For it is not a simple matter for any government agency to venture into the murky and subjective realm of esthetic evaluation. Mr. Rose can anticipate challenges to this initiative from the City Council, whose approval is required, and, most likely, from the legal system, in which the debate over landmarks legislation was fought all the way to the United States Supreme Court. He surely will arouse the ire of community boards that have enjoyed considerable power over the design of new buildings.
Not least, Mr. Rose can expect opposition from residents who will undoubtedly question his willingness to override the new zoning regulations on the basis of outstanding design. Who will make the determination that a design is outstanding? What values will be represented by the advisory panel Mr. Rose proposes to create? How can this group gain the trust and respect of communities affected by its decisions?
In addition to proposing an advisory panel on architectural design, Mr. Rose declared his intention to abolish the urban planning model that has governed high-rise development since the adoption in 1961 of the Zoning Resolution.
"The 1961 zoning imposed an esthetic regime of a tower in the park, which has proven to be a fundamentally flawed, anti-urban, and anti-New York concept," he said. "We are going to drive a stake through the heart of tower-in-the-park zoning and its trail of exceptions, caveats, and interpretive gymnastics."
In practice, the revised zoning would limit the transfer of air rights and permission to build "bonus" floors in exchange for the creation of public plazas. Instead, the Department of City Planning will propose a unified set of bulk regulations for middle- to high-density development.
Mr. Rose is not proposing a new architectural esthetic. Rather, he seeks to liquidate two old ones that have persisted past their prime.
The first, the tower-in-the-park concept, originated in the 1920's with the French architect Le Corbusier. At the time, it was a visionary idea for introducing light and open space into congested urban areas, and for preparing the city to cope with the age of the automobile. The concept was taken up after World War II by idealistic American architects, with results that often fell far short of the ideal.
The taste for historical pastiche began in the 1960's in a similarly idealistic spirit. It represented a reaction against the sterility of streets like Avenue of the Americas after they became lined with relatively uniform glass towers in the modernist mode. It was not until the 1980's that this esthetic began to harden into a retrograde and profoundly suburban approach to architecture and urban design. Then, we began to see these tragic remakes of cast iron lampposts, these ersatz 1920's facades pasted over contemporary residential buildings.
The post-modern movement has become an esthetic tyranny: a fear of change. As a result, New York has been deprived of projects like the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, the new Jewish Museum in Berlin, and the Congrexpo conventional hall in Lille, France. These buildings have helped their cities face the future with aplomb.
From an architecture critic's perspective, the big picture is this: Mr. Rose is chief planner of a city where architecture in recent years has become a world-class joke. He spoke for many when he urged, "Instead of cloaking ourselves only in the architectural garb of the 19th and early 20th centuries, we must be able to add to our built environment the best of the early 21st century as well."
Still, if this sentiment is widespread, it has not yet attained the political and social clout that the preservation movement eventually acquired. Many people feel comfortable with buildings that recall the past, not only because of their reassuring familiarity, but because they give communities a sense of control over their surroundings. Others recoil from the new as if it were a form of esthetic terrorism.
New York's civic groups and cultural institutions have done little to whet the public's appetite for architectural innovation. For example, the Municipal Art Society, a group that should have been keeping the city on its architectural toes, has instead contributed to the city's creative torpor. While the city's architecture schools, like those at Columbia University and Cooper Union, have fostered creativity among their students, the schools have shown little initiative in transmitting this spirit outside the classroom, even when it comes to the design of new buildings on their own campuses.
Community groups, and others, may be alarmed by Mr. Rose's linkage between quality and quantity. They are right to be on guard. No one wants to see design used as a rationale for overdevelopment, particularly in a town that has lost its architectural bearings. Still, as Donald Trump's design for a 900-foot skyscraper just north of the United Nations demonstrates, loopholes in the existing regulations already allow developers to pile on bulk. Quantity with quality is a better deal than quantity without.
Mr. Rose has yet to spell out the steps he will take to implement the concept of a design advisory board, or the other proposals outlined in his speech. It's going to be a bumpy ride, but this idea deserves a chance to succeed, and even to fail. It will not be easy to convince people that, even in the subjective realm of taste, it is possible to sort out good ideas from bad ones, or to persuade them that, even when a public agency makes an esthetic fumble, the effort to discriminate is itself worthwhile.
As Alfred North Whitehead put it, "It is the business of the future to be dangerous." Buildings that reflect cultural change can be shocking, but providing such shocks, and provoking public debate over their value, are tasks a vital city should perform.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

All Major Indexes Rebound A Day After a Big Selloff
Shares of technology companies rebounded in heavy trading after Monday's selloff, and investors were seen moving out of economically sensitive cyclical stocks, like industrial and oil companies, which have been rallying.
The Nasdaq composite index recovered 64.03 points of its 138-point loss on Monday and closed at 2,409.64, up 2.7 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 8.02 points, or one-tenth of a percent, to 10,448.55, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 16.69 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,306.17. Page C14. 

Browser Rivals Are Joining Forces
Hadi Partovi, the former lead product manager for Microsoft's Internet Explorer, is joining a Silicon Valley software start-up founded by two former enemies from Netscape, Michael McCue and Angus Davis, and backed by Jim Clark, the co-founder of Netscape. C2.
 
Drug Stocks Rally on Good News
A steep selloff in drug stocks halted after three large drug makers reported strong first-quarter earnings and a fourth received a recommendation from a Government panel that a new drug be approved. What surprised analysts was Johnson & Johnson's 12.3 percent gain. The earnings news lifted the shares of many drug companies, with Johnson & Johnson rising $6, to $96.25. C3.
 
Auto Makers Delay New Factories
An opposition Governor in southern Brazil has disrupted plans by General Motors and Ford Motor to build two car factories regarded as prototypes for the future. C6.
 
Profit Rises at Several Banks
Several of the nation's big banks reported gains in earnings. Chase Manhattan said first-quarter net jumped 61 percent, Bank One said profits were up 23 percent, and Wells Fargo reported a 29 percent rise. C3.
 
Despite pressure from shrinking demand for cigarettes and the cost of tobacco-related lawsuit settlements, Philip Morris posted a 1.4 percent increase in first-quarter profit. C8.
 
Several of the nation's largest phone companies -- Sprint, BellSouth, Ameritech and SBC Communications -- reported strong gains in first-quarter earnings. C12.
 
Auditing Board Considers Change
The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets the nation's accounting rules, is expected to vote today for strict limits or even a ban on the use of the pooling of interest accounting method, which played a prominent part in many of the largest corporate mergers and acquisitions in recent years. C3.
 
Inquiry Hurt Brazilian Markets
Nervousness over a legislative inquiry into reported irregularities during a Brazilian Government bailout of two investment banks earlier this year unsettled financial markets there. The Bovespa stock index gave up 4 percent before recuperating to close at 10,989.42, down 207.18 points, or 1.85 percent. The bailout was organized by Francisco Lopes, who has since been replaced as head of the central bank and is now a consultant in Rio de Janeiro. C6.
 
Inflation Is Expected to Rise
The rate of inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, is likely to jump this year to more than 2 percent from the 1.6 percent of last year. It could increase even more if oil prices continue to rise, upsetting the stock and bond markets. Market Place. C12.
 
Russia Is Seeking Debt Deal
Russia is holding foreign investors to a deadline of today for agreeing to a plan that restructures $40 billion in defaulted Government debt at a fraction of its face value. C6.
 
Protecting Internet Privacy
The Federal Trade Commission has proposed new rules to protect the privacy interests of children on the Internet. They would require commercial Web sites to get parental consent before seeking information from children younger than 13 and would require the sites to post notifications about what they do with any information obtained from children. A20.
