HEADLINE: Reading, Writing and Runny Noses;
For Those Without Insurance, School Health Clinics Fill In

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
At Intermediate School 218 in Washington Heights, 12-year-old Billy W. Vargas had severe chest pains one morning during class and could not catch his breath. He was having an asthma attack, a nurse determined.
Another student, Eddy Peralta, 14, was having difficulty concentrating in class because he kept having severe headaches and getting dizzy. As it turned out, he needed new glasses. 
 And at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Van Cortlandt Village section of the Bronx, Petra Anderson, 17, had coughing attacks that left her breathless and unable to sit still in class. The diagnosis: she had contracted whooping cough.
But instead of going to a doctor's office for treatment, the three children turned to what is becoming the primary source of health care for an increasing number of children across New York City: school-based health clinics. And the reason is simple: more and more families, even those with working parents, are uninsured and cannot afford any other means of health care, providers say.
Once a place to check a child's temperature, bandage a scraped knee or teach teens about reproductive health, school-based clinics are now being used to treat problems like asthma and whooping cough, and to diagnose conditions like heart murmurs and even cancer.
There are a total of 158 centers in some of the most impoverished neighborhoods throughout the state -- 110 of them in New York City. The typical school clinic today looks like a typical doctor's office and has a professional staff that can diagnose illnesses, prescribe medication and make referrals. Some of the clinics are financed by the state, others by the city and some are set up by not-for-profit organizations. Almost all are affiliated with large hospitals or comprehensive neighborhood health centers.
Doctors and school administrators said that their biggest challenge is not only treating the children, but also educating families about health insurance and, in many instances, finding an insurance package that fits their budget.
"I kept him here until the afternoon because I knew he didn't have insurance," said Abby Kemp, the nurse practitioner at I.S. 218, who treated Billy's asthma attack last week. "I wanted to make sure he was going to be O.K. We don't want him having an attack outside of school and winding up in the hospital, racking up bills his mother cannot pay."
In New York State, about 600,000 children -- more than half of them in New York City -- lack health insurance, child health experts say. But not all of their parents are the poorest of the poor, who tend to be covered by Medicaid, the Government health plan for the indigent. Many are part of a growing number of working New Yorkers who have no health insurance, either because they are not offered it through an employer or cannot afford their contribution. And the numbers continue to grow, experts said, as the price of insurance rises and as more people move from welfare to jobs with few benefits.
"The centers are a safety net for lots of parents," said Lisa Keegan, who works at Mount Sinai Medical Center's Adolescent Health Center, which, along with the Children's Aid Society, runs the clinic at I.S. 218. "We don't turn people away based on their ability to pay. The clinics are also helpful for working parents, who don't have to leave work just so their child can go to the doctors. And it's a major aid for educators. We can work with them and send them back to class ready to learn."
Dignora Calderon, 42, a homemaker and the single mother of Eddy and Melissa Peralta, said that the clinic helped her navigate the Medicaid bureaucracy. When Eddy, a jaunty eighth grader with wavy moussed hair, broke the lenses of his glasses, Mrs. Calderon said she was at a loss about what to do because she could not afford new glasses and had no insurance that would pay for them. So Eddy went without them for months.
But when Eddy's headaches finally sent him to the school clinic, the nurse talked to Mrs. Calderon and helped her apply for Medicaid.
Using state, Federal and private dollars, school-based health clinics began opening in New York almost two decades ago as part of a state initiative to improve primary and preventive health care for poor children, said Claire Pospisil, a spokeswoman for the State Health Department.
In the early 1990's, based on the success of the first clinics, the state increased the number of centers and the breadth of service by raising the amount of money the centers could receive from direct Medicaid reimbursements.
"There is a huge group of children with unmet health needs," said Dr. David K. Appel, the director of Montefiore Medical Center's 11 school-based clinics, including the one at DeWitt Clinton High School. "When the state created the opportunity to open more places, institutions responded by opening more clinics. The communities responded by using them very heavily and came to depend on them as a primary source of care."
 
Medicaid Changes Leave Questions
But even the clinics are not free from the convulsing health care industry, which over the last few years has endured a drop in reimbursement rates from public and private insurance, spurred largely by the growth of managed care. To try to save money, the State Health Department last year placed a moratorium on the opening of new school-based health centers after deciding to phase out direct Medicaid reimbursements to school clinics and steer patients to health maintenance organizations beginning April 2000.
Under that program, known as Medicaid managed care, school-based health centers could receive reimbursements from managed care companies. Two issues remain unclear, however: under what circumstances the clinics will be reimbursed, and what the reimbursement rates will be.
Currently, Medicaid pays up to $90 for each visit to the clinics. To save money, the Government plans to pay managed care companies a set fee that covers all of a Medicaid enrollee's health costs. The cost-saving of that system could be undermined, some might argue, if the state also has to pay for a child's visit the school clinic. And school clinic directors are nervous because managed care companies have been reluctant to commit to reimbursing school doctors from their fees, said Dr. Appel, who also heads a coalition of school-based health clinic providers around the state.
"Families tend not to sign up with us as their primary care physicians because they can come to us regardless of coverage," Dr. Appel said. "We are very concerned."
For her part, Wanda Vargas is grateful. With the clinic at I.S. 218, she was able to avoid an expensive emergency room visit for Billy, a round-faced sixth grader. A resident of Washington Heights, which has a high asthma rate, Ms. Vargas had heard about the clinic through friends.
Ms. Vargas, 36, an unemployed beauty technician, lost her Medicaid benefits when she moved to Washington Heights from Providence, R.I. two months ago. After 13 years in New York City, she had moved to Providence last year in hopes of building a better life for her and her two sons, Billy and Wander, 9. But it was hard to make ends meet there, she said.
Ms. Kemp, the nurse practitioner, urged Ms. Vargas to come to the clinic so the staff could help her complete a New York State Medicaid application. Ms. Kemp said that in general, primary care is a major component of the clinic because the school has a large population of children from the Dominican Republic who have never seen a doctor and whose parents are often poorly educated about detecting signs of health problems. "A lot of them would have nothing if we weren't here," Ms. Kemp said.
 
A Catch-All For Students' Health
The clinic, formally known as the Salome Urena Health Center, opened seven years ago on the first floor of I.S. 218, a gleaming two-story, red and beige brick building in Washington Heights, one of the poorest, most violent communities in Manhattan. In addition to medical care, the clinic provides dental and mental health services.
The four-room office suite used to be a storage room. Now it bustles with activity. One recent afternoon, with the sound of a dentist's drill piercing the air, three teen-age girls comforted one another as they waited to see the nurse for stomachaches. Another boy held an ice pack to his nose after hurting it in gym class. All of them planned to return to class after their visits, they said.
Mount Sinai Medical Center, which runs the clinic along with nine others, and saw a total of 32,104 students at those centers last year, has seen a 10 percent drop in Medicaid enrollment among its families since 1996, said Dr. Doris Pastore, the director of the hospital's school based health center program.
"Many of these families are costing out of Medicaid, but earn too little to afford Child Health Plus," Dr. Pastore said. New York's Child Health Plus program for children under 19 is subsidized by the Federal Government and is geared toward families of three with an income under $31,980 a year. It costs about $27 a month.
The results of being caught in the insurance limbo are often severe, experts say. Two years ago, Elaine Dinkins-Anderson ignored her teen-age daughter's persistent cough for as long as she could, telling herself that a doctor's visit was too expensive and that the cough would go away. The family lost its health insurance when her husband retired as a stockman with the New York City Transit Authority, and the four children, Petra, Paige, 18, William, 16, and Pearl, 21, were dropped from his insurance plan.
But after the cough persisted for a month, she decided to try the full-service health clinic at her daughter's school, DeWitt Clinton High School. There, Petra, now a senior, was found to have whooping cough, which is characterized by attacks of coughing that end in gasps, but is easily treated with antibiotics. The cough would have lingered had it not been treated.
Besides treating Petra, Dr. Appel helped Mrs. Dinkins-Anderson apply for insurance through Child Health Plus.
"Fortunate for us, the clinic was there," Mrs. Dinkins-Anderson recalled. "Petra was a sophomore, so we weren't that familiar with the clinic. Now, I swear by it even though we now have our own insurance."

HEADLINE: Unions Tell Mayor They'll Want More

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
New York City's municipal unions warned Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday that they planned to take a hard line in coming contract negotiations and they called on him to set aside $1 billion a year to pay for future wage increases.
Labor leaders said the city's workers made a significant sacrifice by taking a two-year pay freeze in their current contract. Now, they said, the workers deserve a sizable raise since the city's economy is booming and the Giuliani administration is enjoying a budget surplus. 
 "Our city's workers have given plenty," said Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers and chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Coalition, which represents 100 municipal unions. "Time and time again they've been partners in peril. So isn't it only fair that they now be partners in prosperity?"
In a speech given to the union coalition, which represents 300,000 municipal workers, Ms. Weingarten said many city employees were angry that their wages have barely kept up with inflation while Wall Street is at record highs, the real estate market is booming and the city's restaurant and party scene are flourishing.
"Considering the unabashed celebration going on around them, city workers will remember the 90's as the everybody-but-me decade," she said.
But Randy L. Levine, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said the city would not give its workers sizable raises unless the unions gave something back in return.
"If they want more money, we're prepared to discuss it as long as they tell us that they're going to provide a lot more work for that money," Mr. Levine said.
In her speech, Ms. Weingarten took a tougher tone than municipal union leaders did before the last round of contract negotiations four years ago, when the union coalition and its former chairman, Stanley Hill, were cowed into submission by Mr. Giuliani's warnings of layoffs.
For most city workers, their current, five-year, contract included a three-year no-layoff clause and a two-year wage freeze followed by a raise of almost 13 percent over the contract's last three years. Different unions have their contracts expire at different times next year.
Ms. Weingarten, in her speech at the Sheraton New York Hotel, maintained that the salaries of city workers are so low that many of them have a hard time making ends meet. It was a theme echoed by several labor leaders at a subsequent news conference.They also said that many talented teachers and police officers were leaving for the suburbs where their jobs are higher paid.
Mr. Weingarten interrupted her speech to have several city workers stand up to hammer her point home. There was Miriam Mandelbaum, a rare-books expert at the New York City Public Library who earns $36,000 after 14 years on the job. And there was Daniel Perez, an intermediate school teacher in Queens who after five years on the job is leaving his $35,000 post for a $44,000 teaching job on Long Island.
Ms. Weingarten said she expected Mayor Giuliani to assert that the financial cupboard is bare and that the city could therefore not afford large salary increases. But she contended that the city does have the money in its budget, and she urged that it set aside $1 billion a year for wage increases in the future.
City Hall officials voiced discomfort with Ms. Weingarten's proposal for a labor reserve fund, even though the idea is supported by the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, as prudent budget planning to finance future wage increases. Some city officials fear that union leaders will seize on any labor reserve fund as a minimum financial pool that they can build on to win increases above and beyond what is in the pool.
"We negotiate from ground zero," Mr. Levine said. "We don't negotiate you put X dollars in as a freebie and you negotiate from there."
With most municipal labor contracts expiring next year, Ms. Weingarten warned that unions would mount considerably more pressure than before -- they already have scheduled a demonstration on May 12 to protest the Mayor's budget. And she highlighted another tactic: municipal unions will seek to line up support from parent groups, business groups and private-sector unions to press City Hall to come up with more money for higher wages.
Lee Saunders, the trustee who replaced Mr. Hill as head of District Council 37, the giant union representing 120,000 workers, took a much sharper tone than Mr. Hill. Mr. Saunders complained that Mr. Giuliani, in his State of the City speech, never thanked city workers for all the work they have done and the sacrifices they have made.
But Mr. Levine asserted that Mr. Giuliani has been very fair with labor. "We negotiated very fair agreements, and the unions were partners with us," he said. "The unions helped provide concessions and savings for the city, but they managed to protect their jobs. This Mayor is never going to get back to the earlier days when in effect the city gave away the store to the unions and didn't receive anything in return."

HEADLINE: Private School Choice Plan Draws a Million Aid-Seekers

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
A billionaire Wall Street financier who raised $170 million in scholarships to send low-income children to private schools said yesterday that more than a million families had responded to his offer, or nearly one out of every 50 schoolchildren in America.
The financier, Theodore J. Forstmann, better known for his leveraged buyouts of companies like Gulfstream Aerospace, Dr. Pepper and General Instruments, said he had turned his business savvy to helping thousands of children escape failing public schools and go to private and religious schools. But the response to his offer surprised even him, he said, and it has added fuel to the debate over efforts to use taxpayer money to send children to private schools. 
 Although the scholarships were open to students now enrolled in either public or private schools, the vast majority of applicants came from public schools, indicating a deep dissatisfaction among parents with the education their children are getting, Mr. Forstmann said. The 40,000 winners, chosen over the last few days by a computerized lottery, are to be announced today at simultaneous ceremonies in New York and Los Angeles.
In capturing public attention for his cause, Mr. Forstmann was armed with an obvious fervor, immense wealth, and a well-oiled public relations machine that generated public service announcements by the baseball star Sammy Sosa, the poet Maya Angelou and the actor Will Smith. In February, Mr. Forstmann benefited from a dollop of Oprah Winfrey, who instructed viewers to turn off their vacuum cleaners while she interviewed him. A Republican, Mr. Forstmann assembled a board of public figures in both parties, from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, to Gen. Colin L. Powell, a Republican.
Mr. Forstmann said the number of applicants -- 1,237,360, including nearly one out of three qualified students in New York City, Newark, New Orleans, Philadelphia and Washington -- was even more compelling given that the scholarships will amount to only $600 to $1,600 a year for four years, not enough to cover even the $2,500 tuition at most parochial schools, and that the winners will be required to make a matching contribution from their own pockets averaging $1,000 a year.
He called the response "a cry from the heart." Noting that the applicants were, in effect, turning down a free education from the government, he added, "So they're quite impoverished, they get their product for nothing and they're lining up around the corner to pay $1,000."
But critics said that Mr. Forstmann is more interested in undermining public schools, building enrollment in financially troubled parochial schools and advancing a crusade to obtain public financing of religious and secular private schools than in improving education for the poor. The very poorest and most troubled children cannot afford the program, they said, and schools are free to reject those they do not want.
But by mobilizing the public behind their scholarship plan, Mr. Forstmann and his associates could become a powerful tool in pushing state legislatures toward the adoption of taxpayer financing of vouchers to send children to private and religious schools. Mr. Forstmann, who is Roman Catholic, denied that he has any interest in pursuing vouchers. He has supported Catholic-school scholarships in the past, and critics of voucher proposals noted yesterday that his partner, John Walton, owns stock in a profit-making corporation, Tesseract Group, that manages charter schools.
"It's clearly become a stalking horse for vouchers," Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said yesterday. "Raising money for private and parochial schools is a longtime tradition in the U.S. But now you've got people telling parents over and over again that their kids can do better than what they do now. It's all over television; it's on Oprah. When you listen carefully there's something going on about getting kids out of the public schools, and that's terribly unfortunate."
But even the opposition acknowledges that Mr. Forstmann has elevated the debate over whether the public schools are fulfilling their mission of providing an equal education to all, especially black, Hispanic and immigrant children in the inner city as well as children in rural areas. Using an idea that would warm the heart of a free-market economist -- leveraging scholarships to help thousands of children seek a better education -- Mr. Forstmann has tapped into the deepest fears and hopes of parents about the future of their children.
Most of the applicants came from New York City, the nation's largest school system, where 168,184 students applied, or 29 percent of the 587,092 public and private school student who met the eligibility guidelines. Students were eligible, officials said, if their family income was just above the cutoff for the Federal reduced-price lunch program, a measure of poverty. (Parents could apply through the mail, E-mail or a toll-free telephone number.)
Chicago had the next highest number, with 59,186 applicants, or 26 percent of those eligible, Los Angeles had 54,444 applicants, or 18 percent. In Baltimore, 44 percent, or 46,011, of those eligible applied, the highest precentage in the country.
Winners were notified this week. The largest number of scholarships, 3,750, will be awarded in Los Angeles; New York and Chicago will get 2,500 each and other cities will get hundreds. The numbers reflect the amount of money donated to the program from each of those cities.
"I think at some point the public schools start to fail our children, and I think the third grade is that cutoff," said Shelitha Harrelson, a New Yorker whose daughter, Brittney Tucker, was told this week that she is one of the 40,000 winners.
Ms. Harrelson, whose name was provided by the fund, has a daughter in third grade at P.S. 279 in Canarsie, Brooklyn. She said she hoped to use her stipend to help pay the costs at Marymount, a Manhattan private school where she said tuition is $12,000 a year, or Epiphany, another school, where she said it would cost $4,000. Ms. Harrelson, an administrative coordinator at Polo Ralph Lauren and a single mother, met the income criterion of $29,295 for a family of two.
New York City's Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, who threatened to resign last month when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began lobbying for a government-financed voucher program, said he did not oppose the fund, as long as it used private money. "I have never claimed the public school system is a perfect system," he said. "I think this is only natural; it's going to happen. It is a sign that there are people who want choice."
Dr. Crew said he was trying to meet that demand as well with a push to create charter schools independent of the Board of Education and some union rules.
In Chicago, Paul Vallas, the chief executive of the public schools, said: "I'm all for it. Here you have people from the private sector pooling their money to help make a child's education better. How can you be against that?"
At today's ceremonies, Mr. Forstmann, Mr. Walton and Andrew Young, the civil rights leader and former ambassador to the United Nations, are to preside in New York, at the main public library, while Michael S. Ovitz, the former president of Walt Disney, Ronald W. Burkle, managing partner of the Yucaipa Companies, and Eli Broad, chairman and chief executive of Sun America Inc., are to announce the winners in Los Angeles.
Mr. Forstmann and Mr. Walton started the program, called the Children's Scholarship Fund, eight months ago by contributing $50 million each, and said they have since raised an additional $70 million from other donors around the country.
The program is the largest privately financed scholarship program in the country, Mr. Forstmann and his associates said, and also dwarfs experiments with taxpayer-financed voucher programs to send poor children to private schools in Milwaukee and Cleveland. Neither Milwaukee nor Cleveland are among the cities receiving scholarships, according to a list released yesterday.
Several members of the fund's national board of advisers, including Senator Moynihan and Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, said they had signed on to the program because they saw it as a chance for children to attend better schools than the ones they were in, not as an attack on the public-school system.
"I'm against vouchers," Mr. Rangel said.
"I support scholarships for public schools, private schools, and any other kind of schools."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;
SERBS REPORTED TO PUSH ALBANIANS FROM 2D REPUBLIC

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
NATO and Pentagon officials said today that Serbian forces had begun driving ethnic Albanians from Montenegro, signaling a widening of the Balkan conflict.
The Serbs' actions appeared to be focused on Albanians who had fled to Montenegro. Serbia and Montenegro form what remains of the former Yugoslav federation. 
 But initial reports were sketchy and could not be confirmed on the ground, or by other agencies monitoring developments in Yugoslavia.
Describing the reports at his briefing in Brussels, NATO's civilian spokesman, Jamie P. Shea, said: "This is something rather new and distressful if this pattern is now spilling over elsewhere into Yugoslavia. It can only exacerbate the problem, which is already, as you know, of alarming proportions."
The Pentagon spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, said NATO officials had evidence suggesting for the first time that troops in Montenegro are driving out Albanian refugees who had escaped from the Serbian campaign in Kosovo. Neither he nor Mr. Shea indicated where the new refugees may be going.
Late tonight, NATO conducted its first air strike against Serbian television and radio stations, knocking several of them off the air. The building that was attacked by cruise missile, across from downtown Belgrade, also contained offices of two political parties linked to President Slobodan Milosevic. Page A11.
 Allied officials also reported that NATO warplanes had flown 603 missions in the 24 hours through this morning, the highest number in the four-week bombardment.
Military officials said the planes had attacked ammunition depots, an ammunition plant near Belgrade, tanks, trucks and a high-level command post. For the first time, NATO said it had destroyed a support site for Yugoslav Frog surface-to-surface missiles, which have a range of 40 miles.
Mr. Shea assailed Yugoslav authorities with the most grisly list of reported executions, rapes and mass graves in Yugoslavia that the alliance has issued so far. Among other horrors, Mr. Shea said Serbs had taken about 700 Albanian youths, some as young as 14, "either to use as human shields or as blood banks for Serb casualties."
American and other allied officials have watched with growing alarm as tensions intensify between Montenegro and the federal government in Belgrade. Montenegro, a poor mountainous region with a population of 640,000, has been trying to forge economic ties with the West.
The Montenegrin government no longer recognizes the legality of Mr. Milosevic's Government. Montenegro's special forces have fought with Yugoslav Interior Ministry troops, and there have been reports that Serbs shelled refugee camps just inside Montenegro, where about 73,500 Kosovars have sought refuge.
American intelligence has reported other signs of a potential widening of the war. For example, the Montenegrin government has approached Croatia to buy anti-armor weapons and 2,000 sets of fatigues for its security forces to distinguish them from the Yugoslav military police.
Croatia, once also part of Yugoslavia, has cooperated with NATO by closing down an oil pipeline into Yugoslavia on March 28.
There have also been American intelligence reports that senior Montenegrin officials find the allied raids counterproductive because they are galvanizing nationalistic fervor in Serbia, which in turn puts more pressure on Montenegro.
On another front, Romania gave approval today for NATO to cross its airspace. The decision will be put to the Parliament for a vote. Bulgaria has already agreed to allow overflights, though no plans have been announced yet to use those corridors.
And the first of 24 United States Army Apache helicopters remained grounded in Italy today, awaiting clearer weather in Albania so the aircraft and their supporting units can fly into makeshift, mud-clogged landing areas there. Maj. Gen. Charles Wald, a senior officer on the Joint Staff, said the first Apaches should arrive in Tirana, Albania, on Wednesday, barring more rain, and the remainder on Thursday.
The Pentagon is still considering how to meet a request from Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the NATO military commander, for 300 more American warplanes and support aircraft. Military officials have not decided whether to divert the carrier Enterprise and its 70 aircraft to the Aegean and break a near-ironclad policy of keeping sailors and pilots at sea no longer than six months at a time.
The Enterprise is sailing through Suez today and is expected to be in the Mediterranean by early Wednesday. The Navy Secretary, Richard Danzig, and Adm. Jay Johnson, the Chief of Naval Operations, are opposed to extending the Enterprise's tour. The carrier Theodore Roosevelt is now in the Adriatic.
Even as military officials said the air war is grinding down Belgrade's ability to rearm and resupply its 40,000 troops in Kosovo, NATO officials in Brussels described in gruesome detail the atrocities reported from the besieged province.
Mr. Shea said more than 3,500 ethnic Albanians had been executed as part of a strategy by President Milosevic to keep NATO off balance by developing a "surge capability that he can sort of switch on and off as he desires whenever he wants to start a new flood of refugees."
Reports from Kosovar refugees that Mr. Shea emphasized today included the following:
*Near Orahovac, as many as 700 Albanian men were used as human shields last week. The men were forced to stand in front of tanks in the rain for two days with their hands tied behind their heads. A few eventually escaped by paying the soldiers 10,000 German marks, about $5,400.
*In Pec, Serbian forces had rounded up young Albanian women and taken them to a hotel where the local Yugoslav commander apparently has organized a roster of his soldiers to allow them all an evening at the hotel with the women.
*During Serbian raids in some villages, young women have been gang-raped in the homes or on the roadside by soldiers.
"All of this will have to be investigated," Mr. Shea said. "But the reports are too numerous to suggest that these are completely without foundation."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE RECONSTRUCTION;
Allies Seek a Way to Promote Prosperity in Restive Balkans

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
The Western military alliance has begun promoting the idea of a sweeping reconstruction of the Balkans, even as it destroys refineries, bridges, roads and buildings in Yugoslavia.
Though the idea is still vague, the Clinton Administration hopes that the NATO summit meeting in Washington this weekend will produce a framework for the project, which would cover all the countries of the Balkans, the poorest part of Europe. Administration officials insist that carrying out any plan, especially in the countries surrounding Yugoslavia, would not hinge on a resolution of the Kosovo conflict or the ouster of Mr. Milosevic. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that millions of people in the Balkans are depending on an economic rescue and could not be "held hostage" by the fate of one man. 
 The Clinton Administration has not begun to define the scale of such a project or to focus on the nuts and bolts of how much it would cost, which countries would participate and what the precise goals would be. But the theme of such a reconstruction plan is as important as the details in that it signals to supporters of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia that international pressure will be brought to bear on the region to promote economic cooperation and that Yugoslavia's future lies with its integration into Europe.
Various European nations have talked of rebuilding the Balkans off and on over the last few years, with little to show for it. With the war in Kosovo now ruining the province's capacities for production and its transportation system and accelerating the mass exodus of its population into already distressed neighboring countries, the alliance says it is more determined to seek a broad-scale solution.
President Clinton, who discussed the rebuilding of the Balkans privately with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain two weeks ago, first publicly raised the notion of American participation last week.
"We should try to do for Southeastern Europe what we helped to do for Western Europe after World War II and for Central Europe after the cold war," he said in a speech in San Francisco.
Mr. Clinton has been careful to avoid describing the rebuilding as a modern-day Marshall Plan, which invites comparison with one of the most comprehensive -- and most expensive -- peacetime initiatives in world history. Over four years, 16 countries rebuilt a Europe devastated by World War II in an attempt to halt starvation, prevent the spread of Communism, and stabilize the international order to promote free markets. The plan, to which Washington contributed $13 billion starting in 1948, laid the foundation for NATO.
But officials said the Clinton Administration and the European Union are nonetheless striving for a thematic vision comparable to that of the Marshall Plan to signal the West's intentions to bring long-term stability to the region.
Strobe Talbott, Deputy Secretary of State, said that to achieve stability the alliance would need to bolster the countries of Albania, Bosnia, Bulgaria, Croatia, Romania and Macedonia.
How much rebuilding of Serbia would be undertaken and when it might begin are major questions that the alliance has yet to address.
The still-sketchy plan has evolved from notions of tinkering with ways to promote trade within the Balkans to a more expansive economic program that would offer technical and development assistance to the neighboring countries, compensate them for losses in trade and help them pay off their debts.
Officials hope any economic program would involve institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as well NATO members. Some analysts said it could be patterned on the $5-billion, four-year plan to help rebuild Bosnia in which several nations are participating.
Ms. Albright said that the plan had emerged from discussions among European allies and that the allies expected to delve into the subject when leaders of the 19 NATO countries gather here later this week.
"Our explicit goal," she said, "should be to transform the Balkans from Europe's primary source of instability into an important part of its mainstream. And we must work to insure that NATO forces will not again be called on to fight terror and destruction in this corner of the continent."
President Clinton briefly mentioned the NATO gathering at a White House ceremony at which he presented the Medal of Freedom to Helmut Kohl, the former Chancellor of Germany.
He said the crisis was evidence of a need to project Western power and values into eastern and southern Europe. "We can and must remain willing to act," Mr. Clinton said, "because the work of building a new world never ends."

SECTION: Section G; Page 7; Column 1; Circuits

HEADLINE: PC vs. iMac: The Grass Is Always Greener Across the Divide

BYLINE: By JOE HUTSKO; Joe Hutsko is a writer and computer consultant in New York. His novel, "The Deal" (Forge, 1999), is available for Palm Pilot at www.peanutpress.com. Macintosh users may scold him at jhutsko@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I'M conflicted. The iMac is a sensation, with more than a million units sold since its release last August. And like a lot of former Mac users who had made the switch to a Windows 98 PC, I have found myself drawn, even taunted by the iMac's cool esthetic. It has conjured up that old Apple magic for me, that self-righteous promise of a better-built mousetrap that not only compelled me to use Apple computers once but also prompted me to move west and go to work for the company.
I bought an iMac the day it went on sale and yet, as I revise this article on a Windows 98 personal computer, I wonder if that magic is enough to pull me back for good. 
 I was bitten by the Apple bug early. I picked strawberries on a farm as a 16-year-old to bankroll my first Apple, a IIe. But the Macintosh was different. I decided after seeing the famous "1984" Macintosh commercial during the Super Bowl that I wanted a Mac, but I couldn't afford one.
At the time, I was 20 and working as a computer trainer for the Harrah's casino in Atlantic City. The Mac was a foreign language in the casino business. I had read somewhere that Apple had given a Mac to every new employee so I called the company and asked for a job. I was invited to drop by if I was ever in the neighborhood. I called my boss at the casino and asked if he wanted to buy my new Compaq PC. He said yes, and that he would pay me on Monday. Floating myself the cash, I wrote a technically bad check and took the first flight out on Friday.
By the end of the day, I had landed a job in the information services department at Apple. A few months later, I was introduced to John Sculley, then the chairman of Apple. He had heard about my enthusiasm for the Mac and my flight west. He was looking for a technical assistant to teach him how to use the Mac and keep him tuned in to exciting developments in the Mac world. My job was to eat, sleep and breathe Macintosh. It was a dream job, and I stayed with it for nearly four years.
But somewhere in there, I had got it into my head that I wanted to be a novelist. So I quit Apple, and after a few false starts, I followed the advice many successful novelists give to aspiring authors: write what you know about. I started writing about Silicon Valley. And I started going broke.
Around this time Windows was really taking off. Tons of games were being written for the PC, but not so many for the Mac. I faced a difficult decision: PC or Mac? The PC won out, for purely economic reasons. I reviewed PC games to pay the rent. I wrote PC and video game strategy guides. At the same time, I wrote and rewrote my novel.
It has been a decade since I left Apple. My novel was published recently and is getting fair reviews. I bought myself a new Sony Vaio PC that ran Windows 98 and was decked out with the fastest processor, tons of memory and a powerful 3-D card that makes the latest games look great and run smoothly. This should be the happiest time of my life.
But it's not, and I blame the iMac. My attraction to the "VW Bug of computers" is rooted in feelings of sensuality and sentiment. As a computer, it could be frustrating, at least when it first came out. With no floppy drive or Zip drive connection, I couldn't easily transfer my few novels and other writings. With no viable all-in-one personal information manager, like Microsoft's Outlook 98 for Windows, I couldn't easily move over my E-mail, contacts, schedule and task and notes information that Outlook handles so skillfully on my PC.
Still, my new iMac looked great, and I was enormously pleased with how Apple's operating system upgrade, System 8.5, smoothed the appearance of the type on the screen. The Mac's windows are prettier than Windows' windows.
So I went ahead and laboriously sent myself all my files via E-mail, figuring that I would survive with my Palm Pilot as my personal information manager until the iMac could handle that function (which took months). Furthermore, I couldn't use my Hewlett-Packard Laserjet 6 printer; the only choices for iMac were ink-jet printers, which are not ideal for printing 300-page manuscripts. I mentioned to my friends that despite these inconveniences, I was switching back to Mac. They called me crazy.
Then something happened. Software and hardware makers started to become excited about providing products for the iMac. Imation began selling a Superdisk floppy drive that also doubles as back-up storage because it handles both regular and high-density disks. Iomega came out with a Zip drive that works with both PC's and iMacs. Palm Computing began giving away a clever contact manager that runs on Macs. Logitech released the Quickcam Pro, a digital video camera that works with PC's and iMacs. Infowave started selling an adapter that makes almost any PC printer work with the iMac.
Connectix's Virtual PC can, in a pinch, run Windows 98 on the iMac so I can connect my Hewlett-Packard Jornada handheld computer, which I use for writing and the Internet when I visit my family for the weekend. But I missed my PC's wheel mouse: the iMac's mouse turns into a slippery puck during pointing and clicking. Yetthat complaint was only a temporary one: Logitech has just started offering a Universal Serial Bus wheel mouse for iMacs. All should have been right in my iMac world.
But it wasn't. I began to miss my PC. I missed the nearly perfect Outlook 98; I even begged Microsoft to create a Mac version. I missed being able to play the hottest games. I missed the quicker response the PC with Windows always seems to have (my Mac friends actually complain that "it's too fast"). I especially missed the always handy right mouse button that speeds up everyday tasks. And there is more for me to write about in the PC world than the Mac world, and writing pays my rent.
After 5 or 10 bouts of swapping the PC and iMac on my desk, I finally settled on the PC. To resist the temptation of the iMac, I gave it to a financially challenged friend who has been threatening to write a novel of his own. It made perfect sense. He is new to computers and carries none of the baggage -- emotional and practical -- that I do. The iMac is perfect for him.
I have moved past Macintosh in some very specific ways. (I read recently that my former boss, Mr. Sculley, has himself become a PC user.) Still, choice is good, and it's nice to see Apple making a comeback, headed by the iMac's bright alternative to the accustomed Windows view of the world. I should be at peace with my decision, and I am. For now, anyway.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Writer Finds the Facts Don't Support the Image

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

MORGAN
American Financier
By Jean Strouse
Illustrated. 796 pages. Random House. $34.95. 
 In the introduction to her authoritative new biography of John Pierpont Morgan (1837-1913), Jean Strouse makes a startling confession about her experience in writing "Morgan: American Financier," her first book since "Alice James: A Biography" was published in 1980.
Having spent years availing herself of a virtually untouched trove of uncatalogued biographical documents in the Pierpont Morgan Library in Manhattan, as well as additional material in private hands, at the Morgan Grenfell archives in London and other repositories on both sides of the Atlantic, she eventually began to write and got about halfway through a draft when she saw that it wasn't working.
 She explains: "Months later I realized why. From the outset I had found Morgan's detractors more convincing than his champions: they were better writers, they reflected popular American assumptions (including my own) about the 'robber baron' chapter of our history, and their bracing hostility gave the story force. The advocates, by comparison, seemed defensive and fawning. As a result, I had been looking for a modified, human-scale version of the 'boss croupier' of Wall Street -- the cynical tycoon who subjected the entire U.S. economy" to what E. L. Doctorow, writing about Morgan in his novel "Ragtime," referred to as "the psychopathology of his will." But "this was not what I had found," she writes. "The evidence didn't support the picture I had pre-emptively drawn, and I hadn't been noticing what it did suggest."
What adjustments did Ms. Strouse then make that have permitted her to write a book that does indeed work in offering a coherent portrait of Morgan? One set of revelations has to do with his personality. Popular iconography has given us an image of Morgan that is brusque, arrogant, unapproachable, imperious and overwhelming in its force. While Ms. Strouse confirms this side of him, she also shows us a man who was mercurial; given to depression and nervous exhaustion; possessed of what one friend called "a very feminine streak in his nature"; flirtatious; vulnerable to flattery, and occasionally so sensitive to criticism that some felt that his appearance in 1912 before a House Banking and Currency subcommittee trying to establish the existence of a ruling "money trust" helped bring on his terminal illness.
Another dimension of Ms. Strouse's portrait reveals more about Morgan as a great collector of art. His image here, too, has not always been flattering. The connoisseur Bernard Berenson once remarked of Morgan's London house, "It looks like a pawnbroker's shop for Croesuses." The critic Roger Fry delivered a summary judgment that, in the author's words, "has defined Morgan as collector for generations of scholars and readers: 'A crude historical imagination,' the critic wrote, 'was the only flaw in his otherwise perfect insensibility to art .' "
As a corrective to these remarks, Ms. Strouse reveals a man whose sensuous nature was deeply attracted to art, who put himself in the hands of experts and whose "larger project" was "to harvest 'the best' of the world's cultural past for the American future."
But it is of Morgan as a financier that Ms. Strouse offers the profoundest revision. His eloquent detractors have portrayed him as a "great financial Gorgon" set on squeezing to death the farmer and the working man for the sake of his own profit. But while conceding he was "tone-deaf to the sensitivities of people whose interests did not coincide with his own," she argues that in his own mind at least, his interests were always identical to whatever would benefit the public.
His motive for organizing trusts was not to monopolize products but to organize markets more efficiently for the sake of everyone's profit. His bank's manipulations during panics were consistently meant to stabilize the market, no matter how profitable they might prove (and often enough they didn't). His defense of the gold standard was as much to sustain the flow of European capital into America as it was to protect his own interests.
In sum, Ms. Strouse writes: "When Pierpont Morgan died in 1913, at 75, he was the most powerful banker in the world. He had organized giant railroad systems and corporate 'trusts,' presided over a massive transfer of wealth from Europe to the United States, and, at a time when America had no central bank, acted as a monitor of its capital markets and lender of last resort. In the process he helped transform a largely agrarian society into a modern industrial state -- and entered into a struggle over the nature of the country's identity that dates back to Jefferson and Hamilton."
Woven together, Ms. Strouse's revelations tell a story whose interest is only limited by the inherent dryness of banking as an activity. After all, what Morgan essentially did when he wasn't abroad buying art and seducing women was simply to judge financial opportunities, raise money and issue bonds. Even his philanthropy, while heroic, was straightforward.
As authoritative as her text is, her footnotes extend her reach in fascinating directions. In one she quotes Theodore Roosevelt in his autobiography on why trust-busting was not the way to control corporate concentration; Government regulation was. In another she reveals that Cecil Spring-Rice, a British diplomat, "wrote the lyrics to 'I Vow to Thee My Country,' which became the favorite hymn of Diana, Princess of Wales, and was played at her wedding and funeral."
And in yet another she reveals that Morgan did, after all, have one admirer on the left. "In speaking of the capitalists who strive only for profit, only to get rich," Stalin, of all people, told H. G. Wells in an interview, "I do not want to say that these are the most worthless people capable of nothing else. . . . We Soviet people learn a great deal from the capitalists. And Morgan, whom you characterize so unfavorably, was undoubtedly a good, capable organizer."
Which is an understated way of putting what Ms. Strouse has argued with such force here.

HEADLINE: Coca-Cola Posts 13% Drop In First-QuarterNet Income

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
Continuing a recent pattern of weak results, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its first-quarter net income fell 13 percent as the company struggled to expand its business.
The amount of Coke concentrate sold worldwide declined 1 percent, as did revenues, the company said. But expenses rose 5 percent, to $1.953 billion, from $1.857 billion in the first quarter of 1998, diminishing earnings, which were $747 million, or 30 cents a share, down from $857 million, or 34 cents, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. 
 Nearly every one of Coca-Cola's regional markets reported flat or declining volume. The exception was North America, where case volume rose just 1.5 percent, well off the 6 percent increase for the first quarter of 1998. The company said higher prices, instituted in many markets at the start of the year, were responsible for the drop in sales.
Nevertheless, Wall Street bid up the shares $2.3125, to $67.5625, largely because there were some signs that the company's troubles were bottoming out.
Much of the bad news had been shared with analysts last month. But several analysts still expressed surprise at the extent of Coke's difficulties in certain regions.
"These are very discouraging trends in the North American market," said Skip Carpenter, a beverage analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, adding that he was perplexed by the weak demand for Coke products. Sales of concentrate to restaurants, sports arenas, movie theaters and other public places rose just 1 percent in the quarter.
And Michael Branca of Lehman Brothers said he was concerned about the future. Coca-Cola spent heavily for the volume it achieved, he said, and such spending will only increase as the company tries to drive volume overseas.
"Coke is certainly going to have the volume, but at what cost?" Mr. Branca said. Bottlers are starting to want to raise prices around the world to try to increase their returns -- something he said Coke wanted to prevent. "Rather than international bottler retail hikes, which would slow concentrate volume growth, we expect Coca-Cola to fund much of that differential," he said.
The company spent $1.2 billion on marketing support and infrastructure payments for its largest bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, in 1998. Mr. Branca said the company, in similar fashion, will have to "dramatically increase its spending levels overseas."
Coca-Cola's chairman and chief executive, M. Douglas Ivester, announced the results to an audience of generally friendly and supportive investors at the company's annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday morning. He described "a rare but real gravitational pull against our sales and volume" because of recessions around the world, and vowed that the company would bounce back quickly.
"We expect business conditions to start improving as we move into the second half of the year," Mr. Ivester said.
The company reported that case volume fell 4 percent in Latin America in the quarter, compared with a 19 percent increase in the first quarter of 1998. Volume in Brazil was down 10 percent, and in Venezuela and Colombia, the combined volume plummeted by 24 percent. Mr. Ivester said the company "intends to keep investing in Latin America to enhance our business system during the current economic crisis."
Price cuts are planned in Thailand, Germany and South Africa, the company said yesterday, but Mr. Branca predicted those would further erode Coca-Cola's profits.
Volume in the Middle East and Far East was flat, and in Europe, it declined 2 percent. Volume in Africa, one of Coca-Cola's smallest regional markets, declined 1 percent.
The biggest growth came from the company's Minute Maid unit, a small fraction of overall sales, where volume rose 5 percent.
And there were glimmers of improvement in some areas. Mr. Carpenter of Donaldson, Lufkin said, for example, that sales during the Easter holidays were stronger in Germany and some parts of Western Europe.
Andrew Conway, a beverage analyst for Morgan Stanley, also expressed optimism: "We're approaching the bottom. You still need a flashlight, but the tunnel has a little more light."

HEADLINE: Rubin Proposes Modest Limits on Lending Risk

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin outlined a modest five-point American plan today for warding off the kind of financial crisis that rocked three continents over the last two years. He called for strengthened financial disclosure rules and guidelines that would "discourage countries from taking too many risks" when they borrow money.
But Mr. Rubin's proposals, which President Clinton endorsed in a brief talk at the White House on Tuesday, fell well short of creating the kind of new "global financial architecture" that many policy makers debated in the heat of the crisis in emerging markets last fall. His ideas were chiefly modifications of existing rules, more akin to rewiring a building than reconstructing it. 
 At no time in his speech here today before the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies did Mr. Rubin repeat President Clinton's frequent statement last fall that the world was facing its "deepest economic crisis in 50 years." In fact, many American and European officials fear that as Asia's immediate crisis and the threat of economic contagion have receded, the political momentum for far-reaching reforms may have been lost.
Mr. Clinton warned on Tuesday about the dangers of complacency and the Treasury chief said today that he was concerned that in financial markets "even painful lessons recede from memory with time."
Nonetheless, the proposals Mr. Rubin put forward were infused with his characteristic caution about either overregulating markets or expanding the powers of the International Monetary Fund in ways that would signal investors they could count on being saved if a nation appeared on the brink of default. The I.M.F. -- which meets along with the World Bank and the Group of Seven finance ministers early next week -- has been the prime instrument for bailing out ailing nations.
The Secretary made no mention today of turning the I.M.F. into a "lender of last resort" for nations on the brink of bankruptcy, a proposal that some top officials of the fund have floated in recent months. "There was a range of views on that within the Treasury," Mr. Rubin acknowledged in response to a question. But he had opposed the idea, his aides say, fearing that if countries knew that the I.M.F. stood ready to prevent defaults, they would resume the kind of reckless lending that helped Indonesia, South Korea, Russia and Brazil get into trouble.
Similarly, he rejected the imposition of any kind of capital controls, rules that would limit the amount of money countries borrow, and, in times of crisis, prevent investors from pulling their money out. Such regulations, he said, "can be used by politicians as a substitute for real reform of their economies."
Instead Mr. Rubin focused on five areas of reform, some of which are already under way: forcing lenders to pay a greater share of the cost of bailing out nations, discouraging most countries from using fixed exchange rates, encouraging nations to rely more on long-term borrowing and less on short-term, disclosing more information about outstanding debt, and protecting the poor and middle class during crises.
The first initiative arises from the sharp criticism directed at both the United States and the I.M.F. that they bailed out banks and bondholders in Asia by insuring that they were repaid, but did far less for workers who lost their jobs.
Mr. Rubin said today that "market discipline will work only if creditors bear the consequences of the risks they take." He suggested that in future bailouts, the bankers and investors who lent money to a country would have to "share the burden." But he did not say how, and acknowledged that if the rules were too harsh, lenders would steer clear of developing nations.
He was clearer about exchange rates. "At the center of each recent crisis," Mr. Rubin said, "has been a rigid exchange-rate regime that proved ultimately unsustainable," a reference to the efforts by many Asian nations and Russia to peg their currencies to the dollar. He argued that the I.M.F. and individual nations should no provide money to help a country defend a fixed exchange rate, except in rare circumstances.
Mr. Rubin cautioned countries like Argentina that are considering adopting the dollar as their currency, a step many nations see as a way to bring stability to their economies. He said they would be giving up virtually all domestic control over monetary policy, which would be set by the Federal Reserve. And he warned that the Fed would manage the dollar to fit American economic interests -- and no one else's. It would not help supervise foreign banks, he said, or change interest-rate policy to fit another country's needs simply because it had adopted the dollar.
Mr. Rubin was particularly careful in dealing with the question of how to manage the $1.5 trillion that races around the globe each day in currency transactions, purchases and investments. Saying governments "must do a better job of managing their own debt," he warned them against borrowing too much short-term cash, rather than paying more for long-term borrowing. Many nations found that, once their currencies were devalued, they could not meet the short-term debt payments.
Mr. Rubin said that in some cases rules should be adopted to "limit banks' foreign currency exposures." But he did not describe those rules. And while he warned nations against excessive borrowing, he said the best way to deal with the problem was to require countries, banks, securities houses and hedge funds to disclose more data about how much debt they are carrying.
He suggested that Mr. Clinton's Working Group on Financial Markets, which he helps direct, would soon recommend tighter disclosure rules for hedge funds like Long-Term Capital Management, which had to be saved last fall from a multibillion-dollar default. Investigations showed the lenders to Long-Term Capital did not understand how much money the fund had quietly borrowed.

HEADLINE: 2 Exchanges Said to End Merger Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

 BODY:
The American Stock Exchange and Philadelphia Stock Exchange have terminated their planned merger, according to people close to the negotiations.
The collapse of the merger, which is expected to be announced as early as today, comes as Federal officials investigate whether various practices by the options industry inhibit competition and cause investors to pay higher prices. 
 When the two exchanges announced the proposed merger in June, officials had hoped it would allow them to share technology and otherwise reduce costs by bringing trading under one roof.
But the economic reasoning for a merger has eroded, people close to the talks said, partly because of pressure from regulators to allow multiple listing of options -- that is, different exchanges trading the same options -- as well as from the anticipated arrival of competition from a new electronic options-trading exchange.
After it became apparent that a merger was not going to occur, the exchanges discussed other alliances or combinations, but so far those talks have not produced any results, people close to the talks said.
The likely dissolution of the merger was first reported by The Philadelphia Inquirer on Tuesday.
 After the planned merger was announced last year, the Justice Department requested information about the combination. And two months ago, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt, asked the heads of the nation's four options exchanges to cooperate in opening the options markets to greater competition, including the integration of electronic options markets. One such exchange, backed by a number of Wall Street firms and called the International Securities Exchange, applied to the S.E.C. in February to begin trading as early as next year.
The American Stock Exchange, which was itself acquired last year by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which also operates the Nasdaq market, informed the Philadelphia exchange in a letter April 6 that it believed a merger was no longer feasible. A person close to the negotiations denied that the deal collapsed because of pressure from the Justice Department or the S.E.C.
According to this person, the merger was falling apart "before those things came into play. The economics and viability of the combination just didn't pencil out."
The end of merger talks comes three months after the Chicago Board Options Exchange canceled its merger with the Pacific Stock Exchange, citing technological concerns and antitrust questions, including requests by the Justice Department for information about the deal.

HEADLINE: Rising Crime in Argentina Fuels a Listless Presidential Campaign

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, April 21

 BODY:
Crime is emerging as a major political issue for the first time in the big cities of Argentina, a country where people have traditionally stayed out well past midnight to hop from cafes to tango clubs without any fear.
The issue is filling a vacuum in an otherwise listless campaign to succeed President Carlos Saul Menem in which the two leading presidential candidates generally agree on economic and social policy. It is a touchy issue for both the Buenos Aires Mayor, Fernando de la Rua, and Gov. Eduardo Duhalde, who is responsible for governing the province surrounding the capital. 
 Neither presidential candidate is blaming the other for the crime wave, apparently fearing that such a charge could backfire. Mr. De la Rua, the Alianza candidate, has been criticized for a rise in Buenos Aires street prostitution under his watch; while critics of Mr. Duhalde, the front-runner for the Justicialist nod, have attributed a rise in crime around his province to the purging of his corrupt, violent provincial police.
But with recent polls showing that crime is the No. 2 concern of Argentine voters after unemployment, advisers to the two candidates are drawing up detailed anti-crime programs that will shake up Argentina's corrupt and underpaid police departments and court systems.
In recent weeks, members of Congress of the ruling Justicialist Party and the opposition Alianza coalition have traded barbs accusing each other of being soft on crime, but they joined together to lengthen prison sentences for juvenile offenders and for people found concealing guns without a license.
President Menem, too, seems to be trying to capitalize on the growing concerns about crime to help consolidate his control over his party.
"I am not willing to watch unmoved the spectacle of a country where politicians speak while innocent people die," he said in a recent interview. This week he transferred more than 1,500 border police and navy military police to help patrol the streets of Buenos Aires.
Mr. De la Rua's vice presidential candidate, Carlos (Chacho) Alvarez, criticized the President's move, warning that "we should not militarize the conflict." And Mr. De la Rua suggested that crime was rising because the Government was ineffective at fighting poverty.
President Menem responded in an open letter, published in the local press today, scolding the Mayor for "confusing the dignity of the poor with the pathology of delinquency."
While preparing for his run for President, Mr. Duhalde made a pilgrimage to New York City a year ago to be photographed with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and to receive a briefing on the city's successful anti-crime strategies.
Ever since, Mr. Duhalde has included references in his stump speeches to "zero tolerance," the policing theory made popular in New York that a crackdown on small crimes contributes to a decrease of more violent crimes. Meanwhile, Mr. De la Rua had a well-publicized breakfast here with the former New York Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton, in November in which they discussed crime strategy.
Argentina remains one of Latin America's safer countries, and Buenos Aires has nowhere near the crime problem of Caracas, Mexico City or Rio de Janeiro. Still, the Buenos Aires daily La Nacion recently published a front-page article with statistics leaked by the Government indicating that incidents of serious reported crimes in Buenos Aires doubled between 1995 and 1998 in Buenos Aires, from 480,000 to 960,000.

 BODY:

ASIA
 
PAKISTAN: BHUTTO FACES PARLIAMENT OUSTER -- The chief election commissioner issued a notice for former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, to appear on Saturday before the commission, which is expected to take steps to disqualify them from their seats in Parliament. The two were convicted on corruption charges and barred from public office, but Ms. Bhutto, who is in London, has said she will not return to Pakistan until the Supreme Court decides on an appeal of her conviction.Celia W. Dugger (NYT) 

SOUTH KOREA: THOUSANDS ON STRIKE -- Thousands of workers walked off their jobs to protest planned layoffs, tying up the Daewoo shipyard and, for the third day, Seoul's subway system. The stoppages added to what labor leaders hoped would grow into a nationwide wave of strikes aimed at curbing restructuring in the country's conglomerates and money-losing public service corporations. (AP)
 
HONG KONG: 11 DISSIDENTS BARRED -- Immigration officials have refused entry to 11 exiled mainland dissidents invited by local activists to a seminar on May 1 and 2 to mark the 1989 crackdown at Tiananmen Square, Beijing. Several prominent former student leaders, including the Boston-based Wang Dan, were invited by the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of the Patriotic Democratic Movement in China. Officials would not comment on the cases. (AP)
 
INDONESIA: MORE AUTONOMY FOR REGIONS -- Parliament passed a bill giving more autonomy to the provinces, part of an effort to ease simmering regional tensions. The bill gives wide-ranging authority to regional governments in all matters except defense, foreign policy, judicial, fiscal and monetary affairs and matters considered "strategic." It applies in principle to all 27 provinces, although a separate autonomy package has been prepared for East Timor. (Reuters)
 
JAPAN: FORGIVING BILLIONS IN DEBT -- Japan plans to waive loans totaling about $7.82 billion to 41 impoverished countries as part of efforts among developed nations to alleviate the third-world debt burden, a Finance Ministry official said. Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa will inform his Group of Seven counterparts of the plan when they meet in Germany on Monday. (AP)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: DISSIDENT CLERIC JAILED -- An outspoken dissident theologian, Mohsen Kadivar, has been sentenced to 18 months in prison for "disseminating lies" and defaming Iran's Islamic system, his lawyer said. The trial was seen as part of a broader crackdown on the press and supporters of the reformist President, Mohammad Khatami, whose moderate faction is locked in a power struggle with conservative rivals. (AP, Reuters)
 
IRAN: IMPEACHMENT MOVE -- Conservative Iranian deputies called for the impeachment of Iran's moderate Culture Minister, Ataollah Mohajerani, in a new assault on President Mohammad Khatami's reforms. The 31 deputies presented a petition to the 270-seat Parliament, summoning the minister to be interrogated on his policies within 10 days, the Iranian news agency reported. Mr. Mohajerani is accused of following a liberal policy toward the press, book publishing and the arts. (Reuters)
 
IRAQ: U.S. JETS ATTACK -- American jets struck antiaircraft sites in northern Iraq after they were threatened by Iraqi radar, the U.S. military at the Incirlik base in Turkey said. Air Force F-16C's dropped laser-guided bombs on sites west of Mosul while patrolling the northern no-flight zone, the military said. (AP)
 
JORDAN, SYRIA: TIES RENEWED -- In what Jordanian officials called a historic visit, King Abdullah II of Jordan held talks with President Hafez al-Assad, marking a thaw in relations that deteriorated after Jordan and Israel signed a peace treaty in 1994. The leaders held three rounds of talks "in a positive climate," a presidential spokesman said. A Jordanian diplomat said Jordan was "totally supportive" of Syria in its talks with Israel. (Agence France-Presse)

Bernardo Ruiz, was arrested on charges of arranging the 1995 assassination of Alvaro Gomez, then Colombia's main opposition leader, authorities said, ending a manhunt that began in October. Mr. Gomez, a three-time presidential candidate and head of the Conservative Party, was shot dead on Nov. 2, 1995. (AP)

SOUTH AFRICA: POLICE ACCUSED -- Allegations of police brutality have more than doubled in the last 12 months compared with the year before, according to a new agency investigating police misconduct. The figures came to light as the Independent Complaints Directorate took over the investigation of six officers videotaped abusing suspects when they took a television documentary crew out with them one night. The officers were seen kicking, punching and setting their dogs on handcuffed suspects. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

The network was said to have operated from Paris and to have smuggled out weapons via Marseilles. The trial began in January and a verdict is expected soon. Marlise Simons (NYT)

HEADLINE: Police Corner a Big Rat, and Its Union Makes a Federal Case

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER

 BODY:
It's no secret that the Mayor has been trying to crack down on rodents in New York City, making them just one of many targets in his campaign to improve the city's quality of life.
But union leaders said yesterday the Police Department went too far. 
 An inflatable 30-foot rodent used by union leaders to dramatize labor issues was taken into custody during a recent protest outside the CBS building on West 52d Street. The unions went to court this week to get their mascot back.
The rodent has become something of a fixture on city streets, often put to use to symbolize the presence of nonunion contractors at work sites. But the police say it is a traffic nuisance. Instead of setting a trap or using poison, the police took a novel step: deflation.
In demanding the return of the giant rat and damages from the city, the union said the seizure was an unconstitutional attempt to silence one of its most effective protest tools.
The dispute began on April 8, when two members of Local 78, which represents asbestos, lead and hazardous waste workers, were distributing leaflets outside the CBS building, challenging what they said was CBS's hiring of a nonunion contractor.
Towering over them was their favorite prop, which looked as if it was peering right into the third-floor windows of CBS, said Sal Speziale, the president of Local 78.
"This is the biggest rat in the country that they just took," Mr. Speziale said. "You can see this guy for almost half a mile."
Mr. Speziale contended that CBS called the police. "They didn't like looking out of the window at this rat," Mr. Speziale said.
A CBS spokesman said the company had not called the police.
Marilyn Mode, a police spokeswoman, said: "This balloon was, in fact, impeding traffic and blocking parking spots. They were given numerous warnings, which they did not heed."
But union officials say that their rat was not blocking traffic, and that the police were seeking to tear down a powerful symbol that has become almost as ubiquitous as Ed Koch.
"What are they try trying to prove?" said Mike Hellstrom, a union organizer who contended that the city "figured they'd take our rat, and take our fire out from beneath us."
The lawsuit, filed Monday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, says the police violated not only the union's constitutional rights of expression and assembly, but also the civil rights of a member, Frederick Bianchi, who was arrested outside the CBS building and charged with disorderly conduct.
The suit asks that the police stop from interfering in future demonstrations, and pay compensatory and punitive damages, including the cost of replacing the rat, which was a victim of police brutality, the suit contends.
"It was tossed from a Police Department vehicle onto the ground," the suit says. "It was dragged across that ground in a haphazard manner and left outside, exposed to the elements."
The union paid about $8,000 for the rat six months ago. It also uses three smaller rat balloons, which, fully inflated, are 10 to 15 feet high.
Union officials said the balloons are trucked around town as part of an aggressive approach to grass-roots organizing. The rats have been inflated outside ABC, the Carlyle Hotel, Mount Sinai Hospital, Fordham University, The Daily News and Federal Express, Mr. Speziale said.
But demand was greatest for the 30-foot rat, said Lowell Peterson, a lawyer for the union. It was scheduled to take part in another rally the afternoon it was apprehended.
"We're seeking an injunction just to get the rat back," Mr. Peterson said. "This is a popular rat."

HEADLINE: Community College Offers A Nest for Digital Ventures

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
A community college in Manhattan is teaming up with some big-name investors to create a business incubator for emerging companies in digital television and other digital media.
Although research universities, like the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University, are more usually associated with high-technology ventures, the Borough of Manhattan Community College is eager to join the gold rush. The college is providing a floor of Fiterman Hall, in the heart of Silicon Alley on West Broadway in lower Manhattan, for the young businesses to nest in. 
 The college's partners are two venture capital funds, Bear Stearns Constellation Ventures and the Psilos Group, as well as the New York City Investment Fund. The Investment Fund, which was founded by Henry R. Kravis to create jobs and promote economic development, now has $79 million in capital and more than 64 investors, including AT & T, Bell Atlantic, Morgan Stanley and General Electric.
An incubator allows new, small companies to pay below-market rent and often gives technical guidance and other support to help them get started.
Constellation Ventures and the Psilos Group will each put up $500,000 in cash, and their respective chiefs, Clifford Friedman and Albert Waxman, will be managing partners of the new venture, called the New York Telemedia Accelerator.
The Investment Fund, in its first investment in an incubator, is providing another $500,000 in cash and a $2.5 million line of credit. The fund is also looking at several other proposals for incubators in other fields, and talking to several other CUNY colleges about possible partnerships, said Kathryn Wylde, president and chief executive of the fund.
Ms. Wylde said the fund hopes that the Telemedia Accelerator will help keep the television industry in New York and create opportunities for minority and poor students. "The fact that B.M.C.C. is a community college is meaningful to us, since they have a very diverse population," she said.
The college hopes that some of its faculty members will consult with the start-up companies in the incubator, and that some of its 17,000 students will get jobs or internships, said Antonio Perez, the college's president.
The college recently established an associate's degree in multimedia programming and design, and is sponsoring five student internships at the incubator with a $25,000 grant from the May and Samuel Rudin Foundation. (The Rudin family is also an investor in the New York City Investment Fund.)
"To the extent that students can interact with these companies, they will learn what a new industry will be like in the 21st century," said Dr. Waxman of the Psilos Group. Dr. Waxman is a City College graduate who went on to found two companies.
The venture will pay the college a below-market rent of $10 a square foot, about $200,000 a year, and will also pay to renovate the 20,000 square feet of space. In return, the community college will be given a 5 percent interest in the project, and would become vested over five years.
That equity stake has the college's president thinking big. "Let's say one of the companies becomes successful like Microsoft and we make a lot of money," Mr. Perez said. "We could be the only community college in the country not to have to charge tuition."
