HEADLINE: Study Finds Big Jump in Computer-Related Employment

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
Without a lot of hype -- or government help -- the computer-software industry has been booming in New York City, where the number of jobs at software firms more than doubled from 1992 to 1997, according to a report released yesterday by Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller.
The boom represents a sharp rebound from the early 1990's, when computer jobs in the city grew far more slowly than in the nation as a whole. But even with almost 30,000 jobs in the software industry, New York City still ranks only sixth in the nation in terms of the number of software jobs, below not only Silicon Valley in California, but also Boston, Los Angeles, Dallas and Seattle, the report says. 
 The report focuses not on the artists and advertising people who make up the bulk of the employees of "Silicon Alley," but on computer people in the city, including the more hard-core types who might, for example, write codes or create systems for trading stocks. The sorts of companies involved range from tiny one- or two-person operations to Information Builders, which makes business software and employs 900 people in the city.
At a news conference yesterday, Mr. Hevesi attributed some of the growth in the software business to what he called "the shiny city," with its lower crime rates and more business-friendly government.
But he warned that there are still major obstacles to further growth, including the city's tax rates, which he said are higher than those of other cities with software businesses. He said he planned to meet this morning with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to discuss cutting some of those taxes, including those on electricity and telecommunications, which weigh heavily on high-technology businesses.
In fact, the city has just started to use economic incentives to keep software and Internet companies from moving to less expensive areas. In February, the city agreed to provide breaks on electricity costs and other incentives to Doubleclick, a fast-growing Internet advertising agency with two-thirds of its 600 employees in the city, said Kevin O'Connor, the young company's chief executive.
There is a lot of competition among governments in the region and across the country to attract software companies, said Bruce Bernstein, a software developer who is president of the New York Software Industry Association. He said the city is vulnerable to poaching in part because of the high rents, which drive out growing businesses.
The report recommends setting up a government office, like the one that exists for the film industry, to help high-technology businesses. Such an office could help firms find low-cost space in which to do business, and encourage cooperation among the city's educational institutions, which in other cities have been important incubators of technology companies.
The report comes as the city's economy is as strong as it has been in a decade, and when the private sector has finally regained the 360,000 jobs it lost in the recession of the early 1990's. But some government officials and civic watchdogs have become increasingly concerned that the city's economy -- and its tax revenues -- have become too dependent on the volatile securities industry.
"If you depend on Wall Street, you're going to have some disappointment," Mr. Hevesi said. "If the stock market corrects when the Dow Jones industrial average is at 10,000, we'll be fine. If it corrects at 6,000, we're in big trouble."
Software jobs have not paid as well as Wall Street jobs -- but they come closer than those in any other industry in the city, according to the report. In 1997, the average wage in the software business was $69,250; in financial businesses, the average was $106,040.
But for those in the software business, there is clearly a disadvantage to working in New York. New York's computer-services workers ranked fourth in earnings among their peers in 15 big cities, according to the report, but when their salaries were adjusted for the city's higher costs of living, they ranked 14th.
But those numbers date from 1996, before a clutch of the city's Internet firms sold their shares on Wall Street and made their employees millionaires. And that has made a big impression on young people in the city, said Ken Perlin, director of New York University's Center for Advanced Technology.
Professor Perlin, who teaches a course for undergraduates on computer graphics, recently asked his students how many were involved in start-up Internet companies. More than half of the 55 students raised their hands, he said.
"Every year, some of the students I know of go on and become millionaires," he said. "To me, this is a big sea change. Even undergraduates are saying, 'I'm going to stay here in New York.' "

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Keeping Ethnic Tension From Turning Violent

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG

 BODY:
If the world is permitted any nostalgia for Communism, let it note that alongside the many horrors was the virtue of a relative measure of ethnic peace. It is often so with empires -- and when they fall, the ethnic, religious and nationalist conflicts they smothered with their harsh repression can erupt. The fall of Communism, and the end of American and Soviet sponsorship of political wars in the third world, have made these ethnic conflicts into the face of war today, exemplified by the former Yugoslavia.
But not every nation with a tense mix of ethnicities has slipped into violence. Romania and Hungary, two nations that border Yugoslavia, are trying to manage conflicts surrounding the Hungarian minority in Romania peacefully. The same is true with the Hungarian minority living in Slovakia. Many former Soviet nations are arriving at democratic ways to deal with the large Russian populations in their midst. Latvia, for example, has now agreed to remove most barriers to citizenship for the one-third of its residents who are ethnic Russians. And while several ethnic enclaves of the former Soviet Union, like Chechnya and the ethnic Armenian region of Nagorno-Karabakh, have fought separatist wars, many other enclaves have not. 
 History was one thing that made Yugoslavia different. In the Balkans, the ebb and flow of empires over the centuries -- Ottoman, Austro-Hungarian and others -- left a long cycle of killings and revenge. The identity of each ethnic group, particularly the Serbs, was largely shaped by memories of victimization, military defeat and humiliation, leaving people susceptible to hate propaganda. This is not just ancient history, as World War II saw mass killings of Serbs at the hands of Croats and, to a far lesser extent, Muslims.
Yet the Yugoslavia that emerged from the war was a multi-ethnic state, with high rates of intermarriage. The country's strongman, Tito, who was half-Croat and half-Slovene, permitted no public discussion of ethnic tensions. Communist ideology promoted universalism. Class, not ethnicity, mattered. "Brotherhood and Unity" was Tito's slogan. He balanced the demands of various ethnic groups, and used Yugoslavs' consciousness of their victimhood to unite them as a small country standing up to Stalin. He also used repression, clamping down on various outbreaks of Serbian, Croatian and Albanian nationalism and purging or jailing the leading proponents.
The positive side of Tito's control was that people felt secure that they would not become ethnic victims. But after his death in 1980, the rules changed. Yugoslavia was governed by a rotating presidency, and there was constant uncertainty about whether the next ruler would have a particular ethnic tilt. The new leaders also permitted Serbs, always the largest and most powerful group, to express their grievances in public.
The single most important factor in Yugoslavia's violence, however, was the emergence of Slobodan Milosevic, a leader willing to destroy his country to keep himself in power. Ethnic conflicts do not explode on their own. They are exploited by ruthless leaders who want power, land or treasure.
The rise of Mr. Milosevic threatened non-Serb minorities such as Croats and Bosnian Muslims, who then seceded from Yugoslavia. But since the new nations had Serbian minorities, Serbs grew nervous, allowing Mr. Milosevic to use propaganda to exploit their fears and turn them into killers.
Mr. Milosevic had the tools to do this, because Yugoslavia never shook off its Communist system. The same powerful and well-controlled structures Tito used to repress nationalism -- the party, Interior Ministry, army and media -- were intact and available for Mr. Milosevic to employ in the service of hate.
Other ethnically mixed nations of the former Communist world have been more fortunate. Few other ethnic groups in the region can match the Serbs for their sense of humiliation and victimization -- sentiments that unscrupulous leaders can turn into hate. The Hungarians in Slovakia and Romania, for instance, worry about agricultural policy and establishing a university in their language. They do not worry about mass killing.
Political factors also matter. While Mr. Milosevic promised Serbs a better life through ethnic cleansing, the leaders of Hungary, Romania and Slovakia held out the promise of joining Europe. These leaders were essentially told that they had no chance of NATO or European Union membership until they solved their ethnic problems. Similar statements helped persuade governments of the Baltic States to treat their Russian minorities more justly. It is not only the heavy hand of imperial rule that can impose ethnic cooperation. In most circumstances, the desire for democracy and economic growth can do the same.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Technology Shares Climb As Stock Rally Continues
Strong profit reports helped fuel a rally in stocks as technology and consumer issues appeared to regain the leadership they long enjoyed. Stocks tied to the business cycle, meanwhile, mostly paused after their recent jumps.
The Nasdaq composite index posted a gain of 79.44 points, or 3.3 percent, to 2,489.08. Combined with Tuesday's rebound, that wiped out Monday's 5.56 percent slide. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 132.87 points, to 10,581.42, a record. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased by 29.95 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,336.12. C10. 

Breaking an Internet Monopoly
America Online was one of five companies chosen to compete with a Government-backed monopoly in the lucrative business of assigning Internet domains. The surprising choice introduced a seemingly formidable competitor to the business and prompted questions about whether smaller companies would ever effectively compete. C2.
 
Borders Chief Resigns Abruptly
Just a little more than five months after boasting about hiring Philip M. Pfeffer, a longtime book industry executive, as its chief executive, Borders Group unceremoniously announced his abrupt departure. The company, the second-largest bookseller in the nation after Barnes & Noble, also said that its first-quarter earnings would be 4 to 5 cents a share, lower than analysts' estimates of 7 cents. C4.
 
Rubin Offers Plan to Avoid Risk
Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin outlined a modest five-point American plan for warding off the kind of financial crisis that rocked three continents over the last two years. But his proposals, which President Clinton endorsed on Tuesday, fell well short of creating the new "global financial architecture" that many policy makers debated in the heat of the crisis in emerging markets last fall. C4.
 
Compaq Posts Dismal Earnings
Confirming the bad news that led to the ouster of its chief executive this week, Compaq Computer announced that it earned half of what analysts had expected only two weeks ago. The company's chairman and acting chief executive called the results unacceptable but declined to provide much information to illuminate the sources of Compaq's problems or to outline its path back to financial health. C6.

The charges echo the Federal fraud charges filed against Mr. Hoke last week. C22.
 
A Pleasant Economic Conundrum
Economists find themselves without an explanation of a felicitous combination that was supposed to be impossible: higher productivity with lower unemployment and inflation. Michael M. Weinstein: Economic Scene. C2.
 
Ban Is Threatened on U.S. Beef
The European Union's executive agency threatened to ban beef imports from the United States, intensifying a long-running feud over beef from hormone-treated cattle. C8.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
As agencies hold their annual conference, the accentuation is very much on the positive.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE sunny skies over Madison Avenue, metaphorically speaking, are likely to extend to northern Florida at the 81st annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
The meeting, which began yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Amelia Island, brings together top executives of an industry that is enjoying what is likely to be a sixth consecutive year of robust growth. And for the largest agencies, whose executives are most visible at such conferences -- from the meeting rooms to the golf courses to the bars -- business has rarely been better. 
 The optimistic mood is reflected in attendance for the event, which continues through Saturday: executives from member agencies are expected to turn out at the highest rate since 1990, the last year before a wrenching recession took hold.
When times are tough, members hunker down at home, passing up stays at ritzy hotels. When their mood is ebullient, $255 a night at a "special conference rate," as described in the meeting brochure, is not too costly an expense.
Because this could well be "a record year for the industry by any measure," said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the association, which is known as the Four A's, "everybody's going to this meeting in very high spirits."
As a result, he added in an interview before the meeting began, he planned to devote his annual speech opening the general session this morning to "12 things to celebrate." By comparison, Mr. Drake's opening speech last year centered on concerns that he thought needed to be addressed.
Two issues that bothered association members in 1998 seem less pressing. One was the encroachment of management consultants into the realm of brand-building services offered by agencies.
"Last year, we seemed to be a little more up in arms about being under attack from consultants," said Patrick J. McGrath, the 1998-99 chairman of the association who is president and chief executive at Jordan McGrath Case & Partners/Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising.
"But now, rather than worrying," he added, "the smart thing seems to be to reassert what we do, how we do things that no consultant can do."
Mr. McGrath said that he would describe one way to accomplish that in a speech scheduled for this morning. He plans to outline the efforts of a group formed at the 1998 meeting to produce "The Chairman's Initiative," a series of taped interviews with "C.E.O.'s of major corporations, talking about how important advertising agencies have been to their brands and businesses."
Mr. McGrath said he would show segments of the initial tapes, featuring John Pepper, chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company, who is speaking at the meeting, and Herbert D. Kelleher, chairman, president and chief executive of the Southwest Airlines Company.
Four additional executives have agreed to be interviewed for the series, Mr. McGrath said: Robert A. Eckert, president and chief executive of the Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Companies; Alan G. Hassenfeld, chairman and chief executive of Hasbro Inc.; Edward B. Rust Jr., chairman, president and chief executive of the State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, and Stephen W. Sanger, chairman and chief executive of General Mills Inc.
The other issue that bothered members last year involved a surprise move by the Association of National Advertisers, the trade organization that represents marketers, to invite agencies to join. That initiative was announced at the annual conference of the advertiser association in October, with little or no consultation with officials of the Four A's.
"That triggered a decision point for advertising agencies, to affirm or deny whether we need an industry association," said Shelly Lazarus, the 1998-99 chairwoman of the Four A's, who is chairwoman and chief executive at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of WPP Group P.L.C.
"The answer was a resounding yes," said Ms. Lazarus, who favors agency membership in the advertiser association, followed by "a certain searching for a reaffirmation of what is valuable to our members."
"That makes some people nervous," she added, "but I think it's healthy."
Ms. Lazarus, who is to speak on Saturday, said she intended to discuss the need for agencies "to know how to work their magic through every point of contact, every way of reaching consumers, or lose our appeal to clients."
Another topic on her agenda, she said, was the "opportunity for getting the talent we need for the future" by taking advantage of the "fascination with the new media" among young potential employees.
"If we're viewed as being at the center of trying to figure out a whole new world of communications, that would be extremely compelling to them," Ms. Lazarus said. "But if we're seen as 'the place to call if you want a television commercial,' we will not be particularly interesting to future talent -- or to clients."
At a business session that opened the meeting -- formally known as the 1999 management conference and annual meeting -- Ms. Lazarus was elected chairwoman of the Four A's for 1999-2000.
Also, Phil Dusenberry, chairman of BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, was elected vice chairman for 1999-2000. And John Emmerling, chairman and chief creative officer at Emmerling Post in New York, was elected secretary and treasurer for 1999-2000.
While attendees may be beaming over the bright forecasts for the industry, the actual weather is of some concern. That is because Amelia Island was the site of a previous conference that became synonymous with disastrous weather among the denizens of Madison Avenue.
In October 1996, the marketers' association held its annual conference at the Ritz-Carlton during a rare Florida northeaster that lasted throughout the entire event. Many attendees, forced inside and deprived of their patio cocktails and sports tournaments, developed cabin fever and fled. The pouring rain and gale-force winds did not relent until the conference ended.
"Florida and I are not a good combination," Ms. Lazarus said when reminded of the incident. "Whenever I go, it really rains."
Mr. Drake called the 1996 conference "the worst four days of my life."
"But I have my fingers crossed," he said. "I figure the A.N.A. had all the bad luck and the Four A's is due for some good luck."
Mr. McGrath agreed.
His weather forecast? "Bring your shorts."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Dow Jones Annual Meeting Used as Forum for a Protest

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
Spearheaded by two Wall Street Journal reporters who just won the Pulitzer Prize, about 100 employees told the annual stockholders meeting of Dow Jones & Company yesterday that proposed cuts in pension benefits for more than half of the company's 8,300 employees are sapping loyalty and could provoke a strike.
Bob Davis, the White House reporter of one of the two top-selling newspapers in the country, told the gathering on the 106th floor of the World Trade Center that he wanted "to alert the Dow Jones shareholders to the anger and resentment in the newsroom over management's decision to slash our retirement benefits." 
 Mr. Davis, one of a six-member team that won the 1999 Pulitzer Prize for international reporting last week, added, "I believe workers would rather strike than accept management's terms."
Through January, Dow Jones each year has paid 15 percent of the salaries of vested employees into a retirement account. But shortly after this year's contribution was deposited, Peter R. Kann, the chairman and chief executive of the company, said that the 15 percent payments -- technically designated as profit sharing -- could not be sustained when the company's profits had lagged for several years running.
At the moment, the company is negotiating a new pension arrangement with the Independent Association of Publishers' Employees. The union numbers 2,400 Dow Jones employees among its members and, since January 1997, has been an affiliate of the Communications Workers of America.
The initial Dow Jones proposal, according to both the union and company executives, would provide employees with a 5 percent benefit from company funds. In addition, employees could contribute up to 6 percent of their salaries toward a pension, with the company matching 50 percent of the employees' contribution.
That proposal, last year, would have cost the company $21 million, as opposed to the $40 million it actually paid to about 5,500 company employees.
Mr. Davis's allusion to a strike was not echoed by any of the negotiators for the union; indeed, as long as the contract remains in effect, employees are barred from such an action.
Dow Jones's annual meeting has not been devoid of protests before, but participants in yesterday's protest said it was unusual for prominent Journal reporters to take the lead in such an action.
Mr. Kann's opening speech to shareholders alluded to the complaints even before they were made. Looking out at dozens of his employees sitting among the audience of investors, he said, "The company is determined to make sure that the compensation packages we offer employees remain fully competitive." The company's opening offer, he said, "would already equate with what our competitors do, on average."
Steve Liesman, another reporter on the Pulitzer-Prize winning international reporting team, followed Mr. Davis to the microphone and predicted there would be a potential loss of shareholder value if journalists brought less commitment to their work. "You can't punch it into a spreadsheet," he said, "but it's there."
In response, Mr. Kann said, "I do understand the depth of feeling on this," although he added, "I do not think this is a productive forum for negotiating this issue."
The poor performance of the company's market information business, Telerate, depressed earnings for several years before Dow Jones sold Telerate to Bridge Information Systems. Dow Jones had a net loss of $802 million in 1997 and net income of just $8.4 million in 1998.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Earnings Prove Happy Surprise For Wall Street

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
First-quarter earnings reports are pouring in, and they are pleasing. Citigroup beat Wall Street estimates by 16 percent. I.B.M. had a robust quarter. Boeing pleasantly surprised. International Paper's earnings fell less than expected while its executives pointed to rising paper prices and returning demand in Asia.
Even Exxon, which experienced a sharp drop in earnings because of plummeting oil prices in January and February, beat analyst estimates by a penny. Similarly, Coca-Cola's revenues and profits did not fall as much as had been feared, giving its stock a lift yesterday. 
 Positive earnings surprises are running higher than the historical average, with about half the 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's index of large companies reporting, according to I.B.E.S. International and the First Call Corporation, which track earnings projections and results.
If the trend continues, earnings this quarter could grow 9 percent to 10 percent, according to First Call. That pace would make the quarter the first with above-average earnings growth since the end of 1997.
But even more significant is the steady rise in earnings forecasts for all of 1999 by Wall Street strategists.
Without doubt, the overall economic outlook has improved both in the United States and abroad. There are signs of a turnaround in Asia, battered since the devaluation of the Thai baht in 1997. European central bankers have cut interest rates to spark growth. Investors are betting again on emerging markets, and Brazil seems to be getting its problems under control just months after it devalued its currency.
What's more, higher earnings are looming for the oil industry since oil prices have risen sharply in recent weeks. And better results than expected last quarter for American industries, like paper, and for cyclical companies that thrive when the economy is strong are causing financial analysts to reassess.
The brightening picture is encouraging investors to take a longer view and providing signs of support for the stock market in the months ahead. And the overall rise in expectations is distracting from some of the big disappointments, like the earnings shortfall at Compaq Computer and Intel's weak first-quarter sales.
In just five months, Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, has moved from forecasting a 5 percent decline in operating earnings for the S.& P. 500 in 1999 to an increase of 8.5 percent. Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan, is now predicting an 8 percent jump. Stronger-than-expected growth at home and abroad caused him to jettison his measly forecast of 2 percent earnings growth last fall.
And corporate profits for 2000 are looking good, a fact that should buoy investors, who bet in large part on what a company is expected to earn in the years ahead. In fact, Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwomen of the investment policy committee at Goldman Sachs & Company, puts earnings growth next year at 8 percent, slightly stronger than this year's upwardly revised 7 percent.
All this rosy talk has obscured the stock market plunge of last fall and the third quarter's decline in operating earnings, the first quarterly decline since 1991.
But as the selloff early this week in growth and technology stocks indicates, the question remains whether these improved earnings projections are enough to support the high cost of stocks. I.B.E.S., which gauges the attractiveness of stocks based on corporate earnings and interest rates, shows stocks at their highest valuation since 1987.
Even with higher earnings, "the market will still be too expensive," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. He estimates that the S.& P. 500 index is overvalued by about 26 percent, a level that in the past has signaled a stock market correction. Another cautionary note may be seen in the declines in the shares of Exxon and Microsoft yesterday even though both companies reported numbers that were better than expected.
Still, confidence begets confidence. An improved earnings outlook may encourage investors to ignore warning signs, as they have in the past. The Leuthold Group's major trend index for the stock market has blinked red since June 1998, with a brief exception from Nov. 9, 1998, to Feb. 8, 1999, when the stock market was recovering from last fall's 19 percent drop in the Dow Jones industrial average and the 30 percent plunge in the Nasdaq composite index from its high.
And if the recent investor moves out of technology and growth stocks result in a broadening rally in the stock market, some strategists will become more confident about the outlook, despite record high valuations.
Thomas McManus, the equity strategist at NationsBanc Montgomery Securities, predicts that a good first quarter will just spur analysts to increase their earnings expectations more for the rest of the year.
The actual rate of earnings growth is not that important, he said. Instead, it's the ratio of positive surprises to negative surprises that matters, he said, "because a surprise in earnings is what drives analysts to revise their expectations upward and that, in turn, can help drive the stock higher."
According to First Call, the earnings estimates for the paper and aluminum industries have already been revised upward. International Paper is now expected to report 1999 earnings of $1.03 a share, up 23 percent from the estimate before the company released its first-quarter earnings.
Mr. McManus and Mr. Cliggott of J. P. Morgan also tend to ignore the overall earnings growth for the S.& P. 500. They consider it misleading because the index is weighted in favor of big names, like Microsoft, General Electric and Exxon. And the earnings performance of these few companies can overshadow the general trend.
For example, overall S.& P. reported earnings rose 9.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1998 from a year earlier. But when calculating the average by giving each company the same weighting, earnings fell 2.5 percent, according to Bloomberg News, indicating that many more companies had earnings declines. (Reported earnings are the actual profits reported. Operating earnings, which most market strategists and analysts use, strip out one-time charges and other factors that may distort the longer-term trend in a company's earnings.)
So far this year, more companies are healthier financially, according to Bloomberg. Reported earnings for the first quarter are up 5.5 percent when weighting each company in the S.& P. equally and 17.4 percent when favoring the returns from the big stocks.
The one caveat, of course, is that the improving earnings picture is based on an economy that keeps humming. If growth is so strong that inflationary pressures build, the Federal Reserve may have to rein in the economy by raising short-term interest rates, a move that almost always punishes stocks.
Mitchell J. Held, the co-manager of United States economics at Salomon Smith Barney, is not worried about the Fed raising rates this year. But he says a rate increase could come next year. And if it does, he said, "that is when the market gets hit, and the higher the valuation, the sharper the fall."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Unemployment's natural rate may have a mind of its own.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein

 BODY:
ECONOMISTS are compulsive naysayers -- professionally dedicated to tweaking anyone naive enough to overlook the fact that good things have a cost and not all good things are affordable or possible. This spinach-eating mentality partly explains why they failed to predict the relentless good news in the 1990's, during which the growth rate of productivity rose and unemployment and inflation rates fell by half.
That felicitous combination was supposed to be impossible. Driving unemployment down was thought to drive inflation up, and economists ridiculed anyone, especially politicians, who denied the vicious trade-off. By the end of the decade, economists find themselves without an explanation of high productivity or low unemployment, the keys to economic prosperity. 
 A discipline in crisis? Not really. Just because economists, like physicists, do not have a Theory of Everything, that doesn't mean they cannot explain a lot about what has happened in the 1990's -- such as the increasing concentration on unemployment rolls of people who are permanently out of work.
Economies change, with academic theories following close behind. In the 1930's, Keynes taught the profession that Government could spend its way out of a recession. True enough, but the sense that economists could manage endless prosperity did not survive the rising inflation of the 1960's wartime economy. Tight labor markets led to rising wages, which, in turn, led to higher prices. Paul Samuelson and Robert Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology taught the profession the logic of the Phillips curve, the inescapable trade-off between unemployment and inflation.
But even that formulation proved overly optimistic. Inflation in the economy, propelled by loose monetary policy, did not just jump to a higher level and stay there. Inflation accelerated, rising to higher rates each year. Economists began to preach a tougher message. There was, alas, no permanent trade-off between inflation and unemployment. If government tried to drive unemployment below its so-called natural rate, it would accelerate inflation, threatening monetary stability and eventually forcing the Federal Reserve to crack down. Enter Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman who broke the back of the 1970's inflation spiral by throwing the economy in deep recession (and throwing President Carter out of office).
Economists forever warn against advice by Pollyannas who urge the Fed to stimulate and then stimulate some more. The natural rate dictates how far the Fed could go in generating jobs. By the end of the 1980's, some economists thought the natural rate hovered around 7 percent. Others argued for 6 or 6.5 percent. Liberals hoped for 5 percent. Almost no one thought it could be any lower.
Until now. Last year joblessness fell to 4.5 percent. Some economists called on the Fed to tighten monetary policy to ward off inflation before it could take hold. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, chose instead to wait for inflation to rise before he cracked down. It did not, so he did not.
Today, unemployment is under 4.5 percent and inflation is falling. Something startling changed from the 1980's. But exactly what?
Prof. Robert J. Gordon of Northwestern University attributes much of the favorable inflation data to special events of no long-term significance -- falling food, oil, import and medical costs.
Profs. Alan Krueger and Robert Shimer of Princeton and Lawrence Katz of Harvard estimate that the natural rate probably fell by about one percentage point, in part because of the aging and growing stability of the labor force and the rising use of temporary workers by employers.
The largely unnoticed lesson of the Katz-Krueger data is that almost the entire drop in unemployment, from around 9 percent early in the decade to under 4.5 percent now, is from the ranks of the short-term unemployed. Students, spouses and laid-off workers find jobs quickly. Those who remain unemployed are people who have a hard time finding work at all, presumably because they have a physical or mental limitation.
This finding colors policy responses. Temporarily unemployed people need job-search assistance. The economically disadvantaged need expensive training and government subsidies.
Professors Solow and Krueger, under the auspices of the Russell Sage Foundation and the Century Foundation, are putting together a team of economists to pursue the unanswered questions. How low is the sustainable rate of unemployment, and can monetary and fiscal policies maintain it or push it even lower?
As for monetary policy, says Prof. Robert Hall of Stanford, "the 1990's have taught central bankers here and abroad that the best policy is to set clear targets for inflation and stick by them." The task is hard because monetary policy operates with long lags. That means the Fed must make predictions about the state of the economy a year into the future. One, but hardly the only, factor in that prediction is where the Fed thinks the unemployment rate is relative to the natural rate.
But with or without knowledge of the elusive natural rate, the Fed can and does make continual assessment of inflationary pressures. Professor Hall argues that if the Fed convinces traders in financial markets that inflation will be low and steady, the economy will gravitate toward the lowest possible unemployment rate.
Smart policy, by this argument, reveals the natural rate. Smart policy does not, Professor Hall says, need prior knowledge of the natural rate. That may be the most optimistic spin on policy making since Keynes.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Accord Comes After Promise of No Meddling

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: ROME, April 21

 BODY:
Two of Europe's largest telecommunications companies, Telecom Italia S.p.A. and Deutsche Telekom A.G., reached a formal agreement tonight to merge in a share swap valued at nearly $82 billion after the Italians obtained assurances that Germany would not interfere in the new combined company's operations.
The merger of the two former state-owned monopolies, which still faces enormous obstacles, would be the biggest ever in Europe and the second-biggest in history behind the $84 billion Exxon-Mobil merger announced last year. 
 The board of Telecom Italia approved the deal after the German Government, which still controls 72 percent of Deutsche Telekom's shares, satisfied demands by Telecom Italia and offered written assurance that it would not seek to influence the new combination's business strategy and management.
The merger, expected since Monday, would be the most far-reaching in a recent wave of giant European combinations, as companies maneuver to meet the challenges of globalization and opening European economies.
Details of the merger were to be announced at a news conference on Thursday in London.
The combined company would be the second-largest telecommunications business in the world, with revenue of $63 billion surpassed only by the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. It would create the world's largest local phone service provider and one of the biggest mobile phone companies. It would have roughly 240,000 employees and a strong presence in Europe, Asia and Latin America, though not in the United States.
"Scale is the main advantage," said James Thomas, a telecommunications consultant with Arthur Andersen in London. "In principle, it makes sense. It follows the rules of consolidation."
The merger is subject to the approval of shareholders and of Italian, German and European Union regulators. The companies said they would also seek Securities and Exchange Commission approval in the United States, which is required because the companies intend to list shares in the American stock market.
The German and Italian Governments are likely to approve, seeing the deal as necessary in the face of liberalizing telecommunications markets and global competition.
Telecom Italia, in a statement, said the German and Italian companies "intend to integrate their activities giving life to the world's second-largest telecommunication group."
The deal was sought earlier this year be Telecom Italia's tough new chief executive, Franco Bernabe, essentially as a defensive strategy to thwart a $65 billion hostile bid for Telecom Italia by its main domestic rival, Olivetti S.p.A.
Olivetti officials made clear today that they would continue their bid and would seek approval from Italian securities regulators on Thursday for documents to solicit shareholders.
Olivetti has bid 11.50 euros ($12.25) a share in securities and cash for Telecom Italia, versus securities valued at 12.02 euros a share for Telecom Italia in the deal with Deutsche Telekom. But Olivetti officials are hoping that the complexities of the rival bid, its size and regulatory uncertainties will sway investors toward Olivetti.
Telecom Italia's board had tentatively approved the deal on Tuesday night after two days of meetings but made final agreement contingent on a pledge by the German Government, which would control about 45 percent of the combined company, to limit its voting rights. Telecom Italia was taken public last year, though the Italian Government retains a 3.4 percent share.
The Italian demand appeared to have been met earlier today when Germany's Finance Minister, Hans Eichel, in a letter to the Italian Treasury, which controls Rome's stake, expressed support for the merger and said it was the German Government's policy not to interfere in how Deutsche Telekom was run.
That policy, he said, would also apply to the merged company.
Mr. Eichel said Germany intended to proceed with a previously planned sale of Deutsche Telekom shares, though only at a pace that would not upset equity markets.
Telecom Italia said the deal involved an exchange of stock that would give Deutsche Telekom shareholders a share of the combined company for each share they now own, for 57 percent of the total. For Telecom Italia, the exchange ratio is 1 new share for 3 ordinary shares or 5.61 nonvoting shares.
If 90 percent of shareholders accept, the terms are sweetened slightly to a ratio of 1 new share for every 2.9 ordinary Telecom Italia shares,5.5 nonvoting shares or 0.9 Deutsche Telekom share.
Based on Deutsche Telekom's closing price of 36.08 euros today, the deal values Telecom Italia's combined 5.26 billion ordinary shares and 2.17 billion nonvoting shares at $81.8 billion.
The value of the deal does not include the 40 percent of Telecom Italia's mobile phone subsidiary that the Italian company does not own. If the merged company were to buy that as well, the value of the deal would rise substantially.
The shares of the new company would be quoted in Frankfurt, Milan and New York.
Telecom Italia shares have been suspended most of the week on the Milan exchange pending news of the merger, but the company's American depository rights traded on Wall Street have been hurt on investor skepticism that such a deal would work.
Deutsche Telekom has likewise suffered; its price closed down 1.4 percent in Frankfurt today.
The deal will bring together two of Europe's toughest executives. Mr. Bernabe, 50, took over Telecom Italia in a management shake-up late last year, after turning around the big Italian energy group, Eni. Under the merger pact, he would be one of two joint chief executives with Ron Sommer, the 49-year-old Deutsche Telekom chief. Mr. Sommer has been advised by Goldman, Sachs; Telecom Italia's advisers include J. P. Morgan and the Credit Suisse First Boston unit of Credit Suisse Group.
The merger plan, which stresses equality to satisfy Italian political sentiments, despite Deutsche Telekom's larger size, foresees a German corporation with a 10-member supervisory board, to set company policy and appoint management, evenly split among Italian and German representatives. The board's chairman will alternate each year between Germany and Italy.
If it proceeds, and full approval could take months, the deal would have resounding effects through the industry. It was unclear what name the company will bear, though German newspapers have taken to calling it "Telecom Transalpina."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 37; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1112 words

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Both Founder Of a Nation And Designer

BYLINE: By Wendy Moonan 

 BODY:
In New York, George Washington is more than a household name. Streets, avenues, a park, two bridges and a magnificent marble triumphal arch all bear his name. And this year, the city is marking the bicentennial of his death with exhibitions, books and lectures. New York loves George Washington.
But the feeling was not necessarily reciprocal. As indicated in "Washington's New York," an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York that runs through July 4, New York was a tough town for Washington. He suffered his greatest military defeat in the Revolutionary War here, and in 1783, when the British finally evacuated the city, he promptly left; he gave his famous farewell address to his officers at Samuel Fraunces's tavern and took a ferry to New Jersey, en route to Annapolis to resign his commission. 
 He returned to the city as President in 1789, because New York was the first capital of the United States. That year he contracted what was then called anthrax (an abscess that took three months to heal), and in 1790 he caught pneumonia. In August of that year he left New York, never to return.
As First Lady, Martha Washington held an open house on Friday evenings at the first Presidential mansion, on lower Broadway near Bowling Green, when she and, often, the President would entertain visitors with ice cream and lemonade. The museum show includes a misspelled letter she wrote in October 1789 in which she complained, "I lead a very dull life hear and know nothing that passes in the town."
She continued: "Indeed I think I am more like a state prisoner than anything else. There is certain bounds set for me which I must not depart from -- and as I cannot doe as I like I am obstinate and stay at home a great deal."
"Washington's heart was in Virginia," said Dr. Deborah Dependahl Waters, the curator of decorative arts and manuscripts at the museum, who organized the show.
Washington's spiritual home was always Mount Vernon. And a new book by Allan Greenberg, an architect and architectural historian, explores Washington's passion for his house and analyzes the architecture and landscape of Mount Vernon as one might study a great American antique.
The book, "George Washington Architect," is to be published in June by Andreas Papadakis. (Mr. Greenberg will lecture on his theme as a benefit for the Sir John Soane's Museum Foundation on May 11 in New York. Tickets are $75; reservations: (212) 258-2635.)
"Mount Vernon was Washington's lifelong preoccupation," Mr. Greenberg said in an interview. "The bulk of his correspondence deals with the farm."
In his book, Mr. Greenberg quotes Washington's detailed letters of instruction to his estate managers throughout the Revolutionary War, the Constitutional Convention and his first term of office.
"It is clear from Washington's voluminous correspondence that from the time he took possession of Mount Vernon until his death 45 years later," in 1799, "the condition of the house and surrounding farms was always in the forefront of his mind," Mr. Greenberg writes. "His letters reveal his passionate preoccupation with every aspect of daily life."
In studying Mount Vernon, Mr. Greenberg, who has taught at Yale University's Schools of Architecture and of Law, the University of Pennsylvania and the Department of Historic Preservation at Columbia University, considered form, plan, design and execution.
He argues that Washington deliberately designed Mount Vernon to be asymmetrical in plan and elevation, inside and out. None of the four facades of the estate is symmetrical. The doors and windows, even the cupola, are slightly off center. Similarly, the interior elevations are asymmetrical.
"The circulation through the rooms is deliberately informal," Mr. Greenberg said. "None of the doors line up with each other."
Mr. Greenberg said Washington considered asymmetry "a design theme that unifies the house." As he explained: "Bringing the informality of a vernacular farmhouse into a great mansion was very unusual. Washington was preoccupied with asymmetry in a way that has become important as a model for Americans who built houses in the 19th and 20th centuries."
Indeed, in Mr. Greenberg's view, these designs showed Washington's desire, as an amateur architect, to give the house a distinctly American style. He postulates that Washington's contribution to American architecture, landscape architecture and city planning rivals that of Thomas Jefferson, who is usually seen as the President who had the most influence on American architecture.
When Washington inherited Mount Vernon from the widow of his half-brother Lawrence, it was 1,280 square feet, with four rooms flanking a center hall.
He added two floors and extensions on either side: a large dining room to the north and a study to the south. He put on the 90-foot-long porch overlooking the majestic Potomac River and two open arcades to link the house to the dependencies on either side.
By the time he was finished, the house and outbuildings totaled nearly 20,000 square feet. As Mr. Greenberg writes, "Between 1754, when he first leased Mount Vernon, and his death in 1799, Washington increased the size of the estate from 2,126 acres to more than 8,000 acres, or 12.5 square miles."
He experimented with crops of alfalfa, clover, rye, hops, wheat and vegetables; put in orchards, and raised beef cattle, dairy cows, hogs, sheep, various fowl and horses.
"He considered economic self-sufficiency to be the basis of freedom and prosperity," Mr. Greenberg writes.
The two-story porch, in particular, was a Washington invention.
"It was the first of its kind in domestic architecture that we know of -- anywhere," Mr. Greenberg said. "Before, such a portico would have only been seen on a public building like the Pantheon. At Mount Vernon, the columns are square and paneled, which tells everyone they are wood. Of course, such porches later became the mark of the great Mississippi River plantations."
Mr. Greenberg also describes Washington's decorative elements at Mount Vernon. Instead of Greek gods, lyres, crossed weapons with shields or other symbols of glory, Washington enriched his ceilings with carved rakes and hoes and curling vine motifs.
"Carvers did not use such idiosyncratic themes in plaster decorations," Mr. Greenberg said. "Farm implements on the ceiling of a major house is very unusual."
The leader of the new republic seems to have been looking for an architecture appropriate to the new nation. How could he have predicted that nearly every suburban housing tract in America would have its own Mount Vernon 200 years later? Happy anniversary, George.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 34; Column 5; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 1341 words

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Kick Up Your Heels! Housework Can Be A Whole Lot of Fun

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG

 BODY:
Ralph Bartholomew Jr. united two important inventions of this century: the strobe light and the active American woman. He did not invent either of these but put them together in a winsome photographic way, with the active woman in her unmentionables yet. This ingenious combination is one aspect of Bartholomew's advertising photographs at the Keith De Lellis Gallery uptown.
The strobe, an ultra high-speed electronic flash that could stop such minute actions as a drop of falling milk splashing up in a corona, was invented in the 1930's by Harold Edgerton, an engineering instructor at M.I.T. By the mid 30's Edgerton had perfected a multi-flash technique that could capture every split-second stage in a golfer's swing within a single frame. He showed the world an infinite array of things it had never seen before. 
 As for the active woman, she had begun to step out in the late 19th century, when she occasionally donned bloomers or split skirts to ride a bicycle and scandalize the neighbors. After World War I short skirts, more women in the work force and new mores gave her new freedom, but fashion and photographers would not overly indulge her. Fashion, advertising and Hollywood still photographers preferred languid or static heroines; women could be shown standing with a tennis racket in hand but seldom racing to the net.
The first fashion picture to show what a fashion editor called "a typical American girl in action" was Martin Munkacsi's shot of a woman in a short cape running down a beach, published in Harper's Bazaar in 1933. A spate of fashion photographs of women dashing about in sports clothes followed, and not long after World War II women in fashion magazines and sometimes in ads took to waltzing, sashaying and leaping through the air as if that were the most natural thing in the world.
From the late 1930's to the early 50's Bartholomew (1907-85) was a major advertising photographer as well as a successful editorial and fashion photographer. He learned Edgerton's technique fairly early. In "Retail Fictions: The Commercial Photography of Ralph Bartholomew Jr.," the catalogue for a show of his work at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art last year, Tim B. Wride writes that Bartholomew initially designed and fabricated his own speed-light equipment because, the photographer said, "while some people are afraid of snakes, others have phobias about high places, I'm scared of long exposures."
For a 1939 ad for a household cleanser, he photographed a pretty housewife wearing an apron and moderately high heels and exuberantly leaping off the ground with a can of cleanser in one hand and a saucepan in the other, as happy housewives were no doubt wont to do in 1939. A couple of years later he photographed a woman in mid fall as she slipped on a carpet with an expression of horror worthy of Lucille Ball.
After the war Bartholomew put the multiple-flash technique to work in the service of Playtex underwear; in 1949 this ad campaign won him the top advertising award from the Art Directors Club. Six of the 42 pictures at De Lellis show your typical American girl in action in her bra, girdle and stockings, and a seventh shows her perfectly still from the back, clad only in girdle and shoes and holding a ball above her head as if she were the backside of Roy Lichtenstein's famous painting, copied from an ad, of a young woman on the beach holding up a ball.
In the multiple-strobe pictures the woman is repeated five or six times as she pursues her vigorous existence: bowling, throwing a ball from a kind of sling, climbing stairs, performing a ballet or merely leaping about.
In 1946 Bartholomew took a panoramic shot of a woman skipping rope at 26 almost infinitesimally different moments and printed it as a negative, an elaborately decorative image with a rope tracing elegant, black, calligraphic lines across the surface. This was several years before Edgerton himself took a panoramic picture of a woman skipping rope, but perhaps Edgerton didn't look at lingerie ads and had never seen Bartholomew's, and besides, his rope skipper was fully dressed.
Photographs of (absolutely still) women in corsets and bras had appeared in ads at least since the 1920's, but Bartholomew's pictures were earlier than the "I dreamed I was a lady ambassador," or sailed down the Nile or whatever, "in my Maidenform bra" ads that simultaneously made fun of lingerie advertising and raised the ante on eroticism in advertising. Bartholomew tried to keep it sweet and safe, partly through the realism of hiring ballet dancers rather than professional models, so the movements would be correct.
But the advertisements, meant to say how forgiving the undergarments were, were also advising women that they could be as energetic as they pleased and still be both beautiful and ladylike. Whether it was realistic to picture women bowling and executing jetees in girdles and stockings is another matter, though not altogether impossible.
At the time most proper women wore girdles, and even those as slim as models wore lightweight girdles like those in these pictures, partly to keep their stockings up, partly because God forbid they should jiggle. They were also keeping fashion history intact: one of the lingerie industry's major contributions to the reconfiguring of the female anatomy, along with the waist cincher and the Wonder Bra, was the girdle that guaranteed a monobuttock.
Eastman Kodak was another of Bartholomew's major clients, and for Kodak he created more standard pictures, single images made without strobe, of the happy families and hopelessly normal teen-agers that advertisers in the years right after the war were trying to sell America, which dearly hoped they were true. In his search for an authentic look, Bartholomew used young people who were not professional models.
Youngsters taking pictures of one another were a market Kodak was working hard to cultivate. In a booming economy, adolescents had some money to spend, and camera sales were a growing business. By the late 1940's photography was such a dominant mode of seeing and presentation that one art critic in 1948 complained that furniture was being designed to look good in photos, a style he dubbed "Kodak modern." As for people, selling permanent memories to families had long ago become a growth industry, and many wanted to look like the families that Bartholomew brought to the pages of their magazines.
Bartholomew's ads were white bread, if white bread of a very tasty sort, in keeping with the menu for the day. There was very little ethnic advertising at the time, no broken families, no poor folks, no one who did not revel in housework or gardening or marketing or washing the car, and no one troubled by acne except in ads for products that would clear it up.
Unfortunately the gallery does not display a single magazine showing how the pictures were used in ads or on editorial pages, though advertising photography is a dependent medium that changes when art directors and copywriters get their hands on it. Now that the photography market has absorbed commercial photography, photographs are often diverted from their purpose and exhibited as if they were independent works of art. Some of them unquestionably qualify, and others may pass as cultural history.
In the 1920's and 1930's Edward Steichen used to include some of his commercial work in his art shows, and some advertisers have used photographs that were not originally intended as ads, including work by Ansel Adams and Dorothea Lange.
Bartholomew's advertising photographs come as they are. A picture of a couple as horrified by their flooded basement as they would be to find Dracula in the mudroom could only be an ad, and the same is true of the damsels in their latex undies. Bartholomew, like many advertisers, told the half-naked truth.
 "Retail Stories: Photographs by Ralph Bartholomew Jr." remains at the Keith De Lellis Gallery, 47 East 68th Street, Manhattan, (212) 327-1482, through June 12.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 23; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2225 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.
 
Now Playing
 
* "ANALYZE THIS," starring Robert De Niro, Billy Crystal. Lisa Kudrow and Chazz Palminteri. Directed by Harold Ramis (R, 110 minutes). The title, concept and teaming of these co-stars are all funny before the lights go down, so think of this comedy as an offer you can't refuse. Cast as a mobster whose confidence is shaken, Mr. De Niro is hilarious simply by playing his role halfway straight, in classic goodfella style. His mobster finds just the right comic foil in Billy Crystal, as the psychiatrist who utters the immortal: "When I got into family therapy, this wasn't the family I had in mind." There's a lot more where that came from in this breezy comic treat (Janet Maslin). 

* "CENTRAL STATION," starring Fernanda Montenegro, Vinicius de Oliveira and Marilia Pera. Directed by Walter Salles (R, 115 minutes). In this quiet, luminous Brazilian gem, a joyless older woman crosses paths with an orphaned boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling. As these characters develop a fractious bond, then embark on a road trip that takes them vividly to Brazil's hinterlands in search of the boy's father, Mr. Salles brings great tenderness and surprise to the events that punctuate their journey. Ms. Montenegro's tough bravura performance was one of last year's very best (Maslin).
 
* "COOKIE'S FORTUNE," starring Charles S. Dutton, Glenn Close, Patricia Neal, Julianne Moore and Liv Tyler. Directed by Robert Altman (PG-13, 118 minutes). What a treat. The sweet assurance and guerrilla wit of Mr. Altman's vintage ensemble films make a copacetic return with a Southern small-town black comedy. Seamlessly made and completely enveloping, it tells of the machinations set off when a wealthy old woman (Ms. Neal) outrages her diabolically genteel niece (Ms. Close) by committing suicide. As the old woman's dearest friend and the niece's unwitting nemesis, Mr. Dutton is rock solid and appealing. The entire cast works on a single wavelength as Mr. Altman makes the most of a well-woven screenplay by Anne Rapp (Maslin).
 
* "THE DREAMLIFE OF ANGELS," starring Elodie Bouchez and Natacha Regnier. Directed by Erick Zonca (R, 113 minutes; in French with English subtitles). In this very special French film about two freewheeling young women, their turbulent friendship is frayed by sexual passion and economic realities. The weaker and more head-turning of the women (Ms. Regnier) falls for the advances of a rich nightclub owner, while her fiery friend, played with unforgettable immediacy by Ms. Bouchez, rages against what she views as imminent disaster. In the process, Mr. Zonca shows astonishing acuity in observing how the women's diverging values affect every aspect of their lives. A rare and wrenching drama (Maslin).
 
* "EDTV," starring Matthew McConaughey, Ellen DeGeneres, Woody Harrelson, Martin Landau, Jenna Elfman and Rob Reiner. Directed by Ron Howard (PG-13, 120 minutes). In this good-humored, deceptively easygoing satire, Mr. Howard holds up a fun-house mirror to a world ruled by voyeurism and specious fame. The subject matter is familiar by now, but this film about a Trumanesque nobody as 24-hour-a-day television star has a shrewd way of drawing the audience into its web. Permeated by all the crassness and absurdity inherent in celebrity-mad culture, and by our collective obsession with snoopy trivia, it features a fine ensemble cast and a dependably jokey screenplay by Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel. It helps that most of the principals, in a cast that also includes Elizabeth Hurley, have played this game for real and act their roles with a comic vengeance (Maslin).
 
"ELIZABETH," the Oscar winner for best makeup. Starring Cate Blanchett, Joseph Fiennes, Geoffrey Rush and Christopher Eccleston. Directed by Shekhar Kapur (R, 124 minutes). In this lurid costume drama depicting Elizabeth I as a royal rookie, the impressive Ms. Blanchett plays the Queen as if her principal responsibilities were being bejeweled, selecting consorts and saying "Leave us!" with a wave of the hand. For all its putative concern with Roman Catholic-Protestant strife at the start of Elizabeth's reign, this is historical drama for those whose idea of history is back issues of Vogue. Intent on spectacle, complete with burning at the stake and one dance scene reminiscent of "Saturday Night Fever," it winds up imagining the Queen as a glamorously stressed-out modern woman afflicted by a super-intense case of having it all (Maslin).
 
"GO," starring Sarah Polley, Katie Holmes, Timothy Olyphant, Taye Diggs, William Fichtner, Scott Wolf and Jay Mohr. Directed by Doug Liman (R, 100 minutes). This three-episode demimondaine comedy borrows truckloads of inspiration from "Pulp Fiction" but still has some flash and personality of its own. Mr. Liman, who shot the film as well as directed it, uses a supermarket as ground zero and sends a sullen cashier (Ms. Polley) out to make a drug deal. Then he embellishes this situation fully enough to send his film down the rabbit hole into neo-Tarantino adventures, some of which (guys go to Las Vegas, then get into trouble with strippers, gunplay, car theft and a brake-screeching chase) are a lot more tired than others. The ensemble cast shows cool comic flair (Maslin).
 
* "GODS AND MONSTERS," the Oscar winner for best adapted screenplay. Starring Ian McKellen and Brendan Fraser. Directed by Bill Condon (not rated, 105 minutes). In a performance that well deserves to be remembered, Mr. McKellen becomes the deliciously urbane James Whale, depicting the gay "Frankenstein" director late in life. Shaken by the aftereffects of a mild stroke, this Whale finds his past coming back to greet him just as the present offers new fascination in the Adonis-like form of the gardener (Mr. Fraser, also fine), whom Whale finds mowing his lawn. This beautifully acted, witty and heart-tugging film, from a Christopher Bram book, imagines what Whale's final days might have been like while shaping a splendid character study and a droll portrait of closeted gay Hollywood. Lynn Redgrave provides ballast and comic relief as Whale's perpetually scandalized housekeeper (Maslin).
 
* "HIDEOUS KINKY," starring Kate Winslet. Directed by Gillies MacKinnon (R, 99 minutes). Ms. Winslet knew best when she took on this offbeat, richly atmospheric adventure in the wake of "Titanic." The leading role in Mr. MacKinnon's vividly colorful film offers her a field day. She plays a young hippie mother who brings her reluctant English daughters to Marrakech, circa 1972. The film, about the mother's willfulness, the girls' reaction and the sheer headiness of their surroundings, belongs to the striking sub-genre in which it is baby-boom adults, not their children, who most need to come of age (Maslin).
 
"LIFE," starring Eddie Murphy, Martin Lawrence, Rick James and Ned Beatty. Directed by Ted Demme (R, 105 minutes). Though it's hard to miss the basic unfunniness of seeing two black men sentenced to life at a Mississippi State Prison, this mild-mannered comedy is more likable than it sounds. If it awkwardly straddles the line between period piece (it begins during Prohibition) and comedy, it also keeps the stars kidding their way from youth to curmudgeonhood. Mr. Murphy in particular gives a more substantial performance than might be expected here. Stick around for closing out-takes that show (for instance) a cell phone ringing during a scene set in 1932 (Maslin).
 
"THE MATRIX," starring Keanu Reeves, Laurence Fishburne and Carrie-Anne Moss. Directed by Andy and Larry Wachowski (R, 120 minutes). The time-traveling story steeped in virtual reality will be all but incomprehensible to non-technofreaks. And the film borrows unapologetically from other sci-fi extravaganzas, with a big debt to "The X-Files" in the paranoia department. But the storytelling is intricately bizarre and the special effects are indeed special, notably when it comes to midair martial arts with a gravity-defying gusto. And Mr. Reeves shows that you can look like a Prada model while behaving like an action hero. One of the main stars here is Bill Pope, an inventive cinematographer. He and the Wachowskis provide a couch-potato epiphany: while the characters seem to be performing marvelous feats, they're often lying stock-still in the grip of virtual reality (Maslin).
 
* "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE" (the Oscar winner for best film, best original screenplay, best art direction, best costumes and best comedy score). Starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow (the best-actress winner), Geoffrey Rush, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench (best supporting actress). Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile, this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
"SLC PUNK!," starring Matthew Lillard and Michael Goorjian. Directed by James Merendino (R, 97 minutes). Maybe only real experience as an alienated teen-ager in Salt Lake City in 1985 could have led a filmmaker to such a (perhaps deservedly) overlooked time and place. But Mr. Merendino supplies enough absurdist humor to make sense of the setting. His film follows Stevo (Mr. Lillard), the kind of anarchist who likes making rules, and whose rebel streak is about as authentic as his blue hair. As the rare punk who may be headed for Harvard Law School without even trying, Stevo is glib but entertaining. For all the film's appealing outlandishness, it's finally as mainstream as its hero proves to be (Maslin).
 
* "A WALK ON THE MOON," starring Diane Lane, Viggo Mortensen, Liev Schreiber, Tovah Feldshuh and Anna Paquin. Directed by Tony Goldwyn (R, 107 minutes). This evocative 1969 period piece, set on the brink of Woodstock in a Catskills holiday camp, is as seductive as the handsome, itinerant hippie who turns its heroine's life upside down. Thoughtfully conceived and movingly acted, it sweeps a housewife and mother named Pearl Kantrowitz (Ms. Lane) into a torrid extramarital romance and then weighs the consequences. With a tenderness that's unusual for a contemporary American film, it tells an enveloping tale enhanced by artfully selected Woodstock-era music. Mr. Mortensen may strain credulity as the foxiest blouse salesman in the Catskills, but he certainly does wonders for the movie (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
ALFRED HITCHCOCK CELEBRATIONS. Alfred Hitchcock's birthday doesn't arrive until Aug. 13, but that isn't stopping anyone from celebrating the centennial of the master of suspense (1899-1980). The tributes are already in progress. At the Museum of Modern Art, "Alfred Hitchcock," with more than 50 features, shorts and documentaries, as well as an exhibition of posters, photographs and papers, is trumpeted as the most comprehensive Hitchcock film retrospective ever mounted in the United States. And in conjunction with the film retrospective, the Museum of Television and Radio is presenting "Hitchcock by Hitchcock: A Centennial Salute," a complete retrospective of the 20 television films he directed between 1955 and 1962, along with some rarely seen interviews and a documentary on Hitchcock by Richard Schickel. At the Museum of Modern Art, this weekend's attractions include the director's first sound film, which was also Britain's first talkie: "Blackmail" (1929). The film (with Hitchcock's first cameo appearance) was released in silent and sound versions. The sound version will be shown at 6 P.M. today, followed by the silent version at 8; and sound and silent versions will be shown consecutively beginning at 1:30 P.M. on Sunday. Continuing through June 13 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, the series "Alfred Hitchcock" is free with museum admission: $9.50 for adults, $6.50 for students and people 65 or older; free for visitors under 16 accompanied by an adult. Pay what you wish on Fridays from 4:30 to 8:30 P.M. Screening information: (212) 708-9400. Continuing through June 6 at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52d Street, Manhattan, the series "Hitchcock by Hitchcock" is free with museum admission: $6 for adults, $4 for students and people 65 or older and $3 for children under 13. Information and screening schedule: (212) 621-6800 (Lawrence Van Gelder).
