SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 25; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2604 words

HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
 
ALL AND LAGWAGON, Tramps, 51 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 544-1666. Back in the 1980's, when most of the members of All were in the Descendents, they were already meshing punk drive with pop tunefulness. All, formed in 1987, hasn't given up on the idea, even as youthful punk tantrums have begun to share space with admissions of love. Lagwagon, a newer band, chops up its pop tunes a little bit more, but the same impulses -- frustration, scorn, humor, hormones -- propel the songs. With Latex Generation and Wretch Like Me opening. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; admission is $10 (Jon Pareles).
 
TIM BERNE AND BLOODCOUNT, Knitting Factory, Old Office, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Mr. Berne, who plays alto and baritone saxophones, has led excellent and influential bands for 15 years. He takes composition seriously -- he's got a passion for odd rhythmic cycles and multiple, intertwining voices -- but this group, with the reed player Chris Speed, bassist Michael Formanek and drummer Jim Black, has the unfussy strength of a good old blowing band. The thrills are in the long haul. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 and 9:30; admission is $10 with a one-drink minimum (Ben Ratliff). 

* ROB BROWN QUARTET, Brecht Forum, 122 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-4201. Rob Brown, an alto saxophonist, writes music with sharp angles; if you're attracted to peering over the precipice into jazz with free tonality but still like to hear it played with definition and clarity, Mr. Brown is your man. One of the best players in New York's free-music scene since the late 1980's, he chooses his spots to holler and to be graceful; there's a precise mind at work in his music. Opening for Mr. Brown is a trio led by the drummer Whit Dickey, with Mr. Brown on saxophone and Chris Lightcap on bass. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $10 (Ratliff).
 
GEORGE COLEMAN QUARTET/GEORGE COLLIGAN TRIO, Flushing Town Hall, 137-35 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, (718) 463-7700. The loose-limbed charms of Mr. Coleman's band may come at the expense of dynamics. But the tenor saxophonist and the pianist Harold Mabern, who both come from Memphis and share a nearly 50-year history in jazz, like to please themselves generously; they play with a good dollop of personality. Mr. Colligan, a pianist, opens the show. Tonight at 7:30 and 9:30; $20 general admission, $17 the elderly and students (Ratliff).
 
THE CREATURES, Irving Plaza, 15th Street and Irving Place, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. The Creatures are Siouxsie Sioux and her one remaining Banshee, the drummer Budgie, who is also her husband. Although they broke up the Banshees in 1995 to avoid being a nostalgia act, they hold on to the old goth-rock tone of knowing, unflinching fascination with bad news. Her voice, with its moans and glottal stops and electric-eel vibrato, now hovers over a beat that mixes muscle and electronics. Tonight at 9 with KHZ opening; tickets are $22 (Pareles).
 
D GENERATION, Coney Island High, 15 St. Marks Place, East Village, (212) 674-7959. Glam rock, that pungent brew of high fashion, low morals and gender-bending outrageousness, has always found its earthiest practitioners on the streets of New York. This East Village-based band of veteran club punks carries the torch once held by the New York Dolls and points it toward the millennium. With "Helpless," a catchy new generational anthem based on the immortal rock-and-roll lyric "Na na na na na" getting radio airplay, D Gen could finally be headed for its 15 minutes. Whether or not, the singer Jesse Malin and his boys will never abandon their rule of St. Marks Place. Tomorrow night at 9, with Thin Lizard Dawn, Shiny Mama and others opening; admission is $12 (Ann Powers).
 
DANIELSON AND EDITH FROST, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111. Danielson sings about Christian faith and the vagaries of the flesh in songs that are proud to sound both arty and amateurish. Edith Frost is a disciple of Neil Young, seeking the kind of simplicity that sounds like a direct confession of painful secrets. Tomorrow night at 9; admission is $10 (Pareles).
 
LOU DONALDSON, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037 When Mr. Donaldson sings that his woman likes whisky so much she puts it on her cornflakes, it becomes clear that be-bop and vaudeville can coexist freely. And when he solos, using his alto saxophone, it's equally clear that be-bop is a language in which real improvisation can flourish. So Mr. Donaldson is deep in the American tradition of entertainers who come with technique. Shows through Sunday are at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., with no third set on Sunday. There is a $20 cover ($15 Sunday) and a $10 minimum (Peter Watrous).
 
CANO ESTREMERA, Copacabana, 617 West 57th Street, Clinton, (212) 582-2672. The singer came to prominence as the front man for Bobby Valentine's group, one of Puerto Rico's best salsa orchestras. Mr. Estremera is among the island's best improvisers, and when he gets going he can take a tune and work it for half an hour, improvising on New York, the women in the audience, whatever catches his attention. He's a master. Shows tonight start at 11; the cover is $15 for men and $10 for women; $5 before 9 P.M. (Watrous).
 
* FAIRFIELD FOUR, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-7880 or (212) 228-6300. The Fairfield Four is a traditional a cappella gospel group that dates back originally to the 1920's. It's based on old-fashioned quartet style -- although it currently includes seven members -- that's no stranger to secular audiences after backing up such singers as Lyle Lovett. The call and response between the group's driving chordal harmonies and its gruff or soaring lead vocals testify to the power of faith and long years of teamwork. Tonight at 7:30 and 10:30, with Tommy Castro opening; tickets are $17.50 (Pareles).
 
* LEE HAZLEWOOD TRIBUTE, Fez, inside Time Cafe, 380 Lafayette Street, at Great Jones Street, East Village, (212) 533-2680. Lee Hazlewood, a scratchy-voiced songwriter with a calmly jaundiced worldview and a penchant for bleak story songs, reached his pop peak when he collaborated with Nancy Sinatra to produce "Some Velvet Morning" and "These Boots Are Made For Walkin'." By then, he already had a long, checkered resume as a producer and songwriter, with a catalogue of songs that stretches back to the 1950's. The pop archivists at the Loser's Lounge have dug some of them out, just in time to coincide with the first reissues of Mr. Hazlewood's albums from the 1960's and 70's. Tomorrow at 7 and 10 P.M.; admission is $15 (Pareles).
 
FREDDIE HUBBARD, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. What lessons Mr. Hubbard dispenses, not all of them musical. One of the grand trumpeters to arrive in the 1950's -- and one of the few to move easily between jazz camps from the avant-garde to fusion -- he was an improviser who helped define the synthetic quality of music in the 60's. His problems are public, and it's best to check with the club to find out if he's shown up for his show, before opening the taxi door. Shows through Saturday are at 9 and 11 P.M.; the cover is $20 and the minimum is $10 (Watrous).
 
KITARO, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824. With grandiose synthesizer chords and touches of Asian exotica, Kitaro proves that the West has no monopoly on somber kitsch. Tonight at 8; tickets are $32.50 and $50 (Pareles).
 
MYRA MELFORD TRIO, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7503. Ms. Melford, a pianist, plays shifting mixtures of rhythm and blues, modern classical music, Indian music and jazz; her episodic pieces are tightly written and composerly. She'll be playing piano and harmonium alongside the bassist Stomu Takeishi and the drummer Kenny Wolleson; sets are tonight at 9 and 10:30, and admission is $10 (Ratliff).
 
* JOE MORRIS AND WILLIAM PARKER, Brecht Forum, 122 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-4201. The electric guitarist and bassist, appearing together as a duo only for the fourth time, both use the threshing-machine esthetic of free jazz, in which they try to fold as much music as they're hearing into one small space; but with the clean tone of a standard guitar-bass jazz duo, they'll find their way to a subdued beauty as well. Opening the show is a duo of the fearsomely expressive Boston-based violinist Mat Maneri and the drummer Randy Peterson. The concert is tonight at 8; tickets are $10 (Ratliff).
 
DANILO PEREZ, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-8592. He's one of the reigning new pianists in jazz, furiously talented and virtuosic. And Mr. Perez is at an important nexus: he's as adept in the jazz world of swing as he is in the Afro-Latin world, an extremely rare thing. Beyond his considerable improvisational talents, he's also a formidable formalist, and his tunes, with their cuing system and improvised form, allow for group improvisation. He'll be taking jazz into the 21st century. Mr. Perez will be joined by the Cuban trumpeter Arturo Sandoval, who is also virtuosic and let's you know all about it, too. The sets through Sunday are at 9 and 11:30 P.M.; the cover is $30 and there is a $5 minimum (Watrous).
 
* PINETOP PERKINS, Chicago Blues, 73 Eighth Avenue, below 14th Street, West Village, (212) 924-9755. Pinetop Perkins was the longtime pianist in Muddy Waters's Chicago blues band. He has the entire blues vocabulary in his fingers, from boogie and shuffle bass lines to florid barrelhouse trills and filigrees. But he plays his solos like a card sharp who only shows what he needs to, and his ruthless economy translates into pithy, ornery blues. Tonight and tomorrow, with sets at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. Admission is $15 (Pareles).
 
* REICH REMIXED LIVE, Irving Plaza, 15th Street and Irving Place, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. Repetition and layering, polyrhythm and new patterns emerging from complexity -- these are methods and ideas that dance-music disk jockeys and programmers share with the great Minimalist composer Steve Reich, even though he had his short fling with tape loops long before some of them were born. An album, "Reich Remixed" (Nonesuch), set loose dance remixers including Coldcut, Mantronik, D. J. Spooky, Andrea Parker and Takamura on Reich compositions; at this event, they'll play full-length sets that expand on their remixes from the album. The chamber group Bang on a Can will play a complete Reich composition. Tomorrow at 9 P.M.; tickets are $20 in advance, $25 tomorrow (Pareles).
 
PETE (EL CONDE) RODRIGUEZ, Copacabana, 617 West 57th Street, Clinton, (212) 582-2672. Mr. Rodriguez, as the lead singer for Johnny Pacheco's band and on his own, helped construct the sound of Fania Records, the label that basically constructed the sound of salsa in New York. He's heavily indebted to Cuban music from the 1950's, and he's a fine improviser who knows how to lead a rocking dance band. It's hard-core salsa, with little use for the prettified music that now makes it on the radio. He'll be joined by Maelo, the son of Ismael Rivera, and Luisito Carrion, another good singer from Puerto Rico. RZA, Tramps, 51 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 544-1666. JIMMY SCOTT, Iridium, 48 West 63d Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. HEADLINE: P.& G. Profit Up 8.2% in Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, April 22

 BODY:
The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's largest maker of household products, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 8.2 percent but warned that continued slow sales abroad would hold fourth-quarter profit below forecasts.
Net income at P.& G., the maker of Tide detergent, Folgers coffee and Crest toothpaste, rose to $1.04 billion, or 72 cents a diluted share, compared with $961 million, or 65 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Analysts expected the company to earn 70 cents a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. 
 Results overseas were hurt by recessions in Russia and Brazil and slower growth in China. The company, which gets half its sales outside the United States, said slumping sales in those markets would also cut into fourth-quarter sales and profit.
Revenue rose 3.9 percent, to $9.23 billion, because of higher prices and its new products.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
World Trade Study Says Export Growth May Slow Further

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON

DATELINE: GENEVA, April 22

 BODY:
The rate of growth in world merchandise exports fell to 3.5 percent last year, only one-third of its 1997 growth rate of 10.5 percent, mainly because of the Asian economic crisis, the World Trade Organization said here today.
The organization said in an annual appraisal of global trade trends that export growth could slow further in 1999, depending largely on what happens in the United States, the strongest industrial nation. Many expect American growth to slow later this year, which could reduce exports to United States markets. 
 The study said that part of 1998's decline in export growth reflected lower commodity prices, including a 30 percent drop in the price of oil. Other commodity prices fell 20 percent in 1998, said Patrick Low, the World Trade Organization's chief economist.
The report said 1998 was the first time since World War II that commodity exports represented less than 20 percent of all exports. Many developing countries are still highly dependent on the exports of commodities, including food, and a continuing drop in world prices of raw commodities has widened the disparity between rich and poor nations.
Trade performance in 1998 varied widely among regions. Exports increased 3 percent from North America, while imports there rose 10.5 percent. Increases up to 10 percent in exports and imports were recorded in Latin America and some Eastern European countries.
Western Europe was the only region where the growth rate in imports did not fall from a year earlier. It remained at 7.5 percent.
Imports into Asian countries fell over all by 8.5 percent last year, and by double that in the once-booming economies of Hong Kong, Malaysia, South Korea, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand.
Mr. Low said at a news conference that signs of improvement in Asian economies could mean that exports to Asia increase in 1999. "But if we see too sharp a slowdown in the United States and Western Europe," he said, "then this will definitely threaten to swamp whatever happens in Asia."

U.S.-China Talks Resume
 BEIJING, April 22 (AP) -- Senior Chinese and American negotiators resumed talks here today on China's bid to join the World Trade Organization.
Robert Cassidy, an assistant United States trade representative, and Long Yongtu, China's top negotiator on W.T.O. entry, held a half-hour meeting early today and a longer negotiating session in the afternoon.
The meetings revived talks between the two countries on China's protracted effort to become a member of the organization that sets global commerce rules. During the visit to the United States of Prime Minister Zhu Rongji a couple of weeks ago, he and President Clinton agreed to reconvene the discussions after Mr. Clinton had rejected Chinese trade concessions as insufficient.
The official New China News Agency said today that negotiators needed to resolve differences over tariffs on industrial goods, legal terms for admission to the trade group and China's commitment to open financial, insurance and telecommunications markets to foreign businesses.

HEADLINE: Intel Planning Big Move Into Internet Services

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation, the leading maker of microchips, said yesterday that it was planning a big move into the Internet services business by building and running data centers around the world.
The move is a striking departure for the big microprocessor producer, known for pumping out millions of silicon Pentium chips that serve as the electronic brains of most personal computers. Analysts say the Intel announcement reflects just how far the company is willing to go in seeking new ways to grow as it recognizes the Internet as both a challenge and an opportunity. 
 "This is a stretch, but you have to give Intel's management credit for recognizing that the world is rapidly changing around them and trying to do something about it," said Drew Peck, a managing director of S. G. Cowen & Company, a securities firm.
Sprawling installations filled with powerful small computers, known as server farms, are used to handle electronic commerce and host the World Wide Web sites for other companies. Intel presented its plans for the data farms at a meeting with securities analysts yesterday in New York.
Though Intel's profits have held up well so far, many analysts believe that the rise of the Internet will inevitably erode its margins. Consumers are increasingly expected to use simpler, lower-cost devices -- from hand-held machines to television set-top boxes -- to gain access to the Internet.
The proliferation of these so-called Internet appliances, they note, will not replace personal computers by any means. But the Internet will fuel more diverse computing technologies and other access devices. This in turn will undermine the profits of the technology standard-bearers in the PC-centric era, that is, Intel and the Microsoft Corporation, whose Windows operating system runs most PC's.
"Intel has to look for other opportunities for future growth and server farms could be a reasonably good hybrid," Mr. Peck said.
Other analysts are quite skeptical. They say Intel is a late entrant into the fast-growing market for server farms, trailing established computer services powerhouses like the International Business Machines Corporation and Web hosting specialists like Exodus Communications Inc.
These analysts also doubt that Intel's skills as a chip maker give it any edge in running huge data centers. "This is not a business for Intel to be in," said Howard Anderson, managing director of the Yankee Group, a research company in Boston.
Intel insists that the server-farm plan fits neatly with its long-term strategy. "We want to be the building block supplier to the Internet economy," said Craig R. Barrett, the president of Intel. "And as part of that plan, we are going to make substantial investments to set up server farms around the world."
Intel already has a pilot operation in Santa Clara, Calif., equipped with a few hundred server computers, powered by Intel microprocessors. By the third quarter of this year, Intel intends to have its first data center with more than 2,000 Intel-based PC servers running, catering to customers including Excite, the Web directory service.
Soon after, the company plans to begin a network of data centers worldwide to host Web sites and handle electronic commerce for businesses. These huge computer farms, Intel says, are expected to cost more than $100 million each and be crammed with more than 5,000 servers.
Intel views the server farms as "bit factories," said Gerry Parker, an executive vice president. The expertise the company has developed in planning, building and managing chip factories, he said, should translate well. "A lot of the same skills are involved," he said.

HEADLINE: Indonesia's Responsibility in East Timor

 BODY:
Deadly violence returned to East Timor last week, and militias backed by Indonesia's army are clearly to blame. Their goal is to thwart a plan by Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie, to let Timor's people choose between autonomy and independence. A tentative cease-fire signed Tuesday is encouraging, but not enough. The United States and other countries must insist that Mr. Habibie disarm and disband the militias.
Indonesia's 1976 annexation of the former Portuguese colony of East Timor has never been recognized by the outside world or accepted by Timor's people. Mr. Habibie wisely recognized that an Indonesia struggling to recover from economic collapse and moving toward democratic elections would be better off letting East Timor go its own way. Indonesia and Portugal are negotiating arrangements for a vote on autonomy. If the Timorese vote no, Indonesia would concede independence. But this solution could fall apart if Jakarta fails to stop the militias, which have acted with the blessing of local army and police commanders. Washington must warn Indonesia that international loans could be suspended unless it acts. 
 The autonomy talks should also be completed quickly so that U.N. monitors can be sent. These are critical days for East Timor. A strong international message to Jakarta can make a difference.

HEADLINE: Greenspan View on Wider Use of Dollar

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, joined the Clinton Administration today in saying the United States would be open to proposals from other countries that want to adopt the dollar as their national currency.
But in testimony before a Congressional committee, Mr. Greenspan and Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, warned countries that might be contemplating such a step that monetary union with the United States could never be a substitute for pursuing sound policies to strengthen their economies and financial systems. 
 Presenting a united view on the topic, Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Summers also emphasized that the United States would not change its monetary policy to deal with economic problems in other nations using the dollar or serve as a lender of last resort to their banks.
A number of countries have been considering abandoning their national currencies and adopting the American dollar -- the accepted international benchmark of financial stability -- as a way of reducing interest rates, inflation and exchange-rate volatility.
The discussions have been most serious in Argentina, which has already held informal talks about the possibility with the Treasury and the Federal Reserve. The issue is also being openly debated in Mexico and, to a lesser extent, in Canada.
The idea has got increasing attention following Europe's decision to create a common currency, the euro, a step that is expected to increase the European Union's growth prospects and competitiveness in the long run. Some economists say making the dollar the common currency of the Americas could greatly expand trade and help the United States by creating more stable and vibrant markets for its goods among its neighbors.
Mr. Summers said the Administration's position on another country's desire to adopt the dollar would depend on the country and the circumstances. "But it is absolutely not our intent to close the door on the consideration of this issue by countries who have that interest," Mr. Summers said.
Other countries would not have to seek permission from the United States to use the dollar as their legal tender. Several countries, including Panama, already use the dollar as their official currency, and the dollar is widely used on an unofficial basis in many other nations, from Russia to the Philippines and Bolivia. So strong is foreign demand for dollars that roughly two-thirds of all American currency is in circulation outside the United States.
But because of the stakes involved, the big countries weighing the possibility of dollarization have signaled that they would only take such a step in coordination with the United States. Among other things, countries would need large quantities of cash from the United States during any changeover.
Speaking before two subcommittees of the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan said that in recent years some small countries with generally sound economic policies had found themselves buffeted by global forces. Those countries, he said, probably would have fared better had they "locked themselves into a currency of one of the more stable, larger countries" like the United States.
But Mr. Greenspan said adopting the dollar would not help another country unless that country was also willing to develop a well-regulated, well-capitalized financial system, keep a lid on budget deficits and avoid running up big foreign debts.
"It is very important for us to be certain that dollarization as we view it is not some means to bypass the types of policies that are required to create stability," Mr. Greenspan said. A country that adopts the dollar without pursuing sound policies generally, he said, "will find within a reasonably short time that it will fail, and that in the process of failure, they almost surely will be worse off than they were without it."
Dollarization is a component of a broader debate over how developing nations can best manage their currencies and foreign-exchange systems in a world where rapid flows of capital can knock all but the mightiest of economies off track.
At meetings next week, financial officials from the leading industrial nations and delegates to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank will consider how to respond to the global financial turmoil of the last two years.
Exchange-rate systems are at the top of the agenda, with many countries having come to the conclusion that developing economies need to choose between two options at opposite ends of the spectrum of possibilities: allowing their currencies to float freely in value, or irrevocably fixing the value at a certain level.
Replacing a national currency with the dollar is in effect the most dramatic and unambiguous way of freezing that currency's value irrevocably. Such a move would effectively eliminate the exchange-rate fluctuations that can bedevil borrowers and exporters in a developing nation, since the dollar is the benchmark against which other currencies are usually valued.
It would all but eliminate inflation, since the money supply would be controlled not by the nation's central bank but by the Federal Reserve. And because exchange-rate and inflation risks would be substantially reduced, interest rates within the nation adopting the dollar would probably come down.
But in adopting the dollar, a country would give up control of its own monetary policy, reducing its ability to cope with any ups and downs in its economy.
It would be restricted in its ability to deal with a banking crisis, since it could not inject money into the financial system. And it would give up what economists call "seigniorage," the interest payments it receives from holding foreign currency reserves in the form of United States Treasury bonds, for example.
Many economists favor dollarization as a realistic way to help bring stability to emerging economies, especially in Latin America. Before joining the Clinton Administration, Mr. Summers was an enthusiastic proponent of dollarization.
But the issues involved are not just economic. Giving up a national currency -- even a troubled or weak currency -- is a major political decision in any country, and involves a substantial ceding of sovereignty. And Mr. Summers and Mr. Greenspan discussed in their testimony today the possibility that a dollarized nation that hits a rough economic patch will likely attribute its problems to the United States, creating diplomatic issues as well.

HEADLINE: Ralph J. Perk, 85, a Republican Who Led Cleveland in the 1970's

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Ralph J. Perk, the hard-luck Mayor of Cleveland whose misfortunes included accidentally setting his own hair on fire at a ceremonial appearance, died on Wednesday at the Cleveland Clinic Hospice unit of the Corinthian Skilled Nursing Center in Westlake, Ohio. He was 85.
Mr. Perk, a Republican, was Mayor from 1972 to 1977. 
 A native of Cleveland, he was also self-made. He dropped out of high school, managed to get some college education and peddled ice in the Depression. He benefited from enthusiastic backing of blue-collar voters in being elected a Cleveland Councilman and, later, Mayor.
But even The Cleveland Plain Dealer acknowledged that he was "probably best remembered nationally as the Mayor with the flaming hair, whose wife preferred bowling to dining at the White House."
It was in 1972 that, as R. W. Apple Jr. has written in The New York Times, Mayor Perk, "at a ceremony designed to demonstrate his solidarity with the city's working men, somehow managed to set his hair alight with a blowtorch." He was wielding it to sever a steel ribbon and thereby formally open a convention of the American Society of Metals.
Some months later, President Richard M. Nixon invited Mr. Perk and his wife, the former Lucille Gagliardi, to a dinner at the White House. But Mrs. Perk sent word that she could not attend because it was her night to go bowling.
Mr. Perk campaigned for election as Mayor on an anti-tax platform. After taking office, he oversaw the borrowing of nearly $130 million to pay the bills of the city, whose manufacturing industries were battered by recession in the 1970's.
He also reduced the work hours and pay of the city's employees
In 1978, not long after Mr. Perk left office, Cleveland, with Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich in charge, defaulted on its financial obligations.
Mr. Perk lost to John Glenn, a Democrat, in a Senate race in 1974.
He is survived by his wife, Lucille, whom he married 59 years ago; a daughter, Virginia Bowers of Cleveland; six sons, Ralph Jr., a municipal court judge in Cleveland; Thomas, a Councilman in Valley View, a suburb of Cleveland; Kenneth, a member of the Valley View school board; Michael, of Cleveland, an employee of the Cuyahoga County Board of Elections; Richard, of Rocky River, west of Cleveland, an employee of the Ohio Lottery Commission, and Allen, of Gahanna, near Columbus; two brothers, Albert and George, both of Cleveland; 16 grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Strong I.B.M. Report Helps Propel Dow to Another High

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
I.B.M.'s strong profit report helped propel the stock market to another big advance yesterday as large growth stocks, which had fallen out of favor as perhaps too expensive just a couple of weeks ago, continued to rebound.
The rally, which brought another record for the Dow Jones industrial average, came despite a slump in the bond market that raised interest rates along a broad front. 
 I.B.M. was the star performer after reporting a 42 percent rise in first-quarter earnings on Wednesday, climbing 22 5/8, to 194 1/2. It accounted for 105 of the 145.76-point gain in the Dow, which finished up 1.4 percent, to 10,727.18. Even lacking I.B.M., the Nasdaq composite index did twice as well, advancing 72.53 points, or 2.91 percent, to 2,561.61. The index is now just 37 points shy of its all-time high.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 22.70 points, or 1.7 percent, to 1,358.82 also a record.
Analysts pointed to several more reports of surprisingly good earnings besides I.B.M.'s as the main impetus for the market's third consecutive advance after Monday's swoon.
"It's a continuation of some really impressive earnings, definitely better than the Street was expecting," said Warren Epstein, head trader at Richard Rosenblatt & Company. "There's a tremendous amount of buying momentum."
Combined volume on the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq was more than two billion shares.
According to I.B.E.S, which tracks analysts' profit estimates, the quarter ended in March appears to have been the best for positive earnings surprises in 11 years. Many analysts cut projections last autumn on spreading economic turmoil overseas.
And more companies reported today, bringing the season's total to about 50 percent of the S.& P. 500. Among them were Lucent, up 2 5/8, to 61 3/4; American Express, up 2 5/16 , to 137 3/16 ; Chevron, up 2 1/8, to 98 1/2; Nokia, up 2 9/16 , to 81 3/16 , and Quaker Oats, up 4 1/4, to 67 3/16 .
Some, however, slumped after disclosing results. Procter & Gamble declined 4 13/16 , to 94 1/8; Black & Decker dropped 4 7/16 , to 5 41/16 , and McDonald's fell 11/16 , to 44 11/16 .
Charles Schwab, which rose 2 13/16 , to 120 13/16 , announced a 2-for-1 stock split, its seventh since the brokerage firm went public in 1987. The previous split, which was 3 for 1, was in December. Sara Lee, which warned analysts to expect lower profit growth and was downgraded by Merrill Lynch, fell 1 1/8, to 24. After the market closed, the company said it was bidding $10.50 a share for Chock Full o' Nuts which had risen 3/8, to 6 3/8. Chock Full responded by calling the offer "inadequate."
Computer and other technology issues, benefiting from I.B.M. fallout, turned in another strong performance, with Amazon.com climbing 10 13/16 , to 190 1/16 ; America Online up 5 15/16 , to 148 11/16 ; Microsoft rising 2 15/16 , to 84 15/16 , and Yahoo up 9 1/8, to 184.
Timothy M. Ghriskey, a value-oriented portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation, expressed hope that the market's sudden mid-April lurch toward cyclical and smaller stocks would resume, but he was unwilling to predict this.
"The market is so dominated by megacap growth stocks, and I don't think they'll be abandoned so quickly," he said.
A total of 928 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange as 1,705 stocks advanced and 1,307 declined and new 52-week highs outnumbered new lows by 65 to 28.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasuries Fall Sharply
 (By Bloomberg News)
 The stock market rally reduced demand for less-risky Treasury debt yesterday, pushing bond prices to their worst decline in more than seven weeks.
"The bond market's taking its cue from the stock market," said Scott Grannis, who helps manage about $50 billion at Western Asset Management in Pasadena, Calif.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 1 1/32 , to 94 31/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, climbed to 5.60 percent from 5.53 percent.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: DIPLOMACY;
Russian Ends Peace Visit; Slight Signs Of Progress

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, April 22

 BODY:
President Slobodan Milosevic spent nine hours today with a Russian peace envoy but appeared to give very little ground.
The Russian envoy, former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, left Belgrade late tonight saying that Mr. Milosevic had agreed to an "international presence in Kosovo under United Nations auspices," to implement any political settlement. 
 But Mr. Milosevic has agreed to such a United Nations presence before, and details were scarce tonight, including the key point of whether international participants would be armed, and if so, under whose control.
"What kind of international forces they will be, or from which countries -- this is yet to be discussed," Mr. Chernomyrdin said at the Belgrade airport before leaving here. "But the main thing is that Russia will take part in them."
NATO insists on an armed "international security force" with NATO troops as its core, so it is highly unlikely that Mr. Chernomyrdin has made enough progress to change NATO's plans to continue the bombing. Mr. Milosevic continues to insist that NATO stop bombing first, before any talks proceed on a Kosovo settlement, and he has refused to withdraw all Serbian security forces from the province.
Mr. Chernomyrdin described his long session with Mr. Milosevic as important progress, but initial Western reactions were dubious.
President Clinton, responding at a Washington news conference on the eve of NATO's 50th anniversary summit meeting, said: "If there is an offer for a genuine security force, that's the first time Mr. Milosevic has done that, and that represents, I suppose, some step forward."
British officials said it was too early to judge the outcome, but emphasized that NATO's demands included issues like the safe return of all ethnic Albanian refugees and the ability for international investigators to pursue allegations of Serbian war crimes in Kosovo.
Washington is hoping that the Russians can mediate this conflict, but they have limited influence over the Serbs.
While Mr. Milosevic spent hours with Mr. Chernomyrdin, it is not clear he liked what he heard. State television gave the Chernomyrdin visit very little airtime late in the broadcast, a sharp contrast to the lavish treatment given the visit April 14 of the Belarussian leader, Aleksandr Lukashenko.
Then, Mr. Lukashenko said at a joint appearance with Mr. Milosevic that Belgrade would accept unarmed civilian monitors from non-NATO countries in Kosovo under a United Nations mandate.
Earlier, Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Milosevic signed a joint declaration calling for an end to the air strikes, the safe return of refugees to Kosovo, a possible reduction of Yugoslav troops and police but also for a withdrawal of NATO troops from the borders of Yugoslavia.
Mr. Chernomyrdin said relief agencies should be allowed to carry out work in Kosovo, economic aid should be offered to Yugoslavia and talks on broad autonomy should continue.
Mr. Chernomyrdin, appointed Russia's special Balkan envoy last week by President Boris N. Yeltsin, came with specific proposals that included some form of armed international presence in Kosovo, but one that would be agreeable to all sides.
His trip came one month after a mission led by the Russian Prime Minister, Yevgeni M. Primakov, ended in failure. Unlike the visit to Belgrade by Mr. Primakov and a delegation of military and intelligence officials days after the bombing began, Mr. Chernomyrdin's visit was designed to elicit some concessions from Mr. Milosevic.
"The goal of Primakov's mission was to show an effort, but he was fully aware of the impossibility of achieving any results," said a Western diplomat based in Moscow. "Mr. Chernomyrdin has no need to repeat that effort. He needs to bring home something."
Mr. Chernomyrdin has already moved away from a one-sided condemnation of NATO's bombing campaign, calling yesterday for an end as well to "ethnic cleansing and separatism" in Kosovo.
Mr. Chernomyrdin spent two days this week consulting with the leaders of Georgia, Azerbaijan and Ukraine, seeking support close to home.
The war is growing increasingly costly for Yugoslavia. Milan Komnenic, the Information Minister, said today that 517 civilians, including 13 children, have been killed in the bombing campaign.
He said that more than 4,000 civilians were seriously injured since the start of the strikes on March 24.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Secrets of the War

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The train pulls in and the refugees are herded out. Then they are sold to waiting merchants, into slavery.
Slavery, not forced labor or some such euphemism. Slavery, do you hear -- branded, flogged, raped, tortured into renouncing their religion, and then put to work for their owners. 
 They were captured and sold in Sudan by government soldiers and militias. Relatives who escaped capture starve; the regime will not allow food to reach them.
A friend asks why, after writing often about human rights, I oppose the war against Serbia, ruled by a dictator. I do not put dictators into two groups -- one to oppose, the other to strengthen because they are customers. The one word for Slobodan Milosevic and all dictators, whatever their religion or country, is: killer.
I oppose the war because it has been mismanaged, misplanned, politically, diplomatically and strategically slovenly and amateurish -- adding up to disaster for the victims. This air war allowed Mr. Milosevic to drive Albanians out of Kosovo. It gave him information that should have been top secret -- that the U.S. would not send in ground forces.
The only way it has helped human rights is to make more disgusting the icy Western attitude to other huge human rights crimes, as the massacres and slave trains in Sudan. They could have been stopped without war.
Now two roads are open to recoup what our leaders lost in Kosovo.
We can send in hundreds of thousands of troops -- without illusion. The dictator will exact as many NATO lives as he can and his goal will be to spread the war throughout the Balkans, and beyond.
Or we can negotiate out. But then we must use the years afterward to strengthen the Serbian democratic-minded opposition against the dictator, with a smidgen of the financial investment of the Kosovo war, and little of Serbian and Kosovar blood.
And without forgetting Yugoslavia, the West could remember that in Asia and Africa are human rights violations amounting to genocide. Even in peace, the West now struggles for human rights only where its trade interests are not risked.
China's President was pleasant in Beijing to America's President about easing the pain of Tibet, 50 years a captive nation. He lied to a man who longed to be lied to.
As crackdowns in Tibet and China increase, and knowledge of Beijing's nuclear-weapon espionage is uncovered, Washington campaigns to give China the economic benefits of the World Trade Organization.
Unsaid is that Beijing's membership would formally wipe out any effort to use the only human rights tools we have in China. Those tools are linking trade with easing persecution and warning allies we will exact economic reprisal if they then double-cross us by sopping up our China trade. We would rank people as important as bananas.
We ignore Sudan. Why? Oh, come on. For 16 years, the ruling Arabs of the north have been at war against southern Sudanese, mostly Christian or animists, and all, you know, black.
We could help the victims by positioning monitoring stations in the territory they still control, sending food directly to them, overflying the government blockade, by treating Khartoum as an enemy economically, and its prey as an ally.
American moral honor is upheld by some among us -- the students working on the Campaign of Conscience for Sudan, the Center for Religious Freedom of Freedom House, and a few legislators.
This capsule comes from Senator Sam Brownback, Kansas Republican: More southern Sudanese have died from guns, bombs and starvation than all the victims in Bosnia, Kosovo and Rwanda combined -- at least 1.9 million. About 2.6 million face starvation because of genocidal withholding of food, and 4.3 million were driven from their homes -- the largest displaced population in the world.
Elie Wiesel, supportive of NATO in Kosovo, asked President Clinton publicly why we had not been involved in Rwanda. Mr. Clinton said he would do his best to make sure there was not another Rwanda.
Sudan had slipped his mind. So has his overdue obligation to appoint Presidential members of the commission against religious persecution, passed by Congress.
Slaves. The number in Sudan can roughly be estimated -- tens of thousands. Only owners take precise slave-counts.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

I.B.M. Lifts Dow to Record As Nasdaq and S.& P. Soar
I.B.M.'s strong profit report helped propel the stock market to another big advance as large growth stocks, which had fallen out of favor as perhaps too expensive just a couple of weeks ago, continued to rebound. 
 The rally brought another record for the Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 145.76 points, or 1.38 percent, to 10,727.18. The Nasdaq composite index did even better, gaining 72.53 points, or 2.91 percent, to 2,561.61, just 37 points shy of its all-time high. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 22.7 points, or 1.7 percent, to 1,358.82, also a record. Page C6.
 
Greenspan Backs Wider Dollar Use
In testimony before a Congressional committee, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, presented a united openness to other countries seeking to adopt the dollar as their national currency, but warned that such a move should not replace sound monetary policy. C3.
 
Intel to Expand to the Internet
Intel said it was planning a big move into the Internet services business. The strategy is a striking departure for the maker of Pentium chips that serve as the electronic brains of most personal computers and reflects how far Intel is willing to go to grow. C3.
 
Lazard Settles Municipal Bond Case
Lazard Freres & Company, the Wall Street investment bank, agreed to pay $11 million to settle Federal charges for inflating the prices of Government securities it sold to municipalities. The settlement ends the firm's disastrous foray into municipal finance. C2.
 
Pepsico Earnings Beat Forecasts
Pepsico reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings, but the company's shares fell after its chief financial officer said future earnings might be a little lower than analysts had been led to believe by the company's chairman and chief executive, Roger A. Enrico. Pepsico will spend $75 million to upgrade its computer systems. C6.
 
Profits at Lucent Technologies, the phone-equipment maker, Airtouch Communications, Bell Atlantic and GTE met or surpassed Wall Street expectations. C6.
 
Xerox said first-quarter earnings rose 14 percent, mostly through cost cuts, but its shares fell because revenue did not increase. C4.
 
Coca-Cola Accused of Racial Bias
A group of black employees filed a class-action lawsuit accusing Coca-Cola of discriminating against African-Americans in pay, promotions and performance evaluations. The suit contends that the company pays its average black employee nearly $27,000 a year less than its average white employee and limits black workers' chances for promotion. C3.

The Federal Government began cracking down on the deceptive practices of a proliferating number of private investigators who advertise on the Internet that they can inexpensively provide confidential details about bank accounts and telephone records. A14.
 
Profit Declines 54% at RJR Nabisco
In its final quarter as an international tobacco and food company, RJR Nabisco Holdings reported that its first-quarter earnings fell 54 percent because of declining cigarette sales and costs to settle tobacco litigation. C4.
 
Export Growth Plunges to 3.5%
The World Trade Organization said the rate of growth in world merchandise exports fell to 3.5 percent last year -- only one-third of its 1997 growth rate -- mainly because of the Asian economic crisis. It warned that growth could slow further this year. C2.
 
Loss to Gitic Creditors Worsens
In another blow to foreign banks, a Chinese court said that it expected to salvage only $783 million in assets from one of China's largest and most troubled companies, Guangdong International Trust and Investment. C2.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1325 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Bankers, Too, Chart Internet's Stratosphere

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
The quickest way for a chief executive to bolster his company's stock price, it appears, is to announce a connection to the Internet. In recent weeks, the banking industry has become accustomed to such announcements -- and with the associated stock-trading frenzy.
The stocks of little-known regional financial companies like Florida Banks Inc. of Jacksonville, First Sierra Financial Inc. of Houston and the Patriot Bank of Pottstown, Pa., have jumped as much as 300 percent in a single day after the companies publicized their intentions to provide banking services over the Internet. 
 Investors who bought in before the announcements are mostly sitting on paper profits. Among the buyers have been executives and directors of Florida Banks, First Sierra and Patriot Bank who purchased shares in the four to six weeks before each company announced its Internet plans.
The executives say that while they are enthusiastic about the Internet plans, their recent stock purchases were not timed to take advantage of an Internet premium. And few, if any, of the insiders have cashed in so far by selling stock.
In buying shares shortly before announcing their Internet ventures, however, the executives raise questions that are relevant to a large number of companies today. At a time when any corporate press release with the the word "Internet" in it seems to move stock prices, corporate America might need to take a broader view of what is considered material information to investors.
The Securities and Exchange Commission defines materiality as anything a typical investor would need to know to make an informed decision. Securities laws prohibit people who are in a position of fiduciary responsibility and who have access to material, nonpublic information from trading on that knowledge.
But it is not at all clear whether the executives in these instances ran afoul of those rules. In a legal sense, materiality cannot be judged solely by whether an announcement causes a stock price to move.
Investors, it seems, have quite another view.
The enthusiasm for Internet banking can be linked directly to the stock performance of Net.Bank Inc. and the Telebanc Financial Corporation. These two companies, which say they do all their business in cyberspace without the burden of brick-and-mortar branches, have captured the fancy of investors largely because they have already demonstrated the ability to generate profits.
Telebanc, for example, is expected this year to earn $2.6 million, or 15 cents a share, double its profit last year. Those earnings would be even higher without a huge advertising budget intended to attract customers, said Henry Blodget, who tracks the company for Merrill Lynch and is recommending its shares.
Mr. Blodget says the attraction of Internet-based banks is that they are not limited to serving customers in areas where the bank has branches. Like other Internet service businesses, the banks aim to pass the savings along in the form of higher interest rates on deposits.
The public has enthusiastically responded to the stocks, if not the on-line bank accounts, pushing Telebanc shares up to $104.50 from $34 at the beginning of the year and less than $8 last October. Similarly, Net.Bank shares closed yesterday at $182.4375, up more than 500 percent since the beginning of the year.
It is not surprising, then, that investors seem to have jumped on any bank's decision to reach out over the Internet. On April 13, when Florida Banks announced that it would begin offering Internet banking services in the third quarter, its shares soared from about $8, where they had been trading for most of the previous year, to as high as $37.75, closing at $31.25. They have since declined, closing yesterday at $11.8125, 47 percent higher than before the Internet announcement.
Just three weeks before the announcement, four insiders bought 9,000 shares of Florida Banks at about $7 each. The purchases, totaling $63,500, increased each person's holdings by 1 percent to 20 percent. Though the purchases were relatively small in terms of the company's $63 million market value, they accounted for as much as half of the trading in the stock March 22-24.
Should the insiders have been allowed to buy stock when an announcement about their companies' Internet plans was looming?
T. Edwin Stinson, the chief financial officer of Florida Banks, who was one of four officials who bought shares, said the news was important but not entirely new. Florida Banks' plan for Internet banking was outlined in the company's prospectus for its initial public offering last July, he said.
"We were extremely surprised by the reaction" of the stock, Mr. Stinson said. The main reason the company issued the press release, he said, was because it had signed a final agreement with a service provider that would allow the formal startup of the Internet service, and it wanted to get the news out before discussing it at an investment conference that week.
Florida Banks also draws a strong distinction between its strategy and Telebanc's. "We don't want to service commercial customers that are not in the geographic markets that we are in," Mr. Stinson said. "We didn't imply that we are trying to be an Internet bank."
The stock purchases were made "because the stock was trading below book value," Mr. Stinson said, referring to the net value of the company's assets and liabilities. Some of the company's directors had been lamenting that the shares seemed appreciably cheap, and "none of us benefited at all" since none of the shares have been sold, he added.
Several weeks before First Sierra Financial, an equipment-leasing company, announced that it would establish "the first Internet-based business-to-business bank," its chief executive and a director bought 50,000 and 29,600 shares, respectively, at about $9 each.
The purchases each represented about a day's average volume in the shares, which trade on Nasdaq. After the announcement on April 14, First Sierra's shares jumped as high as $30 and have since settled at $14.50.
Thomas J. Depping, the chief executive, points out that the company's share price had started to move up after First Sierra reported strong first-quarter earnings.
"I've been consistently buying shares since November," shortly after their price fell to $9 from $33 amid a downdraft in speciality finance shares, Mr. Depping said. A large block of stock became available in mid-March, prompting his decision to buy more, he said. The decision "really had very little to do with the fact that we were working on an Internet bank," he added.
Joni S. Naugle, chief operating officer of Patriot Bank, said she, too, was surprised at the market reaction to Patriot's April 12 introduction of "Virtual Access Internet Banking" service.
The company's shares, which had traded around $9.50 for two weeks, jumped as high as $18.75 on the news. Roughly a month before the announcement, Ms. Naugle and another company executive bought 1,000 shares each, while a director bought 7,400. Each paid about $10 a share.
"The purchases were not related at all" to the announcement, Ms. Naugle said. "Insiders have been buying because the stock is on sale," trading roughly at book value, and they did not sell shares when the price jumped. Since then, the price has returned to its previous level, closing yesterday at $10.
That is probably because once investors read Patriot's press release closely, they might have noticed that while Patriot was adding Internet banking services -- including the ability to transfer funds and pay bills on line -- it was not becoming an Internet bank.
Similar services have been offered by big financial institutions like Citibank for more than a decade. But to date, only a small portion of Citibank's customers use the service regularly.
The lesson for investors, of course, is that not all Internet connections are equal.

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 720 words

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Stop the Music

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
It is said that a camel is a horse designed by a committee. It may not be pretty but it gets the job done, especially in the desert.
By that standard, NATO's air war over Yugoslavia is a military strategy designed by a 19-member alliance. It's also not pretty, but its very weakness could be a strength. 
 Bombing the Serbs from 15,000 feet is the only military strategy that all 19 NATO members, the U.S. Congress and the Russians can agree upon as tolerable in Yugoslavia today. While there are many obvious downsides to war-from-15,000-feet, it does have one great strength -- its sustainability. NATO can carry on this sort of air war for a long, long time. The Serbs need to remember that.
While it is true that NATO will never liberate Kosovo from the air, there is still a chance that this sort of sustained bombardment can achieve our basic objectives -- which are to compel Slobodan Milosevic, either tacitly or by negotiation, to enable the return of the Kosovo Albanians to their homes, with self-rule, protected by an international peacekeeping force that would patrol a fence between Albanians and Serbs.
But if NATO's only strength is that it can bomb forever, then it has to get every ounce out of that. Let's at least have a real air war. The idea that people are still holding rock concerts in Belgrade, or going out for Sunday merry-go-round rides, while their fellow Serbs are "cleansing" Kosovo, is outrageous. It should be lights out in Belgrade: every power grid, water pipe, bridge, road and war-related factory has to be targeted.
Like it or not, we are at war with the Serbian nation (the Serbs certainly think so), and the stakes have to be very clear: Every week you ravage Kosovo is another decade we will set your country back by pulverizing you. You want 1950? We can do 1950. You want 1389? We can do 1389 too. If we can frame the issue that way, Mr. Milosevic will blink, and we may have seen his first flutter yesterday.
Will this strategy halt the barbarism still going on in Kosovo? No. The war to prevent the refugees from being thrown out of Kosovo, or abducted, was lost the first week -- when NATO and the Clinton team bombed the Serbs without having either adequate ground or air power in place to deter them, and without understanding Mr. Milosevic's capabilities or his intentions. That was a strategic blunder for which the Kosovars have paid dearly.
The question now is how best to reverse that, without the U.S. and NATO becoming so enmeshed in the Balkans that it will weaken their ability to operate anywhere else, and strain their cohesion as never before. The only way is a merciless air war.
What about ground troops? NATO should continue planning for a ground war, as the British and French are urging, both because it might influence Mr. Milosevic to blink sooner rather than later, and because it would inject some realism into the debate about this subject. The U.S. public and Congress need to understand just what would be involved in a ground war. Invading Kosovo means owning Kosovo. A ground war would likely require going all the way to Belgrade and end up making both Albania and Macedonia, from which any invasion of Kosovo would be staged, U.S. protectorates.
Be advised, these are weak, tribalized states that can fall apart in our hands. Albania is non-country country. It is a country where police estimate that more than half the cars on the road were stolen from somewhere else in Europe, where everyone has a gun at home and where just two years ago the whole banking system was based on pyramid schemes and three-card monte. The Wall Street Journal recently quoted an unemployed worker in Tirana as saying, "It would be better if Milosevic bombed here, and we could all go as refugees to Italy and Germany."
That is just one reason that, for now, we must stick to a strategy that at least holds out the hope of achieving our objectives without NATO ending up owning the Balkans. Because nothing would do more to sap public support for American internationalism than America's taking over history's oldest hornet's nests.
Give war a chance. Let's see what months of bombing does before we opt for weeks of invasion, where, if we win, we get to occupy the Balkans for years. Let's make Kosovo Mr. Milosevic's Vietnam, not ours.

NATO Missiles Strike Targets in Belgrade
NATO knocked Serbian state television off the air in the middle of a newscast early today, leaving the building that housed the state's main propaganda arm in flames, with reports of many casualties. Early the day before, NATO bombed the residence of President President Slobodan Milosevic, an elegant 1936 villa that is the most famous address in Belgrade. A1 

Yugoslavia denounced the strike on Mr. Milosevic's house as an assassination attempt. American and NATO officials denied that the attack was a deliberate attempt to kill Mr. Milosevic, who was not at the house. They asserted that the target was a legitimate assault on the Yugoslav military leadership. A11

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Players and W.N.B.A. Call Off the Agreement

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
The Women's National Basketball Association announced yesterday that the agreement in principle it reached last week with the players union had fallen apart and, as a result, it was postponing next Tuesday's draft.
The breakdown came only nine days after both sides hailed what appeared to be a historic first contract for a women's professional basketball league in the United States. In doing so, the W.N.B.A. and its newly formed players union, which is represented by the National Basketball Players Association, had managed to avoid a labor dispute similar to last year's N.B.A. lockout. 
 "We had hoped to avoid what happened in USA Basketball and the N.B.A.," said Valerie B. Ackerman, president of the W.N.B.A. "For whatever reason, that was not possible. Instead, there is no deal and we have no choice but to postpone the draft indefinitely."
The draft was for teams to select former American Basketball League players and players coming out of college.
In talks late Wednesday night, both sides said, there were disagreements over certain provisions that they had not anticipated during more than two months of bargaining and the final negotiations that led to the deal.
The union said it was under the impression that players from the defunct A.B.L. would not be classified as rookies by the league, but considered as veterans and allowed to negotiate their salaries based on the veterans' scale.
The W.N.B.A. has said that for league purposes, the A.B.L. players, like veterans who have played overseas and joined the league, are considered rookies, and would be paid as such, depending on where they are drafted.
"The word shouldn't be used to describe someone with numerous years of experience," said Edna Campbell, who played for the A.B.L.'s Colorado Xplosion and was invited to last week's W.N.B.A. tryout camp. "I consider that a slight, and I don't think just because they've decided to refer to us as rookies we should be treated as such, especially when it comes to our pay scales."
The union also took issue with the number of appearances players would be required to make during the season. Union officials claimed the two sides settled on a total of 12, but that the league now says the figure applies only to appearances for league sponsors, not community-related appearances for which there was no limit set.
"We thought we engaged in good-faith negotiations and we thought we had a lot more negotiating to do, but the league felt they would not give in on a number of economic issues," said Pamela Wheeler, director of operations for the Women's Basketball Association and one of the union's chief negotiators. "In our mind, this is an attempt to scare and intimidate the players."
According to Bruce Levy, an agent who represents players in both the W.N.B.A. and the former A.B.L., the players thought their preliminary agreement with the league gave them the right to hold out.
"Then they learned that players who had not signed a contract with the league by the beginning of training camp would not be allowed to play for the season," Levy said. "That means that on May 7, the league's lawyers could give us 70 veteran contracts and say, 'if in one week these aren't signed by your clients, your clients are out of the league.' With that kind of threat, how much negotiating can you do?"
Wheeler insisted that a deal could be made with no more than a few hours at the bargaining table, but no new talks were scheduled. Wheeler was returning to Phoenix to prepare for her organization's move to New York, and Billy Hunter, executive director of the players associations, was out of town.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE WHITE HOUSE;
Birth of Land-Assault Plan Darkens Already Grim Eve of Summit

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
On the eve of the opening of the NATO summit here, President Clinton and NATO leaders vowed to intensify the military and economic punishment of Serbia even as they reserved judgment on a possible peace proposal from Belgrade.
American and NATO war planners in Washington and Brussels began drawing up options for a land assault to drive the forces of President Slobodan Milosevic from the Yugoslav province of Kosovo as alliance leaders gathered in Washington for a suddenly grim commemoration of NATO's 50th birthday. 
 Mr. Clinton, standing in the Rose Garden with Javier Solana, NATO's Secretary General, said that Mr. Milosevic must withdraw his troops from Kosovo "or he can watch as NATO grinds down his war machine, and the Serb people he claims to represent face mounting hardship."
As the summit opens, some difference are clear within an alliance that has struggled to present a unified face. Prime Minister Tony Blair and other British officials, the first arrivals, aggressively pushed a hard line on Kosovo in a series of meetings with President Clinton, members of Congress and business leaders. Mr. Blair has been the most outspoken of the NATO leaders in urging the deployment of ground forces.
Sketchy reports that Mr. Milosevic was willing to accept some form of international monitoring force in Kosovo were called a possible "step forward" by President Clinton at the news conference today. However, those reports left it unclear whether Mr. Milosevic would accept an armed international presence.
As the President spoke this afternoon, NATO warplanes and missiles began a third night of attacks on leadership targets in Serbia. NATO bombs hit Mr. Milosevic's presidential residence and the Government television station in Belgrade.
Yugoslavia denounced the strike as an assassination attempt, which American and NATO officials denied. They portrayed it as a legitimate assault on the military leadership of Yugoslavia, though not on Mr. Milosevic directly, effectively drawing a distinction without making a difference.
Mr. Clinton said that removing Mr. Milosevic from power was not one of the aims of the conflict, and that if Mr. Milosevic withdrew his troops from Kosovo and allowed the peaceful return of the refugees, NATO would wreak no further damage and would not seek to unseat the Yugoslav President.
"Well, we set forth certain conditions, and if he meets those conditions, and the Serbian people are willing to continue him in power, then I could imagine such an outcome," Mr. Clinton said.
The President also endorsed what he called Mr. Solana's decision to study the possible need to introduce ground forces into the Balkans conflict. When asked whether an international security force could be sent into Kosovo without Mr. Milosevic's approval, the President said, "Well, that's a hypothetical question, but of course there are scenarios under which that could occur."
Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the former Russian Prime Minister, said today after meeting with Mr. Milosevic in Belgrade that Mr. Milosevic would be willing to accept an unspecified international "presence" in Kosovo to monitor the return of refugees. The United States and NATO have tried to suggest to the Russians that Russian troops be part of some type of land force there.
Administration and allied officials said tonight that they were skeptical about the Russian-Serbian initiative and that few details were available.
A European official said he thought Belgrade and Moscow might be trying to undercut the summit by offering a vague peace plan just as NATO leaders sat down to map a military campaign.
One senior American official said he suspected the initiative was a propaganda ploy designed to appeal to the Russian people; an American aide said that the proposal had gaps on issues like the size and composition of a peacekeeping force.
But Mr. Clinton did not dismiss the offer out of hand.
Mr. Clinton repeated that such a force could include not only American and NATO troops, but also Russians, Ukrainians and soldiers from other Slavic and Orthodox Christian countries.
"If it is true," Mr. Clinton said of the Milosevic offer, "then it is at least the first acknowledgment by Mr. Milosevic that there will have to be a security force there. But for the security force to work, it will have to have the confidence of the people who live there, and it will have to operate in a way that protects all the people there, including the Serb minority."
The NATO summit was intended to be a celebration of the alliance's victory over Communism and a seminar on its future. Instead, it has become a war council on Kosovo, with all its reminders of the grisly ethnic conflicts that grew into the century's bloodiest wars.
A senior European official said that Mr. Milosevic's apparent willingness to consider an international presence in Kosovo was a sign that he was beginning to crack.
On Capitol Hill, Mr. Blair staked out a hard line as he moved from speech to speech in his first full day here. Addressing about 30 United States Senators, he laid out what one Congressional aide called a "compelling case" for the allied attacks on Yugoslavia.
Alistair Campbell, chief spokesman for the Prime Minister's office, said that Mr. Blair was trying, in his public and private comments, to assure allied unity.
His language has been more forceful than Mr. Clinton's, in part because the President fears alienating an American public that lags behind the British people in support for the Balkan conflict, Mr. Campbell said. But he denied that the British were serving as the stalking horse for the Americans.
And he insisted that the two countries are on the same track on Kosovo. He said that Mr. Blair was determined to use the NATO summit "to send powerful signals to Serbia and rest of world about NATO determination and confidence the air campaign is working."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE HISTORY;
How the Midwives of NATO Prevailed

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, whose 50th anniversary will be ceremonially commemorated by the leaders of its 19 member nations here this weekend, was the brainchild of a portly, rough-hewn former trade union leader with a grade-school education, the illegitimate son of a serving girl.
His name was Ernest Bevin, and he was Britain's Foreign Secretary. In the anxious early days of 1948, with Czechoslovakia slipping under Communist sway and Berlin blockaded, he feared that the Soviet Union would pick off the nations of Western Europe one by one. 
 Mr. Bevin therefore proposed to the British Cabinet on Jan. 8 "that we should seek to form with the backing of the Americas and the dominions a Western democratic system comprising Scandinavia, the Low Countries, France, Italy, Greece and possibly Portugal. As soon as circumstances permit, we should, of course, wish to include Spain and Germany, without whom no Western system can be complete."
With minor changes, that idea became NATO, the centerpiece of the allied containment policy.
"It was superb idea, and it turned out to be a superb accomplishment," said Lucius D. Battle, now 80, an American diplomat who was present when the treaty establishing the organization was signed on April 4, 1949. "Surprising, in a way. It was not at all clear, and there was by no means universal agreement, that it was the right way to go."
After some initial hesitation, the far-seeing American Secretary of State George C. Marshall, who had served as the nation's military Chief of Staff during World War II, and his discreet, patrician Under Secretary, Robert A. Lovett, came to agree with Mr. Bevin. (At one early stage, Mr. Lovett accused the British of "asking us to pour concrete before we see the blueprints.") They oversaw months of negotiations that produced a draft treaty by Christmastime.
Mr. Marshall's successor, Dean G. Acheson, pushed the talks to a conclusion in 1949 and won Senate approval with the help of Senator Arthur Vandenberg of Michigan, a Republican and former isolationist.
But the real American midwife of the new organization, the first major military alliance the United States had ever joined in peacetime, was a career diplomat named John D. Hickerson. Unknown then and all but forgotten now, Mr. Hickerson, a wry, 50-year-old Texan who had worked his way through the University of Texas at Austin, in part by shining shoes, championed the concept.
Ultimately he persuaded Mr. Marshall, and through him, President Harry S. Truman, of the importance of the principle that became Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty: An armed attack on any of the signing countries would be considered an attack on all.
That, he believed, would provide the tight links between Europe, the United States and Canada that Mr. Bevin sought. For most of the rest of 1948, while President Truman was staging the whirlwind campaign that produced his upset victory in November, Mr. Hickerson and his No. 2 in the State Department's Bureau of European Affairs, Theodore C. Achilles, labored in the shadows with Hume Wrong of Canada and senior European diplomats to pound a treaty into shape.
"They were the valiant workers in the vineyards," said George Elsey, now 81, then an aide to Truman. "They were the ones who put things together."
That it could be done at all was remarkable. It is an iron rule of American politics that lame-duck Presidents take few initiatives. Those they do take almost always misfire. Truman, seen as a sure loser to Thomas E. Dewey, not only laid the groundwork for NATO but also instituted the Marshall Plan.
But those were extraordinary times. The Allies were keeping Berlin alive only with an airlift of unprecedented dimensions. On March 10, 1948, the body of Jan Masaryk, the Czech Foreign Minister, was found on the pavement outside his apartment; it was never established whether he had been killed by the Communists or had committed suicide in political despair. In Asia, Gen. Douglas MacArthur was warning that the imminent victory of Chinese forces "imperiled" the United States. And in Washington, the Red Scare was under way; on Dec. 15, Alger Hiss was indicted for perjury.
Times were hard in Europe. The Washington lawyer Lloyd N. Cutler, then a junior Government official, recalls staying at the grand Claridge hotel in London and shivering because there was no heat. According to his biographer, Alan Bullock, Mr. Bevin was horrified that spring when a French minister told him the Russians would be in Paris by August.
In the United States, the mood was grave but not frantic. "We took the cold war seriously," Mr. Elsey said, "but I would not say there was a sense of crisis -- nothing remotely resembling the feeling later, during the Cuban missile crisis. Like the Marshall Plan, NATO was carefully crafted, by people who didn't let the alarm bells distract them."
Not that everyone agreed that NATO was the right solution. George F. Kennan, then the director of policy planning at the State Department, favored the containment of the Soviet Union. But he saw the problem as basically political, and he warned that the proposed pact "would amount to a final militarization of the present dividing-line through Europe" (which, in the event, it did).
Paul Nitze, who was to be his successor, said last week that NATO "seemed to me at the time an overcommitment on our part." When the Russians soon after announced that they had developed an atomic bomb, "I took a much more radical line," Mr. Nitze, now 92, recalled. "I thought getting rid of our nuclear weapons, unilaterally if necessary, was the best way to go."
The leading American journalist of the day, Walter Lippmann, wanted to neutralize a united Germany, rather than try to ally with the western part of a divided Germany. He argued that Germans would "never align themselves honestly and reliably with one side or the other," and he dismissed NATO as "inflationary paper from the mimeograph machine in the State Department."
But significant as those voices were, the State Department's European desk -- Mr. Hickerson and Mr. Achilles -- "carried the day," said James Chace in his biography, "Acheson" (Simon & Schuster, 1998).
The founding members were the United States, Britain, France, Canada, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Portugal, Iceland, Norway and Denmark.
In April, the treaty was signed in the Departmental Auditorium building, since renamed the Andrew Mellon Auditorium, on Constitution Avenue. Mr. Acheson signed for the United States, Truman at his side. The Marine Band played airs from "Porgy and Bees," rather disconcertingly including "It Ain't Necessarily So" and "I Got Plenty of Nothin'."
"Who in the world picked the music?" Mr. Acheson asked.
The ratification debate was not plenty of nothin'. Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the unofficial leader of the Senate Republicans, opposed the treaty, largely because it would commit the United States to fight alongside any attacked member, robbing Congress of its Constitutional authority to declare war. That, of course, was just what the Europeans wanted.
Mr. Acheson's negotiations, as he wrote in his memoir, "Present at the Creation" (W. W. Norton, 1987), "became a contest between our allies, seeking to impale the Senate on the specific, and the senators, attempting to wriggle free." With Mr. Vandenberg's help, he convinced both groups, and the treaty was resoundingly approved by the Senate, 82 votes to 13, on July 21.
