HEADLINE: Giuliani Budget Proposal Calls for Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $35.3 billion spending plan for New York City yesterday, emphasizing tax cuts, school vouchers and other initiatives favored by the national Republican Party at a time when he has all but declared himself a candidate for the United States Senate.
The Mayor stepped up his criticism of the city's public schools, vowing to pursue a voucher program over the objection of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and saying the school system "should be blown up." Page B10. 
 But as Mr. Giuliani proclaimed that the city had a record surplus of $2.1 billion, Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council, questioned why the Mayor had proposed cutting more than $110 million for libraries, cultural groups, youth services and other programs. He also complained that Mr. Giuliani's tax cuts were insufficient and his voucher plan inappropriate, setting the stage for a battle over how to spend an unusually large pot of money.
"What I see is a great economy, but a budget that does not go far enough," Mr. Vallone said yesterday. "These are not good cuts. These are not good ideas."
Except for $157 million in new tax cuts, Mr. Giuliani's budget plan was almost identical to the one he proposed in January, which called for accelerating a class of 1,500 police recruits and building new schools with the city's anticipated share of the settlement with the tobacco industry.
But while Mr. Giuliani proposed putting $6.15 billion toward school construction in his preliminary budget, he vowed yesterday to withhold the money until the Board of Education presented him with a detailed plan for spending it.
"By law, they were supposed to present us with a plan by March 1," Mr. Giuliani said. "We really need to hold them to a very strict standard."
But the education proposal that drew the most scrutiny yesterday was Mr. Giuliani's plan for an experimental voucher program, which would use millions of tax dollars to send poor children from a single school district to private and parochial schools. The Mayor had originally proposed administering the program through the Board of Education, but Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew protested and even threatened to quit.
So in his budget presentation yesterday, Mr. Giuliani proposed running the program out of City Hall instead, using $12 million from the general budget as "incentive money" for whichever school district volunteers. But Dr. Crew said later in the day that he was still adamantly opposed to the voucher proposal, and he also expressed frustration with the Mayor's plan to withhold the capital funds.
As he has done in recent speeches to Republican audiences around the nation, the Mayor spoke passionately about the need for vouchers, saying the competition they created would force failing schools to improve. "This is where America is going to be five years from now," Mr. Giuliani said. "We've got to open up our thinking and get out of almost the inquisitional mindset that we're in, the box that we're in, and understand this and embrace it."
But Council leaders loudly protested the voucher plan, saying that it probably was unconstitutional and that any education dollars should be invested in the public school system. "My personal position has always been and will remain that until we improve and do what it takes to make our public education system excellent again," Mr. Vallone said, "I am not about to divert any money from it."
The Mayor said he wanted to use most of a $2.1 billion surplus from the current fiscal year to reduce future budget gaps. A large chunk of the surplus -- about $830 million -- would pay for social service, education and public safety programs, including anti-smoking initiatives, the acceleration of the police class and the hiring of 150 new crossing guards. An additional $405 million of the surplus would finance new tax cuts.
Mr. Giuliani, who abandoned his traditional charts yesterday for a high-tech projection screen and laser pointer, used superlative after superlative to describe the effects of his policies on New York City and even on the nation.
The city gained more private-sector jobs in 1998 than in any previous year, he said, and it now has the lowest unemployment rate since 1990. The Mayor, who is highlighting the city's falling crime rate as he tests the waters for a potential Senate race, also said the drop in New York City's murder rate during his first five years in office had been a driving force behind the national drop in crime.
"We are creating the reputation of the state and to some extent, the reputation of the nation in crime reduction," Mr. Giuliani said as he discussed his proposal to accelerate the police class, a plan that the Council has promised to fight.
Critics of the Mayor said his proposals to hire more police officers and experiment with school vouchers suggested that he was more interested in winning national Republican approval than making life more affordable in New York City. Even his tax cuts were not particularly generous, they said.
In particular, critics said that Mr. Giuliani's plan to provide an earned income credit to 600,000 of the city's poorest families was not enough.
The proposed credit, which would cost the city $48 million, would save an average family about $80 per year. But a similar proposal by the Council, which would cost the city $190 million, would save an average family about $360.
"It's a good idea, but the Mayor is doing it on the cheap," said Glenn Pasanen, associate director of City Project, a liberal public-policy organization. "With a $2.1 billion surplus, where is the enhanced quality of life for the people who really need it?"
In addition to the earned income credit, Mr. Giuliani has proposed reducing the city's portion of the sales tax on books by 50 percent, which would cost about $14 million next year in lost tax revenue, and extending a tax relief program for owners of co-ops and condominiums, which would cost $166 million.
Almost all of the Mayor's tax cut proposals would need approval from Albany, and one in particular -- a plan to eliminate the sales tax on clothing and shoes costing more than $110, which would cost the city about $90 million a year -- is unlikely to win legislative support.
Speaker Vallone has proposed his own set of tax cuts worth $700 million, and city officials predicted yesterday that budget negotiations between the Giuliani administration and the Council would focus on which taxes to cut. In particular, the Council wants to eliminate the commercial rent tax, which brings the city more than $400 million a year in revenue.
But Mr. Giuliani would rather dedicate $882 million in commercial rent tax revenue over the next four years to stadium construction, a proposal that Mr. Vallone strongly opposes. Budget negotiations last year broke down over Mr. Giuliani's plan to use tax dollars to build a new Yankee Stadium in Manhattan, and while he has abandoned that plan, stadium construction could become a contentious issue again this year.
Mr. Vallone has said he is not against using tax dollars to build stadiums, but he would rather use revenues from the hotel tax, which are more modest.
Although Mr. Giuliani insisted that spending would decrease by 1.6 percent in the coming fiscal year, independent budget monitors predicted that it would actually increase by almost 5 percent. The city is not projecting a spending increase because under its own accounting rules, the surplus is counted as being spent in the current fiscal year, even though the Mayor is using it to cover next year's anticipated shortfall.
The independent monitors also criticized Mr. Giuliani's use of the surplus to cover the anticipated budget shortfall, saying he should instead use it to reduce debt or pay up front for capital projects. They said that while the city was generally in good fiscal shape, the Mayor should not necessarily be taking credit.
"It's a relatively simple year for balancing the budget, and that's a function of the local economy," said Douglas A. Criscitello, director of the city's Independent Budget Office. "My view is that the Mayor has very little to do with record Wall Street profitability over the last few years."
Mr. Criscitello and other budget monitors warned that if the economy slows down, the city will not have the large surpluses it has come to depend on to fill budget gaps, which they said were largely created by heavy borrowing.
"Debt service will continue to eat up more and more of the city budget," Mr. Criscitello said. "So I would argue that the city's largest fiscal challenges are lurking beyond the next couple of years."

HEADLINE: High Priorities for India

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "A New Trial for India" (editorial, April 20), you state that "India's challenge is to prevent the present political turbulence from undermining the drive to make peace with its neighbors and among the warring groups within its borders." 
 Such foreign policy initiatives are important.
However, the real failure of India's leaders has been the failure to provide an acceptable standard of living for its people. One hopes that India's leaders will soon realize that the best way to insure their electability is by improving the lives of the people who vote for them. Perhaps education, health care and drinking water may all become a reality for India's impoverished millions.
 
VISWANATH SUBRAMANIAN
Sunnyvale, Calif., April 20, 1999

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Finish Mixed On Seesaw Day

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury issues were narrowly mixed yesterday as prices spent the session moving in the opposite direction from the stock market.
"The stock market and Treasury market are moving in opposite directions from time to time," Gary Nadich, a fixed-income portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation, said. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32 , to 95. The bond's yield was unchanged at 5.6 percent.
The pattern held throughout the trading session. When stocks were weaker, Treasury prices were higher. Treasuries wiped out those gains when the stock market erased its losses. When stocks turned slightly lower, Treasuries did slightly better.
Mr. Nadich said that in addition to competition from a strong stock market this week, Treasuries came under pressure from the supply of so-called spread product -- corporate, agency and asset-backed debt issues offering higher yields than Treasuries. "The typical Treasury investor is looking at areas offering spread over Treasuries, which include some of the foreign bonds as well," Mr. Nadich said.
Brazil, for example, issued a five-year, $2 billion global bond this week at 675 basis points over the comparable five-year Treasury note. And Freddie Mac sold $3 billion in 10-year reference notes at 123 basis points over Treasuries. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"When you're in a low-rate environment, when those opportunities for higher yields present themselves, you take advantage of that," Mr. Nadich said.
In the absence of any fresh economic data, comments by Federal Reserve officials attracted some attention but had little effect on prices.
Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, said the economies of United States trading partners would begin to recover in late 1999 or early 2000.
At a Jerome Levy Economics Institute conference in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., a Federal Reserve governor, Edward M. Gramlich, said the potential noninflationary growth rate of the gross domestic product was 2.5 percent to 3 percent.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Poverty Vow Wasn't Meant To Go So Far

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
ED PHELAN took a vow of poverty when he joined the Christian Brothers, a Roman Catholic religious order. He is in no danger of breaking that sacred promise. He runs the Highbridge Community Life Center in the Bronx, directing an 80-person staff that provides welfare recipients and high school dropouts with counseling, job training and an education. It's front-line social service work that gives him more psychic income than the green kind would.
In January, he opened a line of credit to sustain successful training programs financed last year through the Federal empowerment zone in the South Bronx. A $494,000 grant for the second year of staff salaries and program costs has been held up, because the empowerment zone board has not met to approve any projects. Brother Ed, whose group trained almost 70 people for jobs as nurse's aides or package deliverers last year, had entered the new year borrowing money and shifting other grants, thinking the money would be approved quickly. But the empowerment zone seems like the Twilight Zone. 
 "There are people on my staff who say, 'Ed, you took a vow of poverty, but I don't have to live it,' " he said. "This has sapped all of my energy trying to find money, worrying about it and trying to keep the message from our staff that it's panicville."
The board was to have met last February, but the meeting was canceled when Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington, who represents the city, asked for more information on zone projects in Harlem. While another meeting is scheduled for next month, Brother Ed has tried without luck to shake loose his group's share of the money a little earlier. He said Mr. Washington has yet to respond to his entreaties.
Payrolls can't wait, and Brother Ed had to take out $230,000 in bank loans at 8 percent interest. Although only six staff members are affected by the impasse in financing, his entire staff may have to take pay cuts to keep the programs running.
"We're going from day to day," Brother Ed said. "We need to bring pressure on Rudy Washington to approve this contract. The city talks about the importance of people getting off public assistance and into jobs. Their delays are killing us."
A spokesman for Mr. Washington did not respond yesterday to a request for comment.
Joe Ithier, the president of the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, and a member of the zone's board, said the Highbridge group was not the only project affected by the delay in convening the board. He said that several businesses that have applied for grants and loans to open up in the zone have had plans stalled.
"They could tell us they're going to Jersey where things move fast," Mr. Ithier said. "The empowerment zone is supposed to cut red tape. What we're doing is adding to it."
Moving anywhere is not an option for Brother Ed. He has stayed in this hilly corner of the Bronx for years, even when some of his friends joked that it seemed the landscape got bleaker the longer he was there. Things have changed.
"A lot of people are working together," Brother Ed said. "It's not about having a lot of awards or nice-looking buildings. It's about the struggle of people. It's about helping."
HE does not want people to get lost in the quagmire over budgets and grants. Every day he sees his neighbors from Highbridge sitting at computers or filing into classrooms ready to learn new skills. Dorenda Gibbons was there last Monday, studying for her high school equivalency diploma. She used to be stuck at home, surviving on welfare and feeling sorry for herself because of chronic bursitis.
"I have to get off public assistance," she said. "I can't take it anymore. If I can get my diploma, I'm good to go."
Nearby, Betty Mitchell was taking a break from her first day of nurse's aide training. She already earned her high school diploma at Highbridge, now she wanted to find a job in a nursing home to help care for the elderly. She got the idea for that recently, when her parents died from cancer months apart.
"Not many people show emotion when they care for old people," she said. "It's just a job to them. I want to make a difference in somebody's life. We're all going to get old. We all need somebody to help us eventually."
Brother Ed nodded. He understood her perfectly well. Especially on payday.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Soros SaysSale of Debt Means End of World Crisis

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
George Soros, the financier, said yesterday that Brazil's $2 billion note sale showed that the world's financial markets had recovered after their turmoil last year.
"The global financial crisis is now officially over," Mr. Soros said at an investors conference in Manhattan. "So now we can look for the next one." 
 Brazil's sale of five-year notes marked the first time the country tapped international capital markets since last April. The notes were priced on Thursday to yield 11.88 percent, 6.75 percentage points more than United States Treasury securities of comparable maturity.
Demand was strong. Arminio Fraga, the president of the Brazilian central bank, said yesterday that there were more than $6 billion of bids for the $2 billion of five-year notes.
About two-thirds of the notes sold on Thursday went to United States investors, with the rest going to Europe. There was a total of 308 separate accounts, Mr. Fraga, a former aide to Mr. Soros, said at a news conference.
"We were very happy with the $2 billion cash offer," Mr. Fraga said. "It achieved the objectives we set of borrowing to cover both domestic and foreign debt and set a benchmark for foreign issuers."
Mr. Fraga said Brazil planned to sell more debt, but he would not say how much or what terms. "We are putting together a program to better manage our yield curve," he said, referring to Brazilian efforts to sell debt with longer maturities.
The second part of Brazil's debt sale -- an exchange -- closed yesterday. Investors will be able to swap previously issued Brazilian Brady bonds they own for the new five-year notes. Mr. Fraga declined to discuss the results of that sale.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Debt-Relief Plan Is Flawed, 5 Nations Say

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
With the number of people living in absolute poverty on under $1 a day likely to reach 1.5 billion next year, five major industrialized powers -- the United States, Canada, France, Germany and Britain -- have acknowledged that a plan devised three years ago to forgive debts of the poorest countries is not working well.
Suggestions these countries have made for improving that plan, the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Debt Initiative, will be discussed at the meeting on Monday of finance ministers from the so-called Group of Seven richest countries, which also includes Italy and Japan. 
 A final decision on ways to change the initiative, first disclosed in October 1996 by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, is expected at the Cologne meeting of heads of government of the Group of Seven in June.
Twenty-nine countries have been classified eligible for relief under the plan because their debts are more than two-and-a-half times export earnings, average incomes are less than $925 a year and they have carried out at least three years of economic changes approved by the I.M.F.
But the debts of only two -- Uganda and Bolivia -- have been reduced. Another five -- Burkina Faso, Guyana, Ivory Coast, Mozambique and Mali -- are likely to receive relief this year.
In a confidential report to member governments earlier this month, the monetary fund acknowledged what it called the shortcomings of the debt-relief initiative, saying it did not adequately lower payments.
"There is a consensus on the need for further steps to relieve debt," Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F. managing director, told a news conference here Wednesday at the spring meeting of the monetary fund and the World Bank. James D. Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, told a news conference Thursday that "we need to do more."
But a clear difference of emphasis emerged between the I.M.F. and World Bank approaches to easing the debt burden of impoverished nations.
Mr. Camdessus said he favored making more countries eligible for relief since this would bring more developing economies under the fund's supervision.
Mr. Wolfensohn, by contrast, presented debt forgiveness as a way to release additional money for fighting poverty, saying the number of people living on less than $1 a day had risen from 1 billion a few years ago to about 1.3 billion today and would probably reach 1.5 billion by 2000.
Mr. Wolfensohn also warned of the rising cost of granting debt relief. The cost of the current system is estimated at $12.5 billion, and is up almost 30 percent from last summer. This is partly because falling commodity prices have reduced the export earnings of many poor countries.
Suggestions on increasing debt relief to be discussed at the Group of Seven meeting Monday involve relaxing the conditions heavily indebted countries must meet before they can receive help. Canada and Britain are the most generous, France the least. Germany has shifted from opposing debt relief to welcoming it following its recent change in government.
But many private humanitarian organizations pressing for debt relief have criticized these suggestions. "They are all inadequate, though Canada's and Britain's are relatively good," said Veena Saddarth, a representative of the Oxfam International aid organization.
"Debt sustainability is still linked to exports, not to development and poverty reduction needs," said the Jubilee 2000 Coalition, an alliance of private aid and church organizations.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 1; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1645 words

HEADLINE: Grand Strategy: Round and Round On U.S. Interests;
Kosovo Rekindles a Debate, Dormant for Nearly a Decade, Of America's Global Role

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
The American involvement in Kosovo has started the most furious debate since the end of the cold war over what constitutes United States strategic interests.
Not since the Persian Gulf war in 1991 have foreign policy analysts filled the nation's airwaves, newspapers and policy journals with such passion. "The Kosovo crisis has sharpened and intensified what was a largely theoretical debate within think tanks and seminar rooms," said John J. Mearsheimer, a professor of political science at the University of Chicago. "The $64,000 question is what areas of the world and causes are worth Americans fighting and dying for?" 
 Experts call it "grand strategy." During the cold war, containment was the grand strategy; American policy was based on fighting any expansion of Communism. Yet almost a decade after the collapse of the Soviet Union, there is still no consensus over how this new world should be structured and what role the United States should play in it. If the Kosovo crisis does nothing else, Mr. Mearsheimer and others agree, its resolution will affect whose ideas about United States national interests will prevail.
Charles A. Kupchan, an associate professor at Georgetown University, says the United States has essentially been "running on the fumes of cold war thinking for nearly a decade, tinkering and making adjustments in policies left over from that era."
Yet before strategists could figure out what should take the place of containment, they first had to agree on what the post-cold-war world was shaping up to look like.
Frances Fukuyama first gained attention by declaring we had reached the "end of history." The American victory over Communism would usher in an era of peaceful competition among existing and aspiring democracies, he triumphally predicted. Events quickly overtook his theory, however, prompting Mr. Fukuyama to backtrack on his unbridled optimism.
Next, Prof. Samuel Huntington of Harvard University argued that conflict was inevitable. The next century's fault lines would be along "civilizational" or ethnic and cultural divides, pitting, say, Christian Europe against the Muslim Middle East or the Confucian East. Although Mr. Huntington says the Balkans illustrates his thesis, others disagree. "As Kosovo shows," Mr. Mearsheimer says, "the world is not divided into civilizations. In Kosovo the Christian West is battling Orthodox Christian Serbs on behalf of Muslim Albanians."
Then the "globalizationists" or "mercantilists" came along, people like Jeffrey E. Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management, who argued that national sovereignty is inevitably -- and happily -- eroded by global economic forces. Ideology is dead. Long live free markets.
Such grand visions of the world are a starting point, but as Mr. Kupchan explains, "they do not give much direction to American grand strategy or foreign policy." It took the crisis in Kosovo to smoke out the new competing foreign policy camps, which can roughly be divided into three groups.
At one end of the spectrum are the "Fortress America" advocates. Think of Patrick J. Buchanan, the television pundit and repeat presidential candidate, who basically says the United States should not get caught up in other countries' messes, whether they're military, economic or political. Richard N. Haass, director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution, who worked in President George Bush's National Security Council, says the Fortress America contingent has the advantage of being straightforward, relatively consistent and minimalist. "Neo-isolationists believe that the purpose of foreign policy is to have as little of it as possible," he explained. While tragic, this camp argues, the brutal effort to drive Albanian Muslims from Kosovo is not an American problem.
At the opposite end are the "interventionists" or "hegemonists." Philip D. Zelikow, director of the Miller Center of Public Affairs in Charlottesville, Va., and another Bush Administration veteran, however, prefers to call this camp "expansive idealists." They can be either liberal or conservative.
The interventionists have found common intellectual ground in the idea that the United States is the only superpower left standing and simply cannot avoid getting involved. The United States has an obligation to do whatever it takes to create a world where it dominates, the thinking goes. In this view, the United States has a "window of opportunity to shape the world in its image," Fareed Zakaria, the managing editor of Foreign Affairs magazine and a skeptic of this approach, explains.
Interventionists on the right include Robert Kagan and William Kristol, whose prescription for victory in the Balkan war in a recent issue of The Weekly Standard is to "liberate Kosovo and drive Milosevic from power," using ground forces and whatever else to "win it." Defeat or even the perception of defeat must be avoided at all costs. "At stake is the single overriding question of our time," they write. "Will the United States and its allies have the will to shape the world in conformance with our interests and our principles? Or will we allow much of the world to slip into chaos and brutality, to be shaped by men like Milosevic and Saddam Hussein . . . and the dictators in Beijing?"
A similar definition of national interest in the Kosovo conflict comes from liberal or "humanitarian interventionists," who argue that preventing and stopping genocide, "ethnic cleansing" and other gross violations of human rights are in the United States strategic interests. "Humanitarian intervention is a more important challenge than our interventions in Korea or Iraq," argues Leslie H. Gelb, president of the Council on Foreign Relations, "in that it goes to the very heart of who we are and what we think our role in the world is all about."
President Clinton's foreign policy is liberal interventionist, many analysts on the right and left agree. He has also been intent on obtaining cooperation and consent for American policy from the allies. "This Administration is very Bolshevik in its use of force," said Mr. Mearsheimer, in an unusual choice of words. "Air power is their favorite tool and they haven't been reluctant to use it. They've bombed four separate countries."
Mr. Kupchan, a more liberal analyst, concurs: "The Administration has been incredibly lucky in its interventionism until now. There have been American troops everywhere, but except for Somalia, no Americans have died. Clearly that can't last." He and other experts say that Kosovo, particularly the decision on whether to send in NATO ground forces, will test liberal interventionism. "Until now," says Mr. Kupchan, "we've had liberal interventionism on the cheap."
Some critics, like Charles Krauthammer, a conservative columnist, say liberal interventionism will fail the test. In a recent essay in The New Republic, he denounced President Clinton's foreign policy as "hopelessly utopian." Peacekeeping or mending civil wars is not the job for a superpower, he writes. "It is a job for Canada." Forget about multilateral agreements and consensus. A superpower should concern itself with "real" threats, like the aggressive conduct of North Korea, and not worry about what other nations think. In an interview he called liberal interventionism "dangerously ill conceived."
Mr. Krauthammer calls himself a realist; it is a label that the majority of foreign policy experts in this third camp are probably most fond of using (although Mr. Mearsheimer prefers to say that his group favors "offshore balancing," intervening to prevent the emergence of potential competitors). "Most realists are offshore balancers," Mr. Mearsheimer says. "And most of us do not see any such threat emerging as a result of Kosovo."
Mr. Haass, whose book, "Reluctant Sheriff," reflects and promotes "realist" foreign policy thinking, argues that the American role is the "regulation of great power relations," that is, to work out "rules of the road with other major power centers." Building alliances that promote free trade, discourage the use of force and limit the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction all advance American strategic interests.
As for Kosovo, Mr. Haass and other realists tend to be cautious. And they often disagree over whether strategic national interests are at stake. Do American interests justify "such a commitment in blood and treasure"? he recently wrote. The United States must "balance humane impulses with strategic imperatives." Liberating all of Kosovo with military force "is not worth the costs it would entail."
Yet as Kosovo illustrates, defining an American grand strategy or the country's national interest is not necessarily straightforward even if one has a clear notion of how the world should be organized. Regardless of whether Kosovo is worth fighting for, by getting involved, the United States has created a strategic interest there even if one didn't exist before. "Once America stakes its credibility on an issue, it automatically becomes strategic," Mr. Zakaria says. Even those "realists" who disapproved of American involvement in the war against Yugoslavia concede that having made the commitment, the United States must pursue victory with all possible means, including ground troops.
Of course not all self-described realists agree. Henry A. Kissinger, who presided over the Vietnam War, which cost 50,000 American lives, argues against "the proliferation of open-ended American commitments involving the deployment of U.S. forces." He draws the line on sending American ground troops to Kosovo; the Europeans should provide the soldiers.
Until there is more of a consensus over how the United States should respond in this changing world, it may be that the United States grand strategy can best be described as muddling through.

HEADLINE: A Military Alliance, and More

BYLINE: By Tony Blair; Tony Blair is the Prime Minister of Great Britain.

 BODY:
Our common fight in Kosovo will dominate the NATO summit that opened yesterday in Washington. I'm sure that America, Britain and all the other NATO countries will make clear our determination to see this military engagement through to the end. President Slobodan Milosevic should be in no doubt about the alliance's strength, commitment and resolve.
Only NATO has the ability to oppose the Serb campaign of ethnic cleansing -- a sustained campaign of brutality that has turned Kosovo into a slaughterhouse, with Mr. Milosevic's death squads burning, raping and killing. Let us not underrate what we have achieved already. As Gen. Wesley Clark told the summit yesterday, we have destroyed significant parts of the Serbian air defenses and attacked Mr. Milosevic's armed forces. We have severely degraded oil transport and oil refining capabilities and radically reduced the Serbs' industrial and administrative infrastructure. 
 I know that the media discussion has been focusing on the use of ground forces. As I have said repeatedly, the difficulties of a land force invasion of Kosovo, against an undegraded Serb military machine, in the face of Serb resistance, are formidable.
At the same time, Mr. Milosevic cannot be granted a veto over our actions, and Javier Solana, NATO's Secretary, speaks for us all in saying we must continually assess and update all our options. There will be no deals and no compromises. Mr. Milosevic must cease all military operations and end all repression in Kosovo. He must withdraw his forces. The refugees must be allowed to return. And he must acquiesce in a NATO-led international settlement.
NATO, for its part, must tighten economic sanctions. And we must continue to provide humanitarian assistance to the refugees.
It is important, too, that we plan for the long-term, cooperative security of Europe. This means redefining the core functions of the alliance as military planners prepare for the 21st century. Article 5 of the Washington Treaty, which established the alliance in 1949, treats an attack on one as an attack on all.
It is the most remarkable mutual guarantee ever given among nations. We are extending that to three new partners -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic -- and preparing for the admission of new members in the future.
NATO comprises three crucial partnerships that we need to nurture and develop. Foremost is the partnership between Europe and North America. It extends beyond the security sphere. The shared values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights make NATO more than a military alliance. They are the practical and political embodiment of trans-Atlantic unity.
Americans seem to recognize that the developing European Union is in the best interests of NATO. While the United States may well be the only remaining superpower, the union packs a big punch in trade and economics. But we need to develop its political clout, too, so that America can look to its European allies to share more of the defense burden. As the European Union improves its ability to manage political crises, Europe will make a stronger contribution to NATO.
NATO will always be the bedrock of our collective defense. But Europeans also need to be able to take on security tasks where the alliance as a whole is not engaged.
This is a concept we will develop further at the summit, without duplicating NATO's impressive apparatus for planning and for mobilizing force, and in a way that will mean we can better carry out our military responsibilities whenever we need to act.
The wider Euro-Atlantic community of nations will be exemplified at the summit when we are joined by our partner countries in the Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council. This will underline that NATO is not an inward-looking club of the secure West, but an alliance dedicated to fostering security and stability throughout Europe.
I also would like to see Russia become an active and successful member of this Euro-Atlantic community, as is now the case with Ukraine. Russia belongs to Europe spiritually and politically as well as geographically. We need to learn how to insure that Russia and the allies can work more effectively to pre-empt crises like Kosovo. A necessary first step is to resume the military cooperation and political dialogue that was developing well before the current crisis in Kosovo.
NATO's first task, of course, is to protect its own member countries. But we will be judged by our more general ability to deliver security and personal freedom. That means NATO must have a moral perspective and a conscience. We must be willing to right wrongs and prosecute just causes.
That is what we are doing over Kosovo, and why our pilots and crews will be operating over the Balkans again tonight. That is the clear message from NATO. And that is the lesson Slobodan Milosevic will learn.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

THE AMERICAS
 
CHILE: NEW PINOCHET STRATEGY -- In a new legal strategy, Chile announced that it would request arbitration from the World Court at The Hague to determine whether Britain, Spain or Chile has the sovereign right to decide the legal fate of the former dictator Augusto Pinochet. General Pinochet has been held in Britain since October on a warrant issued by a Spanish judge charging him with various crimes against humanity. Clifford Krauss (NYT) 

VENEZUELA: U.S. AIDE'S TRIP PUT OFF -- The U.S. has indefinitely postponed an official trip to Caracas by an Assistant Secretary of State, saying "now is not a good time" for him to visit. The action came after Foreign Minister Jose Vicente Rangel accused Washington of exerting "elements of pressure" to prevent President Hugo Chavez from carrying out the "peaceful revolution" he has pledged, and described American policy toward Cuba as "a stupidity." Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
MEXICO: ELECTORAL REFORMS PROPOSED -- The four opposition parties that control the Chamber of Deputies introduced a package of electoral reforms. One provision would enable Mexicans living in the U.S. to vote in Mexico's presidential elections next year. Another would make it easier for opposition parties to unite behind a joint presidential candidate in 2000. President Ernesto Zedillo's governing party, known as the PRI, opposes the reforms. They are likely to be approved in the Chamber but blocked by the PRI-controlled Senate. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
SCOTLAND: NATIONALISTS FADING -- Two polls showed the Scottish Nationalist Party, advocates of full independence for Scotland, losing substantial ground to the Labor Party in campaigning for May 6 elections to the new parliament in Edinburgh. The Glasgow Herald, whose poll was based on interviews with 3,255 voters, making it the biggest poll conducted in Scotland, said Labor appeared headed for a majority of seats and that the earlier support for the Nationalists, headed by Alex Salmond, above, was now "in free fall." Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
BRITAIN, TURKEY: KURD TV BANNED -- Regulators revoked the license of Med-TV, a Kurdish-language satellite television channel based in London, saying it had been used to promote violence. Turkey has accused the channel of broadcasting attack orders from Kurdish rebel commanders after the capture of the rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan. Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey welcomed the decision. (AP, Reuters)
 
SWITZERLAND: EASING DRUG LAWS -- A Government commission has recommended that the sale and use of marijuana be legalized under certain conditions. The recommendations were part of an overall study of Swiss drug laws, which have failed to prevent a rise in marijuana consumption. To prevent the country from becoming a drug haven, purchasers would have to prove they lived in Switzerland. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: DEATH PENALTY REPRIEVE -- President Boris N. Yeltsin plans to commute all death sentences in Russia as the country moves toward eliminating capital punishment, said Robert Tsivilev, who heads the presidential department for pardons. He said Mr. Yeltsin wants the cases of the roughly 300 convicts on death row to be reviewed by the end of May. (AP)
 
ASIA
 
MALAYSIA: 3 ANWAR ASSOCIATES INDICTED -- Prosecutors indicted three associates of former Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim, compounding the ex-minister's legal position a week after he was jailed for corruption. Mr. Anwar's brother, Sukma Dermawan, left, was charged with sodomy, assisting sodomy and perjury. His former private secretary and a fashion designer who has worked for Mr. Anwar's wife were indicted for perjury. The three are central to other charges hanging over Mr. Anwar. (Reuters)
 
AFGHANISTAN: GETTING ON-LINE -- The Internet, E-mail and direct international dialing are about to come to Afghanistan, a country with only two known international land lines and a domestic phone system dating to the 1950's. Local officials said the first direct links would bring Afghanistan on-line within two to three months as part of a 15-year program. The move, which has the blessing of the governing Taliban, follows talks with the U.S.-based Telephone Systems International Inc. (Agence France-Presse)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
MOROCCO: ARAB RIGHTS CONDEMNED -- Rights activists from 15 Arab countries said violations in the Arab world had soared in the 1990's with the rise of Islamic militancy and worsening economic conditions. With few exceptions, human rights records in Arab countries continued to deteriorate, they said at a three-day international conference on Arab rights. The harshest criticism was leveled at the Government of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. (Reuters)
 
AFRICA
 
SOUTH AFRICA: BLACK CRICKETER CONVICTED -- Makhaya Ntini, the only black cricketer on the national team and central to its efforts to recruit black youths to the game, was convicted of rape. The team, which had supported him through the trial, immediately suspended him. Mr. Ntini denied raping or having consensual sex with a young woman who asked him for a ride home from a cricket ground, and his lawyers said they would appeal. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)
 
SOUTH AFRICA: PEOPLE'S POET GETS 13 YEARS -- Mzwakhe Mbuli, a musician and writer known as the People's Poet, was sentenced to 13 years in prison for his part in a 1997 bank robbery. Mr. Mbuli claimed that he was framed because he had information about drug-running and gun-smuggling by high-ranking members of the African National Congress. Mr. Mbuli said he would appeal. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)
 
UNITED NATIONS
 
DEVELOPMENT CHIEF APPROVED -- The General Assembly approved the candidacy of a British World Bank official, Mark Malloch Brown, to lead the largest U.N. agency, the U.N. Development Program, which dispenses some $1 billion a year. Mr. Malloch Brown was chosen to succeed James Gustave Speth, an American, who is leaving to become dean of the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies at Yale University. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Nasdaq Continues to Climb On Strong Earnings Reports
After setting a high Thursday, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slid 1.97 points, to 1,356.85. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 37.51 points, to 10,689.67. The Nasdaq composite index, which includes many computer companies, climbed 29.08 points, or 1.14 percent, to 2,590.69, capping its second-best four-day gain ever. 
 Computer shares rallied for a fourth day on optimism about profits, while AT&T pulled the Dow Jones industrial average lower on concern that the phone company's $58 billion bid for Mediaone would hurt earnings. I.B.M. soared over 200 before settling at 199 3/4, up 5 1/4. The computer maker gained $28 billion in market value this week after reporting higher-than-expected profit and sales. Page C3.
 
Chock Full o'Nuts Shares Acquired
Three directors of Chock Full o'Nuts, including the 84-year-old chairman, bought company stock in the months after they rejected an unsolicited takeover offer from Sara Lee, but before that offer was disclosed to the public. The suitor remains interested, however, and this week disclosed that it had approached the company recently, sending the stock up almost 50 percent. C3.
 
Merck Profits Rise 12% in Quarter
First-quarter earnings at Merck & Company jumped 12 percent, to $1.3 billion, on gains in the sale of key prescription products and growth of its drug benefits business. Sales rose 24 percent, to $7.5 billion. C3.
 
Mercedes Opens a Plant in Brazil
DaimlerChrysler opened a factory to produce Mercedes-Benz cars in Brazil. DaimlerChrysler, which already assembles Dodge pickup trucks at a plant in southern Brazil, hopes to produce at least 25,000 A-Class compact cars in the first year at its $820 million factory. If the Brazilian economy manages to grow next year, company officials said they could almost triple annual output to 70,000 by 2000. C2.
 
Debt-Relief Plan Is Not Working
With the number of people living on under $1 a day likely to reach 1.5 billion next year, five major industrialized powers -- the United States, Canada, France, Germany and Britain -- have acknowledged that a plan devised three years ago to forgive debts of the poorest countries is not working well. C2.
 
Soros Declares Financial Crisis Over
The financier George Soros declared the global financial crisis over and said that Brazil's $2 billion bond sale showed that the world's financial markets had recovered after their recent turmoil. Brazil's sale of five-year bonds marked the first time the country tapped international capital markets since last April. The bonds were priced on Thursday to yield 11.88 percent, 6.75 percentage points more than United States Treasury securities of comparable maturity. C2.
 
Losses at Japan's Brokerage Firms
Japan's biggest brokerage firms reported huge losses for the year. Nomura Securities cited a $3.3 billion loss on its overseas bond trading and aid to an affiliate. Daiwa Securities, Japan's second-biggest brokerage firm, and Nikko Securities also reported losses for a third year, as they too wrote off bad loans at financing affiliates and closed most of their overseas operations. C2.
 
Energy East to Buy Gas Company
Energy East plans to acquire Connecticut Energy, which is based in Bridgeport, Conn., for about $617 million in stock and in cash. Energy East, based in Ithaca, N.Y., said Connecticut Energy shareholders would receive $42 a share and could specify the percentage they wished to receive in stock and in cash. C4.
 
Hyundai Group Planning to Revamp
The Hyundai Group plans to reduce the number of its subsidiaries to 26 from 79 by 2003 through sales and mergers. C2.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1257 words

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: MILITARY ANALYSIS;
One Month: No NATO Victory, No Serb Loss

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
As NATO leaders gathered today behind closed doors to consider their next moves against Yugoslavia, the alliance's commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, offered a strikingly optimistic view of the progress so far. "We are winning," he declared today. "He is losing. And he knows it."
In fact, NATO is far from winning. 
 A month into the air war in the Balkans, Yugoslavia has withstood nearly 3,000 combat raids and shows no signs yet of breaking. President Slobodan Milosevic has succeeded in expelling hundreds of thousands of Albanians from Kosovo, routing the rebel force fighting for its independence and steeling the will of the Serbs in support of his repressive rule.
From the start, NATO's campaign has stumbled over a series of foreseeable and unforeseeable problems -- from political limitations on its initial strikes to Yugoslavia's success in husbanding its air defenses.
The latter has forced NATO to alter its raids and put off the kind of low-flying patrols that could make a real difference against the tanks and artillery battering Kosovo villages.
The Apache helicopters that began arriving in Albania with much fanfare on Wednesday are not expected to begin flying combat strikes into Kosovo for many more days or weeks, officials said, in large part because the Serbs have retained enough of their air defenses to keep allied pilots guessing about the threat they face.
"I don't know what's been done right here," said Gen. Michael Dugan, a retired Air Force Chief of Staff. "The air war has been carried out without much political will or military decisiveness."
It is very difficult, of course, to assess winners and losers after only one month of conflict. Thirty days after Iraqi forces seized Kuwait in August 1990, for instance, it was unclear how Washington and its allies would evict President Saddam Hussein's troops.
To commanders at NATO and the Pentagon, Mr. Milosevic's achievements thus far are fleeting, tactical gains that have brought him little strategic advantage.
The expulsion of the Albanians, which first stunned and then distracted NATO with a parallel relief operation, has only served to harden the resolve of NATO's 19 members. As the air campaign has continued, the allies have become more willing to approve attacks on sensitive targets, like state-run television and Mr. Milosevic's homes.
Officials vow to continue to grind away at Yugoslavia's military and political leadership, insisting that time and firepower are on NATO's side, though time may be what is needed most. "Milosevic will run out of bullets and gas long before we do," a Pentagon official said today.
From the beginning, the United States and its allies laid out political objectives that military commanders warned would be difficult to achieve by bombing alone.
President Clinton said the air campaign had three objectives: to underscore NATO unity in opposing aggression; to deter Mr. Milosevic from expelling ethnic Albanians, and, if necessary, to hurt Belgrade's ability to wage war by "seriously diminishing" its military abilities.
The only objective met so far is a firm display of unity. Yugoslavia's ability to endure the strikes has left NATO no option but to step up the size and scope of its campaign far more than the alliance envisioned when the attacks began in March. General Clark has asked the Pentagon to provide 300 more warplanes and dozens more from other allies, raising the total to more than 1,000, which more than doubles the number on hand when the war started.
NATO's campaign has become a case study in gradual escalation, comparable more to the Vietnam War than the Persian Gulf conflict. In the air war against Iraq, allied pilots flew as many as 3,000 missions a day, compared to 300 to 600 against Yugoslavia. From the first day, gulf commanders targeted the heart of the political and economic power in Baghdad, a tactic only recently adopted against Belgrade.
Senior American military officers initially warned that it could take weeks to break Mr. Milosevic's will. But some top Administration officials privately were convinced that Mr. Milosevic would fold after a few days of air strikes.
Instead, he grew more defiant, and his forces in Kosovo splintered into smaller units that were harder to detect or hit. Many of them have been hunkered down in defensive positions for the last few weeks, out of NATO gun sights, in forests or next to residential buildings and churches where NATO is afraid to bomb.
Unable to eradicate Yugoslav forces in the field, NATO has made its attacks more personal. In addition to hitting Mr. Milosevic's house and national television studios, the alliance also struck two electricity transformers, cutting off power to command bunkers in Belgrade and to the residential and commercial areas around them.
Those targets signal a shift in tactics, one aimed at trying to undercut Mr. Milosevic's popular base. It is a strategy that still relies on an uprising that shows no sign of forming.
"You can have your rock concerts, but pretty soon it's going to be Belgrade unplugged," said the President's spokesman, Joe Lockhart.
There is no question that the attacks have hurt Yugoslavia, destroying its indigenous oil production and shattering its transportation network as NATO cruise missiles and aircraft pick off highway and railroad bridges from one end of the country to the other.
In the Pentagon's latest damage assessment, the director of intelligence for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Rear Adm. Thomas R. Wilson, described Yugoslavia's military and police forces as badly strained, running low on fuel and ammunition and harassed by a down-but-not-out Kosovo Liberation Army.
But Yugoslav forces have been resilient, having learned from Saddam Hussein's mistakes. A defense intelligence official described those lessons, noting that the forces in the field have effectively tried to slip out of NATO's reach rather than confront the alliance's air power head-on. "They've learned how to offset our advantages," the official said.
Yugoslavia's leadership has been resolute and resourceful, too. Mr. Milosevic's special police forces, which have been relocating their headquarters to basements in Belgrade hotels, are still functioning despite the destruction of the headquarters three weeks ago, the official said.
And it was only a matter of hours after American F-117 fighters leveled the headquarters of Serbian television in Belgrade that state-controlled broadcasts were back on the air, leaving NATO little option but to go after the backup sites.
"Stay tuned," the Pentagon's spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, said today, openly vowing to keep Mr. Milosevic's propaganda off the air.
The question in the end is which side can outlast the other. NATO's leaders vowed to stay the course, with some Pentagon commanders warning that the attacks could go for months, even though they have no clear idea when or if Mr. Milosevic will ever relent.
Which is why the NATO Secretary General, Javier Solana, has authorized General Clark to at least update the assessment for using ground troops in Kosovo. Even that threat may not be enough to budge Mr. Milosevic, who has proved difficult for Western leaders to read.
"It's very hard to gauge the level of pain that somebody is willing to endure," Admiral Wilson said. "And I don't know what President Milosevic's level of pain is. But other parts of the society have a level of pain which may differ. And it's getting higher all the time. That's all I can say."

LENGTH: 1256 words

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: OVERVIEW;
NATO Approves Naval Embargo on Oil Going to Serbs

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
On the opening day of the NATO summit meeting, the alliance agreed today to impose an oil embargo on Serbia and to enforce it by searching ships in the Adriatic Sea suspected of carrying fuel for forces fighting in Kosovo.
Defense ministers of the 19-nation alliance took steps toward enforcing the restrictions after NATO leaders made the decision at a three-hour session focused on the Kosovo war. By providing ships to conduct searches and inspections, NATO would try to dry up the flow of oil into ports on the coast of Montenegro, which supply Serbia, a Pentagon official said. It was not clear what actions NATO might take if ships carrying oil defied the alliance. 
 NATO also decided to order the alliance commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, to carry out heavier air strikes against overland pipelines and railroads that carry the fuel to Serbia, the Pentagon official said.
The alliance leaders have gathered here to celebrate 50 years of the alliance, but the gathering has been overshadowed by the month of fighting in Kosovo.
At their session, the NATO leaders issued a communique spelling out their intentions for Kosovo's future.
If President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslav began to withdraw his forces according to an agreed-to timetable, the communique said, the allies would deploy an "international military force" and set up an "international provisional administration" in the province, which would give it autonomy, but not independence.
The idea of deploying an international force and setting up some form of protectorate has been intensively discussed in Brussels, Washington and other NATO capitals.
But the leaders' communique marked a formal commitment by NATO to those conditions for a settlement.
The allies also pledged to seek a United Nations Security Council resolution to demand the withdrawal of Serbian forces.
The specification that the force and the interim administration in Kosovo would be "international," and not necessarily NATO-led, and the inclusion of the Security Council appeared designed to encourage the participation of Russia in a diplomatic solution, which in turn was expected to make it easier for Mr. Milose-vic to accept.
At the same time, the allies officially rejected recent offers of a settlement made by Mr. Milosevic through Russia's Balkan envoy, former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. Without naming Mr. Chernomyrdin, the communique said the Yugoslav leader's "offers to date" did not meet NATO conditions.
Military leaders have been pushing for ways to choke off oil supplies to Yugoslavia, arguing that new oil was arriving even as they were bombing oil installations.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said on Thursday that "basically it didn't make a lot of sense for us to be bombing refineries and at the same time not doing enough to prevent the access of oil by sea." She added, "We are particularly focusing on oil because that is the way that forces move around."
Earlier in the day, the European Union pushed through a decision to ban the supply of oil and refined products to Yugoslavia, excluding supplies for relief efforts.
The Pentagon official said an effort would be made to minimize the damage to Montenegro, a republic of Yugoslavia that has opposed the Government of Mr. Milosevic. "The question is how to stop the flow of oil into Montenegro and to stop the flow out of Montenegro without hurting the Montenegrins."
In their communique, the 19 leaders reaffirmed the five basic demands that Mr. Milosevic must agree to for the bombing to stop. They are a verifiable cease-fire; withdrawal of all Serbian military and police forces from Kosovo; the stationing of an international military presence that would have NATO at its core; the safe return of the ethnic Albanian refugees to Kosovo, and a willingness to work toward a political agreement based on accords from the failed talks held in Rambouillet, France, in February.
The formal 17-point communique of the summit was released against a backdrop of tough language. Phrases like "resolve to see this challenge through" and declarations that "NATO will prevail" reverberated throughout the day.
Jamie P. Shea, the NATO spokesman, set a tone that combined perseverance and defensiveness. He said: "NATO has an obligation to succeed. We cannot afford to lose this one."
At a closed session of the 19 leaders, General Clark gave an upbeat 10-minute briefing on the status of the air campaign. He told them that NATO had "achieved air superiority at mid to high altitudes throughout Yugoslavia," according to his spokeswoman.
General Clark flew back to Brussels tonight, without meeting with President Clinton. His spokeswoman said he had to get back to the war.
And in public briefings by various NATO leaders, their ministers and spokesmen invoked the idea of ground troops as they tried to send a unified message. Much of that talk seemed aimed at Mr. Milosevic, since the alliance leaders still insist that the air campaign is effective.
That option -- of when and how they would enter Kosovo -- was not addressed in the official 17-point communique on Kosovo.
But there was "some discussion" about ground troops at the closed Kosovo session of the 19 leaders, the Canadian Defense Minister, Art Eggleton, said in an interview. The talk focused on asking the military planners at NATO headquarters to review all options, but did not get into specifics, he said.
Their discussion followed a decision two days ago by NATO's Secretary General, Javier Solana, to review all plans for introducing group troops into the region, a decision made at the request of the allies.
The British, who have been the most vocal on the subject of ground troops, reiterated today that they envisioned a situation where troops could enter Kosovo after Serbian forces had been very heavily punished and where Mr. Milosevic had not given his consent.
On Wednesday night, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain spent two and a half hours with Mr. Clinton in a private dinner at the White House, trying to explain to the President the necessity of being prepared to send in troops without Yugoslavia's consent but after Serbian forces had been severely weakened, British officials said today.
Britain's chief of the defense staff, Gen. Charles Guthrie, repeated this theme at a news conference today, saying: "President Milosevic's war machine has been seriously weakened. It's going to be weakened again, day after day, week after week." He added, in reference to going into Kosovo, "And we will be able to choose our time."
General Guthrie said that there were now about 19,000 allied troops in Macedonia and Albania and that more be sent in the coming weeks to be ready to "to take the refugees back."
The general said that he was not prepared to say how many troops would be needed for the operation but that it would need to be more than the 30,000 proposed as a security force in Kosovo before the air attacks began. The British officials stressed that none of the allies would agree to ground troops' fighting their way into Kosovo. "We are not talking about an invasion force," Defense Secretary George Robertson of Britain said.
The Pentagon announced tonight that about 2,300 troops accompanied by heavy armor were being sent to Albania, adding to the 3,000 American soldiers already there.
The new troops were being sent with 15 tanks, 14 Bradley armored vehicles, eight howitzers and a company of soldiers armed with anti-tank weapons.

HEADLINE: Did He Inhale?

BYLINE: By Richard L. Berke; Richard L. Berke is the national political correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:

GORE
 A Political Life.
 By Bob Zelnick.
 384 pp. Washington:
 Regnery Publishing. $29.95. 
 Al Gore presents the ultimate challenge to a biographer, and not just because he is hardly a scintillating politician. He has been a public fixture for so long that the story lines about him are so well established that they are practically cliches: he is animated in private but wooden in public; his father, the Senator, so groomed him to be President that Gore is out of touch with ordinary people; he is trustworthy and reliable, but the accusations about his fund-raising practices in 1996 exposed his need to indulge in the political games that he expects will carry him to the White House.
In "Gore: A Political Life," Bob Zelnick offers a useful and comprehensive survey of the highs and lows of Gore's political career as he embarks on his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination. But the book falls short in offering readers any sense of Gore that is more textured or revealing than what has already appeared in newspaper and magazine articles.
While the book lauds Gore on several points -- his service in Vietnam, his knack in Congress for identifying hot new issues, his intimate, hands-on role in the White House -- there are many areas where Zelnick interprets Gore's actions in the most deprecatory way possible. The book starts on a positive note but, as the chapters progress, turns increasingly critical.
For example, while some environmentalists describe Gore's book "Earth in the Balance" as an impressive work that incorporates his knowledge of global warming and other issues, Zelnick dismisses it as "pathetically one-dimensional in its view of Western civilization, shabby in its ignorance of economics, simplistic in its approach to problem solving."
In describing Gore's participation at a White House session with several leading conservatives, Zelnick is clearly put off by his blunt defense of racial preferences. While many Democrats were impressed by Gore's outspokenness, Zelnick sees it another way. "Clinton's reputation for empathy, analysis and nuance was put on dazzling display," he writes, while "Gore's reputation for stiff-necked condescension was also very much in evidence."
And while many politicians in both parties cheered Gore's performance in debating Ross Perot on the North American Free Trade Agreement, Zelnick ridi-
cules him for offering "anecdotal nonsense, a list of treaty endorsements and some rather nasty ad hominem attacks on Perot."
Zelnick does little to dispel accusations from Gore loyalists that his was the latest conservative-tinged book from Regnery Publishing. The book was controversial even before it was published. Zelnick resigned last year as a correspondent for ABC News after the network said that for him to write a book about Gore and cover national politics constituted a conflict of interest.
One frustration is that Zelnick provides no footnotes. That makes it hard to separate fresh reportage from material that has already been published. That is a particularly important matter because the book cries out for new insights or revelations, especially since Gore did not cooperate.
Even if he did not uncover much, Zelnick does provide some tantalizing tidbits. He recounts, for instance, that Gore liked to smoke marijuana at Harvard and that he and his wife, Tipper, used the drug recreationally for a decade. He explores how Gore was an ardent foe of spending Federal money on abortion -- until he hooked up with Bill Clinton. And he offers evidence that the image of Gore as superorganized and disciplined may not be so accurate.
In his years as a reporter for The Nashville Tennessean, Zelnick recalls, there was "little passion, humor, calculated irony or human insight in Gore's journalism." Zelnick's prose at times seems to share a certain lifelessness. His is a somewhat disjointed book that lacks overarching themes and whose writing is serviceable but hardly graceful.
Even so, as the first in a parade of biographies of the Vice President, this book is likely to become a resource for Gore watchers as the campaign unfolds -- at least until another biographer takes a stab at coming up with a new story line.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1774 words

HEADLINE: Passing the Bucks

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria; Fareed Zakaria is a managing editor of Foreign Affairs and the author of "From Wealth to Power: The Unusual Origins of America's World Role."

 BODY:

False Dawn
 The Delusions of Global Capitalism.
 By John Gray.
 262 pp. New York:
 The New Press. $25. 
 If I had to write a bumper sticker to describe the climate of today's world , it would read: "Globalization -- Love It or Leave It." John Gray once loved it -- he was a Thatcherite in the 1980's -- but now he has left it, and how! His new book argues -- actually, thunders -- that the global economic system is immoral, inequitable, unworkable and unstable. (I think I've got it all.) In "False Dawn," Gray takes on an immensely important subject, ranges widely and vibrantly and makes some telling criticisms. He recognizes that the movement toward free markets, goods and ideas is not a naturally occurring process but rather a political project that rests on American power. His solution is quite simple: Good riddance. He hopes for the return of distinct national variations on capitalism, most of them with high levels of state intervention. His passion is heartfelt, but in the end it overwhelms all else in this book. Gray, a professor of European thought at the London School of Economics and the author of an intelligent study of Isaiah Berlin, charges that the policies advocated by the United States, the International Monetary Fund and most economists -- free trade, liberalization, deregulation -- are wreaking havoc on societies around the globe. They are destroying the welfare state in Continental Europe and East Asia, traditional communities in the developing world and the family everywhere. But they will not succeed because the effects of these reforms will "trigger political countermovements that challenge the very ground rules of the global free market." Globalization, then, is a dangerous fantasy. Dangerous because of its effects; a fantasy because it will not achieve its goal.
Instead, Gray advocates an acceptance of the varieties of capitalism, most of them much more statist than in the United States and Britain. The goal of the liberalizers, he asserts, is to return the world to something close to the first age of globalization -- from about 1870 to 1914 -- when laissez-faire truly reigned. He believes that this romantic view of the belle epoque generalizes from the experience of one country, Britain, and to a lesser extent, the United States. In fact, he argues, British-American development was unique. In all other cases, capitalism was an intensely state-driven project, and those models are the ones the world should follow. And even in Britain and the United States, the state was massively involved, through the enclosure laws in Britain and high tariffs and railroad subsidies in America. And by the way, the 19th-century free market destroyed the social fabric in much of Europe. (This is what lawyers call arguing in the alternate: "I wasn't present that night. And if I was, I didn't break the window.")
Gray has created an elaborate straw man against whom he argues with great relish. In fact, none of the policy recommendations in vogue today could conceivably return Europe to anything like 19th-century laissez-faire. Despite all the oft-mentioned regulation, tariffs and subsidies, the 19th-century state's role in the economy -- even on the Continent -- was tiny. The simplest and best measure of this is state spending as a share of the gross domestic product. In 1870 it ranged from 4 percent in America to 13 percent in France. Today the figures are 33 percent and 53 percent respectively; they actually rose slightly in the libertarian 1990's.
Most free-market reforms discussed in the West are modest attempts to pare back some of the expanding regulations, taxes and entitlements that accumulated in the 1970's and 1980's. (In 1960, after the New Deal, after social markets were established, public spending in Western countries was still only 30 percent of G.D.P.) The most radical free-market reforms being touted by various right-of-center parties would shave a few percentage points off state spending. Gray can relax; the era of big government is here to stay.
Gray also gets the developing world wrong. East Asia grew mainly through laissez-faire, not state direction. Unlike most third world countries, East Asians opened themselves to foreign investment and allowed vigorous internal competition in almost every sector. The state's role in these economies is smaller even than in America, about 25 percent of G.D.P. (because they have few middle class entitlements and welfare programs.) East Asia's statism, exaggerated by anecdotal analysis, is actually limited and often not very helpful. Japanese growth, for example, owed more to those sectors in which brutal competition prevailed -- cars, consumer electronics -- than those the government favored. (Remember high-definition television?) If East Asia is the model, then countries like India, Egypt and even Brazil still have a lot of liberalization left to do. Also, many of the reforms being "imposed" on East Asian societies by the I.M.F. will actually enhance governmental power, mainly through increased regulation of the financial sector. Globalization can sometimes strengthen the state.
The villain of "False Dawn" is America, about which Gray writes with undisguised scorn. "Free markets have contributed to social breakdown on a scale unknown in any other developed country. . . . Levels of inequality in the United States resemble those of Latin American countries more than those of any European society," he writes, and says later, "The middle classes are rediscovering the conditions of assetless economic insecurity that afflicted the 19th century proletariat." Some of his charges are telling; he points repeatedly to America's large prison population, which he dramatically refers to as the result of "a policy of mass incarceration," a formulation that brings to mind -- as I'm sure it's supposed to -- peasants being rounded up by the thousands. Others are simply false; American levels of inequality are actually much closer to European than Latin levels. (The World Bank provides these figures.) Gray also seems to have missed the rise of middle-class capitalism. Over 50 percent of Americans have investments in the stock market, which has quadrupled in value in the last decade.
What troubles Gray most about America is that the rest of the world will become like it. He proposes a version of Gresham's Law; under globalization, "bad capitalism tends to drive out good." Forced to compete with American laissez-faire, other countries will eventually copy it. In fact, this exaggerates the power of global markets. Of course they limit a state's ability to endlessly spend money foolishly, and they do tend to demand some overall efficiency. But every country can achieve efficiency in its own way. America provides lavish subsidies for home ownership; Germany gives its workers generous benefits; France spends extravagantly on culture. All are inefficient from a purely economic point of view, but my guess is that all will survive the ravages of global markets. Indeed, most European societies have already done what Gray hopes for. They seem to have decided not to roll back their welfare states but rather reform them gradually, accepting the lower growth rates such a process entails. Nineteenth-century globalization did not turn every country into Britain; 21st-century globalization will not make every society like America.
Gray exaggerates the power of global capitalism in another sense. The reforms being implemented by all Western countries are not simply the result of globalization or the bewitching power of Thatcherism. The neoliberal policies of the 1990's are a rational response to the stagflation, low growth and overregulation of the 1970's, just as the Keynesian policies of the 1950's, adopted by all Western governments, were a response to the domestic realities of the 1930's and 1940's -- mass unemployment and social chaos. The demographics alone are compelling. Welfare states built on ratios of several workers to one retiree will have to be scaled back as the number of retirees grows in the coming decades. By 2030, Germany's pensions, if they are not trimmed, will take up almost 17 percent of the budget; the figure for 1995 is 11 percent.
Gray's most sweeping charge is that global capitalism is flawed because it is a utopian idea, a product of Enlightenment visions of a perfect society. He sees great similarities in this sense between capitalism and Communism: "They embody the same rationalist hubris and cultural imperialism that have marked the central traditions
of Enlightenment thinking." Gray's last book, "Enlightenment's Wake," was a wholesale attack on the Enlightenment itself, whose emphasis on reason, science and progress, he claimed, had "desolated traditional cultures everywhere and visited devastation of their natural environments." But Gray doesn't seem to recognize that his own vision of a good society is imbued with Enlightenment rationalism. The modern bureaucratic-administrative state, wisely regulating the economy, meeting material needs and promoting social cohesion, is as much an Enlightenment idea -- some might say a utopian idea -- as the free market or Communism. The trouble with the Enlightenment is that you can't get away from it.
The real fantasy in this book is of those wonderful traditional societies that flourished before modernity and the free market wrecked them. The reality in those communities for most people was -- and is -- medieval levels of poverty, disease and starvation. That is why in every third world country peasants flee their settled patterns of life by the busloads, hoping to find jobs in factory towns and cities. Capitalism has provided the only durable path out of misery for ordinary people, first in the West and now around the globe. Of course the movement out of centuries-old poverty is highly dislocating, but the response can hardly be therefore to stop it.
There are moments of wisdom in this book. Gray reminds us of what Daniel Bell called "the cultural contradictions of capitalism" -- the fact that the dynamic force of market economics erodes social cohesion, traditional culture and the institutions that give human beings a sense of security. But the serious discussion in most societies today is about how to tame capitalism enough so that people have some safety and dignity and yet not so much that it denies them material progress and opportunity. In this Gray is little help, because he seems unaware that for the vast majority of the world, the greatest danger of globalization is not that it will succeed but that it will fail.

TYPE: Review
