PUB-DATE: April 25, 1999

SECTION: Section 6; Page 48; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3692 words

HEADLINE: Tropicalia, Agora!

BYLINE: By Gerald Marzorati; Gerald Marzorati is the editorial director of the magazine.

 BODY:
At the time Claude Levi-Strauss was traveling through Brazil in the 1930's, a brilliant new generation of samba composers was emerging in Rio, writing popular songs as cosmopolitan as Cole Porter's. But Levi-Strauss -- who loved music, Italian opera and Stravinsky especially -- never noticed, or so you'd have to conclude from "Tristes Tropiques," his famous anthropological travelogue. Everything about Rio left him sad. Contact with the West had corrupted the tropics, he was convinced; Rio and Sao Paulo, too, where he taught for a time, were little more than modern urban ruins, their up-to-date streetscapes masking an epic loss of human difference. Only when he ventured deep into the interior, and encountered the Bororo -- the pure, unadulterated Other -- did he like what he heard. At night, the men of the tribe, naked except for straw penis-sheaths, shook gourd rattles and chanted in a low-pitched guttural tongue; the "intensity and quality" of the principal players was so remarkable, he wrote, "that no conductor of a large European orchestra could have surpassed them."
I found myself thinking about Levi-Strauss -- of his longing for "authentic" cultures untouched by Western modernity, and of his pessimism about the possibilities afforded by cultural commingling -- as I watched David Byrne one evening last month, hunched behind an up-to-datish stack of audio equipment, mixing together sound-bite-size samples and layering atop them stray electronic noises and pulsing digital beats in the way club D.J.'s do these days. Byrne is still best known as the singer-songwriter who propelled Talking Heads, the great art-rock band of the late 70's and early 80's, but for the past 10 years or so much of his energy has been devoted to introducing Brazilian popular music to America, chiefly through recordings released on his own independent label, Luaka Bop. It was mostly Brazilian music he was electronically mixing and matching that evening at the Lucky Lounge in Austin, Tex., where the annual South by Southwest music conference, the alt-indie music world's answer to the Sundance Film Festival, was in full swing. That the bar was packed with rock critics, music-industry hipsters and barely post-teen musicians in their T-shirts and Vans sneakers is a fairly good indication of how Brazilian pop suddenly finds itself the focus of America's late-90's vanguard. The music at pop's outskirts is not only ever more digitally driven but also increasingly panglobal, and with regard to this polyglot mixing, America's outre popsters have discovered that the Brazilians got there first. 
 Like Levi-Strauss, Byrne has done a good deal of fieldwork, and the composers and musicians he has been most passionately drawn to are those who emerged in the late 60's from Brazil's short-lived counterculture. They saw themselves as pop avant-gardists, and as part of a movement that also manifested itself in poetry, drama and visual art. They didn't create a new musical style so much as a new approach to music-making, combining the ambitious album-oriented rock then making its way to them from England and the United States with Brazil's various rhythm-thick musics and a variety of other ingredients, including difficult modernist poetry and weird found sounds. They wrote wildly prismatic lyrics about the ambivalence they felt concerning Brazil's more and more Americanized, consumer-oriented culture and careful (and eventually not so careful) lyrics about the constraints of living under a military dictatorship. They called the music they were making "Tropicalia," and they created three-minute songs that had all the jagged jump-cuts, wised-up art-about-art references and sheer pop lyricism of a two-hour Godard movie.
"What drew me to it was the sophistication -- the musical sophistication but also the sophistication they had about their situation globally," Byrne told me. "What was 'center,' what was 'periphery.' This sense that Brazil was still this place tied up with our notions of the exotic, the 'primitive' -- they were on to that, and in the music, they were combining all this stuff they were getting from us with other stuff and sort of throwing it back out there. Not in an angry way, but with irony and adventurousness, and with all those great rhythms -- which gives it its particular flavor."
A number of Brazil's greatest contemporary songwriters, including Caetano Veloso and Gilberto Gil, who went on to become huge stars in their country, began their careers at the center of Tropicalia, but their music has taken a while to arrive in America, and not just because the songs are in Portuguese. Only with the advent here of an appropriate-and-recycle, combine-and-recombine esthetic could the Tropicalistas' music -- along with the music of younger Brazilians they've influenced -- finally be heard for what it is: radically ingenious pop.
Beck, who perhaps is making the most ingenious American pop at century's end, has a song on his latest album called "Tropicalia," which borrows its weird noises and samba groove from a song by Os Mutantes (the Mutants), an arty Sao Paulo psychedelic band of the late 60's. That Beck titled his album "Mutations" was taken to be a homage of sorts by the kind of college-radio D.J.'s and hole-in-the-wall record-shop owners who are also into experimental bands like Stereolab and Tortoise and the High Llamas. For that matter, the members of Stereolab and Tortoise and the High Llamas are into the Tropicalistas, too. John McEntire of Tortoise told me recently, "Maybe we're finally catching up to them."
Next month, the members of Tortoise will be playing with Tom Ze, the most far out of the original Tropicalistas, as he begins his first nationwide American tour following the release here last fall of his critically acclaimed album "Fabrication Defect" (Luaka Bop). An album of remixes of Tom Ze songs by McEntire, the High Llamas and others, called "Postmodern Platos" (Luaka Bop), will also be released in the coming weeks, as will a sweepingly ambitious and densely percussive new album by Caetano Veloso, "Livro" (Nonesuch). Veloso is to begin his first big U.S. tour in June, about the time Luaka Bop is planning to release a selection of Os Mutantes' greatest hits, this following the rerelease earlier this year of the group's first three albums by the tiny Omplatten label, which is run by an owner of Other Music, a small record store in lower Manhattan that over the past year or so has been doing a brisk business in hard-to-find Brazilian-pop CD's.
What would appear to be an American moment for Tropicalia -- a moment entailing any number of remarkable musical border crossings and crossbreedings -- is perhaps most tellingly represented not by any list of album releases or concert dates but by a 30-second TV spot for Banana Republic. What you see is a montage of gently evocative images of very beautiful young men and women having very good times in very pale clothes. What you hear is part of a Brazilian pop song, sung by Arto Lindsay (in English) and Marisa Monte (in Portuguese). Lindsay's family moved from Virginia to northeastern Brazil when he was 3; he moved to lower Manhattan in 1974, and in the years since has developed a singular sonic-noise guitar style and has also been involved in the making of a number of the finest Brazilian-pop albums of the past dozen years. Monte was born in Rio, but studied Levi-Strauss's beloved bel canto in Italy before returning to Brazil and, in short order, emerged as a kind of third-generation Tropicalista; she is currently Brazil's leading pop diva.
That Banana Republic, a company that has worked hard to shed a brand image once steeped in fantasies of exotic adventure -- khaki shorts with lots of pockets, anthropologist chic -- would reinforce its new cultivated look with a song from Brazil is what some people might call a paradox. But I think, wittingly or not, that it represents something more, a recognition that "center" and "periphery" are becoming more proximate and less clearly delineated, that borders are growing more porous back and forth, that the Levi-Strauss-Lite differentiation of "world music" from pop music is making less and less sense -- that pop music, in its need to be made ever new (for that is its promise, and pleasure), is going omnidirectionally global, like everything else. Which is way Tropicalia.
For the Tropicalistas, mixing was in the blood. Nearly 40 percent of Brazilians identify themselves as mulatto, but in some ways that figure, astounding as it is, doesn't begin to describe the country's musical miscegenation -- a near-numberless variety of regional styles that fuse African tribal musics (the legacy of slaves), Portuguese ballads, Amerindian sounds, a variety of Caribbean styles (themselves hybrids) and the musics of more recently arrived European immigrant groups. In the towns and cities of Bahia in northeast Brazil, where most of the Tropicalistas grew up, the mixing, racial and musical, is especially pronounced, and by the time Gil and Veloso and Ze (and Gal Costa, who would later sing many of their songs) met in the early 60's at the university in Salvador, the Bahian capital, they were familiar not only with the reigning bossa nova style, which they played on their acoustic guitars and sang with their soft voices, but also with Carnival samba marches and accordion-based rural dance music and also the many foreign sounds the radio brought: Celia Cruz, Duke Ellington, Elvis. Only Ze was studying music at the university -- classical music with Ernst Widmer, a follower of Stravinsky -- but the university was something of an arts hotbed, with new schools of theater and dance as well as music, and the future Tropicalistas were exposed to, and grew increasingly interested in, modernist philosophy and esthetics. Put another way, they were getting the intellectual grounding of a typical contemporary American art-rocker.
Tropicalia emerged in Sao Paulo, where Veloso and the others had settled by 1966. It was there they met the members of Os Mutantes and also Rogerio Duprat, a classically trained arranger and producer who would be to the Tropicalistas what George Martin was to the Beatles. It was an uneasy moment in Brazil: the military, worried about a sinking economy and a restless left, had staged a coup in 1964, which the left protested bitterly and (from time to time) violently -- which led, in turn, to harsher crackdowns. Still, the old-line left, like the right, was nationalist and populist when it came to culture and to popular music in particular, since it was both the most distinctive and most democratic of Brazil's cultural manifestations. According to Christopher Dunn, who teaches Brazilian cultural studies at Tulane University and is at work on a book about Tropicalia, the young musicians gravitated to the "esquerda festiva" (festive left), a circle of artists, journalists and university students who detested the military regime and at the same time dismissed the Brazilian Communist Party as decidedly and hopelessly unhip. Like the generalissimos, the old lefties couldn't stand rock-and-roll, especially the newer, countercultural gringo rock-and-roll.
Veloso, Gil and the others arrived at a different idea about rock. They not only liked the Beatles and Bob Dylan and Jimi Hendrix, whose albums were making their way to Sao Paulo -- they also wanted to use their music, use it to break Brazilian pop out of its nationalist confines or, as Veloso once put it, to help create "an immediate posture of 'being in the world' -- we rejected the role of a third-world country living in the shadow of more developed countries." In their approach, the Tropicalistas were drawing heavily on the thinking of Brazil's modernist writers of the 20's, principally "The Cannibalist Manifesto" of Oswald de Andrade, an antiestablishment poet. Andrade urged Brazilian artists to devour foreign art and information along with their national canon and daily papers and then to "regurgitate" it all, creating new forms of transcontinental bricolage that would inherently comment on Brazil's place in the world. In today's pop terms, it was a call for global sampling and mixing -- and that's pretty much what it amounted to in the music of Gil, Veloso and the rest, once they began plugging in electric guitars and experimenting with different sounds and various sorts of poetry-inspired lyrics.
You can hear it, for example, in Veloso's 1968 rock anthem, "Tropicalia." (The movement's name was taken from an ambient-art installation constructed in the spring of 1967 at the Museum of Modern Art in Rio by one of Brazil's leading contemporary artists, Helio Oiticica.) The song begins with drums and strange sounds that could be bird cries -- Levi-Strauss's virgin tropics! -- followed by a voice declaiming a passage from "The Letter of Pero Vaz Caminha," considered the first literary document of colonial Brazil. Then amid slightly "off" Nelson Riddle-like horn bursts, Veloso juxtaposes allusions to Brazilian culture, past and present, high and low, before a quick cut to a rocking, syncopated northeast-Brazilian baiao beat signals the ironic, but not simply ironic, refrain that translates as:
Long live the forest la-la-land!
Long live the mulatta-ta-ta !. . .
Long live. . .Carmen Miranda-da-da-da-da!
Arto Lindsay, who like Byrne has been immersed in Brazilian pop for years, not only producing albums by Veloso and others but also making Brazilian-infused music of his own, explains the Tropicalia esthetic this way: "A lot of pop musicians in the U.S. and England were borrowing stuff from strange places in the 60's, but they were doing it the way musicians tend to -- blending it in to make it theirs, and in that way sort of hiding it. In Tropicalia, you let the rough edges show, that was the point. The meaning was in the juxtaposition. The juxtaposition said something about the world."
The Tropicalistas emerged as long-haired rock stars and counterculture prophets in Brazil not through radio or big tours but on television. TV stations in Sao Paulo and Rio held annual music competitions during which, for several evenings running, acts performed before juries of critics and record-industry people. These festivals were held in big theaters or arenas -- with boisterous audiences cheering on their favorites or booing -- and were carried live to the millions of Brazilian music lovers who gathered around TV sets at home or in bars. In October 1967, Gil and Veloso introduced the Tropicalia sound at one of the festivals, which until then had been dominated by bossa nova, and got themselves noticed pretty much the way any cutting-edge pop musicians do -- they were loudly cheered and booed.
The following year, at the International Song Festival in Sao Paulo, it got a lot uglier. Having decided to turn the event into an Event, Gil kicked things off with a raucous and clearly anti-military (and also anti-left) song called "Questao de Ordem" ("Question of Order") and was disqualified. Then Veloso appeared on stage with Os Mutantes -- who were dressed in plastic clothes and working up all sorts of electronic distortion and feedback -- and began to sing "E Proibido Proibir" ("To Forbid Is Forbidden"), which is a phrase he had taken from the protests of May '68 in Paris. He never got to finish the song: he was shouted down by the audience, composed mostly of more traditional leftist students who preferred "purely" Brazilian acoustic music and detested the rock, the plastic -- what they saw as pure libertine capitalist decadence. But before leaving the stage, Veloso delivered what sounds today like a Lennon-ist update of Andrade's "Cannibalist Manifesto." Shouting above the catcalls, Veloso declared: "You're out of it! You don't get anything!. . .If you're the same in politics as you are in music, we're done for!"
As a result of this incident and others that followed, he and Gil were done for, and so, as a tightknit movement, was Tropicalia. On Dec. 13, 1968, the military suspended habeas corpus and instituted a blanket censorship. Veloso and Gil were arrested before the year was out and imprisoned for two months before being sent into exile in England, where they remained for several years.
Twenty years after his banishment, on the title track of a brilliant album entitled "O Estrangiero" (Elektra Musician), which could be translated as "The Stranger" or "The Foreigner," Veloso looked back with dark ambivalence at the Brazil of that time and other periods from the vantage point of lower Manhattan, where he recorded the album with Lindsay and a number of other downtown musicians at what was the predawn of the American music vanguard's interest in Tropicalia. The song is long and loud and nightmarishly apocalyptic, and ends with Veloso singing, in English, "Some may like a soft Brazilian singer/but I've given up all attempts at perfection." It may be the clearest distillation of how he sees himself -- except the words aren't his. They're lifted from what Dylan wrote in 1965 on the back of "Bringing It All Back Home," the album on which he turned his back on folk purism and went electric -- that is, crossed borders, recontextualized things, adulterated.
Appropriate. Cut. Paste.
Tom Ze was on the phone from Sao Paulo not long ago, struggling good-naturedly through an interpreter to find the right metaphor for what is happening just now with Tropicalia in America. Echo chamber? Feedback loop? "All these things going back and forth, music and information, are so strange," he said. "I may pick up a phone and be talking to you, but also may pick up the phone and have a Brazilian journalist who had long ago forgotten about me now asking me, 'What is all this interest in your music in New York about?"'
Ze remained in Brazil after the military crackdown on Tropicalia, his music becoming increasingly experimental and iconoclastic through the 70's. He mixed the gentle strains of acoustic guitars with atonal passages and the sounds of floor polishers and bicycle pumps, and wrote lyrics that were often childlike and funny if deceptively political. (The dictatorship continued until 1985.) No one in Brazil seemed to get it, and even as Gil and Veloso re-emerged and became national heroes of a sort, Ze disappeared. By 1986, which was when Byrne discovered his records from the 70's in a Brazilian record shop, Ze had more or less stopped making music. "I was thinking of going in on this gas station with my nephew," he said, "when David Byrne calls me and says he wants to make a recording of my music for America."
Byrne had got into Brazilian pop only months before. "I know there should be an urban-myth version of the story," he said, "but I just went to Tower Records one night and bought a bunch of Brazilian records based mostly on which covers interested me. I liked a few of them. Not long after, I went to Brazil, where I found these records from an earlier period, Tom Ze and others, that were radical but not abrasive or ugly -- which, with my Northern or European understanding, is what I guess I assumed 'radical' music had to be."
Luaka Bop released a compilation of Ze's recordings from the 70's in 1990 and an album of new material two years later, but only with the release last year of "Fabrication Defect" did Ze really catch on here, with the album getting lots of college-radio play -- the infectious rhythms, oddball sounds and cut-and-paste texture of Ze's songs allowing for easy segues to any number of tracks by mix-and-match contemporary avant groups.
It may well be that global-scale mixing-sampling-layering is the only pop-music strategy that suits a quickened world of clicks and info-fragments, jumbo-jet migrations and hyphenated identities. So much of today's "authentic" pop, whether that of Nashville country crooners or gangsta rappers or bands staging patriotic rallies in Belgrade, is little more than exotic kitsch, conveying a romance with the unrecoverable, or worse. More than anything else, pop is about the embodiment of change -- in the music and in you -- and as a result, to keep making meaning, it must evolve. And for the most part it has done so through interbreeding. It is no coincidence that the cultures that have contributed most to pop's evolution -- those of the United States, Brazil, England and the Caribbean -- are those in which African and European musics have fused. Now what has been mostly intranational appears to be going international.
In England, groups like Cornershop and Asian Dub Foundation are scrambling more traditional Indian musics with hip-hop, punk and 60's guitar drones. Bands of this kind tend to be high-tech and ethnically and racially mixed, and at South by Southwest, there were others. A feverishly mix-match Hamburg group called Todos los Manos featured members from Chile, Brazil and Germany. And on the last night of the festival, I caught a spirited set by the downtown New York group Cibo Matto, which is essentially the creation of two Japanese women, Yuka Honda on keyboards and Miho Hatori on lead vocals, who mix Tokyo pop with Motown girl-group harmonies, dreamy electronic soundscapes and hip-hop beats. Rounding out the band were an African-American rapper and percussionist, a white male drummer and, on bass, Sean Lennon -- who happens to be a big fan of Tom Ze and did one of the tracks on the "Postmodern Platos" CD of Ze remixes. That neither Cibo Matto nor any of these groups makes music, not yet at least, with the intensity and quality of the Tropicalistas is a reminder that pop's evolution has always been patchy, and that Tropicalia really was, and is, something else.
"We are at the end, thus, of the composers' era, inaugurating the plagi-combinator era," Ze writes in the liner notes to "Fabrication Defect."
I wouldn't be surprised if someday soon, some kid in Ankara or Bombay or Calgary with an electric guitar -- or, more likely, a keyboard synthesizer, a digital sampler, a drum sequencer, two turntables and a microphone -- steals that line and sings it.

PUB-DATE: April 25, 1999

SECTION: Section 2; Page 27; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Surviving an Era Of Maoist Tumult With Calm Intact

BYLINE: By LESLIE CAMHI; Leslie Camhi's most recent article for Arts and Leisure was about the Spanish director Julio Medem.

 BODY:
Wu Tianming is well acquainted with the whims of fortune: During the 1980's, as an acclaimed director, he headed Xian Film Studio, the cradle of the New Chinese Cinema, which burst upon the international scene with the force of a revelation. Less than a decade later, he was reduced to running a video store in Los Angeles.
Today, Mr. Wu, at 60, is once again working as a director in China. On a recent visit to New York, he looked back on these twists of fate with remarkable good humor. What's the secret of his equanimity? "I'm very easy-going," he explained through a translator. "I have no heart and no lungs." Meaning? "I don't let things get to me. There's an old Chinese poem that says, 'If you've been through the big wave of the ocean, the quiet water of the river cannot disturb you anymore.' " 
 "The King of Masks," Mr. Wu's first film in a decade, opens in New York on May 9. Set in Sichuan province in the 1930's, it follows an itinerant street performer, Old Wang (Zhu Xu), who earns a meager living astounding crowds with his skill at "changing faces." Using elaborate sleight of hand, practitioners of this folk art change masks as if by magic. Master Lliang (Zhao Zhigang), a celebrated female impersonator in a local opera company, admires Wang's artistry, but Wang declines the offer to join Lliang's wealthy troupe. Instead, he longs for a male heir to inherit the secrets of his skill. On the black market, Wang meets Doggie (Zhou Ren-ying), a 7-year-old put up for sale by his destitute father. An ecstatic Wang buys him, but soon discovers that his new "grandson" is really a girl, an inappropriate heir and a worthless creature on the scale of China's social values. There his troubles begin. Doggie and Wang suffer extreme misfortune, but they're bound by love and by their common fate as outcasts.
A simple, sensitive film, "The King of Masks" draws upon Mr. Wu's deep understanding of rural Chinese culture. "He's a country boy," said Donald Gibbs, a professor of Chinese language, literature and film at the University of California at Davis, where Mr. Wu has been a guest lecturer. "He's very earthy and unpretentious. He speaks the language and understands the heart of mainstream country China in a way that city folks never will. That's his gift, that's who he is, and his films reflect that."
Mr. Wu was born in China's Appalachia, the poverty-stricken, agrarian north of Shaanxi province. He began his career in the province's capital as an actor at Xian Film Studio; in 1966, when the Cultural Revolution short-circuited his plans to study film in Beijing, he spent years at home reading about filmmaking in secret.
"Many educational books were destroyed, but film manuals were spared, because film didn't seem to matter much," he said with some amusement. "And then, there were so many books, the Cultural Revolution people could not burn them all."
During those dark years, Mr. Wu's father, a former revolutionary and devoted government official, died shortly after being jailed on trumped-up charges of treason. Mr. Wu himself suffered public humiliation. In his 1987 film, "The Old Well," a young man dies in a tragic accident; party officials attend the funeral to report allegations of his licentious behavior. "That's what those times were like," Mr. Wu said. "People would even accuse the dead."
When the Cultural Revolution subsided, Mr. Wu was finally able to attend the Beijing Film Academy. After graduating in 1976, he returned to Xian and received his first solo directing credit for "River Without Buoys" (1982), a spectacular popular success about three men who share their experiences of the Cultural Revolution as they pilot a raft down the Pushui River. Two years later he made "Life," which focuses on a village schoolteacher who is torn between his intellectual urban aspirations and his love for a peasant woman.
" 'Life's' appeal was so broad," Mr. Gibbs recalled, "that intellectuals and city people loved it, and peasants would place gifts of vegetables and poultry at the door of Mr. Wu's studio with notes saying, 'Please let us know what happened to the characters.' "
As the head of Xian Film Studio, Mr. Wu also promoted artistic freedom; he was open to the fresh ideas and daring approaches of younger directors. His film "The Old Well," about a man striving to find a new source of water for a village nestled high in stony mountains, starred a young actor named Zhang Yimou. Mr. Zhang is better known as a member of the "Fifth Generation" of Chinese directors, who got their start at Xian Film Studio and went on to capture world attention. Films like Mr. Zhang's "Red Sorghum" (1988), a sensuous rural epic culminating in the Japanese invasion; Tian Zhuangzhuang's "Horse Thief" (1986), an austerely beautiful film about Tibetan nomads in the 1920's, and Chen Kaige's "King of Children" (1987), which focused on a schoolteacher sent to the countryside during the Cultural Revolution, were all produced at Xian. Their spectacular visuals and unorthodox subject matter reflected a radical break with prevailing codes of Socialist Realism.
"The Fifth Generation drove home the idea that the official Socialist version of reality was not only boring but a lie," said Xudong Zhang, a Rockefeller Fellow in the humanities at New York University and a specialist in Chinese cinema. "They tried to uncover a deeper reality by inventing a new cinematic language, a new visual culture, and by turning our gaze to truths that had been concealed. Their utopian energy was directed against an ossified state bureaucracy. These Fifth Generation directors were not exactly political dissidents, however; for a brief period in the 1980's, the critique of Chinese tradition in their films fit in well with Deng's ideology of reform."
MR. WU was visiting the United States in the spring of 1989 when the events of Tiananmen Square unfolded. He remained in this country for five years. Returning to China to make "The King of Masks" in 1994, he found a culture in the throes of economic and social transformation. "I don't understand why, all of a sudden, Chinese people seem to have grown so cold," he said. "That's why I wanted to make this film, to show that love and warmth are more important than tradition or money."
China's new entrepreneurial spirit has had mixed results for the nation's vanguard cinema, which now finds itself competing with Hollywood products. Like many recent films by Chinese directors, "The King of Masks" was primarily financed by nonmainland sources, in this case the Hong Kong-based Shao Brothers film studio. Bottom-line concerns have not prevented the rise of a "Sixth Generation" of Chinese directors, however, whose documentary style and focus on private, ephemeral experience stand in sharp contrast to that of their predecessors.
Meanwhile, the irrepressible Mr. Wu keeps working. He has just completed China's most popular television soap opera ever, and is directing another -- 36 episodes about a century in the lives of three families living near the Yellow River. (He expects about 32 episodes to remain when the censors finish their work.) Like Old Wang in "The King of Masks," he changes faces but maintains a deep simplicity.
"That's the film's broader message," he said. "In life in general, you have to keep changing faces in order to survive."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 29; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1951 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Apostle of Inner Struggle and Redemption

BYLINE: By PAUL GRIFFITHS

 BODY:
A WOMAN among composers; a freethinker among Soviet apparatchiks; a Christian among atheists; an Easterner, half Tatar, among Europeans; a modernist among reactionaries, and a reactionary among modernists: Sofia Gubaidulina has lived with many conflicts, both with the outside world and within herself. Her arrival, in her 50's and 60's, at moments of extraordinary musical power has been a triumph of persistence and self-searching. Ms. Gubaidulina, now 67, has become a great light, and her achievement has happily been matched by steadily increasing public recognition, which reaches a culmination in New York on Thursday evening, when two big new works will be presented almost simultaneously: "Two Paths," at Avery Fisher Hall, and "In the Shadow of the Tree," at Carnegie Hall.
"Two Paths," for two violas and orchestra, will be played by the New York Philharmonic, with its front-desk violists, Cynthia Phelps and Rebecca Young, as soloists and Kurt Masur conducting. The work was commissioned by Mr. Masur's wife, Tomoko, who was herself a violist. "In the Shadow of the Tree" also has multiple solo parts, but in this case they are played by one musician, Kazue Sawai, performing on Japanese instruments: koto (the floor-level plucked harp), bass koto and zheng (a similar instrument, but Chinese rather than Japanese and with a wider range). Here the commission came from the orchestra of Japanese radio, the NHK Symphony, which will be conducted by Charles Dutoit. 
 That both scores should be concertos is no accident. For Ms. Gubaidulina, the relationship between soloist and orchestra, whether combative or consolatory, provides an image of the individual in the world and of the truth to be found amid what she has called the "staccato" of life. And it was with a concerto, "Offertorium" for violin and orchestra, that she began to gain attention outside Russia. Composed in 1980, "Offertorium" was taken around the world by Gidon Kremer, who recorded it at the end of the decade. By then, thanks to glasnost, Ms. Gubaidulina was at last receiving official acclaim in Russia, but in 1992 she left for a new home in Hamburg, Germany.
"Offertorium" is typical of Ms. Gubaidulina's work, in that it is a journey through conflict toward new knowledge and illumination, it uses a wide range of musical means, and it justifies that range as a crucial necessity to a composer intent on immediate expressive force. She exhibits no commitment to fine style. The characteristics of her music are instead abruptness, ripped change and a finish that is often rough, raw and ragged. "Offertorium" sounds like a page torn ruthlessly from a book: a book whose subject would have to be the spiritual life. It even makes the tearing sound, as it breaks away from a Bach theme orchestrated by Webern -- two composers Ms. Gubaidulina reveres above all others -- and embarks on a quest for its own continuation and its own way to end.
Along the line of Ms. Gubaidulina's artistic journey, "Offertorium" was a message from halfway. She was born nearly 50 years before, in 1931, in Chistopol, the daughter of a Tatar-Russian couple. Her childhood years were spent largely in the nearby big city, Kazan, in an environment that the musicologist Theo Hirsbrunner has described in terms that surely came from the composer herself: "Life there . . . was rather uninteresting: no trees in the back yard, just a patch of grass here and there -- yet the sight of the sky with its passing clouds captivated the child. A buffoon played the accordion, and Gubaidulina danced to its music."
Dance, as an image of the body and therefore the soul in perfect tuning, has stayed with her; among her recent pieces is "Dancer on a Tightrope" for violin and piano, the latter mostly strummed. And the accordion has stayed, too, for several of her works use the instrument in its ethnic Russian form, the bayan. Even beyond these examples, many of her scores carry traces, in their long sustained tones and their orchestral clamor and wheeze, of the dancing girl and the folk musician.
Ms. Gubaidulina started her conservatory studies in Kazan soon after World War II and completed her education at the Moscow Conservatory between 1954 and 1963. She remained in the capital, though without much encouragement or support. Her regular studies seem to have been less important to her than the contact she made with Philipp Herschgowitz, a Webern pupil who was a vital source of instruction to young Russian composers at a time when anything in non-Russian music since Debussy was virtually proscribed. Her straying from "the bright, pleasant aspects of life" was noticed by an early reviewer, but Shostakovich privately expressed to her his hope that she would continue on her "wrong course."
She did. As a result, her works were rarely played and never recorded. As another result, she had to earn her living by writing film scores. Her achievements in this area include the music for Rolan Bykov's "Scarecrow" and a number of collaborations with Ida Garanina on animated films. But this sort of work was not a chore: it provided her with another kind of education, since the need to match music to gesture gave her a strong sense of how instruments can speak and how music can mimic physical action or, by extension, movements of the mind and spirit.
Neglect also proved useful to her, throwing her back on herself, alone or in the company of a few colleagues. With Alfred Schnittke and Edison Denisov, both recently deceased, she was a leader of the quiet musical opposition, and she made up for the lack of performances by forming an improvisation group with the composer Viktor Suslin and the ethnomusicologist Vyacheslav Artyomov, whose collection of instruments from the Caucasus and Central Asia gave the group a wide sound-world.
The works Ms. Gubaidulina wrote in the 1960's and early 70's already reveal her liking for the soloist-accompaniment format of the concerto, song or instrumental piece with piano, but not until the later 70's was she able to make her expressive purposes explicit. "Hour of the Soul," of 1976, was an early instance: a half-hour percussion concerto in which the soloist stirs up the orchestra; eventually a mezzo-soprano emerges, singing verses by Marina Tsvetayeva. Like most of Ms. Gubaidulina's pieces before and since, "Hour of the Soul" was written for a particular player, in this case Marek Pekarski, so that, in the composer's words, "only at the end does the truly feminine nature appear."
Ms. Gubaidulina would almost inevitably have been drawn to explore in her music issues of maleness and femaleness, and "Hour of the Soul" is by no means the only work in which she has done so. But she adopts a rather conventional position in expressing the contrast in terms of dynamism and stasis, rationality and irrationality, thought and feeling, and it would be hard to identify her musical voice as that of a woman and therefore unlike those of such contemporaries as Schnittke, Henryk Gorecki or Giya Kancheli.
"Two Paths," the Philharmonic work, looks at another polarity, for this double concerto is a double portrait of Martha and Mary, the sisters of St. John's Gospel. These were women who had, as the composer puts it, "two ways of loving: to love taking upon oneself worldly cares and by so doing insure the foundation of life, and to love dedicating oneself to the sublime, to experience together with the Beloved the route of terrible suffering to the cross, so as to procure light and blessing for life."
Wild gestures in the orchestra -- loud swirls and anapaest rhythms -- provoke a response from the two soloists, a response they deliver alone. The second viola, as Martha, starts in the middle register and almost at once slides down toward the bottom of the instrument's range. The first, as Mary, begins just above her sister and moves higher. Both sisters are not only much quieter than the orchestra but much slower and more centered, in keeping with the composer's archetypal view of sexual differences. It will be interesting one day to hear the work performed by male soloists with a woman conducting.
What follows is a sequence of variations. The orchestra returns to attack mode, and this time the violists' move together in response. Mary, in her higher register, makes downward slips; Martha, below, starts to lift, and the two flow side by side in duets. Then woodwind soloists enter the conversation. Once the unaccompanied viola duetting has been restored, the two soloists crisscross through pitch space over a percussive ostinato, and these mirroring upward-downward movements spread into the orchestra. After this tumult, the Martha violist settles on a theme she will hold to the end, while the Mary figure pursues her lyrical flights. A last cruel orchestral outburst does not stop them.
"In the Shadow of the Tree" also has a binary contrast, but now between whole ensembles. A little more than half the orchestral strings play in normal tuning, the rest being tuned a quarter-tone down. The koto and bass koto are aligned with the first group, as are the winds and tuned percussion instruments. (Ms. Gubaidulina, herself a percussionist, uses large percussion sections in both new works.) But the zheng's intonation places it with the "mistuned" strings, which are said to represent "a region of shadow."
The work begins in light and ends there, on the same note played on the koto with the kind of undulating insistence by which Ms. Gubaidulina gives her simple musical facts the force of freshness. But along the way, the shadow comes into its own, and the soloist is able to move from one side to the other. The shadow music is not particularly negative or sinister, and its effect is not so much to contradict the light as to gentle it. So one may come to understand, with the composer, "that shadow is the sphere of existence from which life emanates, and even light."
Initial contradictions -- between shadow and light, between Eastern and Western instruments, between improvised and notated music (in the solo part) -- come to seem less important than the equal necessity of both aspects. And though "In the Shadow of the Tree" may, from its title, contain some Christian reference, Ms. Gubaidulina's message lies at this other level, at once more abstract and more immediate. It is the same message she has always delivered in her best works, a message of fierce struggles and ecstatic coming home.
 
Gubaidulina, Strange and Powerful
 Sofia Gubaidulina has been getting more prolific and, at the same time, more powerful, more economical and more strange. Two of her recent works available in fine recordings are "Now Always Snow," for small-scale choral and orchestral forces, and "And: The Feast Is in Full Progress," her second cello concerto, both from 1993 and based on visionary poems by Gennady Aigi.
"Now Always Snow" begins as a light blizzard of overlapping voices and instruments and ends as a becalmed male-female duet with soaring violin. It is an exceptional piece, strongly presented by Dutch forces under Reinbert de Leeuw (Philips 442 531-2; CD).
The cello concerto also has an impressive performance, from David Geringas with the Finnish Radio Symphony under Jukka-Pekka Saraste (Col Legno 31881; CD).
Among many releases on the Bis label, one is particularly valuable for a selection of smaller pieces, including "Dancer on a Tightrope," with Gidon Kremer, as well as an improvisation by the composer and two colleagues, all recorded at the 1995 Lockenhaus Festival (Bis 810; CD).
Mr. Kremer's classic recording of "Offertorium" is on a Deutsche Grammophon CD (427 336-2). PAUL GRIFFITHS

SECTION: Section 2; Page 35; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Where the Shoppers Can Also Catch a Plane

BYLINE: By THOMAS HINE; Thomas Hine is the author of "The Total Package," about the meaning of containers, and "Populuxe," about commercial design.

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
AMERICANS, it has been learned, are willing to buy underwear at airports. Also shoes, golf shirts, cosmetics, Caesar salad and stuffed animals. Especially stuffed animals.
One result of this discovery is a transformation of major American airports to increase the amount of retail space they contain and to make them more shopper-friendly. Airports, the last bastions of confident functionalism, are being remade as consumer bazaars, near cousins of the shopping mall. The proud drabness with which airports once sought to reassure passengers that everything was under control is giving way to the bright, attention-grabbing, brash brand imagery of some of the world's leading retailers. 
 In creating midways to the runway, retail developers rarely change airport structures, but by giving them color and some of the bustle and clutter of a marketplace, they are changing how airports feel. And because airport stores are highly lucrative, new airports are increasingly being designed with large commercial spaces at their heart. All three of New York's airports are undergoing or planning major makeovers that will increase the amount of space given over to food and retailing, and many other airports in this country have carried out or are planning similar projects.
At the vanguard of this movement is the Greater Pittsburgh International Airport, where the trend first took hold in 1992. The airport with the largest, most visible retail presence, it is a place where architects and retail managers come to learn the new rules of airport design.
For arriving passengers, the airport looks like most others. It appears to be an endless, low-lying building of concrete and glass, its walls bristling with prefabricated jetways. "Welcome to Pittsburgh" reads a perfunctory greeting, stenciled on a beam above the ramp as you leave the airplane.
But when you get into the concourse itself, you can see who is really happy you've arrived. Hanging from the skylighted ceiling above the moving walkways are brightly colored, four-and-a-half-foot-tall shopping bags bearing the logos of Victoria's Secret, Clinique, the Gap and other airport merchants. They have the look of pop sculptures, and they probably make more of an impression than the Calder mobile that hangs at the center of the terminal.
These suspended shopping bags upstage the pleasant-enough architecture of the terminal, an X-shaped building with shallow, barrel-vaulted ceilings. Similarly, at the center of the terminal, where the shops are clustered, the commercial design outdoes the architecture. Precast concrete doesn't have a chance when competing with the cherry-veneer art nouveau shopfront of Godiva Chocolatier or with the bordello look of the gilt and fuchsia Victoria's Secret.
"The days of building an airport as a secular cathedral are over," says Robert Weinberg, chairman of MarketPlace Development Corporation of Boston, which is planning a retail makeover at La Guardia Airport. In fact, only a handful of recent American airports have shown any architectural ambition at all. They have chosen instead to project an image of efficiency and quiet competence. Airport architecture has usually been about speed and movement, even though the airport experience is mostly about waiting and milling around. The in-your-face sophistication of retail design challenges the blandly competent look of the typical airport.
Retail developers are less concerned with the drama of airport architecture than they are with the quality of what they call "the airport experience." This translates into impeccable cleanliness, a calm, pleasant atmosphere that allows passengers to relax, and, most of all, a variety of high-quality, mostly national-brand retailers and restaurants, whose prices are the same as in their outlets outside the airport.
"Passengers are going to expect quality retail in an airport, and airports don't have any choice but to provide it," said Mark Knight, president of B.A.A. Pittsburgh, which manages the retailing at the airport. It is a subsidiary of the company that owns London's airports and is planning a retail makeover of terminals A and B at Newark International.
Newark is only in the early stages of design, says Mr. Knight, who is supervising it for B.A.A., but the company's goal is to get rid of what he terms the airport's institutional look. "Today you have the feeling of straight corridors leading to airplanes, with shops in glass boxes on the sides," he said. "We will try to introduce variety, stagger the shopfronts and let retailers project themselves more into the space."
The company is also planning a sprawling new terminal at London's Heathrow; it would be built around a retail center nearly as large as a regional shopping mall.
THE new airport design, much to the consternation of traditionalists, tends to contradict their longstanding goal of getting passengers from curbside to airplane as efficiently as possible. One new rule is that passengers must be forced to walk past the shops and restaurants. "Retailers want to create turbulence, to divert people from their paths," says Dan Peter Kopple, a Philadelphia architect who has worked on several airports.
Another rule is that retailers have to be allowed to use the graphics and imagery on posters and signs that they use elsewhere, tactics that are anathema to airport designers and administrators who have historically exercised tight control over what passengers see, on the theory that too much visual information is confusing.
In Pittsburgh, even where there are no shops, there are retail reminders, like those suspended shopping bags. Everywhere, posters remind passengers that they can buy food to take on the plane or use their time to do some shopping.
The biggest reason frequent flyers are becoming frequent buyers is that flying has become more time-consuming and less pleasant. Airlines have cut back food service on many flights to pretzels or less, creating a market starved for good, reasonably priced food. Hub-and-spoke airline routes mean more food-free flights and long stopovers. Security concerns have led airlines and airports to recommend that passengers show up earlier than they did before, thus increasing the time they could spend on shopping.
"Really serious security worries that make people edgy, or long delays that make them grumpy, don't encourage people to spend," says Mr. Knight. But, he acknowledges, "People are spending more time in airports, and we can offset some of the negative parts of flying."
Cesar Pelli, an architect who designed the renovation of Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington, says he likes to shop in airports. "When I have to wait for a long time, I find it easier to shop than anything else," he said. But he sees danger when retailing is allowed to dominate the planning of an airport. "When the main goal is to maximize revenues from retailing, that can conflict with designing a good airport," he said.
Mr. Pelli's airport is in many ways the opposite of Pittsburgh's because it places civic expression first and retailing, at best, second. Among airport retailers, Washington National has become a prime negative example because most of its retail shops are clustered away from the busiest passenger thoroughfares. And the airport's configuration requires that this area be outside the security checkpoint, so passengers who find they have the time to browse are deterred from going back.
"I think Washington National is a fantastic building, but as retail it doesn't work," said Mr. Knight. "I don't see any reason why you can't have both. But airport administrators and architects will have to take retailing as seriously as they do the rest."
Retailing has long been an important component of airports that cater to international traffic because of duty-free business. In American airports with primarily domestic traffic, the situation was the opposite. Food was often overpriced and poor, and retailing consisted mostly of magazines and souvenirs. The first attempt to change this came about a decade ago in Portland, Ore., where a strong effort was made to provide good food and products to serve as a showcase for the region.
Still, when B.A.A. came into Pittsburgh seven years ago, Mr. Knight said, the question of whether retailing could work in domestic airports was still open. The company, which had been created in Britain in 1987 as part of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's privatization campaign, had already successfully expanded the retailing at Heathrow and other airports it owns, and it was looking outside Britain for more sources of revenue.
Pittsburgh's new airport terminal was a good place to start because it was designed to have a substantial amount of retail space right at the crossroads of its four concourses. About 70 percent of the passengers in Pittsburgh are changing planes at the U.S. Airways hub, so there are many people in transit who are looking for something to do. By abandoning airport retailers' traditional practice of gouging their captive audience and, instead, charging the same as at nearby malls, Pittsburgh airport became a reasonable shopping alternative. Parents buy "guilt gifts," like stuffed bears and bunnies; flight attendants patronize Victoria's Secret, and everybody eats or grabs food to take aloft.
Eleven percent of passengers surveyed at Greater Pittsburgh International Airport said they chose to change planes there because they liked the airport's facilities, primarily the stores and restaurants, according to Mr. Knight.
The 21 million passengers who use the Pittsburgh airport each year spend an average $8.35 per person, about $3 more than the national average at airports. For Pittsburgh, this is money falling out of the sky. And if travelers' preference for the airport draws more flights, revenues from landing fees -- the chief source of income for all airports -- also increase substantially.
For retail developers and tenants, the economics of airport retailing are extremely attractive. Mr. Knight said that Pittsburgh tenants' sales averaged about $1,000 a square foot of space each year. In a regional shopping center, revenue averages about $250 a square foot, he said. It costs more to do business in an airport, but exposure to such a large, affluent audience makes it worthwhile. "Airports are very predictable places to do business," said Mr. Knight. "We know exactly when people are coming, so you can plan your staff schedule. We know that the audience has above-average income, with a median age of about 42."
Still, while retailing is changing the way airports look and feel, it is unlikely to amount to more than 10 percent of an airport's square footage, and thus it remains only one aspect of the challenge of airport architecture. "An airport might look something like a mall," Mr. Pelli said, "but it will never be a mall."

PERSON: JOHN MAJOR (72%); MARK KNIGHT (56%);

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: April 25, 1999

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1275 words

HEADLINE: Upscale Housing in a Downscale Cincinnati Area

BYLINE: By JOHN ECKBERG 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI

 BODY:
WHEN David C. Imboden bought his first waterfront house in the unfashionable East End neighborhood in 1987 he was struck by the stunning views of the Ohio River and the emerald hills of Kentucky. And, not incidentally, by the development possibilities.
Eventually he bought more than 200 pieces of property in this neighborhood about two miles east of downtown, before clearing part of it for the city's first high-end single-family housing on the river's edge in a century. Because of his vision, 21 two-story red-brick town houses -- 11 sold for $300,000 to $375,000 and 10 renting for $2,500 to $3,500 a month, with leases up to three years -- now line the shore. 
 The $4 million complex, called Riverfront East Condominiums, was built in 1995 and occupied in a year. It fulfills the expectation of city officials that the best way to revitalize this long-neglected stretch of waterfront is with houses for affluent tenants and buyers.
A tax abatement worth $1 million gives property owners a 10-year reprieve on real estate taxes. In addition, the city gave the project a $1 million grant for a retaining wall, brick sidewalks and water, sewer and gas mains.
The next phase of Mr. Imboden's plan, the $4.5 million Riverfront Terrace, is now under way, with 15 two- and three-story detached houses under construction on the north side of Eastern Avenue across from Riverfront East. Plans call for an additional four dozen houses if the market warrants construction.
The notion that river views could help reinvent this rundown neighborhood came to Mr. Imboden after a boat ride on the Ohio River in 1987.
"All of a sudden I looked up over the water and said, 'You know, I wouldn't mind buying one of those shacks,' " he said. He quickly found a "For Sale" sign and for $32,000 had a new home and a toe in the water of urban life. For nearly a decade, he said, he bought every property he could find, relying at times on his credit card for purchases.
"People called at all hours," he recalled. "Somebody might be going bankrupt and I'd say name your price. They'd say $30,000. Boom, I'd buy. At the time, there were shacks up and down the street. It didn't matter. I knew that housing here would one day take off." He said he had a hard and fast rule: He would not buy and evict and he would not jack up rents. "I waited for people to move and then I boarded the place up," said Mr. Imboden, who had previously renovated about 25 houses throughout the city.
The developer, now 42, settled into the East End by living in the house he bought after that boat ride. Not long before, he had quit his job as an inner-city football coach at Taft High School. He and a partner, Mark Meade, founded Alumni Builders and learned the housing business by constructing single-family houses for middle-income buyers in the suburban subdivisions between Cincinnati and Dayton.
HOUSING experts in Cincinnati say the riverside project will help reverse the steady trend of wealthy residents fleeing the city for the suburbs. For the city to thrive, said Dan Brady, president of Tri-State Mortgage Company, it needs suburban-style housing, and this bend of riverfront on the edge of downtown offers an opportunity for it to increase its home ownership rate. With national home ownership rates at about 65 percent, Cincinnati at 38 percent has a long way to go to catch up, he said.
"The problem is they have to find places to bring that number up." said Mr. Brady, a member from 1995 to 1998 of a Federal Reserve committee formed to study home ownership here. "The riverfront has some contiguous sites for development, whereas the rest of the city has spot lots that are not as appealing to builders and developers."
City officials intend to encourage projects like Riverfront Terrace, said Andi Udris, director of the city's Department of Economic Development. "There's no question one of the issues for cities like Cincinnati is the ability to retain its residents," he said. "The goal is to identify specific markets within the city for the large segment of people who want to be near downtown: the newcomers to the city who want to be close in but don't want high-maintenance units."
Riverfront East town houses have 3,000 square feet of living space, with three bedrooms, two-and-a-half baths, a master suite with Jacuzzi, an eat-in kitchen, decks for river views and two-car attached garages. Houses under construction across the street, ranging from 3,400 to 3,600 square feet, will have three or four bedrooms and up to three-and-a-half baths and sell for $329,000 to $400,000, said Denise Guiducci, a broker for Sibcy Cline Realtors.
Other housing projects -- Edgecliff Towers and Kingston House -- have been built on the hillside above the river, but they were high-rise towers targeted for upper-income residents and near East Walnut Hills, an established upscale neighborhood. Until Alumni Builders found its toehold along the river, no developer would risk investing and building in the East End.
In keeping with the Victorian nature of the neighborhood, houses in Riverfront Terrace have widow's walks, decks and large windows. Brick is mixed with faux sandstone and limestone detailing on the exterior and the houses have high-tech intercoms, central vacuuming systems and rooms prewired for computers. Wet bars and amenities like hot tubs abound.
Jerry Warner, 56, a semi-retired entrepreneur and Wall Street investor, was among the first to move into Riverfront East in 1995. Besides the view, he said, he moved to the neighborhood because of its tranquillity and proximity to restaurants and nightlife. While he keeps an 8,500-square-foot home in the Indiana hills near Batesville, about an hour's drive away, Mr. Warner said he finds that he is spending most of his time in the East End.
"You're in the city but it's as quiet as if you're out in the woods," he said. "There are 21 units here but you'd never know it."
MR. WARNER'S town house, typical of others in Riverfront East, has crown molding throughout and there is a fireplace upstairs in the master suite, as well as a a Jacuzzi in the bathroom. Below the ground floor are a family room and a two-car garage. Between his unit and the river is a garden of shrubbery and accent stones that winds the length of the complex. Two gazebos and flower beds are focal points. Mr. Warner said his residence was large enough to accommodate family gatherings, which is one reason why he bought the condominium -- to be closer to his grandchildren.
Mr. Brady, the mortgage broker, said that before the new neighborhood can work, there must be a critical mass of affluent residents. Then the restaurants, groceries and dry cleaners will follow, he said. "I don't want to live on the riverfront and have a beautiful place and have to drive across town to get groceries," he said.
The neighborhood has deep Appalachian roots and a working-class feel remains. A local tavern is called the Du Drop Inn. One nearby property owner is a bell manufacturer.
Mr. Udris, the city's economic development director, projected that as many as 1,200 units could one day stretch from Riverfront Terrace about two miles west to Adams Landing, an upscale condominium complex a block or so off the river.
Mr. Imboden can watch the construction of Riverfront Terrace from a window in an upstairs workout room in his Riverfront East condominium and sometimes he will quit exercising to do just that. "This has been a ride, but it has not just been about money," he said the other day as masons laid brick, surveyors took readings and hammering resounded. "It's been a passion."

HEADLINE: Q&A/Susan Arterian Chang;
Paper Finding Pulse In Community Beat

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
SUSAN ARTERIAN CHANG, who is the founder, publisher and editor of The White Plains Watch, the newest newspaper in White Plains, said she "won't be a Pollyanna" but she does want to bring the city together, applaud its diversity and help mom-and-pop stores survive.
Ms. Chang formerly worked in book and financial publishing and was a freelance writer in Manhattan and Los Angeles before moving to White Plains in 1992. She started the monthly in November 1997 by pooling the money of herself and her husband, Eugene. Time will tell, she said, whether her vision of community is shared by enough other people to insure the paper's survival. 
 On May 8 from 2 to 9 P.M., the newspaper, the White Plains Downtown Business Improvement District and merchants and businesses will sponsor events aimed at getting residents to rediscover the downtown area. The newspaper, which prints 25,000 copies, is distributed free to residents and available elsewhere at other places in the city. Here are excerpts of a recent conversation with Ms. Chang:
Q. Was it always your dream to start a paper?
A. No. It really wasn't. One day I was talking to a friend, and we were saying that there was no community paper in the city. We had had one -- Suburban Street -- but when I moved here in 1992 it was publishing very sporadically. And after 1995 I never saw it again. So at the time I was getting tired of freelance financial writing. I was writing about risk management and very esoteric subjects. I wanted to write about something more concrete and something that had meaning to me. By then, I had started to get involved in the school system, but I still felt very removed from the city. Downtown White Plains was a place I never went to. I felt almost like an outsider, an interloper.
This all came together in my mind: the idea that I wanted to help create a stronger community here, I wanted to be involved in downtown revitalization. I had always been kind of interested in cities. I had lived in Manhattan for most of my life. I loved living where all kinds of people were together. I loved the energy of the city, and I felt that White Plains could be that kind of city on a smaller scale.
Q. Do you have any background in newspaper financing?
A. Not at all. I had no background. Believe me, I made -- have been making -- lots of expensive mistakes. The main one was I started out with a 40-page paper and only about 20 percent of the paper was advertising. I was just bleeding.
Q. What is the goal? Is it 50 percent?
A. Or more. Some papers are as much as 70 percent. If you can get to be a bigger paper you can afford to have a bigger ratio of ads because you have a bigger space for editorial. I'm aiming for 50 to 60 percent.
Q. When did you say, I'm going to do this?
A. It was in the spring of 1997 that I started to get up every morning and say, yes, this is what I want to do. I went through a few weeks or a month of feeling like that. Then I began talking to people in the community about it. And I got such a wonderful response from community people. That really propelled me -- that they wanted a paper here so badly and they felt a need for it. There is a small group of very, very active people in this town and they really make the wheels turn, and they got right behind it. And then I started networking and calling community papers through a directory the suburban newspaper association has. Community newspaper people are really nice. They want to help other people out. I visited some, and they all gave me lots of ideas.
I should say I also got a lot of help from Dee DelBello, publisher of The Business Journal. In fact her production people created my design and produced the paper for the first few months and got me off the ground. I also have to mention Diane Fox, without whom I could never have done this paper. She is the advertising director and associate publisher. She was a parent I knew from Ridgeway Elementary School.
Q. What kind of finances did it take to start the newspaper?
A. My husband and I have financed this paper on our own. My husband was at the time a currency trader and we had saved some money and -- well, he knew I was searching for something -- he got behind it and said let's go ahead and do this. We've invested a lot of money, and we're at a point where we're getting close to breaking even on it. But it was all our funds. We did not borrow any money from anybody.
Q. Have you had anything controversial to write about at this point?
A. Because White Plains is a community that needs to heal, I'm trying not to strike a negative tone. But I do try to be critical on some levels. For instance, I'm concerned about maintaining the qualities of the school system for the middle-class community here because I think it's very important for the integrity of the school system that the middle class wants to stay here and believes in it. So I try to have a dialogue between parents and the school system through the newspaper. We've run a series of articles about heterogeneous grouping in the school system and that's caused a little bit of controversy, but I think it's been very healthy.
Another major issue was the proposal for the video arcade for the Galleria mall. I came out against that editorially and it probably hurt me because the Galleria won't advertise with me. But I felt very strongly about it. The black community that lived close to downtown all spoke against this video arcade, but the Common Council voted for it. I just couldn't understand it. We did an editorial saying that we were against it and against the violence of the games.
After they had approved the arcade, the Council said it wanted to say the arcade couldn't have violent games. But it turned out that constitutionally you can't legislate content. As it turned out, the guy who wanted to do the arcade went away, but that doesn't mean someone else won't come in and try to do the same thing. I think the Council kind of opened up a can of worms.
Another thing we've advocated for is open-space preservation on the New York Hospital property. We have come out strongly in favor of that and think the Common Council and the city should be doing a lot more to see that this happens.
Q. So you are not going to let advertising issues interfere with what you think is the right thing to do?
A. It's hard to say. A lot of people say: you should write about your advertisers and things like that. And when it comes to mom-and-pop stores here, I feel part of my mission here is to make them survive. We're living in the shadow of two huge malls and our downtown needs help. The small guys need help and recognition through the newspaper, and I think it's important for us to recognize their struggles and to recognize that they are really trying to make a positive contribution. So I do think writing about them is O.K., whether they advertise or not. And we do write about those who don't advertise. But we have done things -- thumbs-up, thumbs-down kinds of things -- and we've done thumbs down on the fact that a lot of the windows of stores are covered with newspaper and garbage and advertising, and we have an ordinance in the city that says only 25 percent of your display window can be covered. And we've shown pictures of the ones that are offending.
Q. What is the May 8 program all about?
A. It came from a conversation with Mary D'Amico, who is owner of Articoli, a craft and gift store where I share space on Mamaroneck Avenue. She often does events at her store. What we were feeling is it would be nice to have a day where all the stores were doing something. So we approached the Downtown Business Improvement District, and they are a major sponsor of the event. We call it Downtown Rediscovery Day because a lot of people haven't been downtown for many years since the malls came in and the stores started closing. But there is a season of rebirth here, and I want people to see that and to be part of it and be activists in the community.
It's the responsibility of everyone to make it come back to life. It's part of our mission at the newspaper to try to bring the community together, and revitalizing the downtown is part of that so people have a common place to come. That's when community really starts to happen.
I'm hoping there are enough people who really feel that way. Sometimes I have my doubts. Sometimes I wonder; everyone is so involved in their nuclear families, does community still matter to people? The jury is out. Can we do it. I'm not sure. I get enough positive feedback to think it can happen, but there are a lot of obstacles and challenges in the way.
Q. What is the biggest challenge?
A. Keeping the paper going by convincing local businesses to become advertisers.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
Another Tool to Save Meadowlands Open Space

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
OF the nearly 20,000 acres that made up the Hackensack Meadowlands, 8,400 of them remain a sweep of meadows and marshes blanketed with brown reeds, some rising 12 feet tall.
Surrounded by commercial and residential development and dotted with closed landfills and contaminated waterways, the undeveloped land, most of it fresh-water and salt-water wetlands, is far from pristine. 
 But last month the State Legislature passed a bill to establish the Meadowlands Conservation Trust to preserve pieces of the remaining meadows considered by some to be a rare urban wilderness. The move reflects a growing sentiment in the state to conserve open space.
The move to create a nonprofit trust, which is expected to be operational by year's end, started two years ago and brought together environmentalists, state legislators and officials of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission. The commission, an autonomous state agency, has authority over zoning and planning issues in the 32-square mile Meadowlands region, which covers parts of 14 municipalities in Bergen and Hudson Counties.
The region, nine miles from Manhattan, has long been a magnet for development, including a proposal by the Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., to build a $1-billion, 2.1-million-square-foot mall, with accompanying office towers and a 1,000-room hotel, on part of a 592-acre tract in Carlstadt.
Passage of the Meadowlands Conservation Trust Act on March 2 followed a referendum last November that gave the state a green light to spend $1 billion over the next decade to preserve a million acres of undeveloped land.
It also comes at a time when Federal, state and commission officials are near agreement on a plan that would decrease to 465 acres the amount of the area's 7,700 acres of wetlands that could be filled and developed. Adoption of the plan, known as the Hackensack Meadowlands Special Area Management Plan, is expected in mid-September, involved officials say. That plan could affect the Mills project.
"We have been committed to preserving open space and wetlands, but as a state entity we have been restricted in our ability to do this," said Jane M. Kenny, Commissioner of the state's Department of Community Affairs, as well as chairwoman of the Meadowlands Development Commission, one of her department's agencies. The trust "will give us an additional tool and increased resources to continue to move forward," with or without the special area management plan, she said.
Alan J. Steinberg, executive director of the commission, said that the plan was just a zoning guide to direct growth to a limited amount of the wetlands. On the other hand, he added, the trust will buy land for recreational uses and wildlife habitats, giving the region "an extra layer of protection."
The trust will be financed by fund-raising and selling special Meadowlands license plates through the state's Department of Motor Vehicles. It will also seek funds from private foundations and the state, create public-private partnerships and accept land donations.
At present, the commission is negotiating for the purchase of 1,000 acres of open space, mostly in the central and southern areas of the Meadowlands. They would be added to the 900 acres the commission has preserved, including 186 acres of wetlands in Secaucus, known as the Mill Creek site, once targeted for 2,000 residences.
The Meadowlands was where native Indians once fished and hunted and Dutch and British colonists in the 18th century farmed salt hay and chopped cedar trees. In this century factories sprouted, as did piles of trash. By the late 60's the Meadowlands became a huge dumping ground.
IN 1969 the state established the Meadowlands Development commission to guide the area's growth, protect the environment and provide space for solid-waste disposal. Development in the 70's and 80's created today's landscape, which includes the state's 760-acre sports complex along with a collection of office and warehouse buildings totaling millions of square feet of space, as well as housing. "The only way to really preserve open space is to buy it," said Mr. Steinberg. "With the trust we are not limited to the proceeds of the state's conservation program to achieve that."
Gregory A. Remaud, conservationist project manager at the New York-New Jersey Baykeeper, an environmental group, said the trust was needed because "it could be more flexible and work more quickly" than a government agency. It could also "bypass politics," said Mr. Remaud, whose group is one of the most vocal opponents of development in the Meadowlands.
While the two groups agree on the merits of the trust, they disagree on the merits of the plan. The plan would end a decade-long debate among government regulators and environmentalists over how much development should be allowed on the region's remaining wetlands.
The current plan decreases the amount of developable wetlands to 465 acres, down from 842 earlier envisioned and from the 2,000 originally sought. It would also streamline approvals, require developers to clean some of the polluted sections of the Meadowlands and compensate private landowners not allowed to develop.
The plan is a combined effort of state and Federal agencies, including the Meadowlands commission, the state's Department of Environmental Protection, the Army Corps of Engineers, and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. They were assisted by the White House Council on Environmental Quality.
Mr. Steinberg said the plan "is the ultimate balancing" of economic development and environmental protection. "It places 95 percent of the remaining wetlands off limits to development and allows to be filled only the most severely damaged" wetlands, which have no ecological value, he said.
At the same time, he added, the commission is encouraging development in upland areas and redevelopment on the sites of closed landfills or sewage-treatment plants, which would not negatively affect the environment or further diminish open space. He said the commission was working on 10 redevelopment plans.
One is to recycle a 35-acre parcel, much of it once home to a sewage-treatment plant, into a mixed-use complex. Lincoln Equities Group, a local development concern, recently was named the redeveloper for 28 acres of the site, near Route 17 in Rutherford. The company, said Joel Bergstein, its executive vice president, will clean the site of contaminants and redevelop in phases up to 900,000 square feet of office space and a hotel.
"Our position is that the state has the right to control development," Mr. Steinberg said. "But to ban all development of the remaining wetlands would increase the risks of litigation from private landowners in 'takings' cases." (The Federal Constitution says private land may not be taken for public use without fair compensation.) The current plan will withstand such challenges, Mr. Steinberg said.
"It is not just a development plan," said Richard T. Fritzky, president of the Meadowlands Region Chamber of Commerce. The plan, he said, "has always been about preservation and reclamation and of doing the best we can for this region."
Environmentalists disagree. "We look at it as needlessly filling of nearly 500 acres of wetlands, which is the largest amount of wetlands that would be allowed to be filled since the passage of the Clean Water Act," said Mr. Remaud of New York-New Jersey Baykeeper. The concept of sacrificing some wetlands to save others is flawed, he said.
At the heart of the debate is the Mills Corporation project. Last month the company suspended its application to build its mall by filling 206 acres of polluted wetlands on the Carlstadt site. Instead, Mills has agreed to submit a new application to the Meadowlands Commission for the project on up to 90 acres of filled wetlands allowed under the plan, if the plan is approved.
If the plan is not adopted by September, said the company in a written statement, it will pursue its larger proposal. Either project still must secure approvals.
"We are adamant about preserving wetlands," Mr. Remaud said, "Another mall in the Meadowlands is unneccessary." Whatever happens this September "the process is far from over," he said, noting that his group was pursuing an alternative -- purchasing the 465 acres of wetlands the plan allows to be filled and turn that parcel into a wildlife refuge.
He said the Meadowlands Conservation Trust, while not designed to save all of the remaining developable wetlands, could help.
Mr. Steinberg said the commission remained optimistic that the special management plan would be realized this time. Together with the trust, he said, it will "enable us to preserve more open space and restore and enhance more degraded wetlands" than otherwise could be saved.
