HEADLINE: Building Homes for the Single Homeless

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY, which has seen its stock of last-resort housing for poor single adults withered by waves of market-rate development since the end of World War II, is seeing the return of apartments built specifically for those still hunkered below the bottom rung of the real-estate ladder.
Housing designed to fill that niche -- buildings parceled into small, clean "efficiency units" that are the functional successor to the old, squalid S.R.O. apartments -- are being constructed in some numbers for the first time in five decades. 
 Not big numbers.
Only a few hundred of New York's homeless thousands are or soon will be benefiting from the development. Still, just the fact that ground has been broken within the last two years for 13 efficiency-apartment buildings containing 668 units in all the boroughs except Staten Island -- nine have been completed so far -- represents at least a symbolic shift in a city that has seen, by some estimates, 87 percent of its S.R.O., or single-room-occupancy, stock eliminated since 1950.
The construction is a new phase in the evolution of the 20-year-old supportive housing movement, in which not-for-profit groups join forces with government agencies to finance and operate housing projects that go beyond merely providing a residence. The new projects not only take people off the streets and out of shelters, but offer them the on-site services they need to lead independent and, where possible, productive lives -- medical care, drug counseling, psychiatric help, job training and placement.
The movement attempts to fill the gap gouged by government policies that, for decades, discouraged S.R.O. housing as a cruel and degrading vestige of the past, but mainly by market-rate development that gobbled up S.R.O. hotels and tenement buildings -- first as neighborhoods gentrified during the 70's and 80's and, more recently, as owners renovated buildings to tap potential profit from throngs of tourists to the city.
"It's not like a real estate developer is saying, 'Let me build all this low-income housing,' " said Maureen Friar, executive director of the Supportive Housing Network of New York, a coalition of 115 not-for-profit organizations, "but what we do -- creating and operating supportive housing -- has become the solution to homelessness. So it's a start."
The distinction between the old single-room-occupancy units and the new efficiency apartments is striking. Unlike the S.R.O.'s -- typically unsanitary, with shared bathroom and cooking facilities down the hall -- the efficiency apartment comes with a private bathroom and a kitchenette in a building equipped with lounge areas, classrooms, a laundry and even, in some cases, an exercise room. Rooted in the not-too-distant past, however, those involved in the supportive housing movement and even government officials sometimes slip into the vernacular and still refer to the new units as S.R.O.'s.
Call it what you will, Larry Gatson thinks he's living in a unit of heaven.
"Gatson residence!" is the way Mr. Gatson, 54, answers the phone in his home in the newly constructed, 40-unit efficiency-apartment building at 690 East 147th Street in the South Bronx, owned and operated by University Consultation and Treatment Center, a Supportive Housing Network member.
"Oh man, you don't know how it feels to have a place of my own, 'cause I've been from the shelter to the train to abandoned buildings," said Mr. Gatson, who moved in last May, shortly after the building opened. "I was homeless four years, 'cause, see, I used to be a crackhead."
Members of the network -- in cooperation, particularly, with the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the Federal Government's Department of Housing and Urban Development and the mental health agencies of the city and state -- have created 11,800 efficiency apartments since 1980 by refurbishing dilapidated S.R.O. buildings.
Now they are building new ones.
"The transition to new construction from rehabilitation of existing buildings is the most significant thing about the current focus of the program," said Richard T. Roberts, the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development. "It's a function of the city's success in reducing its housing portfolio -- meaning we don't have as many city-owned buildings to commit to these efforts -- and improvements in the real estate market that make it much less likely for a private owner to sell or donate a building for supportive housing."
But according to Ms. Friar, the director of the Supportive Housing Network, "This is only a start." And she cited the dimensions of the continuing need: "There are still 7,200 single adults in the shelter system, 1,200 persons with AIDS in rundown commercial S.R.O.s and at least 10,000 people on the street."
Of the 13 efficiency-apartment buildings begun in the last two years, seven, containing 341 units, were financed through the New York State Office of Mental Health -- two in the Bronx, two in Manhattan and three in Brooklyn. "They're up and running," Ms. Friar said.
The six other efficiency-apartment buildings were financed through the city's Housing Preservation and Development Department.
In the Bronx, besides the 40-unit building where Mr. Gatson so delightedly now resides, two projects are under construction -- a 45-unit building at 1316 Boston Road in the East Tremont section and a 43-unit building at 1616 Grand Avenue in Morris Heights.
IN Brooklyn, two other H.P.D.-financed projects -- a 68-unit building at 545 Warren Street in Park Slope and a 57-unit building at 2324 Pitkin Avenue in East New York -- are also under construction.
And two weeks ago, Edwin Jimenez stood in front of 223 East 117th Street in Harlem as concrete continued to be poured for a 73-unit building sponsored by the Doe Fund -- the homeless-aid group most visible for its royal blue uniformed street cleaning crews on the Upper East and West Sides.
Mr. Jimenez, 34, can hardly wait for construction to be completed in early 2000 so he can move into his 12- by 14-foot apartment with its large window, polished floor, kitchenette and -- "Can you believe it?" he said -- a private bathroom. He has been living with 10 other men in one wing of the Doe Fund's dormitory-style transitional shelter on Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Harlem since last October.
And that has been one of his more luxurious residences.
"I've been a runaway since I was 13 years old," Mr. Jimenez said. "My father was an alcoholic and always beat my mother; my mother would turn around and beat on me. So I ran to a friend's house on 42d Street and lived in the basement."
"For the need of money for my habit," he said, "I did what they do out there -- sell myself. I've been on drugs, alcohol since I was 9."
When he was 17, Mr. Jimenez met a woman he refers to as "my daughter's mother" -- his daughter, Domanisha, was born in 1986. For four years, he said, "I wasn't exactly clean," of drug use, "but I wasn't as bad as I was." But as his relationship "with my daughter's mother began to crumble," Mr. Jimenez said, he reverted to heavy drug use and wound up back on the street.
"Slept in trains, under bridges, tunnels, abandoned cars," he said, "sometimes in Dumpsters. Off and on for three years, no residence."
In 1994, Mr. Jimenez graduated from a drug rehabilitation program "and got a good job, construction," he said. "Two years, no drugs, no nothing.
"Then I made the cardinal mistake -- just this one time," he said of taking another tumble toward heavy drug use.
Eventually, after months in the city's shelter system, Mr. Jimenez was accepted into the Doe Fund's Ready, Willing and Able Program, which provides housing in exchange for work -- usually on the street-cleaning crew. Doe Fund clients earn $5.50 an hour to start, and pay $50 a week in rent to live in transitional residences, the organization's co-founder, George McDonald said. And they must participate, he said, in a program "that fosters good work and living habits -- getting up in the morning, going to work, filling out resumes, budgeting income -- and support services like frequent drug testing and counseling."
The clients must save $30 a week, which after about nine months equals $1,000 -- a sum matched by the Doe Fund as a down payment on finding their own apartments. But they are required to stay in the program until they have secured a private-sector job. "So the program mirrors, in the everyday repetition of working, getting paid and not spending on drugs, the desired societal outcome," Mr. McDonald said.
Mr. Jimenez said he had gone "from the housekeeping crew to the Community Improvement Division" -- the street cleaners -- "to assistant to the employment developer; I work in a shirt and tie every day." By early next year, he expects to find outside work and to move into the new building, where he will pay $75 a week in rent. "I can hardly wait," he said.
The Doe Fund project, said Commissioner Roberts, "is particularly exciting because it places emphasis on housing the working poor," rather than the elderly or disabled. "The more stability you provide people, the greater opportunity for them to lead self-sufficient lives," he said.
Mr. McDonald hopes the building "will serve as a model for communities as the type of first-rung housing for the working poor they would like to have in their neighborhoods."
Development costs for the Doe Fund building total $8,261,831, financed through two sources: H.P.D. serves as the conduit for a 30-year loan of $6,176,565, at 1 percent interest, from H.U.D.'s Home Investment Partnership Program -- commonly called the HOME Program. The remaining $2,085,266 has been raised from the sale of Federal tax credits to investors who put up the money and then, over 10 years, receive the credit on their tax returns while the Doe Fund immediately receives the equity. The construction cost for each unit is $69,000.
Rents paid by the 73 Doe Fund building residents will be $75 a week each, for a yearly grand total of $284,700. Added to that are subsidies of $150 a month per unit from the city's Department of Homeless Services -- for housing people out of the shelter system -- totaling $131,400 a year. So, taken together, the total annual rental income for the building will be $416,000. "Sufficient to cover the operating expenses," Mr. McDonald said.
Other governmental agencies also contribute to the supportive housing movement, said Timothy O'Hanlon, director of H.P.D.'s Supportive Housing Program. The city's Department of Mental Health, under the New York/New York Agreement -- a program created by the city and state to develop housing for the mentally disabled -- has renovated about 1,400 of the 11,800 efficiency units finished so far.
THE city's Human Resources Administration provides operating assistance for the support of people with AIDS who are referred to the efficiency apartments. And under what are called the Federal McKinney Programs, H.U.D. also provides rental assistance and operating subsidies to organizations housing the formerly homeless.
For Mr. O'Hanlon, "What's unique about the Doe Fund project is that it's the first new construction of this type, aimed specifically for the working poor, in Manhattan."
There was a time, said Anthony J. Blackburn, a housing economist, when communal living arrangements, like the old S.R.O.'s, were a pillar of the city's housing structure.
"If you go back 150 years, most housing involved some form of shared living," said Dr. Blackburn, who, in 1986, wrote "Single Room Occupancy in New York City," a report commissioned by the City Council that offered recommendations for city S.R.O. policy, and then, in 1996, did a follow-up study analyzing S.R.O. data.
"There were tenements where people shared water taps and water closets," said the British-born Dr. Blackburn, "boarding houses, where residents received dining-room service; rooming houses, which were typically converted brownstones with one bath per floor and no cooking facilities." And there were lodging houses for the poorest people, where tenants rented a bed. "Basically, all these forms would, by today's definition, be called S.R.O.'s," Dr. Blackburn said.
During World War II, the city faced a severe housing shortage as laborers from across the country flocked to jobs in war-related factories dotting the boroughs. The shortage was greatly exacerbated when soldiers returned from the war and a wave of migration from Puerto Rico began. Many building owners responded by subdividing apartments into S.R.O.'s.
"The great paradox is this," said Dr. Blackburn, "that starting in the 1940's, good-government types decided that this was a deplorable form of housing." Yet the newly created S.R.O.'s were exempt from rent regulation, which had been enacted during the war because of the housing shortage. "So that was a further incentive to convert," Dr. Blackburn said. "Think about the building owner with 20 apartments; he can convert to 40 S.R.O.'s and avoid rent regulation."
By the 1950's, government officials were increasingly concerned about overcrowding, and about families living in single rooms. In 1960, the city prohibited children under 16 from living in S.R.O.'s. The people who remained were the most desolate and vulnerable. As an article, "Single Room Occupancy, Community of the Alone," written by Joan Shapiro, a sociologist, for the journal Social Work, said in 1965, "Many cluster in single-room-occupancy buildings where untreated illness, hunger, loneliness and sporadic violence are an unrelieved concomitance of existence."
In 1967, a new housing code mandated that all S.R.O.'s in tenements be reconverted to regular apartments within 10 years. But by the early 1970's, Dr. Blackburn said: "The mandated reconversions were taking place anyway. After this assault on S.R.O.s, they became occupied primarily by the poorest people, and the owners found it no longer in their economic interest to maintain them as S.R.O.'s.
"There were terribly deteriorated buildings on the Upper West Side," he said, "which could be incredibly valuable if they were rented to young professionals."
Some owners forced people to leave "by creating unimaginably dreadful conditions in the building," Dr. Blackburn said. "They turned the heat off, they let units to prostitutes, drug dealers." Some hired thugs to simply throw tenants out, and dazed old men and women with their bags of belongings found themselves on the mall down Broadway.
So the city did another about-face. In 1985, the City Council passed Local Law 59, imposing an 18-month moratorium on the conversion or demolition of S.R.O. buildings. In 1987, the moratorium was made permanent. But two years later it was overturned by the New York State Court of Appeals, a ruling that the United States Supreme Court later declined to review.
"Since then," Dr. Blackburn said, "the city has been trying to save some S.R.O.'s and to encourage the development of new ones. And the fact that the moratorium was illegal meant the only way the city could move to preserve S.R.O.'s was by arranging for their acquisition by nonprofit groups."
The question of how many of the old S.R.O. apartments remain is confusing. There once were at least 200,000 in the city. By 1986, however, according to Dr. Blackburn's city-commissioned study, there were only 64,000 units left -- not including about 3,500 beds in lodging houses where, to this day, up to a dozen people might be crammed into a small room and pay perhaps $100 a month each for a bunk bed. In his 1996 statistical update of the report, Dr. Blackburn estimated that there were fewer than 47,000 S.R.O. units left.
BUT that was the estimate for buildings legally classified under the building code as S.R.O.'s, he said. "The question is: What is the size of the illegal S.R.O. inventory? By definition, nobody knows."
"Supposing the city decided to enforce the housing code and issued vacate orders for all the illegal units," he said. "The homeless population would dwarf what it is now."
While appreciative of the city's shift to efficiency-apartment construction, Dr. Blackburn contends that, at least for the near future, it will merely dent the problem.
"The city is spitting in the wind," he said. "It wants to preserve S.R.O.s, but the economics are going in the other direction. So the only ones that come on line are the ones capitalized by the government."
Commissioner Roberts does not disagree. "I think it is certainly a fair conclusion that the need has, for some time, exceeded the ability of the market to provide units," he said. "Certainly that's true for all segments of the housing market.
"And that is why we are exploring as many alternatives as possible to increase support for this type of housing," he said, "including additional financial resources at the Federal and state levels. At the same time, we are trying to identify ways in which we can be more creative with the resources now available to support additional units."
Mr. Gatson, still reveling in his new, real home in the Bronx, certainly appreciates the program. "I cherish this place just like I cherish my life," he said. "I've got pictures all over the wall, carpeting on the floor."
Next to his clock stands Mr. Gatson's new baptismal certificate. Just days after moving in, he went to a revival meeting in a tent in Harlem and "got re-baptized," Mr. Gatson said. "It means I'm starting my life all over again."
Mr. Jiminez knows what he wants to do soon after moving into his apartment in the Doe Fund building: "Hang up a picture of my daughter -- she's a little lady now -- and have her come over to see where daddy lives, and then take her to Central Park."

HEADLINE: THE NEW BERLIN;
Signs of Health

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Though I greatly enjoyed your articles about the transformations of Berlin April 11 , readers may have been left with the impression that the city is not well, that it's burdened by its history, its architecture and its petty political squabbles. And judging by the articles, Berlin is a city without people. 
 Yet Berlin is the most green city I know. Its borders encompass lakes, a forest, a large central park and many small parks. Berlin is a bicycle-friendly city, with biking lanes throughout, and bicyclists have open access to the mass-transit system for long-distance travel.
Berlin is a city of incredible cultural diversity. A year of living in the Wedding district offered ample proof that Berlin, if not Germany, is a multicultural society; this despite the protestations of the Christian Democrats and the frequently reported neo-Nazi activity.
And it's a city of openness. Gay and lesbian couples move freely and openly in public. Access to high culture is seen as a democratic right rather than a privilege reserved for the rich and the sophisticated. The elderly, students and the unemployed have access to museums, opera houses and symphonic halls that could put some North American counterparts to shame. There, a student does not have to stand through Wagner to enjoy Wagner.
As a home for retrospective movie theaters, Berlin places perhaps only third behind Paris and New York. It is a city of offbeat experimentation: Shakespeare im Hof and numerous independent art galleries. Berlin does not need to arrive; she has been with us all along in many different forms.
 
MARK WOLFGRAM
Hull, Quebec

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Clark Munnell and Esra Ansay

 BODY:
Esra Ansay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Engin A. Ansay of New York and Istanbul, Turkey, was married on Friday to Thomas Clark Munnell Jr., a son of Alicia H. Munnell of Boston and Mr. Munnell of Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Pike performed the ceremony, combining Episcopal and Islamic traditions, at the Essex House in New York.
Mrs. Munnell, 26, was until February a vice president of St. Thomas Inc., a leather goods maker in New York. She graduated from Brown University and received an M.B.A. from New York University. 
Her father is a special adviser and a member of the Turkish Mission to the United Nations in New York. Until last year, he was the observer at the United Nations for the Organization of the Islamic Conference, a secular political organization representing Islamic states.
Mr. Munnell, 32, is known as Clark. He is a vice president in private client services at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the New York investment bank. He graduated magna cum laude from Middlebury College, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received an M.B.A. from Harvard University. He is also a founder of Patch the Apple, a fund-raising group in New York that supports neighborhood volunteer organizations.
His mother is the Peter F. Drucker Professor of Management Sciences at Boston College in Chestnut Hill, Mass. From 1995 to 1997, she was the Assistant Treasury Secretary for economic policy. His father is a founding partner of Downer & Company, an investment banking concern in Boston. The bridegroom is a stepson of Eizie Munnell and of Henry S. Healy.
The couple met in 1997 at a polo match in Darien, Conn.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HUNTERS POINT;
Theater Curtain Company Will Stay in City for Encore

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIR 

 BODY:
Housed in a nondescript two-story building between a crab house and a trophy maker is a small company that has played a large part in dressing the stages of dozens of Broadway theaters, as well as opera houses and concert halls across the country. It now looks as if the 100-year-old company will remain there.
From the Shubert Theater on West 44th Street to the National Theater in Washington, as well as dozens of the city's public schools, the handiwork of I. Weiss & Sons has been hoisted to open countless performances. Cut and stitched by hand, its stage curtains currently rise and fall on "The Lion King" and "Miss Saigon" on Broadway. 
 I. Weiss, at 2-07 Borden Avenue, employs 22 needleworkers and cutters who work on more than 1,000 projects a year, from main theater curtains to backdrops to side or "leg" curtains and curtains for audience boxes. Main curtains cost from $15,000 to $50,000.
The work is laborious. It took seven months to stitch the elaborate main curtain and nine scenery curtains used for "The Phantom of the Opera," the long-running musical that went on a national tour and spurred a boom in I. Weiss's business, said David Rosenberg, the company president.
"If you had to pick a show that singlehandedly was responsible for more theater renovations, it was 'Phantom,' " he said.
With business flourishing, Mr. Rosenberg considered moving to larger quarters in New Jersey. But in December he received tax incentives valued at $294,000 through a new city bond program aimed at helping small manufacturers stay in New York City. The incentives persuaded him to spend $950,000 to buy and renovate the 16,500-square-foot Borden Avenue building.
"I. Weiss has been here manufacturing theater drapery for 100 years, and we want to make sure they stay for another 100," said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
The company was founded in 1900 by Isadore Weiss, an upholsterer who set up shop in the theater district and became sought after by Broadway prop men. By the 1940's, Mr. Weiss's sons, Mac and Henry, had broadened the business to include theatrical drapery and rigging. Mr. Rosenberg, a former theater production manager, bought a half-interest in the company from a Weiss grandson in 1985, four years after the move to Queens.
"The only thing I knew," he said of theatrical drapery, "was how to hang it."
But since then he has become involved in complex projects, like the custom-dyed blue velour curtain for "The Best Little Whorehouse Goes Public," a play with a notoriously short run. Sewn to the drapery were 75,000 sequins and 10,000 fiber-optic lights that created a Las Vegas skyline.
"The lights came on, the curtains opened and then the play closed," Mr. Rosenberg said.
 RICHARD WEIR
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Curtains from I. Weiss & Sons rise and fall on Broadway at "The Lion King" and "Miss Saigon." (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "STAGECRAFT: Curtains by Category
Proscenium curtains, the main drapes used to cover a stage, come in three basic types.
 
The Austrian -- This "guillotine" curtain unfurls from the ceiling to the floor, usually in one or two sections.
 
The Tab -- This curtain unfolds diagonally, one section from the upper left corner of the stage and one from the upper right.
 
The Traveler -- This style "travels" across the stage from left to right or right to left. A two-section version, with the pieces meeting in the middle, is the most common type of theater curtain.
 
(Source: I. Weiss and Sons Inc.)

HEADLINE: COPING;
Life and Death in the 90's

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
THE night before we set my mother free, I went to my first political fund-raiser as a paying guest. Two grown-up events within 24 hours.
In recent months, as my mother, 90, lay dying, I thought about health care more as a political than a purely personal issue, particularly for the elderly. I sometimes fantasized that one of the tubes running out of her body was the cash flow to what I have come to think of as the Geriatric-Industrial Complex, that growing Octopus Inc. of hospitals, nursing and funeral homes, drug companies, eldercare lawyers, end-of-life ethicists, retirement villa real estate agents, senior stock churners and golden age entertainers. I imagined my mother in the bull's-eye of an emotional and economic Target Gray. Where were the Gray Panthers? Which politicians were protecting her? 
 So when my friend Stephen F. Cohen, a professor of Russian studies at New York University, asked me to join him at a $1,000-a-plate dinner for Bill Bradley, I said I would consider it seriously if he told the Presidential candidate that I was interested in becoming the Surgeon-Private. Steve said he would consider it seriously.
I had attended political banquets as a member of the press; once I heard President Nixon tell football stories that made me feel sympathy for his dorkiness. But I had never paid to go to one, sometimes I was too cheap, sometimes afraid of compromising myself as a journalist.
I had met Bill Bradley when he broke in with the Knicks more than 30 years ago, and I wrote about the team for The New York Times. We became friends when we both left sports in the 70's. Over the years, I wished he was as warm and funny in public as he was in private. When his wife, Ernestine, joined me in the Cancer Club, she and I exchanged medical notes.
Before my mother's mind began slipping last summer from brain cancer, she had agreed with me that President Clinton's worst offense was dropping the ball on health care. As retired city teachers on pensions, my parents have been fairly well covered medically, but the pilferage and indignities of the system enraged them. They passed that on to me, and I decided to pass it on to the candidate.
My wife, Kathy, and I sent in $1,000 each and arrived at the Sheraton New York Hotel early enough on April 15 to chat with Bill at the cocktail hour. Before I could speak, he said that he knew all about my new one-hour health show on Cablevision's Metro Learning channel. He would like me to contribute to his paper on health care.
Uncoolly, I blurted, "I would hold your feet to the fire on universal care, catastrophic coverage, children and the elderly."
He chuckled in a cool, political way. "I'm glad you don't have strong opinions."
At dinner, I thanked Steve for briefing Bill about me, and said that when I was Surgeon-Sergeant I would lobby for him and his wife, Katrina vanden Heuvel, editor of The Nation, to be ambassadors to Russia.
We applauded when the old Knicks' captain, Willis Reed, told the audience how players used to call Bill Mr. President.
The next morning, my dad, my sister, Gale, and I signed papers so that Fanny F. Lipsyte could be released from life support. Afterward, I sat alone in her Arden Hills Hospital room and told her I was going to be the Surgeon-Major. She had always wanted me to be a doctor.
Mom was able to breathe on her own for a little more than three days.
She died around 8:30 P.M. last Monday. The only undertaker I trust, John Kritl, came up from Manhattan to handle the cremation.
I'm taking off the month of May. I'll hang out with Dad for some of it. He likes my Target Gray image and is collecting research on the topic. He thinks I should write a book. I think he should. He thinks I should be wary of Bill Bradley; his political skepticism has historical sweep. When Sidney Irving Lipsyte was born in 1904, the President was Teddy Roosevelt and the doctor made house calls in the Bronx in a buggy. Now Dad's grandchildren want him to get a computer and E-mail.
Dad, meanwhile, reads mine. An old pal, Ed Weinstein, E-mails that the street con man he calls Red is back in Manhattan. Red guilt-trips affluent white men of late middle age into "lending" him $30 for gas so he can visit his father in the hospital. Red makes his marks believe that his dad was the genial black garage attendant or office building janitor whom they remembered only at Christmas.
After Ed recounted the scam here several years ago, hundreds of men, somewhat proudly, wrote and called to join the club. Last week, Ed spotted Red at Park Avenue and 56th Street and welcomed him back.
"Oh," Red said coolly, "I already borrowed money from you?"
Life goes on.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 908 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: ON THE JOB;
Tarred and Feathered, With Humor

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
Thank goodness for humor. Sometimes when life on the job is at its most tense, when a situation is at its bleakest, a witty word and a good laugh come along to save the day. Readers offered so many cases in point that a second serving of their stories became obligatory.
Some 30 years ago, early in his public relations career, Sanford Teller of New York City worked as a junior account executive in the Manhattan office of a large out-of-town advertising and marketing company. 
 Eager to impress, he usually arrived before 8 A.M. and remained until well after 6 in the evening.
"One morning, after breakfast with a client, I got to the office at 9:30," he writes. "As I passed the desk, the receptionist wished me a good morning and informed that I had to sign 'the book.' "
Mr. Teller was told that the office supervisor had decreed that beginning immediately, all account executives had to sign in each morning, giving their time of arrival. There was also a heading called "reason for being late," and the receptionist said company business was the only acceptable excuse.
"I was appalled that my creativity and professionalism were being judged by the clock," Mr. Teller writes. "And if the company was so interested in the time I arrived, why didn't it care about my time of departure?
"I knew that an angry response would not go down well. Which is why, after some deliberation, I wrote that I was late because 'My parakeet developed a hernia, and I had trouble finding a pet shop that sold a tiny truss.' "
Less than 30 minutes later, Mr. Teller was summoned to the office of the boss, who told him to close the door and take a seat. Mr. Teller could see the book, with its offending entry, open on the desk.
The boss asked him to explain, and he did.
The boss listened carefully, thought for a moment, then broke into a smile. "I think you're right," he said.
The next morning, the book was gone.
Mr. Teller adds two postscripts:
1. "I've used humor in business whenever appropriate ever since."
2. "I must admit that I've never owned a parakeet."
"It was a job seeker's nightmare," writes Peg Mancuso of Hicksville, N.Y. Four high-ranking officials of a university were taking turns questioning her about how she would handle the role of alumni relations director for the institution.
"The university had lost track of many of the alumni and needed to regain contact," Mrs. Mancuso says. "I had some ideas and answered all the questions with the confidence that I could do the job for my alma mater."
But then one of the vice presidents asked, "So, do you think you could find all of the lost alumni?"
Mrs. Mancuso hesitated. The tension built.
"I felt that if I answered 'yes,' I would be showing overconfidence and a lack of knowledge about the challenges of the job," she recalled. "But to answer 'no' would be to admit to the possibility of failure."
Mrs. Mancuso repeated the question and, with a smile, gave her reply: "No, I don't think that I'll find all the alumni, at least not those in the Witness Protection Program."
She got the job.
When George A. Cohon, now senior chairman of both McDonald's Russia and McDonald's Restaurants of Canada, was negotiating in the early 1980's to introduce the fast-food chain to the Soviet Union, he often met with Vsevolod Shimansky, an official of the Russian Federation's Trade Ministry. Mr. Shimansky often wanted to continue their talks over dinner, especially at restaurants with live balalaika music.
One night during this period, on a trip to Australia, Mr. Cohon found himself in a restaurant where the owner went from table to table, playing a different stringed instrument -- a guitar -- in what seemed to be a very accomplished fashion. "But when he stopped strumming, the guitar kept playing; he had a tape deck inside the guitar," Mr. Cohon writes with David Macfarlane in "To Russia With Fries" (McClelland & Stewart). "As soon as I saw it, I thought: Shimansky.
"I got a tape deck. I got a balalaika. I carefully inserted the tape deck into the body of the balalaika.
The next time Mr. Cohon came to Russia, he wasted no time telling Mr. Shamansky that he had been studying the balalaika. Mr. Shimansky wasted no time telling Mr. Cohon that he wanted to hear him play.
Mr. Cohon stalled until the last night of his visit, when they went to Valdai, not only one of Mr. Shimansky's favorite restaurants but also a place that featured balalaika music.
Finally, over coffee, Mr. Cohon said, "Well, it is now time for me to play the balalaika."
The instrument had been planted in a corner. With his back to the table, Mr. Cohon switched on the tape, turned around and began strumming a classic balalaika tune, "Moscow Nights."
Mr. Shimansky was astonished. "He stood there in amazement, moved almost to tears," Mr. Cohon writes.
"How beautiful!" Mr. Shimansky exclaimed. How he wished he could play such a song.
"You can," Mr. Cohon said, still strumming.
Mr. Shimansky said: "No, I have not the gift of music. Not like you."
To which Mr. Cohon replied, "No, really, you can learn."
Mr. Cohon passed the instrument to Mr. Shimansky. "And, of course, when I handed it to him, it continued playing," he writes.
Mr. Shimansky almost fell over his chair. And then his laughter boomed through the restaurant.
"It's a gift," Mr. Cohon said. "For you."
Mr. Cohon writes, "Shimansky turned out to be a good ally for us to have."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2865 words

HEADLINE: The Indexing Giant Nobody Knows

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
IN an era when being biggest in any endeavor brings hubris and hype, Barclays Global Investors stands out by being nearly invisible to the untutored eye.
But it is Barclays Global, not the much vaunted Vanguard Group, that is king of the stock-market indexers -- managing $407 billion in investors' money by mimicking the performance of major market indexes. And it is Barclays Global, not a white-shoe bank or insurance company, that is the world's biggest manager of funds for institutions, like corporate pension funds and nonprofit organizations. It even has designs on displacing the giant Fidelity Investments, with $765 billion in its care, as the world's biggest manager of money. 
 Barclays Global, a unit of the British bank Barclays P.L.C., started out as part of Wells Fargo, the San Francisco bank. The unit already has a remarkable perch, considering that it lacks a well-known American brand name to advertise, sits far from the biggest financial centers, was long hobbled by legal restrictions not affecting some competitors and is led by a chairman who joined the company as a temporary secretary because she couldn't land a job in journalism.
Yet even more than Vanguard, which has concentrated on individual investors and met their demands for an array of products, Barclays Global has ridden the indexing rage to dizzying heights, managing a total of $619 billion at the end of last year.
Part of the reason can be found at the nation's pension plans. Just like small investors across the country, leaders of those plans are often choosing the indexing route, having grown tired of watching most mutual funds and other money managers fail to match the performance of the overall market. After all, what can be more unpleasant, not to mention costly, than having to face disgruntled employees to explain their pension fund's underperformance?
Size, too, works to Barclays Global's advantage. Bigness can be an impediment for so-called active managers of money -- those who use a variety of strategies and criteria to pick and choose stocks -- but it helps an indexer. Barclays Global has so much money under its roof that it obtains staggering economies of scale, allowing it to charge annual fees that are in many cases less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the money being managed, half the level that wins Vanguard so much praise for its fund indexed to the Standard & Poor's 500. And every day, Barclays Global does $1 billion in trades among clients in house.
Moreover, Barclays Global pioneered indexing and remains at its forefront, with a couple of dozen Ph.D.'s prowling the investment frontiers behind doors marked "This is a secured floor." While it manages some $400 billion through plain-vanilla indexing -- in itself not always as easy as it sounds -- it also has huge sums assigned to its computer jockeys, quantitative investors who try to tease a bit more than market returns from more complex investment products.
Indexing, of course, is a rejection of what much of Wall Street holds dear -- especially its faith in stock-picking prowess.
"Most of what happens in this business is more justified by hope -- and perhaps a little greed -- than by experience," contended Patricia C. Dunn, 46, the chairman of Barclays Global, coolly sipping from an ever-handy bottle of spring water. "We get a lot of our energy from being outsiders and challengers of investing wisdom."
As indexing's biggest practitioner, Barclays Global hears all the criticisms leveled at a practice that is both popular and threatening to many plush livelihoods. One contention is that indexing is a fad that has looked attractive because the market has been enamored, at least until this month, of the big stocks that dominate the Standard & Poor's 500, the benchmark for 70 percent of indexed equity mutual funds and a good deal of institutional money.
"If sentiment shifts away from the big-cap stocks in the S.& P., indexing will take a powerful hit," said Jeremy Siegel, a professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. "You leave yourself very vulnerable."
Index-fund management is also inherently a commodity business; it produced a relatively modest $83.2 million of profit last year for Barclays Global's parent, 2 percent more than in 1997. Slender margins put a premium on volume.
AS it aspires to become the world's No. 1 money manager, Barclays Global faces a big challenge: protecting its institutional turf against traditional rivals like State Street Global Advisors, Mellon Capital and Bankers Trust while it pushes into the retail market, especially 401(k) and other retirement savings vehicles.
Coy about its plans, Barclays Global says it will not buy a public mutual fund group. But it rules out little else. Tom Taggart, the company's recently hired spokesman, used the term "instividual" to refer to what is widely seen as a convergence of the institutional and individual investment businesses. "Look for B.G.I. leveraging its expertise in this area," he added.
Others speculate that the company might act as a subadviser to someone else's funds, a business into which it has already dipped a toe, or provide indexing skills in an alliance, say, with a major brokerage house.
What distinguishes Barclays Global from most other money managers is its commitment to indexing, a theory of investing built on the idea that the stock market is a highly efficient information-processing machine, one in which a giant web of participants quickly incorporates every scrap of information into prices. By the time word circulates of a predicted drop in the quarterly profits of Gillette, to cite a recent example, the price has already fallen.
In other words, the stock market is far different from the place portrayed in personal finance magazines, mutual fund advertisements and popular mythology, one in which smart or well-connected people profit by outwitting the less smart.
About $407 billion of the money entrusted to Barclays Global is invested in straightforward replicas of various market averages. But while this kind of investing is often derided as something that could be done by a monkey, Steven Schoenfeld, a senior Barclays Global official whose job title is index strategist -- not an oxymoron -- knows otherwise.
Among the numerous practical problems he faces are dealing with sudden inflows or outflows of clients' money and keeping from running prices up on himself when buying a small-capitalization stock.
And when should someone in his position buy a company like Safeway, which Standard & Poor's announced a few months ago as a new addition to its 500 index? Should he buy as soon as the announcement is made, or the morning of the day the company is initially counted? Or five minutes before the market closes? Or a day or two later? Or should he buy options instead?
It's a constant, high-stakes game of cat and mouse in which Barclays Global, as the world's biggest indexer, is everybody's Sylvester. "We have to make sure our strategy is not predictable -- or we're the suckers," Mr. Schoenfeld said. "There's plenty of hedge funds, mutual funds and brokers who would be all too happy to pick us off."
Indexing gets treacherous overseas when rivals know that Barclays Global is a near-certain buyer in a thin market with rudimentary benchmarks. "Once you go outside the United States, just tracking the index is a major investment challenge," Mr. Schoenfeld said. "Not just anyone could do it."
Russia, not surprisingly, is difficult, but so is a market like Switzerland, which is dominated by a handful of huge companies, mostly in finance and pharmaceuticals.
Barclays Global follows more than 50 foreign markets, so "when you get into all the splicing and dicing, we're probably tracking close to 1,000 different indexes," Mr. Schoenfeld said.
But for all its success as a replicator of benchmarks, Barclays Global also recognizes the human urge to try to do better than average. The company puts about one-third of its invested money in "tilts," funds that are basically index-matched but also "enhanced" with variations engineered to match a client's tolerance of risk.
For example, the product Barclays Global calls NeuAlpha -- in investing, alpha refers to the amount by which you beat a benchmark -- is a long-short tilt, one that, as its name implies, includes a mix of short and long positions that reflect negative as well as positive information the firm has uncovered.
The detective work behind it relies heavily on immense computing power, enough gigabytes to audit every American income-tax return in 15 minutes. "We're not looking at making big bets on 20 or 30 or 50 companies," said Blake R. Grossman, the company's chief global investment officer. "We're making small bets across hundreds," scooping up what he calls the "nickels and dimes" invisible to others.
Many investors, for example, track Wall Street's estimates of company earnings, especially trends in analysts' revisions. Barclays Global keeps tabs on individual analysts, combining their forecasting records with other data to find patterns in how stocks react to shifts by certain analysts on certain companies.
Like many others, Barclays Global also tracks the buying and selling by executives of their companies' stocks, but it evaluates this information in the context of other facts, like how a company's executives are managing its financial structure. For instance, is expansion being financed with borrowing or new shares?
Barclays Global, however, does not borrow money to invest and is sparing in its use of futures and derivatives. "We don't have many funds that are leveraged," said Andrea Zulberti, the head of the firm's risk-management operation.
Over all, Barclays Global's results have been sparkling, people in the industry say. But performance for some clients has been hampered in the last few years by the huge gulf between a relative handful of big-capitalization stocks driving the main indexes and the rest of the market.
"As that top group has done better and better," said John F. Casey, chairman of Barra RogersCasey, a consulting firm in Darien, Conn., the Barclays Global approach "is forcing them to underweight these and to put money into the stocks that are so much cheaper."
But Mr. Casey said the clients he has steered toward Barclays Global are a highly satisfied group. "What they like," he said, "is that the research function is so rigorous that it's like bringing out a new pharmaceutical product in testing these things." And he said Barclays Global makes investment results dependably transparent, giving clients enough information so that they can see the source of the returns.
RIVALS acknowledge Barclays Global's trailblazing in indexing and its aggressiveness in building its institutional business, with clients like the pension funds of Exxon. But they don't hold Barclays Global in awe.
"We're using very similar techniques," said Gus Sauter, who oversees Vanguard's index and active quantitative group. "Everyone, if they're not on the same page, then at least they're reading from the same book."
In fact, Mr. Sauter complained that so-called enhanced indexing products, like the tilts, are not actually index funds; instead, he said, they reflect active strategies, however closely controlled. "There's no such thing as half pregnant or half wet," he said.
Nicholas A. Lopardo, chairman of State Street Global Advisors, which manages $485 billion and is the No. 2 indexer, contended that his old-line firm interacts with clients more than Barclays Global does and noted that it had grown without acquisitions.
(In 1995, however, State Street did seek to buy Wells Fargo Nikko Investment Advisers, as Barclays Global Investors was then known. Negotiations failed over who would end up in charge.)
Barclays Global's money under management has roughly tripled over the last four years -- a result of a combination of mergers, growing interest in outside management of investments for companies, increased popularity of indexing and, of course, one of the greatest bull markets on record.
Some of the growth was at the expense of traditional active managers; other new money came from public entities that had previously been obliged by law to manage their funds themselves.
The chief architect of the firm's development was Fred Grauer, a Wells Fargo strategist who had left the bank after a short stint in 1979 and 1980 and was lured back in 1983, when the business was floundering. He masterminded the 1990 deal in which half of Wells Fargo's investment unit was sold to Nikko Securities, then managed the late-1995 sale of the resulting business to Barclays, the latter bringing $85 billion in managed money.
If the firm is under pressure from London to contribute more to its parent's so-so bottom line these days, nobody here will acknowledge it.
Mr. Grauer, citing an interest in "brand new challenges," resigned suddenly in July, leaving Ms. Dunn in charge; as co-chairman since early 1997, she was the natural successor.
Yet the size of Barclays Global and its reputation do not prevent it from worrying about its competitive position as it serves a highly demanding clientele in a low-margin business.
"One of the biggest challenges they face in this country is competition from the big trust banks that frequently bundle indexed products in with their custody services," said Paul Holt, president of Cambridge International Partners, an investment management consultant. Custody business includes record-keeping, accounting and serving as a transfer agent, and it opens the door to the lucrative practice of lending securities. Such lending, mainly to investors who wish to sell the securities now and repay them later after repurchasing them at a hoped-for lower price, accounts for some 15 percent of Barclays Global's revenues, which totaled about $460 million in 1998, and an even larger share of its profits.
Nobody thinks the Barclays Global retail strategy will be to jump into the mutual fund business or to market directly to individual investors. That, among other things, would violate its stated core belief that it should focus strictly on what it does best -- managing money.
What's more, suggested Avi Nachmany, head of research at Strategic Insight, a New York firm that researches funds, the cost would probably be prohibitive.
Barclays Global expects to unveil an expansion plan in coming months -- an expansion that it hopes will make it burst into public consciousness. "It's not soup yet," Ms. Dunn said of the plan.
But when it's ready, she added in an interview in her 33d-floor office overlooking San Francisco Bay, "we'll be shouting from the rooftops."
 
A Career Detour That Led To the Chairman's Office
 SINCE 1976, when she joined Barclays Global Investors, Patricia C. Dunn has taken a turn at nearly every job there -- the clearing and settling of trades, portfolio management and positions in sales, accounting, trading and administration -- none of which she was initially qualified to do.
Indeed, in the fall she told a women's leadership conference at the University of California's Haas School of Business that she couldn't even have gotten into business school. "My expectations were so low," she said in explaining her start at Barclays Global as a temporary secretary, "that I can honestly say I did not have a career ambition."
When Ms. Dunn graduated from the University of California at Berkeley, she was unable to find a job in journalism, her first choice. She also thought people who worked for long in corporate America "didn't have a life" and recalls thinking, "It's just not in my future to work for a bank."
Yet nobody was surprised last summer when the sudden resignation of Fred Grauer left her the undisputed boss. The two had shared the top job for 18 months.
She has clearly mastered the theory of Barclays Global's heavily quantitative work -- she calls herself a "huge believer" that investing should be considered science, not art. But it is management skill and an adaptive mind that have lifted her to her powerful job. Senior industry officials guess that she earns at least $1.5 million a year and perhaps as much as $5 million.
"Somebody needs to bring together the technical with the real," Ms. Dunn said. "Probably the thing that I did at the point of my career where I advanced the most involved helping clients figure out how to use our highly sophisticated investment services to their advantage."
About the most foolish thing some investors do today, she contends, is chase after the hottest fund managers. "Past performance explains nothing about the future," she said. "That search for predictive power -- you can't find it."
And how does it feel to be responsible for $619 billion? "I dream about it," Ms. Dunn responded. "Sleep deprivation is an occupational hazard."
But she allowed that she would probably worry just as much about one-thousandth of that sum, which would be a mere $619 million. "After a point," she said, fretting that she might sound flip, "it gets to be zeros, doesn't it?" ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLOWBROOK;
Housing for Elderly Is Issue

BYLINE: By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
A fight has broken out between city officials and Staten Island conservationists over the Economic Development Corporation's request for proposals to build a housing complex for the elderly. The complex would be on 40 acres of vacant city land next to Sea View Hospital and Rehabilitation Center and Home on Brielle Avenue.
The borough's largest environmental group, Protectors of Pine Oak Woods, has called for a moratorium on development of the land, known as Northern Parcel, because it is next to the Greenbelt, a 2,500-acre ring of city-owned wooded parkland in the middle of Staten Island. 
 The group's president, Dick Buegler, said the land should not be developed because its large meadows support rare serpentine soil-based plant life and the Argos Skipper butterfly that feeds on them, and because a 1991 master plan for the Greenbelt, drawn up by a task force of city and local representatives, recommended adding the Northern Parcel to the Greenbelt to protect the area's environmental integrity.
Borough President Guy V. Molinari is among city officials who favor developing the 40 acres. He said the hilltop land had been "lying fallow for many years" when his office and the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation urged the Economic Development Corporation last year to sell it to a developer who would build housing for the elderly.
"It's an ideal location for senior housing," Mr. Molinari said. "The grounds are magnificent and safe and a stone's throw from Sea View Hospital." The hospital agency's senior vice president for communications, Jane Zimmerman, said residents supported the building of such housing near the hospital at a public meeting last October.
Mr. Buegler said his group did not object to housing for the elderly, nor to placing it near Sea View Hospital. "But why build in an undisturbed natural area?" he asked. Instead, he proposed that the development agency seek proposals for another 40-acre city-owned site, Farm Colony, across Brielle Avenue from Sea View Hospital, but not next to the Greenbelt.
But both Mr. Molinari and the agency's spokeswoman, Bernadette O'Leary, pointed out that Farm Colony contains several buildings that have been designated landmarks, which might make it less attractive to developers. Ms. O'Leary also said her agency would take into account environmental issues when reviewing developers' proposals.
A dozen developers toured the Northern Parcel site on Friday. Mr. Buegler noted that Northern Parcel is part of the Farm Colony-Sea View Historic District, making new construction there difficult. The spokeswoman for the Landmarks Preservations Commission, Terri Rosen Deutsch, said any proposal for development of Northern Parcel would require a certificate of appropriateness from the commission, which would hold a public hearing on the matter.
"I don't think we'd say that no development is preferred," she said. "We need to review the proposals."
 JIM O'GRADY

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2736 words

HEADLINE: Young-Life Crisis;
They Burned Out Early on the Fast Track. Now They're Choosing Different Paths.

BYLINE: By JULIAN E. BARNES 

 BODY:
EVEN as a boy, Steve Brotman had the spirit of an entrepreneur. At 13, he said, he bought personal computers for $1,500 each and resold them to less technologically savvy neighbors for $2,500. Four years ago, fresh out of law and business schools, Mr. Brotman, then 26, decided that the Internet would be a terrific place for people to post classified advertisements, and for him to make money. He rented a cramped 20-by-10-foot office a few blocks north of City Hall and started up Ad One Classified Network.
As Silicon Alley took off, so did the company. Mr. Brotman was featured in news articles, and newspapers flocked to Ad One to get their classified ads posted on the network. Being a 90's Internet pioneer, he said, "was like being in a 60's rock band." But the rock star glamour faded quickly. During 16-hour days at the office, Mr. Brotman ran a promising but still unprofitable company, juggling 10 credit cards to cover the cost of everything from Ad One's toilet paper to its payroll. Before long, he was $150,000 in debt. 
 The company's computers constantly overheated, forcing the air-conditioning into high gear, which short-circuited the electricity and caused the Web site to crash. Mr. Brotman, dehydrated in his sweltering office, developed kidney stones.
At an age when most business people are starting to climb the ladder, he was burned out. In 1996, he began what turned into a yearlong search for a chief executive. Days after hiring his executive, Mr. Brotman became engaged. Three months later, he ended his management role with Ad One.
"It was like waking up for the first time," he said. "I didn't care anymore. Well, I cared. I cared. But it wasn't the only thing in my life. Once I realized the business wasn't the only thing in my life, I was less intense. I figured out what is really important to me."
Mr. Brotman in essence had a midlife crisis two decades before entering midlife. He is not alone. Sociologists say that many professional men and women in their mid-20's to mid-30's are re-examining career-driven lives, reassessing priorities and quitting their jobs to travel, study or just to find themselves.
This generation is often stereotyped as apathetic, its members more interested in a good time than a good job. But according to a 1997 survey by the Families and Work Institute in Manhattan, 73 percent of college-educated 25- to 32-year-olds worked more than 40 hours a week compared with 55 percent in 1977.
"Their aspirations are focused on economic self-sufficiency less than personal fulfillment," said a professor of sociology at New York University, Kathleen Gerson. "But when one finds that is not enough, that leads to a reassessment."
Professor Gerson and other experts said the pressure to pick a lucrative career early on might be explained in part by young professionals having been reared during the economically uncertain 1970's. In interviews, several 20- and 30-somethings said those early fears had been sharpened when they graduated from college during a recession in the early 1990's.
They also pointed out that their work ethic had allowed them to pay off student loans and save money, which makes an earlier-than-midlife crisis more affordable. It also helps that young workers often delay marriage and that few families these days depend on a single breadwinner.
An N.Y.U. law professor, Stephen Gillers, says he has watched young lawyers burn out for more than two decades, many from the scut work demanded in pre-partnership days. "The problem is that people aren't told up front what the job is like," he said. "But they wouldn't believe it up front, so disappointment is built into the career track."
In New York, a city that worships success, every job change can seem like a crisis. Some young professionals insist that only by leaving can they catch their breath and find some perspective. But for others New York is the place to come for a radical life change.
 
Goodbye to Big Bucks, Hello to Satisfaction
In July 1997, Dan Kwon left his $160,000 a year job as a Wall Street investment banker and moved to San Francisco, where he took another job in finance and enrolled in a screenwriting course. He said he found himself thinking constantly about his script ideas, impulsively jotting down bits of overheard dialogue. Last July, at 26, he quit his day job and started writing screenplays and sitcoms full time.
"If I stayed in New York, I wouldn't be in this situation," he said. "In New York, you don't take the time to stop and think. It is this machine which drives you forward.
"I don't know how many banker friends I have who said, 'I am so proud of you' while in the back of their minds they are thinking, 'I am so glad it's not me,' " Mr. Kwon went on. "It's cognitive dissonance, complete disattachment. They hate what they are doing, but they can't leave."
Lee Whitley remembers feeling consumed by a job he almost didn't get. In March 1990, three weeks after Merrill Lynch offered him a position in investment banking at its Battery Park City headquarters, he received a letter by Federal Express. To Mr. Whitley's horror, it said the recession was forcing Merrill Lynch to scale back hiring. Only the first 30 people who accepted the company's offer would have a job. Mr. Whitley grabbed his phone, and the job, and didn't let go for nine years.
He comes from a lower-middle-class family in Aberdeen, Miss., and, he said, looked to Wall Street for the money. Within two years of joining Merrill Lynch, he had paid off his student loans from Yale. But he regularly worked for three days without sleeping, returning to his apartment only to shower and change clothes, while a company car and driver waited outside to shuttle him back to work. Those 110-hour weeks kept Mr. Whitley from family gatherings, and he lost touch with friends.
"There are a lot of things I could have done that I didn't do because I was married to my job," he said.
Last August, while sitting on a Caribbean beach, contemplating his approaching 30th birthday and those missed events, he decided to quit Merrill Lynch. He waited, though, until February, after he he collected a substantial end-of-the-year bonus that pushed his net worth past $1 million.
"In my 20's, I didn't care about working a lot. I wanted to have a job that I would make a lot of money at," he said. "Going forward, the money is not that important. I have reached a financial goal. Now control over my life style will be more important."
Mr. Whitley says he is toying with the idea of teaching, although he concedes that his appetite for the business world has not completely disappeared. For now he is visiting friends and family in Mississippi. He plans to go to Spain in July, then spend at least two months touring Europe.
The Adventure Cycling Association, a nonprofit organization in Montana that has been leading bicycle expeditions since 1976, said that today far fewer college-age students and far more 25- to 35-year-olds are leaving work behind and taking three months off to bike across the United States.
"People are going right to work but then finding after 5 or 10 years that they are longing to discover themselves or challenge themselves in a nonacademic, nonprofessional way," said Kevin Condit, 35, who during his own young-life crisis six years ago quit as a creative director at an advertising agency in Philadelphia to become the cycling association's marketing director.
This spring, guided by Adventure Cycling maps, Lucy von Brachel, 25, plans to take her own cross-country ride. The trip represents a profound shift in sensibility for Ms. von Brachel, who lives in Greenwich Village and graduated from the Parsons School of Design in 1995. That spring, she turned down her mother's offer to pay for her to travel. "I felt I didn't want to owe anyone any money," she said. "I was driven to be settled, to be financially independent."
So the day after graduation, Ms. von Brachel, still a bit drunk from celebrating, showed up at the Howard Greenberg Gallery in SoHo, where she had accepted a job framing and packing pictures for shipment. She was promoted to overseeing inventory and then to a co-manager of the gallery's backroom operations. In May 1997, she left to join Art Systems, a computer company that produces software to manage gallery inventories.
But last November, Ms. von Brachel said, she found herself at a crossroads, still ambitious to work in the art world but trying to figure out what she wanted from her life, not just her career. "I am at this screwed-up transition," she said. "To feel like you have to have a career planned at 23, and then be working really hard so you will be a success at 25, that is a lot of pressure. I'm looking for something I never got before, time. I've never allowed myself to go on vacation. It was work, work, work."
She is planning to push off on her bike trip on May 19, riding with her boyfriend's sister, Katherine Pushkar, who last December gave up an editing job at The Village Voice to lead, at least temporarily, a Seinfeld-like existence.
 
A Psychologist Pursues A Rabbinical Career
Some young professionals find that worldly aspirations like a six-figure salary or a vacation home become less important over time, replaced by more spiritual concerns. Laura Gold's young-life crisis, which began five years ago, took her from a psychology practice in Ann Arbor, Mich., to the classrooms of the Jewish Theological Seminary on Morningside Heights. Dr. Gold was 34 in the fall of 1994 when, at Rosh ha-Shanah services, she found herself filled with regret that, unwilling to deviate from a career track followed since high school, she had passed up opportunities to study in Israel. As the service continued, she said, the same thought -- and counterthought -- kept recurring: "I should go to Israel. I can't do that now. How ridiculous."
She turned to her brother and announced that she was going to Israel. In June 1995, Dr. Gold took money she had saved to buy a house and a year's leave from her practice, and went to Jerusalem to study. She returned a year later to her old job and home, but her turmoil remained.
"I still loved my work, but that wasn't enough to satisfy my aspirations anymore," she said. "I wanted to make it possible for my love for Judaism to occupy a more central part of my professional life."
In the fall of 1997, Dr. Gold once more threw her life into disarray, closing her practice in Ann Arbor to begin rabbinical studies in New York. She sees a few patients in New York and says she hopes to fuse elements of her new and old careers. Before Dr. Gold left Michigan, her rabbi pointed out that she was giving up a thriving practice, but she remains certain that her decision was the right one.
"There are different circumstances which wake people up to the fact that we have to take responsibility for those aspects of our lives over which we have control," Dr. Gold said.
Her moment of crisis lead her to forge new goals. Other young people may return to plans they had abandoned years before as impractical. Mr. Kwon, the investment- banker-turned-aspiring-screenwriter, had toyed with majoring in English at Harvard, but to his parents' delight settled on the "more practical" course of study, economics.
Although Mr. Kwon was envious when a classmate in a creative writing course, Alec Berg, became a head writer for "Seinfeld," he does not completely regret his own decision to go into investment banking. His Wall Street earnings have saved him from waiting tables while writing screenplays. And he has used his financial skills to secure enough money -- Mr. Kwon calls it fund raising -- to film one of his screenplays, a romantic comedy. He plans to begin shooting in the fall, using $100,000 he has made day trading Internet stocks.
Others may disagree, but Mr. Kwon, who is married but has no children, sees himself as having made the responsible decision. In a few years, he said, it would disrupt his family far more if he gave up a lucrative job to write. And he did not want to reach 50 full of regrets over not pursuing a more satisfying career. "I don't want a midlife crisis," he said. "I'd rather have it now."
His parents have been supportive, Mr. Kwon said, although they see his screenwriting as a phase that will pass. His in-laws, he said, are slightly less sanguine. "They thought they were marrying their doctor daughter off to this professional," he said. "Then they thought, 'Oh, my god, he is a beatnik.' "
There is nothing like a young-life crisis to reveal an attitude gap between parent and child. Since graduating from Yale in 1991, David Sampliner has prepared for a career as a teacher and scholar. Mr. Sampliner, 29, worked at Phillips Academy in Massachusetts and Solomon Schecter Day School in West Orange, N.J., then studied for a Ph.D. in history at New York University. But in February, he shelved his partly completed dissertation, split with his live-in girlfriend, bought a car and headed south.
"As my father put it: 'David has broken up with his life,' " Mr. Sampliner said. He works nights at the counter of Jittery Joe's, a coffeehouse in Athens, Ga., and mornings making omelets at Bluebird, a vegetarian restaurant. He bought a mattress and a desk but has not put down any roots.
"I never did the utterly purposeless wandering where you find out what you want to do, who you are," he said before his trip.
While Mr. Sampliner's father, James, a surgeon, says he is supportive of his son and does not want to drive a wedge between them, he also makes clear that he thinks people should finish what they start. David, said Dr. Sampliner, 61, "reflects a generation that is a little different than our goal-oriented generation."
"People in our generation followed a straight line to a career," he said. "When I had a chance to deviate from my career, the other choice was to go into the Army and go to war." During the Vietnam war, he was drafted into the Public Health Service.
In recent years, he has watched David and David's older brother, Michael, and their friends change directions often. They work hard, he said, but it is not work for its own sake or for the sake of a family. This generation "wants to work hard, make money, then go to the mountains," he said. To Dr. Sampliner, who likes to quote Paul Kennedy's "Rise and Fall of the Great Powers," that shift in priorities is a sign that society has become more hedonistic. "They are less concerned with leaving their mark on society," he said, "so to lollygag around is O.K."
Dr. Gerson, the N.Y.U. sociologist, agrees with Dr. Sampliner that many young-life crises are a result of social change. But where Dr. Sampliner sees a threat to American civilization, Dr. Gerson sees a generation of young people who are trying to better balance hard work and family life. Where Dr. Sampliner sees young people who don't finish what they start, Dr. Gerson sees people who believe in second chances as they strive for the perfect career and the perfect partner. The crisis among young people "is not surprising," she said. "There is more freedom to do that and more need to find satisfying work."

Giving Up a Life In Order to Get One
In August, two years after a burned-out Steve Brotman reassessed his priorities and decided to leave the Ad One Classified Network, he and his wife, Paula, expect their first child. His new life allows him to work at home, and gives him the luxury, he points out, of baking cookies or doing laundry in the middle of the day.
Mrs. Brotman, a classified advertising manager for a weekly newspaper in New Jersey, points out that having the opportunity to do laundry, and actually doing it, are two different things. "If I called him, he would put a load of laundry in, but then he would forget to put it in the dryer, so I don't even bother anymore," she said. "It was a really nice thought, though, wasn't it?"
Mr. Brotman is a general partner of Silicon Alley Venture Partners, a company he started to invest in and advise Internet start-up companies. He works hard, he said, but not with the same chaotic intensity he once did. "At 26, I was willing to give up a life because I didn't have one," he said. "But at 31, life is more complicated. At 26, all you have is the ability to work hard. Later on you have more experience and wisdom."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Euro Has Plenty of Time To Challenge the Dollar

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
WESTERN EUROPE'S new currency, the euro, ought to be a powerhouse, already diminishing America's place in the global economy. Such was the advance billing. But nearly four months into its existence, the euro is hardly noticeable on this side of the Atlantic.
That is not too surprising. Even thoroughbred currencies inch their way up rather than leaping. Children now in diapers may be finishing college before lives are changed by the existence of the euro. And even then, a solid American economy -- one that has avoided the deterioration of severe recessions -- would dilute the impact. The robust economy today keeps the focus on dollars, not euros. 
 Still, the euro's potential challenge to the dollar's dominance is considerable. "Establishing a European currency that will rival the dollar is indeed one of the points of the whole exercise," said Peter Kenen, an international economist at Princeton University.
Not since the dollar finally eclipsed the British pound after World War II has a currency had the potential to eclipse the dollar. In the process, the euro could lift its 11 sponsoring nations toward the top of the heap in political and economic power. Neither the German mark nor the Japanese yen, the closest rivals until now, represents a population or an economy as large as those of the United States. But the euro does.
American hegemony could give way to a 21st century in which America and Europe vie with each other, says Martin Feldstein, the Harvard economist. A more solidified Europe, thanks to the euro, "creates the potential for political clash," he said. France might even succeed in putting one of its generals in charge of NATO in place of an American. Mr. Feldstein argues for diluting European power by dealing with governments there separately, not as a union.
The other great concern is the American trade deficit. Rather than lend so much to Americans to help pay for imports and for spending abroad, the world's investors could funnel some of their money into the new haven. Euro investments in a powerful Western European economy would become an alternative to Treasuries and other holdings in the United States. And Americans would find themselves scratching for overseas loans to finance their way of life -- pushing up interest rates to attract enough money.
"I would not be surprised to see a significant shift to euro investments when and if the marketplace focuses on the widening American current account deficit," said William Cline, chief economist at the Institute for International Finance, referring to all of the nation's international transactions.
According to the advance forecasts, the shift to euros was supposed to have begun as soon as the euro was born, on Jan. 1. But the money did not flow. The euro rose by only a penny from its initial value of $1.17 and then fell steadily to just over $1.06.
The means were there. Checking accounts, traveler's checks and credit card purchases are all now available in euros, as well as in the national currencies of Germany, France, Italy and the eight other countries in the European Union. Hundreds of billions of dollars in stocks, bonds and government securities are denominated in euros. And in 2002, after the new European Central Bank begins to issue euro coins and paper bills, the old currencies will vanish.
BUT confidence in the euro, for all its powerful backing, comes slowly at all levels. American Express says European merchants have sent in only 5,000 credit card charges in euros since Jan. 1, a tiny number. Tourists report that traveler's checks in dollars are far easier to cash in Europe than checks in euros. And central banks continue to keep most of their foreign reserves in dollars, hardly changing the mix since the euro's arrival.
The resistance runs deeper. Even though they are all denominated in euros, European government securities are still issued by the 11 different member countries, with each nation's paper bearing its own separate risk and credit rating, just as municipal bonds issued by different American cities do. As a group, euro securities may represent as huge a market as American Treasuries and corporate bonds, but they do not constitute as unified a market.
"As European financial markets grow and develop, and demonstrate their stability and unity, the euro will gradually rival the dollar, but over a period of decades," said Barry Eichengreen, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley.
The euro arrived just as the American economy completed three years of robust economic growth and Western Europe found itself in a slowdown -- bad timing. "People have been saying for the longest time, 'Shouldn't we worry about the euro?' " Mr. Eichengreen said. "And we should, if the European economy becomes the engine for the world and we stop being the engine." Or if the United States plunges into confidence-robbing troubles like those that characterized the 1980's: inflation, rising deficits, a real estate bubble that burst, a savings and loan crisis.
Then the alternatives were the mark and the yen, neither with the euro's potential for luring worried investors in the event of another dismal spell for the American economy. The 21st century would not then be an American century, but rather a century shared by the United States and Europe.
