HEADLINE: In America;
Bill Bradley's Challenge

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
I looked around to see who might be yawning or nodding off. Bill Bradley had been speaking for more than half an hour and there had been no jokes, no glorious turns of phrase, no splendidly worded calls to action. In fact, the former Senator who is now running for the Democratic nomination for President had a tendency to botch this line or that, and then go back and dutifully say it correctly.
Martin Luther King he's not. 
 But the young men and women in the Wollman Lounge at Cooper Union were paying close attention, and their body language was interesting. Mr. Bradley was talking about race relations, a topic that is talked about incessantly but still makes most people uncomfortable. Yet as he spoke last Tuesday afternoon the people in the audience were focused intently on his every utterance, with some of them leaning forward in their seats, as if straining to hear at least one clear and intelligent voice in the midst of a maddening din.
Mr. Bradley's approach to race relations is an almost irresistible target for cynics. He did not tell his audience that Americans can do better, but rather that we can be better.
He said the road that lies ahead "for those of us who want better racial understanding" stretches far beyond the struggles of the civil rights movement, or the continuing fight over affirmative action and equal treatment in the workplace.
"Our task is more difficult," he said, "and more subtle -- but if we're successful, more long-lasting. It is to vanquish racial discord from our hearts and spirit."
As you watch Mr. Bradley earnestly delivering his speech you come to realize he actually believes this is possible. Maybe he knows something. Maybe it's not so strange for someone who has been a champion athlete and a United States Senator (and who thinks he can be President) to aim incredibly high.
"I care about getting beyond the stupidity of racial division to a time when we can accept each other for who we are," he said. For whatever reasons, probably the quiet sincerity of Mr. Bradley's delivery and the trusting and attentive attitude of his young audience, the words did not sound platitudinous.
The fact that it would take an almost unimaginable effort to hoist ourselves to the level of social and moral excellence envisioned by Mr. Bradley did not seem to concern him. "For something so palpably right to be so demonstrably hard to accomplish only strengthens my determination," he said.
Mr. Bradley's speech would have gotten more media attention if it had not been delivered on the same day that the massacre occurred at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo. But the speech was not a one-time thing. Mr. Bradley has made his commitment to "a deeper racial unity" a cornerstone of his campaign and insists it will be a major focus of his administration if he is elected President.
"When Ronald Reagan was President, everyone knew that if you wanted to please the boss you talked about cutting taxes, increasing military spending and fighting Communism," he said. "If I'm President, I want one thing to be known: If you want to please the boss, one of the things you'd better show is how your department or agency has furthered tolerance and racial understanding."
This is risky stuff. The economy and whatever is happening in Kosovo next year will be far higher on the list of most voters' concerns than a quest for deeper racial unity. I asked Mr. Bradley in an interview why he had decided to make race relations such an important part of his campaign.
"Because this is one of my most deeply held beliefs," he said. "And it's important, I think, when you run for President that you share the deepest part of yourself with the people so they understand who you are."
We'll find out soon enough whether a heartfelt commitment to racial unity is a plus or a minus in a national campaign. Meanwhile, it's refreshing to have a Presidential candidate engage the subject in a sustained and unequivocal way.
Commentators have had a field day with politicians who believe in little or nothing and are shaped largely by the polls. Now comes Bill Bradley with, gasp, a whiff of the idealist about him. He thinks the public is ready for honest leadership on some of the weightier issues of our time.
Stay tuned.

LENGTH: 1095 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Why Governments Tumble;
India's Poorest Are Becoming Its Loudest

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
SINCE the Hindu nationalist-led Government collapsed a week ago, the noisy, gaudy spectacle of Indian democracy has played out here in the capital on familiar public stages: the steps of Parliament House, the courtyard of the President's residence and at the closed gates of the Gandhi family compound.
But the political turmoil that has seen five governments come tumbling down here in just six years is not merely the result of cantankerous rivalries among the country's political parties or the often venal, self-serving antics of its politicians. 
 Even more crucial are profound political changes taking place in hundreds of thousands of villages where most of the nation's 980 million people live and vote. Researchers have learned from election and survey data that in the 1990's the country's most oppressed people -- the low castes, the poor, the illiterate -- have been voting and joining political parties in growing proportions, as have women, who were long at the fringes of the nation's political life.
Many of these voters are flocking to the caste-based and regional parties that more directly reflect their own identities and interests and that now hold the power to make and to break governments.
The India that for most of its history was dominated by the dynastic reign of the Nehru-Gandhi family in the Congress Party has given way to a cacophonous multiplicity of parties, some of them led by populist politicians who metaphorically poke a finger in the eye of the country's Brahmin elite at every opportunity.
Remarkably, the poorest Indians are now more likely to vote than the richest ones. This turns on its head what was true here only a quarter of a century ago, and what is still true of American and European democracies: namely, that the prosperous are more likely to vote than the disadvantaged.
"We've entered what political scientists call a decade of realignment," said Yogendra Yadav, who has researched these trends at the Center for the Study of Developing Societies here. "The stable alignments have broken down and a new era when these linkages are rewoven has begun. One of the consequences of this massive redefinition is instability at the top."
The center's study of survey and voting data found that the current decade has witnessed increased voter turnout, rising membership in political parties and a deepening faith in democracy itself among the people at the bottom of India's deeply inequitable social structure. The study is to be published soon by Oxford University Press as part of a book on Indian democracy produced in cooperation with the University of Pennsylvania's Institute for the Advanced Study of India.
As an example of the trends, the percentage of people from formerly untouchable castes who said they were members of political parties rose from 13 percent in 1971 to 19 percent in 1996, while the percentage from the upper castes who said they belonged to a party declined from 36 percent to 28 percent.
The percentage of very poor people who believe voting makes a difference rose from 38 percent in 1971 to 51 percent in 1996, and jumped from 42 percent to 60 percent for low caste people.
At first, their belief in the power of the ballot seems puzzling. State and national governments have often failed to deliver to the poor the most basic services -- education, health care and clean drinking water among them -- as well as a more rapidly growing economy that could help more people escape poverty.
But in a country where government still plays a central role in the economy and dispensing public goods, politics has given the lower castes the power to claim a share of patronage -- everything from schools to housing to wells to jobs in government.
"People want to come to power to make money," said Jairam Ramesh, an economic policy advisor in the Congress Party. "The goodies are in power."
SCHOLARS say politics has also provided a route to something less tangible but perhaps even more potent politically: pride, dignity and the confidence to fight back against the kinds of indignities the low castes have suffered for millennia -- of being contemptuously called by their caste names, of being forbidden to draw water from the same wells as the upper castes, of being denied the right to ride a horse in a wedding procession like an upper caste groom.
No place better exemplifies both the failings of government and the democratic ferment transforming Indian politics than Uttar Pradesh, India's most populous and most politically powerful state and one of its most impoverished, dysfunctional ones.
For the first four decades after Indian independence in 1947, politics in Uttar Pradesh was dominated by upper castes in the Congress Party, but Congress has been out of power there throughout the 1990's. "The Congress Party never saw fit to have a Dalit chief minister in Uttar Pradesh, though Dalits have the single largest proportion of voters," Mr. Ramesh, the Congress economic advisor, said ruefully, referring to people from castes formerly regarded as untouchable.
In the 1990's, two non-Brahmin, non-upper-caste parties have won growing clout in Uttar Pradesh, and both have played important roles in the latest bout of political turmoil in the capital.
Mayawati, a Dalit woman and a leader of the Bahujan Samaj Party, which is built on the votes of Dalits, pulled the rug out from under the ruling coalition led by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, which has been predominantly run by upper castes.
Mayawati, who like many lower caste women goes by one name, became a symbol of hope to Dalits in two brief terms as Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh in the late 1990's. She lulled the Hindu nationalist leaders into believing her 5 members of Parliament would remain neutral in the confidence vote on April 17. But in the end, her party's legislators all voted against a Government led by people they believed had betrayed them in Uttar Pradesh politics. The national coalition Government lost power by a single vote.
And last Friday, the Samajwadi Party, whose voting base is with Muslims and Yadavs, the middling cow herd's caste, foiled the Congress Party's efforts to form a minority government with the support of smaller parties. The Samajwadi Party leader, Mulayam Singh Yadav, said his 20 members of Parliament would not support any new government unless they were part of it.
Neither Mayawati nor Mr. Yadav is willing to accept crumbs from the tables of the two major national parties. They want to be at the table themselves.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1540 words

HEADLINE: The World;
It's a Wonder This Alliance Is Unified

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
FOR most of the half-century it is celebrating in Washington this weekend, NATO's very existence has been rooted in the idea of a grand design -- to guarantee the safety of the West against the East, to forge a common defense of democracy against tyranny, to prepare, in effect, for World War III.
But now, as NATO's forces press their first true combat mission in a messy conflict in Kosovo, the allies and their neighbors are discovering that war is not just about the grand design of thwarting tyranny, but about niggling details and political line calls. 
 Kosovo is more than just America's war or even NATO's war. It is an ominous prism refracting the national interests of the allies (and their neighbors) from the most sweeping political considerations to the most mundane. For each of the nations involved, the conflict has shades of meaning and ambiguity, revealing the alliance on its 50th anniversary as an assembly of agendas in uneasy cohesion -- and raising the question of whether it can survive an escalation into a ground war.
Consider, for instance, matters as basic as river traffic on the Danube halted by NATO's bombing of bridges, or faltering tourism in Greece and Croatia -- consequences of war that show that the conflict's price will be paid in many coinages, from Budapest to Athens.
Contrast those economic consequences with much bigger, almost metaphysical themes: Germany's fraught dilemma between avoiding embroilment in war while joining in the common campaign against horrors all too familiar from its own past. There is also the perennial fear in Europe -- in Italy, Germany and France in particular -- of being overwhelmed by unwelcome refugees whose presence, political leaders fear, would feed domestic tensions and right-wing extremism.
And consider the dynamics of those lands -- Italy and Greece -- that provide the ports and airfields for a war their people and political elite do not universally approve. Then there is raw, geopolitical ambition -- British in particular, but French, too -- to show military leadership in a continent more used to Uncle Sam's coattails, and to promote the idea of European cohesion, absent for much of this decade's Balkan agony.
"Given the potential for division, the unity has been quite amazing," said Gordon Adams, Deputy Director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.
To say that NATO's members come to the table with varied baggage -- both from their histories and from more modern times -- is an understatement. And it is difficult to categorize their concerns without oversimplification: Like overlays on a presentation board, they overlap, cross-reference and sometimes contradict one another.
In purely economic terms, the damage is felt not just by the allies but by their non-alliance neighbors. At one point last week, over 100,000 tons of waterborne freight intended for Austria, Germany and Hungary were marooned on the Danube in Romania. An Austrian shipping company said it was losing $77,000 a day because of NATO bombing of Danube bridges.
Tourists in droves have canceled vacations on Croatia's Adriatic cost -- much too close to the bombing for beach-lounging comfort. Even in Greece, a tour operator said thousands of Americans had postponed visits in case the Kosovo conflict spills southward. And a ground war -- not to mention the likelihood of a massive postwar reconstruction bill -- would strain budgets across Europe. Even now, simply to keep one British Tornado warplane airborne for an hour costs Britain's taxpayers $33,000. A single payload of bombs costs $640,000, according to defense analysts.
But economic woes may turn out to be far less intractable than some of the political conundrums thrown up by the alliance's embroilment in Kosovo.
It makes for a patchwork of uneasy bedfellows. For example, Spain and Turkey, different in so many other ways, are both NATO members committed to supporting the alliance's aims in Kosovo. But both are also locked in their own conflicts against separatists -- respectively, Basques and Kurds -- who are demanding pretty much the same things sought by the Kosovars whom the two nations purport to defend in the Balkans.
"The totalitarian exclusiveness of nationalism engenders genocide and ethnic cleansing," warned Jose Maria Aznar, Spain's Prime Minister. So why wage war in league with Kosovar separatists?
SPAIN, of course, doesn't have a strategic interest in the Balkans, but Turkey does. Its Ottoman forebears drew the very fault lines of faith and ethnic division that have baffled Western policy makers in the Balkans through two world wars and now for most of the 1990's. And that legacy draws an arc of solidarity embracing Muslim communities from Thrace in Greece to Albania and Bosnia that, some fear, could pull Ankara toward a wider conflict.
No one is more sensitive to that configuration of faith than the Greeks, whose mirror-image sense of kinship with the Orthodox Christian Serbs places the Government of Prime Minister Costas Simitis in a curious position, caught between the powerful pro-Serb impulses of his compatriots and the broader pro-Western interests reflected in Athens' enthusiastic drive to join the European single currency. Orthodox Christianity, indeed, provides a critical link of religious identities, stretching from Athens to Belgrade and on to Moscow.
Urged on by the Greek Orthodox Church, Greeks have demonstrated against NATO's Kosovo campaign, even as the Greek port of Thessaloniki is being used to resupply the 12,000 NATO troops in neighboring Macedonia. At the same time, Mr. Simitis' popularity has risen sharply in opinion surveys, underlining the keen desire of many Greeks to see the war contained as far as possible from their borders, avoiding a broader conflict with Turkey.
Yet here, too, is another overlay, this time from the cold war: If anyone within NATO supports Yugoslavia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, it is Europe's Communists and ex-Communists, who are usually depicted as discredited and spent. The small Greek Communist party -- in tacit alliance with the Orthodox Church -- has helped stage anti-Western demonstrations in Athens. Elsewhere, ex-Communist leaders from eastern Germany and Italy have rushed to Belgrade. Significantly, German opinion surveys show support for the war running at 59 percent in western Germany, but only 38 percent in the former Communist east.
Perhaps surprisingly, this catalog of diversity has not dented the high degree of support across Europe for the Kosovo campaign. Almost universally, Europeans have been horrified -- even ashamed -- by images of refugees streaming out of Kosovo and into a collective memory of the even more massive upheavals of the Second World War.
Strikingly, even those former central European lands that have only just joined the alliance have not broken ranks: Hungary hasn't, and it is on the very front line, with 300,000 Hungarian brethren forming a minority in Yugoslavia's Vojvodina region, and potentially vulnerable to Serbian reprisal.
BUT, more cynically, it is the refugees that propel policies that, in the words of Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, are about moral imperatives and a "just war."
No European power wants a huge influx of outsiders straining the social fabric and state coffers at a time of widespread unemployment.
Italy thus was among the first to send 2,000 troops to Albania to help in humanitarian relief. As on many occasions in recent years, Rome's policy was driven by a calculation that it is preferable to deal with refugees' distress at long range rather than at home.
Greece is already home to 400,000 Albanian immigrants, and the authorities in Athens fear that a flood of Kosovo Albanian refugees could unsettle their land.
Only belatedly last week did France, with its uneasy immigrant population, reverse its refusal to accept even small numbers of refugees. And, after providing sanctuary for some 300,000 Bosnians, many Germans feel they have done enough. Such thinking underpins European calls for a postwar reconstruction strategy on the scale of the Marshall Plan to stabilize the Balkans into the 21st century.
"The priority should be to look after people in the region where they have sought refuge and with which they are linked by language and culture," said Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany. "Any other policy would make us de facto accomplices of Belgrade's policy of deportation."
It is in Germany, of course, that the Kosovo campaign conjures the sharpest dilemma of all, testing many of the nation's postwar assumptions and straining the unity of its coalition Government.
The idea of German troops going to war -- in the Balkans of all places -- deeply offends many Germans nurtured on postwar pacifism. But the notion that, as a NATO member and European leader, modern Germany should stand by is equally repellent, particularly to those who have learned in school that they bear a special responsibility to guard against a revival of the atrocities that mark their nation's past.
"Given our German history," Mr. Schroder said, "we cannot leave any doubt about our reliability, determination and steadfastness."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "One NATO, Many Fish to Fry"
America's 18 alliance partners view the Kosovo war from sharply different perspectives. Some highlights:
 
Belgium -- More inclined to back the air war than ground combat. The war could become an issue in national elections June 13.
 
Britain -- Having shunned the euro, it sees its principal area of European influence in its military readiness and close ties to the United States. Prime Minister Tony Blair calls the Kosovo war a war for justice.
 
Canada -- Grudgingly accepts its role in the air war, but laments loss of the peacekeeping mantle worn proudly by the country for the past 50 years.
 
Czech Republic -- Despite support from President Vaclav Havel for the air war, public backing is muted in this new NATO nation. The Czech armaments industry is suspected of selling to both Serbs and Kosovars.
 
Denmark -- Conservatives see the Kosovo war as a reason to scale back Social Democratic defense cuts.
 
France -- By joining the air war, it has swallowed its aversion to American command of NATO. But it still seeks a more independent European defense profile. Fears a refugee flood.
 
Germany -- Haunted by World War II, it balances aversion to war against revulsion over genocide. The formerly Communist east is less enthusiastic about the bombing than the west. Germans fear a refugee influx that could inflame the right wing.
 
Greece -- Torn between loyalty to NATO and loyalty to the Serbs, who like the Greeks are primarily Orthodox Christian. Domestic anti-NATO sentiment is running high. Tourism is being hurt. Some of Greece's road routes through the Balkans have been cut. Still, Athens seeks to join the single European currency, and sees its long-term interests best served by alliance with the west. Thessaloniki is being used to resupply NATO in Macedonia.
 
Hungary -- Like Poland and the Czech Republic, it became a NATO member just before war began. Trade has been hurt by blockage of the Danube River thanks to bombing. Concerned about the 300,000 ethnic Hungarians in Vojvodina. NATO uses Taszar air base.
 
Iceland -- Has no army, but the Government supports the NATO campaign.
 
Italy -- Fears a refugee flood. Numerous air bases are being used for NATO raids. The moderate ex-Communist Prime Minister, Massimo D'Alema, relies on Communist hard-liners to stay in power, and balances his Western European aspirations against the desire for a negotiated peace with the ex-Communist Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic.
 
Luxembourg -- This financial center worries that a prolonged conflict could further weaken the euro.
 
Netherlands -- Public generally supports the war effort. The 1995 massacre by Serbs at Srebrenica, as Dutch peacekeepers stood by, weighs heavily on the Dutch conscience.
 
Norway -- Thought likely to support United Nations intervention if the NATO campaign fails.
 
Poland -- Its main concern is anything that alienates neighboring Russia from the West -- like the Kosovo war. But public opinion is behind the air war.
 
Portugal -- Supports the NATO campaign, but not wholeheartedly: Many Portuguese recall costly colonial wars in Africa that ended in the 1970's.
 
Spain -- With his Basque problem in mind, Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar says Kosovo highlights the perils of separatism.
 
Turkey -- Largely Muslim, Turks are sympathetic to the primarily Muslim Kosovars. Turkey has longstanding tensions with Greece, its rival within NATO. A paradox: Turkey's own harsh campaign against separatist Kurds.

HEADLINE: The World: NATO's War Aims;
The Test: Getting the Refugees Home

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
YET another specter is haunting Europe, and not just Europe this time: the specter of the permanent refugee.
With hundreds of thousands of Albanians uprooted in Kosovo and spilling across the borders of Albania, Macedonia and Montenegro, some diplomats see the crisis as a defining moment in how the world thinks about the temporarily and permanently displaced. 
 NATO has declared as a fundamental war aim that the Kosovo refugees will get the chance to go back home when the fighting stops. But that isn't the way most wars have ended in this century. Look around the world, and the refugees who call themselves Palestinians, or Cambodians, or Bosnians have by and large not achieved that dream. In fact, millions of people around the world have become permanent refugees or, at best, have found new lives in a new diaspora.
So if NATO can accomplish its war aim, and reverse a campaign of ethnic cleansing, it would be achieving something quite new.
But it certainly will not be easy. Pushing out the Serb forces who expelled the refugees may well require a NATO invasion. Even if NATO goes that far, how many Albanians will be eager to return to a land where their homes have been burned, their husbands and brothers herded off to unknown fates, their former lives shattered?
Richard Betts, a political science professor at Columbia University, warns that in vowing that the refugees will return, NATO "may be making a promise we can't keep, or are unprepared to keep." On the other hand, Arthur C. Helton, who teaches refugee law at the New York University School of Law, worries that if return remains the measure of victory or defeat in the conflict, refugees may be forced or pressured into returning against their wishes.
So, in the end, is it possible that the war will end somewhat short of the goal, with a deal that implicitly acknowledges that the refugees will not be able to return safely?
That is already emerging as a fear among refugee advocates and Albanian-American groups. Some of these people fear that NATO betrayed a crack in its determination last week when the United States decided to permit some 20,000 Kosovar refugees being brought here for safety to be eligible, after a year, to become permanent residents.
Did this not suggest, some complained, that the refugees might not be returning to Kosovo once the fighting ends? Would that not be a a victory for ethnic cleansing and its architect, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia?
Since NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia began a month ago, the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that almost 600,000 of Kosovo's 1.6 million ethnic Albanians have left their homes and crossed into neighboring lands. Ominously, NATO said last week, Yugoslav forces were herding together another 850,000 Albanians inside Kosovo, possibly preparing to expel them, or worse.
The element in this equation that may make this refugee crisis different from others is that the Albanian Kosovars are more than mere byproducts of war. They were the declared reason that NATO went to war. One analyst calls them the "glue" of NATO solidarity.
And for NATO's European members, the motives are not simply altruistic. Even if the refugees don't flood into Western Europe itself, NATO officials fear that their continued presence may upset the delicate ethnic balance of Yugoslavia's neighbors, increasing instability.
L OOKING beyond Kosovo, diplomats and relief groups agree that finding a solution for refugee crises has become one of the world's greatest challenges. At the century's end, some 22 million people have been displaced by wars and civil conflicts. Some 2.6 million Afghan refugees languish in Pakistan, Iran, and camps in other countries, according to the United Nations Children's Fund. The total number of African refugees, displaced persons, and still vulnerable returnees now exceeds 7 million. At least 3.2 million Palestinians are still classified as refugees.
"The thinking about these people has evolved over the past decade," said David M. Malone, the president of the International Peace Academy, an independent group that studies the United Nations. "Before they were considered unfortunate victims of war whose plight had to be addressed. Over time they have become a major factor in peace and security. They are increasingly seen as a source of instability."
Slowly the world is acknowledging that many of these people will never go home. Still, "permanent refugees" pose daunting challenges not only to relief groups but to the states that might accommodate them. "We hate that term; we never use it," said Karen Koning AbuZayd, the refugee commissioner's Washington representative. "The term refugee implies a durable solution -- going home, being locally integrated, or being resettled."
Her agency's insistence on repatriation has sometimes been criticized when people are encouraged to return to politically and economically fragile countries. But Ms. AbuZayd says that it is what most refugees want. In this respect, she said, her agency can be proud. The numbers of people it cares for had dropped in recent years from 27 million to 22.5 million, half of them refugees. The agency has been closing down offices in Central America and Asia. About 1.7 million Mozambican refugees have gone home.
Some countries, in addition to contributing to United Nations relief efforts, have been extraordinarily generous in taking people in. Iran, she notes, is the world's biggest refugee host. In the Balkans, the biggest host has been Serbia, which has had to accommodate Serbs driven out of Croatia and parts of Bosnia.
But taking in refugees is not what NATO has been talking about. Getting them home is. And the Bosnian experience may be instructive.
The Dayton accords that ended the Bosnian war in 1995 specified that refugees could return home, but achieving safety for them in their old neighborhoods was another matter. By mid 1997, Mr. Helton says, about 300,000 refugees and displaced people had returned home, but very few of these went to areas where they would be in an ethnic minority. Meanwhile, 900,000 remained internally displaced and another 900,000 live abroad.
Mr. Malone thinks that if Kosovo is cleared of Serbian pressure, the refugees will return. "So it's important for NATO to decide soon what kind of Kosovo it wants and can achieve," he said. "An independent state? An international protectorate? A combination of the two?"
In any event, diplomats and relief workers have begun to wonder what precedents are being set in Kosovo. Some think the crisis is only receiving great attention because these refugees are Europeans, and few lessons will be learned.
Leonard Rubenstein, executive director of Physicians for Human Rights, a private group, has another fear: "If intervention to save peoples' lives fails this time and people are not protected or permitted to return, the impetus to try again next time may simply not be there."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
82% of School Budgets Are Approved by Voters

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
Voters approved more than 82 percent of the school budgets in the annual school board elections last week, the highest rate since 1986. Board members and budgets were considered in 551 districts, and 456 approved their budgets, according to the New Jersey Schools Boards Association. Last year, 75 percent of budgets passed.
As in the mid-1980's, a healthy economy and low unemployment probably account for the high approval rate, said Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the association. 
 In addition to voting on the base school budget, voters must approve any spending that exceeds 3 percent over last year's. There were 176 of these so-called second-budget questions, and 66 percent were approved, compared with nearly 59 percent last year. Budgets and second-budget questions that are defeated are then decided by the municipal governing bodies. In about 100 districts, local officials vote on the school budget.
Turnout remained typically low at 13 percent of registered voters, compared with 14 percent last year. KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
For Island's Economy, A Solid Forecast

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
The Long Island economy will remain strong through 1999 but cool ever so slightly in the year 2000, a regional economist, Thomas Conoscenti, told the Long Island Regional Planning Board this month.
Mr. Conoscenti said the regional economy's current growth rate of 2.6 percent would slow to 2.5 percent next year, but still remain far above the 1.5 percent average growth rate of the past 30 years. 
 Factors in the vibrant regional economy, he said, included low interest rates, a strong national and New York City economy, high consumer confidence on Long Island and a record bull market on Wall Street.
In addition, Mr. Conoscenti said, a relatively stable inflation rate "has resulted in people being able to put money aside for large durable goods purchases and to accumulate cash to buy houses or other big-ticket items."
Mr. Conoscenti said Long Island had also completed a transition to a market-driven economy and no longer depended on military industries that were the foundation of Long Island prosperity during the expansive early and middle 1980's, when real-estate prices also soared.
But he counseled against elimination of county sales taxes on clothing items because of revenue shortfalls of $32 million in Suffolk and $71 million in Nassau that would result.
The planning board voted to recommend to both counties to continue collecting the full local share of 4.25 percent.
Lee E. Koppelman, the board's executive director, said board members were "very optimistic for 1999."
"The only concern we really have is whether we will have an adequate labor force for high-technology sectors," Dr. Koppelman said. "The recession we went through several years ago when Grumman closed up shop is over and we have made a complete recovery. These are good times and we expect they will continue through 1999, and there's no reason they won't continue after that.
"We see nothing on the horizon that would be negative unless the stock market collapses. And I don't think that will happen." JOHN RATHER

HEADLINE: Ex-Strongman's Next Move Intrigues Dominicans

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 21

 BODY:
In a dusty neighborhood of wooden barracks here that house 1,600 families left homeless in a hurricane last year, Yudelki C. Savinon said she appreciated President Leonel Fernandez's efforts to help the victims, including starting construction on permanent housing nearby.
But even in her gratitude, she longs for another leader whom she regards almost as a father, one who is 92, blind and ailing. His name and face have been plastered all over this capital in posters and murals that proclaim, "Balaguer -- one more time, out of necessity." 
 "He can do anything, as long as he wants it," Ms. Savinon, 65, said of Joaquin Balaguer, the strongman who ruled here for 22 years and for whom she would vote again.
Mr. Balaguer was forced to step down in 1996 by a constitutional amendment that bars a second consecutive term for a president. But because the measure also prevents Mr. Fernandez from running again, Mr. Balaguer looms as a potential candidate for the elections in May 2000.
The turn of events reassures some and haunts others among the nearly eight million Dominicans. But it hardly surprises anyone.
"Dr. Balaguer loves power more than life itself," said Milagros Ortiz Bosch, a niece of former President Juan Bosch, and one of the people who are vying for the nomination of the Dominican Revolutionary Party, one of three major parties. "He wants a quota of power."
The possibility of Mr. Balaguer's candidacy, political analysts said, underscores how the nation that elected Mr. Fernandez in 1996, expecting sweeping changes, is still in transition from an authoritarian tradition to modern democracy.
The analysts said Mr. Fernandez's administration had had mixed results. He has presided over high economic growth and made the Dominican Republic an active player in Caribbean affairs after decades of isolation. Under his leadership, the nation restored diplomatic ties with Cuba, began high-level contacts with Haiti and was host to several top-level international meetings, with another planned for this year.
"He's admired as a young President with a relatively novel platform, with an understanding of the need to modernize institutions and with a very accessible personality," Jose Oviedo, a sociologist at Catholic University here, said.
But Mr. Fernandez, 45, a lawyer who grew up in New York, is also criticized for not having done enough about corruption and patronage, or about poverty, a fundamental problem for 60 percent of the population.
A hurricane that killed more than 200 Dominicans in September and exposed serious flaws in warning and emergency systems "showed how inadequate the state still is in the fulfillment of its obligations," said Anibal de Castro, publisher of Rumbo, a newsmagazine.
Mr. Fernandez, who inherited the problems from Mr. Balaguer, was forced into an alliance with Mr. Balaguer and his Social Christian Reformist Party to win in 1996. That, analysts and American diplomats said, has tied Mr. Fernandez's hands in making certain changes.
He has also joined the Reformists in decidedly undemocratic maneuvers to wrest control from the Revolutionary Party, which dominated congressional and municipal elections in May and now has a majority of legislative seats and mayoralties.
In one highly publicized incident in January, the police surrounded the headquarters of the Dominican Municipal League, through which the central Government channels money to municipalities. The police moved to prevent elections for league leadership during a fight for control of the institution among the three major parties. Mr. Fernandez eventually called for a dialogue among the parties, and the dispute is now in court.
"This is a country that is stumbling toward a new way of government," an American diplomat here said. "It's not pretty. But it's not particularly violent or repressive."
The parties have scheduled their nominating conventions for this year. Advertising is flooding the news media and the streets for the "precandidates."
Mr. Balaguer himself has not spoken on whether he wants to be a candidate. But political veterans say the Reformists do nothing without his consent. One called the party "his personal property."
Experts say Mr. Balaguer's chances of returning to the presidency are remote because his party has less than 10 percent backing in polls, trailing the Revolutionary Party, with 35, and Mr. Fernandez's Dominican Liberation Party, with 27.
Because no party has a majority, the Reformist push to nominate Mr. Balaguer is a way to maximize its political influence as a swing force. That makes him more likely to be a kingmaker than a serious candidate.
But Mr. Balaguer's readiness to enter the fray hinges on his health, which was set back this year. He was flown to Houston to treat circulatory problems and the flu. He returned walking better and looking more alert, many said, and apparently ready to seek a seventh presidency.
"He is extraordinarily lucid," Donald Reid Cabral, 76, acting president of Mr. Balaguer's party, said. "One is surprised at how many things he does during a day. He writes. He answers letters. He sees 10 to 15 people a day."
Mr. Balaguer, who remains a prolific writer and released his latest book, on ancient Greece, this week, declined an interview request through Mr. Reid Cabral. The former President said he was booked up.
In a television broadcast on Monday about the book, "Eternal Greece," he looked frail and shrunken, sitting in a high-back chair, as he listened with semiclosed eyes to speeches in his praise.
"I've tried in a simple language within the reach of all human intelligence to make available to Dominican youths a fundamental aspect of the universal culture, that of eternal Greece," Mr. Balaguer said in a raspy whisper.
Many Dominicans smile and roll their eyes when Mr. Balaguer is mentioned, saying that nothing about the long-serving former President surprises them. But some stressed that even when the country seems to take a step backward, it is going inevitably forward toward democracy, as shown by the two elections since Mr. Balaguer ruled politics.
"The country is marching slowly but profoundly toward solidifying its democracy," said Mr. de Castro, the publisher. "In the next years, we'll see a strengthening of institutions, an understanding of how the separation of powers works, and we'll have more accountable governments, no matter who wins."

HEADLINE: Selling Sudan's Slaves Into Freedom

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

DATELINE: YARGUT, Sudan

 BODY:
Over the last few years, evidence has slowly solidified that slavery not only exists, but may be widespread in parts of Sudan. On a recent day in this tiny, scorching village, there seemed little to dispute that. Seated under trees, on dirt baked so hard that a child's foot barely made a mark, were several hundred women and children. They told stories of abduction and rape, of tending goats and wringing dirty clothes for their captors.
But there has been growing international scrutiny over the kind of transaction that followed. 
 "That's one million," John Eibner, a quietly intense American, said as he reached into a bag fat with Sudanese money. "That's two million."
He was counting out cash to pay a trader for 535 of the slaves, Dinka people from the south taken captive by Arabs from the north. The cost: 26.8 million Sudanese pounds, about $27,000, or $50 a person, the price of two goats. In a week, Mr. Eibner, an official with a Swiss group called Christian Solidarity International, bought freedom for 1,783 slaves -- by far the greatest number since he started coming to Sudan in 1995.
As the number of redeemed slaves and groups trekking to the war zone of southern Sudan to free them has risen, the practice is coming under fire. Critics say that redemption, which began locally in the early 1990's, is becoming big business, and that people like Mr. Eibner may even be inadvertently encouraging slave raids. "Once the numbers started to increase drastically, that caused people who follow the slavery issue to have a look at what is really going on," said Jemera Rone, counsel for Human Rights Watch in Washington.
Ms. Rone recently wrote a paper accusing the Sudanese Government of using slave raids as a weapon in its 15-year war with southern rebels and warning of the dangers of redemption. She worries that unscrupulous middlemen -- traders who bring the slaves back south -- may increase profits by packing groups of slaves with "borrowed" children, and that peace in Sudan may be discouraged if raiders have a financial incentive to keep the war going.
Last month, the United Nations Children Fund also raised some questions, partly in response to the American schoolchildren, in Massachusetts, Colorado and Oregon, who raise money for the cause.
"We want to try to deal with ending slavery as a fundamental change within Sudan, rather than having to watch human beings being bought and sold," said Stephen Lewis, Unicef's deputy executive director.
He said Unicef officials were working with Sudan -- which denies slavery exists but concedes "tribal" hostage-taking -- to allow a study of slavery and a mechanism for freeing captives. "We have to get rid of the practice, period," he said. "We need a political solution."
Unicef's position has in turn been criticized by, among others, a former New York Mayor, Edward I. Koch, who has written a column about the subject calling its stance "inconceivable." Others note that the Sudanese Government has been far from cooperative on the slavery issue.
Lady Caroline Cox, who runs a British group that redeems slaves, acknowledged that redemptions were "a gray area" but said they were unavoidable. "As far as redemption is concerned," she said, "we justify it by saying: it's not the answer but I don't think you can look a child in the face and say, 'I'm sorry, you have to remain a slave until there is a political solution.' "
Mr. Eibner, whose group claims to have freed 7,725 slaves since 1995, also sees redemptions as imperfect but necessary.
"Knowing that tens of thousands of people are still enslaved and knowing that we can get them out," he said, "I couldn't live with myself and say, 'Sorry, I'm stopping because of some criticism from an ivory tower in London or New York.' " Mr. Eibner, 46, is a native of Valhalla, N.Y., who lives in Geneva.
He was standing in a scrubby field between two groups of women and children who said, in random interviews, that they had been escorted back south after spending as long as five years in the north.
Local officials and other experts say slavery has long existed to some extent in Sudan, often involving Muslim masters and slaves who are Christians or animists. But, they say, the raids picked up in the late 1980's along with fighting between north and south. According to a recent United Nations report, an Arab militia known as the muruhaleen and the People's Defense Force, both aligned with the Government, guard a train that runs from the capital of Khartoum in the north to Wau, a Government garrison in the south.
Within 30 miles of either side of the track, these forces raid Dinka villages, mostly to steal cattle. But they also take hundreds of human captives -- or more -- to carry booty and to be used, the United Nations report alleges, for "cooking, cultivation, tending to animals, collecting firewood, washing clothes and other domestic chores."
The report, by the United Nations special envoy to Sudan, also alleges "rape, forced 'marriage' and other sexual abuse amounting, in some cases, to sexual slavery."
The stories of the women and children, in three groups interviewed over several days, were horrifying and consistent. Achol Tong Nyan, a Dinka woman about 27 years old, sat on the ground holding a baby whose bronze skin was many shades lighter than hers. The girl, she said, was the product of rape by her master, Ishmael.
"What can I say?" she asked. "I will treat her as my child."
She said she had been captured about a year earlier in the town of Warawar. Men on horses and in uniforms stormed the village.
She said 250 people were marched north. Ten died of thirst on the way. Another 20 were shot. One night, she said, she was raped by 10 men.
After spending time in a camp with other slaves in the town of Muglad, she said, she went to live with Ishmael. She slept in the kitchen, washed clothes, fetched water and was forced to have sex. Then, two weeks before she was redeemed, a trader visited. "I don't know what they paid Ishmael, but one day he called me in and introduced the trader," she said. "Ishmael said, 'He will take you back to your people.' "
Thik Anon Thik, a tall and thin boy of 11, said he too was taken in a raid about a year ago, kidnapped with his mother and five siblings from a village called Kuiel.
In the north he lived in a camp with other slaves and tended goats. He said he was often beaten. One night a guard helped him escape, bringing him to one of the half-dozen traders Mr. Eibner works with. Their business is to go to Arab homes and camps in the north and offer money for the slaves, even though they say they would be arrested if discovered.
One trader, who uses the name Ahmed Bashir, said he bought the slaves for $20 to $80 and averaged about $10 in profit per slave. He and the other traders who deal with Mr. Eibner claim that they only buy slaves that will be freed.
For Thik, freedom was not enough: He has not seen his family since he was captured.
"Now I am not happy," he said. "I'm alone and without my mother and father."
Critics argue that such stories are so numerous, and the slaves' movement so hard to conceal, that the Government must know about the trade, and may profit from it. Another suspicion is that southern officials, including the rebel groups, are getting a cut.
Father Renato Kizito, a Roman Catholic priest who travels to Sudan, said redemption "is extremely risky if it is not 100 percent truth. Khartoum will have an easy way of saying it was a trick."
Defenders of redemption say it has, at a minimum, raised awareness about slavery in Sudan. Baroness Cox notes that the price has not increased over the years. Mr. Eibner defends the program by saying he will not pay more than $50 a person. He says he will stop if redemption evolves into a "free market."
"Slavery long predated C.S.I.'s presence here," he said, referring to his organization. "There is no evidence that there is any more slavery since we started this.
"The fact is that slavery is not primarily economically motivated. The primary motive is political. The motive is the Government using these slave raids as a way to wage war on these people."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: ATHENS;
NATO Bombing Tears at Greek Loyalties, Reawakening Anti-Americanism

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

DATELINE: ATHENS, April 23

 BODY:
Anti-American demonstrations, like dinner, start late in Athens. But for some Greek teen-agers, too young to remember similar riots of the 1960's and 1970's, protesting against the United States is still novel.
Hours before protesters and riot policemen clashed in front of the American Embassy on Thursday night, two sisters, Eleni and Constantina Vafiadou, sat by a fountain in Constitution Square expectantly ready to register their anger over the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia. 
 "It's ludicrous to say the bombing is to help humanity," Eleni, 18, said over the rally's amplified Serbian music -- the soundtrack to "Underground," a popular Serbian film. "It's about the U.S. pursuing its own expansionist strategic interests."
Her 16-year-old sister explained the film's allegorical antiwar message her own way.
"It's like what Ashley told Scarlett," Constantina said, referring to characters in "Gone With the Wind." "After all the war and destruction, nobody remembers what they were fighting about in the first place."
Sympathy for the Serbs -- and a cultural affinity with the United States -- is deeply rooted in Greece. But the latter sentiment is being sharply tested. More than any other country in NATO, Greece has been struggling between loyalty to the Western alliance and outrage over the bombing nearby.
While Prime Minister Costas Simitis is attending the NATO anniversary summit meeting in Washington this weekend and has restated Greece's support, back home Greeks of every age and political conviction are voicing fierce opposition to what they view as an unjust war.
Some of the wrath stems from Greek ties to Serbia, a historic ally and key trading partner that shares the Orthodox Christian faith. Much of it is caused by anxiety over what a new war in the region could do to Greece's fragile economy and uneasy borders. But it is fueled by a revival of anti-American sentiment that, though dormant, has never really died.
Greece, which has been steering toward full integration with Europe, now finds itself pulled back into a tragic Balkan history, and into feelings that the United States played a pivotal role in Greek suffering. Greeks blame the United States for supporting the military dictatorship and for failing to prevent the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in 1974. The bombing has not only created new fears but has also resurrected old grievances.
"America, way on the other side of the world, keeps interfering in something that is not their business, and that will not affect them," Margaret Liaveris, 25, a civil servant, said. "I find it so annoying when Clinton says, 'Our children need a free Europe.' Most of their children never even come here."
Her views, among them a fear that the conflict could destabilize the region and reignite tension with Turkey, are widely shared. A recent poll published by Greece's largest daily newspaper, Ta Nea, indicated that more than 95 percent of Greeks oppose the bombing. Some 63.5 percent of those polled expressed a favorable view of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. And 94.4 percent said they had a negative view of President Clinton.
Greek newspapers and television have fanned public discontent, stressing the suffering of Serbian civilians over the plight of Albanian refugees from Kosovo. And that has alarmed the country's 500,000 Albanian immigrants, who mostly work illegally, and are viewed with suspicion by many Greeks.
"I ask myself, why is Greece supporting Serbia; aren't they in NATO?" a 52-year-old unemployed immigrant said, adding that he relied on the Albanian-language service of Voice of America.
Some Greek journalists agree that there is an imbalance. "Greek television shows the exact opposite of what Americans see," Stelios Koulogrou, a well-known television documentary filmmaker, explained. "On CNN you see 80 percent refugees and 20 percent Serbs. On our channels it is the reverse."
Coverage of American news, meanwhile, is newly shaded by the war.
To the newspaper Ethnos, a center-left daily, the mass killings at a high school in Colorado this week had a direct link to NATO bombings. "The violence that Pentagon hawks are using in their foreign policy has boomeranged on social life in the U.S.," a front-page headline said on Thursday. "The evidence is overwhelming: 10,000 assaults in American schools each year."
A Greek naval officer who was given a two-and-a-half-year sentence this week for refusing to serve on a destroyer set to join NATO forces in the Adriatic has become a hero of left- and right-wing groups, as well as many in the Greek Orthodox clergy. Archbishop Christodoulos Paraskevaidis has described the bombers as "pawns of Satan."
Greeks have not taken their anger out on their Government, which has given NATO access to two air bases and its land routes into Macedonia, and is seeking a cautious balance between loyalty to NATO and support for a cease-fire. Since the crisis broke out, Mr. Simitis's ratings have risen.
"There is a silent majority that feels that Greece has no choice but to be prudent, prudent, prudent," said Thanos Veremis, who runs a foreign policy research institute in Athens. "We are a small, weak country and people feel that poor Simitis has no choice for now." He added, "But that of course could change."
Relations between Turkey and Greece have been relatively free of strain since the bombing began on March 24, but many Greeks nevertheless worry that the war will reignite that conflict.
"Thrace," a 25-year-old engineering student replied when asked about his opposition to the war. He was referring to the small Muslim minority in Thrace, whose rights are yet another sore point between Greece and Turkey, which is largely Muslim.
"Turks could use Kosovo as a precedent," he said. "As an excuse to demand autonomy for Muslims in Thrace."
He, like many others, complained that NATO was applying a double standard on human rights in the Balkans. As Eleni Vafiadou put it: "Albanians had some rights in Kosovo, but the Kurds in Turkey don't have any. Why hasn't the United States bombed Istanbul?"
The anxiety over the war is free-floating. The Greek stock market has fallen, some tourism agencies are reporting cancellations and Greek investment in Serbia, worth more than $1 billion, is at obvious risk.
Greek political leaders and voters speak passionately about the need to protect borders, fearing that any redrawing of the map of Kosovo could infect Macedonia or spawn Muslim aspirations of a "Greater Albania" including northern parts of Greece.
And there is growing talk of sinister American goals in the Balkans that have little to do with defending an oppressed minority.
"I think America is threatened by an independent Europe," said Leon B. Karapanayotis, editor in chief of Ta Nea, "and it is no accident that now the euro is falling against the dollar. The U.S. is asserting itself in Europe, and Europe is now considerably weaker. I suspect the U.S. has no reason to feel unhappy about this."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A Nation Turns Its Eyes to Center Field, One More Time

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
The most haunting question in all of sports -- "Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio?" -- should be answered today. Joe DiMaggio has gone to the monument valley beyond center field in Yankee Stadium. While his body is not buried there, his spirit will be consecrated in that hallowed ground.
What each of us makes of his spirit, that is. 
 Private to the point of paranoia, DiMaggio took charge of his final illness with the same steely reserve that informed his baseball career, his marriage to Marilyn Monroe, his afterlife as living legend. He was his own curator. He allowed us to believe that his genius, like Albert Einstein's, Greta Garbo's, Orson Welles's, had earned him the right to be left alone except when he wanted attention, to be excused whatever smudges might appear on the shiny image.
We scrabbled to justify his aloofness as dignity (but never shyness or contempt), to find grounds for forgiveness in his coffee-maker commercials, to place him in historical context. He had ridden into our consciousness just as the myths of the frontier West were receding, one of a posse of cowboys in the outfield who became our new manly heroes, lone individuals standing just outside the group, our last defense.
He was the son of an immigrant, but graceful and cool, so all the immigrants' sons who were writing about sports identified with him and, in the words of the old sports editor Stanley Woodward, "Godded him up." DiMaggio was a demanding employee, especially around contract time, but fans forgave him because he seemed like such a passionate performer.
But that still doesn't quite explain this: even though some of his replacements in that very same outfield -- Mickey Mantle, Reggie Jackson, yes, Darryl Strawberry -- were infinitely more interesting and entertaining as human beings, it is DiMaggio who will continue to be beatified.
Soon, a major New York City highway will be renamed for DiMaggio, a major mistake. He may not deserve such a civic immortality, but he certainly doesn't deserve to be cursed by thousands of motorists every day stuck on an outmoded, graceless road. He will end up remembered for traffic jams, overheated cars, noise and fumes.
But then he does owe New York. The other great outfielders of his era might have become crossover personalities had they played here in the days when all the national media were only a cab ride away. Stan Musial, a harmonica rascal of almost silly geniality, could have become Lawrence Welk as a Yankee. Ted Williams was the man whom John Wayne tried to play in movies. When you recall that another Marine fighter pilot, John Glenn, spoke of the joy and comfort of flying into combat with Ted Williams on his wing, it is hard to ever again take another outfielder more seriously. Ted Williams's spit was too good for the fans it hit.
So why DiMaggio? There could be clues in the retirements of Michael Jordan and Wayne Gretzky, two men of privacy, discretion and cool who quit while they were still pleasures to watch. But Jordan and Gretzky overwhelmed and ennobled their sports; they might as well have been superior beings from another planet.
DiMaggio was not in their league.
In the long run, he didn't embarrass us, perhaps because we never got into all the nooks and crannies of his life. He was just smart enough to know he wasn't smart enough to unspool sound bites and commentary. We saw just enough to be able to make up the rest of him. Always dressed for dinner at "21", he drifted through the rest of his life with the same outward economy he displayed as he drifted under fly balls. He knew just where they would drop.
This was a lonely man of the night, we could imagine, a Sinatra without the mean streak. His skin color helped him; when Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruth's career home-run record, DiMaggio's 56-game hitting streak suddenly became the most important record in baseball.
Strawberry was supposed to be the next DiMaggio. You could look it up. When the Mets brought him up in 1983, before his time, an unfinished 19-year-old, the front-office people actually compared him to the Clipper. What was done for Darryl and to him, what he could and couldn't do for himself, is another story, yet unfinished, too, but I must admit I have felt far more human interest for him than for DiMaggio.
Commentators have been beating up on Strawberry for letting us down. Poor Darryl, a wildly talented, madly destructive charmer, let only himself down. A case could be made for how poorly he was served by the Mets, and how even the Yankees needed to show more support. A recovering addict and recovering cancer patient who is a fading athlete unsure of his place on a team needs help and encouragement to come back from a slip.
Of course, this could never have happened to the Great DiMaggio. The Clipper was too tightly wrapped, the cops, gangsters and news media would have protected him, and he usually had a bobo at his side to hold his coat and bimbo, much less anything that could have been considered a controlled substance. Another haunting question is this: groomed to mature rather than just star, would Strawberry have become the next DiMaggio?
Last haunting question: where will you go, Darryl Strawberry?

HEADLINE: Whites' Bias Lawsuit Could Upset Desegregation Efforts

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 22

 BODY:
One could hardly blame Bill Capacchione for wanting his 6-year-old daughter Cristina to attend Olde Providence Elementary School.
The sparkling school set in Charlotte's fast-growing Southeast quadrant has 30 up-to-date Apple computers in its computer laboratory, a television studio where students produce and broadcast programs to all the school's classrooms and an involved parents' organization that raised $26,000 for supplies and student activities last year. 
 Olde Providence is a magnet school with an enriched academic program set up as part of a school desegregation plan ordered by a Federal judge in 1969. Some of the school's pupils are assigned there by lottery to maintain a student population that is 60 percent white and 40 percent black, reflecting the makeup of the district.
In 1996, Cristina, who is white, was denied admittance to Olde Providence because she was not selected in the lottery. Her father sued the school district, charging that his daughter had been denied admission because of her race. There are separate lotteries for blacks and whites.
The trial of the lawsuit by Mr. Capacchione, who was joined by six other white families, against the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education is under way in Federal District Court. The suit, which was broadened by the Reagan-appointed trial judge, Robert Potter, into a full legal assault on the district's integration plan, is being watched closely by civil rights advocates and conservative opponents of affirmative action and school desegregation plans that are based solely, or in part, on race.
The families are also seeking monetary damages because of the harm they say their children suffered.
The case has both historic and legal implications. In a 1971 decision, Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education, the Supreme Court allowed Federal courts for the first time to impose far-ranging actions -- including the busing of students -- to integrate schools.
The school district curtailed the use of busing several years ago and nearly all of the 12,000 students who are still bused are black. Still, the school board and lawyers for black students who have intervened in the case want to retain the desegregation plan to insure that African-American students have access to some of the better schools, which tend to be in white neighborhoods, as is Olde Providence.
"Charlotte, after an initial period of resistance, became known as the place that made" massive transportation for desegregation work, said James E. Ferguson 2d, a lawyer representing the black students in the case and in the original case that brought about the desegregation plan. "So I think the eyes of the nation are on this place."
The white plaintiffs say the fact that Charlotte is under a Federal court order to integrate its schools is no defense against their complaint of reverse discrimination. The desegregation order, they argue, is 30 years old. The judge who issued it and monitored compliance has long since died and the school board has not filed any reports recently on how well its school integration efforts are proceeding, or whether such efforts are still practical or needed.
Should the plaintiffs win, and should the court award them the monetary damages they seek for the alleged harm done to their children, then the dozens of school districts still under decades-old court desegregation orders could be vulnerable to lawsuits from white parents, lawyers on both sides say.
"If this case goes in our favor," said Lee Parks, the plaintiffs' main lawyer, "it's going to signal to a bunch of districts that they have to bring these desegregation plans to an immediate close or run the risk of paying damages to parents who are harmed. There is going to be a price to pay if you try to hide behind court orders."
The current lawsuit threatens to disrupt the tenuous racial harmony that has existed in an area where conflict has been submerged by a rising tide of prosperity. The case has been a heated topic in the local newspapers and on radio talk shows.
Some blacks say that the suit stems from the influx of white professionals from the North who have helped increase the number of Charlotte school pupils to 100,000 over the last 10 years, making it the nation's 23d largest district, up from 29th. Many of the newcomers, drawn to Charlotte's suburbs by the area's balmy weather, low taxes and booming economy, have no memory of racial segregation and see little justification for maintaining efforts at integration.
As she watched her son Matthew hustle around a dirt running track at Olde Providence Elementary, Naomi Ballard spoke of being a volunteer at the school office and answering questions from newcomers who were surprised they could not automatically send their children to the school.
"They had moved into the neighborhood because they heard it was a good school and now they were being told they might not be able to send their kids there," said Ms. Ballard, who is white. "They're confused. It's like a foreign system to them."
Blacks are particularly incensed over the idea that the white plaintiffs are seeking monetary damages for the emotional harm they contend their children suffered from not getting into particular schools. On the witness stand this week, Mr. Capacchione, who moved to California after the suit was filed, testified that his daughter "felt she wasn't smart enough to get into Olde Providence."
Some school officials scoff at the notion that the girl suffered any emotional damage, noting that as a result of her rejection at Olde Providence, Cristina ended up at a school that was rated academically as one of the top 10 elementary schools in the state.
"Tell me how they are harmed," said Arthur Griffin, the chairman of the Charlotte-Mecklenburg school board. "Tell me how you are harmed by going to a brand new school. Tell me how you are harmed with teachers that have higher credentials. Tell me how you've been harmed when you have access -- there's been no denial -- to quality education."
Mr. Parks, the plaintiffs' lawyer, agrees that the harm to Cristina and the other white plaintiffs may seem trivial compared with the suffering of blacks during segregation. But, the lawyer said, that should affect only the size of the award, not whether it should be granted.
"You might make that comparison and say, 'Cristina, get over it,' " he said. "But the board's policy still categorized people and told them where to go and where they can't go because of their race. You're talking about degrees of harm. When you get into constitutional law there aren't degrees of constitutionality."
Defenders of the desegregation plan say the lawsuit is part of a coordinated strategy to attack any state policies, like affirmative action plans, that confer advantages on blacks and other minorities. They note that Mr. Parks, the plaintiffs' lawyer, led the legal fight earlier this decade to overturn a Georgia redistricting plan that had created Congressional districts with large majorities of black voters.
Mr. Parks does not dispute that he is seeking to attack the use of race in a number of settings. But he argues that eliminating its use would merely put the country through some tough therapy that will not be as harmful to minorities as many fear. As evidence, he noted that those black representatives in Georgia like Cynthia A. McKinney and Sanford D. Bishop Jr., who saw the percentage of black voters in their districts plummet as a result of his suit, still won re-election.
