HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: SNAPSHOTS;
Night and Day, Day and Night Between Washington and the Balkans

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
NATO's anniversary pageant is playing on two stages, as political theater and in the theater of war, and its powerful rhetoric clashes with the forces of battle in Belgrade and the Balkans.
President Clinton was alone in his residence at 8:10 P.M. on Thursday, reviewing his summit speeches, work left undone in a hectic week. At that moment, the state television station in Belgrade exploded, wrecked by NATO's missiles. 
 At 7:30 A.M. Friday in Washington, black limousines bearing Prime Ministers tore through downtown toward the White House, and green tractors hauling refugees groaned toward the Macedonian border town of Lipkovo. Among the exiles was an old man named Rifat Bajrami.
"The Serbs have made me live like an animal," he said. "For what? What harm have I brought to them? A man spends his entire life building a home for himself. Then his life is destroyed by irrational hatred."
At 9:30 A.M. in Washington, while rescue workers searched the rubble of the Belgrade television station, Mr. Clinton took to the world's airwaves, opening the summit meeting by criticizing the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic.
"Mr. Milosevic's forces burn and loot homes and murder innocent people," he said. "Our forces deliver food and shelter and hope to the displaced. Mr. Milosevic fans the flames of anger between nations and peoples." The Serbian leader, he said, "knows only one way to achieve his aims -- through force."
As Mr. Clinton spoke, Branko Novakovic, a retired Yugoslav diplomat with pleasant memories of his nine years in Washington, looked out his seventh-floor apartment window in Belgrade at the ruins of the former Communist Party headquarters, hit by NATO on Wednesday night.
Mr. Novakovic, who is 78, awoke Friday morning after a fitful night punctuated by explosions, turned on his radio, and heard of the television station's destruction -- a dozen dead, many missing.
"Very bad news," he said over a clear telephone line. "This has been bombed, that has been bombed. Many people are living in shelters, under very hard conditions, and they are very distressed, psychologically in a poor condition. They don't know what to expect the next day. They live in fear. Some people cannot bear it. The bombing goes on, and they don't understand why.
"They are not guilty," he added. "They did not expect this from the countries they considered friends. They used to like these countries and now they are beginning to hate them."
The words of Mr. Clinton's opening speech were read to him. "Whatever he thinks and whoever they blame, this is not the right way to do it," Mr. Novakovic said. "We don't have any idea what the situation is down there in Kosovo. But to keep the whole population under siege for so long, this is horrible. It is not human."
Shortly after 1 P.M. in Washington, NATO's 19 leaders began speaking in turn, some at length. The shortest speech by far was from Costas Simitis, the Prime Minister of Greece, a nation less than enthusiastic about NATO's air war. It was a kind of parable, and this was it in its entirety:
"Ladies and gentlemen, 50 years ago, in 1949, the Government troops entered a Greek village and killed two young people. Asked why, they answered: they were Bulgarian Communists. Two days later, the rebels came and they killed also two young people. Asked why, they said: they were American fascists. NATO was and should be an effort to put an end to such practices and such mentalities. NATO should be an effort to secure cooperation, peace and prosperity. I think it's a great aim and we must work for it."
Mr. Clinton quoted a 1949 speech by Dean Acheson, the Secretary of State who hoped NATO's creation would "free the minds of men in many nations from a haunting sense of insecurity."
By 3 P.M., the leaders were done speaking, and the exiles from Malisevo, a village of 800 homes outside Gnjilane in Kosovo, were bedding down on blankets laid over newly spread crushed stone in a cleared garbage dump. Newly arrived at a refugee camp in Neprosteno, Macedonia, they told their stories to a researcher for Human Rights Watch, Ben Ward.
The Serbian paramilitary squads came to the village. They stole everything they could and separated the old from the young. The young were told to lie face down with hands behind heads. The masked men pulled out a list of peoples' names and told their captives to inform or die. Two men, ages 18 and 20, were shot. Another man, age 34, was ordered to bury them with his bare hands.
"One thing that came through strongly was the absolute terror people felt," Mr. Ward said by telephone from Skopje.
It was 4:15 P.M. in Washington when air raid sirens pierced the night in Belgrade. A few minutes later, a bolt of lightning flashed and an enormous thunderclap broke over the White House, setting off electronic security alarms in the streets of a capital on high alert against terrorism.
At 4:40 P.M., the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said NATO's leaders had agreed to step up its attack on the political, military and economic architecture of Mr. Milosevic's power, aiming more bombs and missiles at Belgrade.
In Belgrade at that hour, Gordana Ristic, 33, was preparing to spend another night in the basement-cum-bomb shelter of her apartment building, a mile from the heart of the city.
"It was a really horrible night last night," she said by telephone. "There were explosions every few minutes after 2 A.M. This morning I woke up in a totally strange situation. I went to my job, marketing and public relations, in the center of Belgrade, and when I came in I looked around to see if everything was in its right place.
"I thought, 'Maybe this is my last day. Tomorrow things will not be there. My plants. My computer.'
"I really love Belgrade," added Ms. Ristic, no fan of Mr. Milosevic, but of late a Serbian nationalist. "I'm sorry that leaders in your country are not willing to read history. You destroy what is material in this country. Buildings. Bridges. But never people."
A reporter read to her from Mr. Clinton's speeches at the summit meeting. She sounded torn between anger and tears. "This is the bottom to which civilization, in which I believed, has gone," she said. "Clinton is playing a role, singing a song in an opera. It kills me."
As she slept, NATO's leaders dined on soft-shell crabs and spring lamb in the East Room of the White House. Dessert was a little chocolate globe. Jessye Norman sang arias. And as the last limousine left, near midnight, Saturday morning's all-clear sounded in Belgrade, a gray dawn came up over the Balkans, and rivulets of people rose in the mountains and began to flow down toward the mosque in Lipkovo.
Saturday morning in Washington, as NATO's spokesmen recited the list of what was destroyed overnight -- an oil refinery, an airport, a bridge, a television tower -- day ending in Belgrade, and in the ruins of the broadcast station, the search went on for the missing and the dead.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1042 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
Bosnia's Loss is an American City's Gain

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
AN unexpected side effect of the turmoil in the Balkans has Steve Hrdlicka hopping.
For most of the 1990's, the Southern Commercial Bank branch on Gravois Avenue, where Mr. Hrdlicka is a loan officer, was a forlorn place, stuck in an aging neighborhood in a shrinking city. New accounts were few, and the shuttered businesses along Gravois and other once-bustling streets in the Bevo neighborhood of south St. Louis suggested little hope for the future. 
 All that changed when a stream of new immigrants, largely Bosnians leaving behind the ethnic conflicts in the former Yugoslavia, began settling in this unlikely patch of the Midwest. "Eight years ago when we opened this branch, we sat on our hands most of the time -- we used to sleep quite a lot," recalled Mr. Hrdlicka (pronounced HERD-lick-a), now 39, who grew up in predominantly white, working-class south St. Louis, the great-grandson of Czech immigrants. "Then this place became a rally place for Bosnians. They would come in and ask for a loan for furniture. Then a car. Then it was a house, for themselves, their cousins."
Largely thanks to the Bosnian newcomers, who have developed a reputation for hard work and thrift, Mr. Hrdlicka's branch has doubled its deposits in the last two years.
For greater St. Louis, an unexpected opportunity for revival is seen in the arrival of an estimated 15,000 Bosnian immigrants in the 1990's -- a concentration second in size only to Chicago's -- along with smaller groups of newcomers from Mexico, Vietnam, Ethiopia and Somalia.
This kind of story, of a critical mass of hard-working immigrants revitalizing a sagging urban neighborhood, is a familiar one in immigrant havens like New York or Houston. But it is big news in St. Louis, which has largely been starved of fresh immigration for half a century.
In the late 1800's, new arrivals from Germany, Ireland, Italy and Eastern Europe were building St. Louis into an industrial and commercial metropolis to rival Chicago. But after World War II, the city lost its appeal to ambitious newcomers.
Since 1950, the population of the city has shriveled from 857,000 to roughly 350,000, proportionally the sharpest decline of any major American city. The vast surrounding suburbs, home now to roughly five times as many people, at first grew rapidly but have since also ebbed. In the 1990's the region has lost 63,000 people to other parts of the country and has ranked among the slowest-growing in the nation.
One important reason is that domestic migration out of St. Louis has not been balanced by immigration from abroad, as it has in New York or Los Angeles. According to William H. Frey, a demographer at the University of Michigan, the St. Louis metropolitan area, now the nation's 18th largest, ranked just 35th in the number of immigrants who settled there between 1990 and 1998, below much smaller cities like Hartford.
The paucity of immigrants locked St. Louis into what Mr. Frey calls a Rust Belt pattern of decay, which was easy to discern on the south side, historically an immigrant district. Old brick owner-occupied homes were gradually becoming rentals, and thriving commercial districts were slowly being abandoned. Prices for homes, stores, factory buildings and warehouses plummeted.
But those depressed conditions have made possible the current upsurge in Bosnian immigration, according to Ann Crosslin, president of the International Institute of St. Louis, a nonprofit group that aids refugees and promotes international cultural programs in the city. She said the small first wave of refugees, in the early 1990's, found housing costs so low -- a two-bedroom apartment in Bevo rents for roughly $400 a month, and $50,000 buys a decent house -- that the area soon attracted fellow Bosnians who had first landed in other places.
"St. Louis is seen as a cheap place to live," noted Jasna Mruckovski, a refugee from Banja Luka, the Bosnian Serb capital, who arrived in St. Louis in 1994. "People come from California, Chicago and Florida, where it's more expensive. Bosnians don't care if they start by buying the smallest, ugliest house. At least they feel they have something."
Ms. Mruckovski (pronounced muh-ruh-KOV-ski), 25, should know. By day a translator in Southern Commercial's Bevo branch, she moonlights as a real estate agent and has helped sell 33 homes in the area over the last year, all but one to Bosnian buyers. In many cases, she said, whole families including children pooled wages to buy those homes.
THE willingness of Bosnian immigrants to work hard at two or even three jobs is becoming legendary among local employers. With unemployment in the region only slightly over 3 percent, opportunities abound. At Willert Home Products, a local maker of mothballs and potpourri, a third of the 320 employees are immigrants.
"You want to find employees with a good work ethic, and the refugees are about the best," said W. D. Willert, president of the company. "We now have 12 nationalities here, and when we need more workers we know the Bosnians will call their cousins."
Almost no immigrants in the St. Louis area are on welfare. Of the estimated 17,000 families receiving benefits through Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the largest welfare program, just 40 are foreign-born, according to Ms. Crosslin.
Like many other immigrant groups before them, the Bosnians will probably have an increasing impact on their new home as business owners. Bosnian immigrants have already started a trucking company and dozens of Bosnian restaurants, shops and grocery stores, Mr. Hrdlicka, the banker, said.
One of these new entrepreneurs is Alem Boric, 27, who came here from Sarajevo in 1995. He started as a laborer, first at a pipe company and later at a battery maker. Using his savings, he opened Europa Market last year, selling mainly Balkan specialties to local customers. But Mr. Boric (pronounced BOW-rick), who owned a casino in Sarajevo and left only when Bosnian Serbs began shelling the city, has bigger plans: video distribution and wholesaling.
"This is a great place to start a business, because it's cheap and there's a lot of opportunity," he said. "St. Louis is also going to be a great place to make a lot of money."

HEADLINE: WORKING;
Too Personal At the Interview

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. I am just beginning a job search, and I've already been asked twice in interviews whether I am married, have children or plan to have children. While my answers to the first two questions are yes and no, I have dodged the third, for fear that any child-bearing plans might cost me a new job. Is it true that employers aren't supposed to ask? How should I handle it when they do?
 
A. A job hunt is tough enough without having to dance around uncomfortable -- and, yes, illegal -- interview questions. 
 In many states, it is illegal even to ask about a candidate's marital status, said Mark A. Jacoby, an employment lawyer at Weil, Gotshal & Manges in Manhattan. And regardless of where you live, interview questions about pregnancy or plans for becoming pregnant are forbidden. Under Federal law, he explained, "The issue would be tied to a possible disability as a result of pregnancy -- in effect, discriminating against someone who plans to get pregnant and therefore be disabled."
As is often the case, however, boldly asserting your legal rights may not be the best way to get what you want. "You can say, 'Those are illegal questions,' and refuse to answer," said Caryl Rae Krannich, co-author of "Interview for Success" (Impact Publications, 1998). "That may make you feel good at the moment, but it is sure to kill your chances of getting the job."
In some cases, the interviewer is just trying to make small talk and isn't thinking about the legal consequences of his questions, Mr. Jacoby said. If you make a big deal out of a question, you're likely only to increase the interviewer's interest in it.
One approach is to finesse the issue by playing it "honest but smart," Ms. Krannich said. If you deny any plans to have children, but then show up pregnant shortly thereafter, she said, you could hurt your relationship with your new employer.
"At the same time," Ms. Krannich cautioned, "you want to put the best face on the situation." Offering too much information -- how many children you're hoping for, or just when you plan to have them -- falls into the "honest and stupid" category, she said.
Keep your responses brief and to the point, she advised. "A lot of people talk too much when asked about things that make them uncomfortable," she said. "Just answer the question and move on."
A long, rambling response will alert an observant interviewer to your discomfort and can make the interviewer wonder, "If she responds this way to this question, what will she be like to work with?"
If you object on principle to the questions, you can make the subtle point that they are inappropriate, Ms. Krannich said. "Say something like: "Gee, that's interesting. I've not been asked that question before in a job interview."
Unfortunately, in some cases an interviewer's motives may not be so innocent. If you sense that your questioner knows that his line of inquiry is inappropriate but is pursuing it anyhow, you may want to reconsider whether to work for that company.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she responds to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: May 9, 1999, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Working column on April 25, about personal questions in job interviews, misstated the legal treatment of interview questions involving a potential employee's pregnancy or child-bearing plans. Under Federal law, a company cannot use the answers to such questions in a decision on hiring, but it is not prohibited from asking them. The courts, however, usually regard such questions as evidence that pregnancy was a factor in refusing to hire someone, according to a lawyer at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
The column also misstated the treatment of pregnancy in disability law. Under the Americans With Disabilities Act, normal pregnancy is not a protected disability.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
'Internet Governor' Woos Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., April 25

 BODY:
James S. Gilmore 3d, the Governor of Virginia, stood on the steps of the Netscape Communications Corporation's headquarters last Tuesday and smiled in the morning sun. The man Virginians know as the "Internet Governor" was 3,000 miles from his constituents but he insisted he felt at home in Silicon Valley.
"I speak their language," Governor Gilmore said. "We're on line together." 
 Whether the Governor correctly interpreted the ties remains to be seen. One thing is certain: as the worlds of politics and high technology increasingly come together, Governor Gilmore is a man who would like to be at the nexus.
In recent years, Virginia's high-technology economy has surged and Governor Gilmore, a Republican, has made Internet policy central to his 18-month stint in office.
He helped create and signed what supporters deemed the nation's first comprehensive set of state Internet laws, created the first state technology cabinet post, made fast ties with Virginia's technology industry and aggressively recruited technology companies to consider making Virginia their home.
Now he is seeking to parlay his efforts into a national role. Last December, he was named to a Federal commission charged with studying Internet tax issues, and he hopes the Internet policies pioneered in Virginia will be used as a blueprint by other states.
His three-day tour of California last week represented a coming-out party of sorts, an effort to sell himself and Virginia at ground zero of the digital revolution. He said he felt a warm reception from executives at the likes of Netscape, Oracle and Cisco Systems. But it was also clear that Governor Gilmore's portrayal of Virginia as the "Internet state" did not overly impress the industry titans in Silicon Valley.
"Everybody comes here trying to get a little Silicon Valley dust on their shoes," said Netscape's chief executive, James L. Barksdale, during his meeting with the Governor, though not appearing to refer to the Governor personally.
Then again, what made the visit to Netscape particularly symbolic is that Netscape recently was purchased by America Online, the brightest jewel in Virginia's high-technology crown.
In addition to America Online, Virginia is home to MCI Worldcom and one of its subsidiaries, Uunet, as well as Psinet. Governor Gilmore is fond of saying that thanks to the presence of those companies -- Uunet and PSInet are Internet service providers -- 50 percent of all Internet traffic goes through Virginia.
More generally, Virginia's high-technology economy has been on a tear. Over the last five years, the technology sector has generated more than 60 percent of the growth in the state's economy, according to the Governor's office. The office also projected that the number of technology businesses in Virginia would grow to 5,300 by 2002, up from 3,400 now.
Governor Gilmore says he has never called himself "the Internet Governor," but he does not mind the title a bit. "If somebody wants to refer to me as that, I won't run from it," he said.
Not everyone, however, agrees with the moniker. To his detractors, Governor Gilmore is a Johnny-come-lately who has tried to transform himself into a "governor.com." Critics say he hardly uttered a word about technology until after he became Governor in 1997 and has since sought to take credit for Virginia's high-technology growth. They point out that Governor Gilmore's gubernatorial opponent, Donald S. Beyer Jr., was much more closely tied to northern Virginia's technology companies.
"The high-tech economy has been booming for years," said Kenneth R. Plum, chairman of the Democratic Party of Virginia. "He's gotten on board and is riding it for all it's worth."
Still, Mr. Plum and other critics do not dispute that Governor Gilmore and the Internet industry have become fast friends in the intervening months. Many in the industry say the Governor is one of the few politicians who has made a truly concerted effort to understand their new economy.
"He's recognized what the Internet is, how it got there and what impact it can have" said Stephen M. Case, the chief executive of America Online, adding that Governor Gilmore's efforts in Virginia are being emulated elsewhere.
"There is a recognition this is a launching pad," Mr. Case said. "The policies set in Virginia could become a blueprint."
It has not hurt the Governor's standing among the state's technology companies that he has offered tax breaks to support their growth. For example, he engineered an $18 million tax break for America Online as an incentive for the company to build a new data center in Prince William County.
Supporters also credit Governor Gilmore with being the first governor in the nation to create a technology cabinet post (although Democratic critics in the state contend they had the idea first). The Secretary of Technology post is held by Donald W. Upson, a former marketing executive, who is charged with attracting high-technology business to Virginia and exploring how the state can use information technology internally.
Based on the work of a state commission created by Governor Gilmore, he signed the nation's most broad-based state Internet laws last month, giving force to seven bills called the Internet Policy Act. Among other things, the act has provisions to protect consumer privacy, make it a crime to use encryption for criminal activity and make it a criminal offense to send unsolicited commercial E-mail.
Numerous other states are considering Internet-related laws, and some are patterning them after the work of Virginia, said Paul Russinoff, state policy counsel for the Internet Alliance, an industry trade group.
"If you're a fan of heavy regulation on the Internet, you may find the Virginia act unsatisfying, but it is one of the few policy initiatives I've seen at a state level that takes a realistic approach," Mr. Russinoff said.
"I'm not saying there aren't other 'Internet governors' out there," he added. "But Governor Gilmore is absolutely focused on the medium."

HEADLINE: Unbowed and Only Slightly Bitter;
An Indonesian Writer and Survivor Preaches Courage

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
For three decades Pramoedya Ananta Toer, Indonesia's greatest modern writer, felt the full force of President Suharto's military state.
Clubbed on the head when he was seized by the police in 1965 -- Indonesia's infamous "year of living dangerously -- he lost much of his hearing. Arrested without charge, he was imprisoned and silenced for 14 years, confined for most of that time to a remote island penal colony where he was forced into hard labor and had to forage for food. More than a dozen years of closely monitored house arrest followed. 
 He is a free man now on his first visit to the United States, his first trip abroad since 1959. At 74 he is small and frail and speaks sparingly and quietly. But when he speaks there is no mistaking his strength, and no sign that his tormentors ever came close to breaking his will.
"You can't just seem strong; it takes more than strength to survive," he said on a balmy afternoon in the garden outside the United Nations, which he had just toured. "It took resistance, mental resistance as well as spiritual resistance. Strength was not enough."
Mr. Pramoedya's story of suffering and survival on the prison island of Buru is the theme of a memoir, "The Mute's Soliloquy," to be published in the United States on Wednesday by Hyperion East.
"The Mute's Soliloquy" is a collection of ruminations from the Buru experience in the form of notes to himself and unsent letters to his eight children, whose growing-up years he missed. The letters are full of fatherly advice: don't swim carelessly in the sea; take your vitamins; learn to relax before falling asleep at night; study history.
Speaking in Indonesian through an interpreter, his American editor and friend, John H. McGlynn, a co-founder of the Lontar Foundation to promote Indonesian literature abroad, Mr. Pramoedya (pronounced pram-OOH-dee-ah) is still pained by the damage his ordeal caused his family. In an interview, he was acerbic about the quality of Indonesian intellectual life and guarded in his predictions about Indonesia's future.
Last May the 30-year rule of General Suharto came to an end amid street protests against his corrupt and dictatorial military Government. At the same time an economic crisis gutted the currency and Indonesian living standards, bringing the International Monetary Fund into the management of the economy. Under an interim President, B. J. Habibie, elections are to be held in June to elect a new parliament, which in turn is to choose a new president this fall for Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous nation.
Mr. Pramoedya seems to doubt that Indonesians, consumed now by the settling of ethnic and political scores through violence on several islands, have the courage to make a clean sweep of the old order.
"We have a whole country of 'yes' people," he remarked dismissively.
He never was one. A leftist and supporter of Indonesia's first President, Sukarno, Mr. Pramoedya, continues to hold some anti-Western opinions and suspicions about the United States. He discourses freely on the corruption of the Indonesian military and the cowardice of the older generations, now closing ranks, he says, against change and possible revelations about the past.
He still has critics who suspect that he was closer than he admits to a Communist movement that was intent on controlling intellectual life in the 1960's and may have been prepared to seize political power in 1965, when General Suharto stepped into a murky coup and tens of thousands of suspected leftists and ethnic Chinese were slaughtered.
 
Late Recognition Is No Recompense
Mr. Pramoedya says that he cannot understand why anyone would be interested in these old accusations. But he says that to get into politics now would only revive old charges that he is a Communist. Mr. Sukarno's daughter, Megawati Sukarnoputri, is expected to be a leading candidate for president in the fall.
Mr. Pramoedya, who says he freed himself from house arrest in 1992 by simply walking out onto the street on Human Rights Day, has picked up several international prizes in recent years, among them the 1995 Magsaysay Award, Asia's top honor and a Unesco award in 1996.
His newest book was the subject of an Asia Society program on Thursday. Last week Fordham University, which arranged his trip to the United States, held a three-day symposium on his work. He is to receive an honorary degree this week from the University of Michigan and then plans to visit the University of Wisconsin and Berkeley before touring Canada and finally the Netherlands, the colonial power in Indonesia for 300 years. In 1947 Mr. Pramoedya was imprisoned by the Dutch.
For Mr. Pramoedya, recognition late in life is no recompense for "all the things that have been stolen from my life." Years of separation from his wife, Maimoenah Thamrin, and children in the 1960's and 70's was a kind of torture in itself, because he had vowed as a young man to be a better father than his scholarly but distant father had been. Even postcards to his children were censored. "But an even greater tragedy than being unable to teach my own children was that the atmosphere created by the New Order acted as a stronger teacher for them," he said, using the Suharto regime's name for itself.
"It was extremely difficult for them. During the time I was away they had to bear the burden of curses, people looking down on them, people exiling them within the community, so that they themselves didn't grow up naturally. They didn't become the people they should have been."
One of his daughters was barred from taking a final exam in pharmacology, although she topped the class. Even after Mr. Pramoedya's release from Buru in 1979, he said, his only son, then a young teen-ager, was beaten by a gang of taunters, then arrested and tortured by the police officers who arrived to break up the brawl.
If Mr. Pramoedya was deprived of a normal life, Indonesia was also denied the work of many writers and thinkers who shared his experience of harassment and years in prison. He does not hold the Government solely responsible for their isolation.
"You have to look at the intellectuals themselves," he said. "A good portion of the blame rests on the intellectuals. The Indonesian intelligentsia has no tradition of speaking out. The intelligentsia, for the most part, comes from the upper class. And that particular group of people was raised to respect the status quo. They listen to what their superiors say. This unfortunate aspect of Indonesian culture came to the fore in the past 30 years, where everyone from top to bottom had to listen to the top. The only exceptions you might find were the intellectuals who lived abroad."
But not many Indonesians lived and wrote abroad, being unable to tear themselves away from the intense cultures of their archipelago.
"Part of the problem is that many Indonesians felt that they could not survive abroad, not just in the intellectual sphere but in the material sphere," he said. "Indonesians seem to have a bit of an inferiority complex presenting themselves to the foreign world. Even when you talk about Indonesia itself, you don't find many Indonesians who know their own history. A lot of them have to read textbooks written by foreigners."
In Jakarta, where Mr. Pramoedya is still wary of leaving home alone for fear of Government spies or the police, his books of both fiction and history remain officially banned, though they are now widely available. His best-known novels form a four-part series, the Buru Quartet -- "This Earth of Mankind," "Child of All Nations," "Footsteps" and "House of Glass" -- built around the life of Minke, a Javanese boy who comes of age in the waning years of Dutch colonialism. The books were composed in his head on Buru, a mental exercise that helped preserve his strength and sanity. They were written down only late in his imprisonment, when he was allowed a typewriter.
 
Bravery as Capital For the Future
Politically charged students now flock to Mr. Pramoedya to draw on his wisdom.
"Wave after wave of young people come to my house and I keep telling them, 'Have the courage to stand up for your convictions,' " he said. "All that the younger generation needs is capital, capital in the sense of bravery and courage. Bravery and courage does not come down from the heavens. You have to create it yourself. It's as much a part of fitness as a physical fitness exercise."
Mr. Pramoedya is impressed by the emergence of the student movement that drove Mr. Suharto from power last May, especially since many of the young people were drawn from comfortable families in which challenging authority was not encouraged. "Oddly enough, having been raised in deceit has also opened their eyes to deceit and has brought them together as a class," he said. "They are without power. They had no weapons. They were without hope of success. But they went after Suharto and they brought him down."
The future "is completely dependent upon the youth," he said. "If they can pass the test of history itself, Indonesia will survive and become stronger. But if they can't, I don't see much of a future. I see only two choices ahead: one is that students achieve their goal of complete reformation of the Government or, if that doesn't work, the consequence could well be social revolution. If the latter were to happen, that would be the end of Indonesia as we know it."
Mr. Pramoedya, spends his days writing a diary and occasional articles, while collecting histories of prisoners whom the Dutch sent into exile in Irian Jaya, Indonesia's share of New Guinea. He is keeping a journal about this trip and his impressions of the United States. For years he held this country responsible for prolonging colonialism in Indonesia and interfering even after it ended.
"In general my intellectual opinions about the United States are pretty much what they once were," he said. "But this trip has given me the opportunity to balance my views, to fill out the picture. I find it such a pleasure to see so many ethnic groups, religions, people from all over the world being able to live here in harmony and peace," he said, after stops in Washington, Bennington, Vt., and Ithaca, N.Y., before arriving in Manhattan on Tuesday. "I am pleased to see police forces without the arrogance that is apparent in my own country." Not yet knowing about the criticism of police violence in New York recently, his general reaction to American police was positive.
"Indonesians seem to have a problem with power," he said. "They get just a little bit of it, even an ounce, and they go overboard."

HEADLINE: Economist at Harvard Awarded Prize

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Andrei Shleifer, a Harvard University economist who immigrated to the United States from Russia when he was a teen-ager, has won the John Bates Clark Medal, the most prestigious prize in economics short of the Nobel. The medal, awarded every two years by the American Economic Association, goes to an outstanding economist under 40 years old.
Mr. Shleifer, who is 38, was honored for his empirical research into the workings of financial markets, commercial law and corporate securities, particularly in countries making the transition from socialism to a market economy. Some of his research has focused on Russia. 
 "Mr. Shleifer represents a continuation of the empirical tradition that really started with Lawrence Summers and continued through David Card and Kevin Murphy," said Dale Jorgenson, a Harvard economist and president-elect of the American Economic Association, which chose Mr. Shleifer at an executive board meeting in Chicago on Friday.
Mr. Summers, then of Harvard, Mr. Card at the University of California at Berkeley, and Mr. Murphy, at the University of Chicago, are the three previous Clark medalists -- Mr. Summers in 1993, Mr. Card in 1995 and Mr. Murphy in 1997. They are all prominent empiricists. Rather than focus on theory, they focus on what amounts to experiments that elaborate on existing theory, amend it or create new theory. Mr. Summers is now deputy director of the Treasury Department; Mr. Card and Mr. Murphy are labor economists. Mr. Shleifer won out over four or five others who had been considered by a selection committee, including Alan B. Krueger of Princeton University, who was the most prominent on the list.
Some of Mr. Shleifer's work elaborates on a theory developed by others that says it is impossible to write a contract between two parties -- whether they are two individuals or a corporation and its shareholders -- that covers all contingencies in a binding fashion. As a result, a strong court system is necessary to resolve disputes. Financial markets work best in countries with such a system, Mr. Shleifer has found. They do not work well, he maintains, in countries where parliaments have a bigger say, and politicians and powerful shareholders can influence legislation.
"This award to me is to some extent a recognition of how important finance is to economics and vice versa," Mr. Shleifer said yesterday.
In the discussion leading up to Mr. Shleifer's selection, the economic association's executive committee did not consider a conflict of interest case in which Mr. Shleifer was involved in 1997. "It was not even mentioned," Mr. Jorgenson said.
Mr. Shleifer had been a steward of a program financed by the United States Government to help Russia develop capital markets and new commercial and civil laws. The Harvard Institute for International Development ran the program under a $57 million contract from the United States Agency for International Development. AID canceled the contract in May 1997, contending that Mr. Shleifer and another official had benefited from private business dealings.
Mr. Shleifer was said to have invested in Russian securities while advising the Russian Government. He has never been formally charged with a misdeed, and he has denied any wrongdoing. He was dismissed, however, from the Harvard Institute, whose director is Jeffrey Sachs, also a Harvard economist. Asked about the announcement that Mr. Shleifer had won the Clark award, Mr. Sachs declined to comment.
Mr. Shleifer finished high school in Rochester, where he had settled with his parents after coming from Russia. He excelled in mathematics, which was his major as an undergraduate at Harvard University, but he became a research assistant to Mr. Summers, who drew him into economics. Mr. Shleifer earned his Ph.D. at M.I.T. in 1986 and five years later, at age 30, he was a full professor at Harvard.

Sun Microsystems plans to introduce software today that is designed for companies that want to let their employees use various devices to connect to corporate computer networks, secure from unauthorized access. A New Tack on the Shipping News
The Journal of Commerce, which has provided a mix of trade policy analysis and coverage of the shipping industry, is changing its focus. It is jettisoning most of its policy coverage, all of its commodity price listings and 20 percent of its editorial staff and is devoting itself to "those who control the movement of goods," in the words of a recent editorial. It will also convert from a broadsheet to a tabloid format on June 1. The newspaper, led by its new editor, Peter Tirschwell, plans to move from its broader perspective to porthole-to-porthole coverage of an industry that has all the glamour of the industrial age at a time when the financial world is fixated on all things digital. HEADLINE: Syria Sneaks Iraq's Oil Out As Old Foes Become Friends

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: TADMOR, Syria

 BODY:
In a brazen violation of United Nations sanctions, scores of Syrian trucks laden with Iraqi oil now shuttle past this desert oasis every day, reflecting the ties that have turned the former foes into friends.
Until October 1997, the border between the two countries was closed, and sniping between top Syrian and Iraqi officials took place regularly. 
 But now trade between the two countries has blossomed. Some of it is authorized by the United Nations, under arrangements that allow Iraq to import limited quantities of goods. Some of it, like the oil-tanker traffic, is quite certainly not authorized.
The unauthorized deliveries have angered the United States and British Governments, which have asked the Syrian authorities to stop them, said diplomats based in Damascus, the Syrian capital. But the Syrians appear in no mood to do so, and some diplomats say they believe that the Syrian Government may play a role in distributing the oil once it reaches Damascus.
The scope of the operation could be plainly seen on a recent visit here, northeast of Damascus.
The town lies on a desert highway that has become a main thoroughfare for the illicit deliveries. The smuggling is so open that drivers regularly pull off the road at the Roman ruins of Palmyra here, in full view of the Syrian police.
Syria and Iraq have long been bitter enemies, with their ruling Baath parties divided by internecine rivalry.
In the early 1980's, when Iraq and Iran went to war, Syria sided with the Government of Iran and closed its border with Iraq. In the Persian Gulf war of 1991, Syrian troops and tanks were part of the American-led coalition that drove Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
But there has been an abrupt realignment in the last two years, with Syrian trade delegations visiting Iraq, and then with the reopening of the border.
Along with economic rewards, the warmer ties appear to have provided the two countries with important mutual political support. Syria, feeling slighted by the West for the hard line it has taken toward peace with Israel, has become a loud critic of recent American-led efforts to isolate Iraq.
As far as oil smuggling is concerned, the diplomats say, the operation clearly benefits both countries. It provides Iraq with a market to export oil beyond what the United Nations allows, and it gives Syria access to oil that it might otherwise have to import.
Like Iraq, Syria is also an exporter of oil. But it must import some oil products, most notably fuel oil and diesel. The diplomats say they do not know exactly what is being carried in the oil tankers, but a leading theory is that it is fuel oil, perhaps in a barter arrangement in exchange for Syrian goods.
The smuggling operation became apparent several months ago, when the tankers began to appear on Syrian highways, the Damascus-based diplomats say. They say that its volume appears to have increased in the last month and that hundreds of tankers each week now deliver oil to Syria from Iraq.
Of the three border crossings between the two countries, only one is monitored by United Nations inspectors, and their mandate allows them to search only shipments entering Iraq. Each crossing is staffed by Syrian military and intelligence personnel, but the diplomats say there is no evidence that they have tried to obstruct the oil shipments.
"When we raise the issue, the Syrians say, 'Well, it's a long border and we can't patrol every inch,' " a Western diplomat said. "But they clearly know what's going on, and some of us believe they're facilitating it."
In a prelude to the current operation, other diplomats said, large quantities of Iraqi fuel were being smuggled by way of Syria to buyers in Turkey shortly after the Iraqi-Syrian border was reopened. But that trade was halted when the Turkish Government began to intercept the deliveries at the Turkish border.
This time, the diplomats say, it appears that the Iraqi oil either is ending up in Syria, where it is sold or bartered to buyers who may include the Government, or is driven on to Lebanon, where Syria is the main power broker.
The diplomats say it is clear that the operation is more than profiteering and is being coordinated on both sides of the Iraqi-Syrian border.
As part of its warmer ties with Baghdad, Syria has said publicly that it intends to open a long-closed pipeline that would allow Iraq to ship its oil to Syrian ports on the Mediterranean, in addition to the pipeline that Iraq uses through Turkey. But Syria has said it would do so only if the United Nations approved such a step.

HEADLINE: Study Suggests Repetition Gets Drug Warnings Across

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
Parents who talk to children about the risks of illicit drugs sometimes despair that their warning goes in one ear and out the other. But the message just might stick in a young brain if it is repeated enough, according to a study of parental and adolescent attitudes released today.
The study by the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, a nonprofit coalition, also reported a dramatic disconnection between parents and children in getting the message through. The study is being released at www.drugfreeamerica.org. 
 An overwhelming 98 percent of the parents in the study said they had talked with their children about drugs, but only 65 percent of teen-agers recalled having had such a conversation. And 27 percent of teen-agers said they learned a lot from their family about the hazards of drugs.
Not surprisingly, the study reported that the more adolescents heard from parents about the risks, the less likely they were to use drugs, even though some failed to heed the advice. Of the teen-agers in the study who said they had heard nothing at home about the risks of drugs, 45 percent said they had smoked marijuana within the last year. One-third of those who said they had learned a little at home used marijuana in the same period. But among teen-agers who said they had learned a lot, only 26 percent said they smoked marijuana, the drug of choice after alcohol and tobacco.
Comparable reductions were reported in the use of inhalants, hallucinogens like LSD and crack cocaine.
When parents hesitate to tell their children about drugs, said Stephen Dnistrian, executive vice president of the partnership, "We can make a pretty safe assumption that there is probably not a lot of communication between parent and child about a lot of things."
The latest Partnership Attitude Tracking Study, the 12th such study since 1987, was conducted last year by Audits and Surveys Worldwide, a market research firm based in New York. It sampled 6,852 teen-agers, ages 13 to 18; 2,358 children, 9 to 12, and 809 parents across the United States. The margin of error in the responses was 1.8 percentage points for teen-agers, 2.8 for pre-teen-agers and 3.9 for parents.
Though virtually all the parents said they raised the issue of drugs with their teen-agers, fewer than half, or 48 percent, said they had done so four or more times in the previous year.
Black parents were more likely than Hispanic or white parents to say they discussed the risks of drugs regularly with their children. Fifty-seven percent of black parents in the study said they did so, compared with 45 percent of Hispanic parents and 44 percent of white parents. And 31 percent of the black children in the study recalled having such conversations, compared with 29 percent of Hispanic children but only 19 percent of white children.
Many parents cannot seem to bring themselves to believe that their children might experiment with drugs. According to the study, 42 percent of the teen-agers said they had tried smoking marijuana, but only 14 percent of the parents thought this was possible. And 53 percent of teen-agers said they had been offered marijuana; 37 percent of the parents considered it likely.
The White House's director of national drug control policy, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, said the study made an important point about the disparity between perception and reality in parents' conversations with their children about the dangers of drugs. "Like a good teacher, they must check the feedback," he said.
General McCaffrey's Office of National Drug Control Policy defined as its first goal educating and enabling young people to reject illegal drugs, as well as alcohol and tobacco. Congress appropriated $195 million for a national campaign to sway an audience of 9- to 18-year-olds with prime-time commercials and print advertisements. The campaign, which began in July, also tries to persuade parents to confront the problem.

HEADLINE: Little Urgency on the Eve Of World Bankers' Meeting

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
When the finance ministers and officials of the world's biggest economic powers last met in Washington six months ago, President Clinton declared that he and other leaders were confronting "the biggest financial challenge facing the world in a half-century."
Now, on the eve of another such meeting, millions of people are still suffering, national economies are still shrinking, but the crisis seems oddly abated. 
 The crisis preoccupying Mr. Clinton and other leaders is in Kosovo, not the emerging markets. Fear of new forms of "economic contagion" has been replaced with far older fears of military contagion. Asia's slow recovery has moved it off the political radar screen, and even the continuing economic chaos in Russia and Indonesia seems far more contained than it did six months ago.
Without last year's sense of urgency, the chances of remaking the "global financial architecture" through fundamental changes -- the rallying call of meetings last fall -- have diminished considerably. But there have been some modest steps, including one today by the International Monetary Fund's executive board. As part of the agency's efforts to offer some way to prevent economic turbulence from spreading from country to country, the board approved a program for contingency credit, Michel Camdessus, its managing director, announced.
The program, first called for by Mr. Clinton last September, will allow the I.M.F. to offer a line of credit to any country determined to be following sound economic policies. The hope is that such support will deter speculators from attacking a nation's currency and will preserve investor confidence.
The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said that the I.M.F.'s action was a victory for Mr. Clinton's financial stability agenda and that the program would provide "an expanded capacity to help maintain confidence when countries face the threat of financial contagion."
An unresolved problem with the program is that the standard -- sound economic policies -- is likely to be hard for the most vulnerable nations to meet, while many eligible countries are less likely to be hit by contagion.
As the leaders of the I.M.F. and the World Bank, in Washington for their spring meetings, start occupying the hotel rooms abandoned today by NATO leaders, some officials insist that the biggest worry once again is the absence of fear itself.
"There is a real danger, which I sense already, that the pressure to reform is weakening around the world," James D. Wolfensohn, the president of World Bank, said this weekend. "There were a lot of powerful and wealthy interests who opposed reform, and they have been able to reassert themselves."
Mr. Clinton warned last week of the dangers of "complacency," endorsing an agenda of reforms spelled out the next day by Mr. Rubin. Those proposals, however, turned out to be modest at best: more disclosure rules to force countries, companies and hedge funds to make information about their financial health public, and some "voluntary guidelines" to try to prevent countries from taking huge financial risks.
To many experts, the package looked more like interior decorating than real architectural alterations. Mr. Rubin shied away, for example, from any proposals to control the flow of capital into or out of vulnerable countries, or to expand the powers of the I.M.F. to be a "lender of last resort" for stricken nations.
For some of the countries hardest hit by the economic crisis, notably Thailand and South Korea, a sense of optimism has replaced gloom. Though their economies will still shrink this year, their stock markets began rocketing back almost as soon as the last set of meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund ended in the fall.
By some measures, South Korea's market has returned to where it was before the crisis struck, and Hong Kong's has roared back to life. Brazil, which in January appeared to be the next domino to fall, has stumbled into unexpected stability.
While the good news has buoyed investors, it has also emboldened the leaders of huge businesses -- like South Korea's powerful industrial groups, the chaebols, which came to symbolize crony capitalism -- to resist real change.
"The crisis came about because of some misjudgments about the fragility of the system," said Jeffrey Garten, the dean of the Yale School of Management, who had called for some tough reforms, including the creation of a global central bank, several months ago. "Now there is a feeling in the air that the system is more resilient, more capable of bouncing back fast, than anyone thought. When you put that together with vivid pictures out of Kosovo, you can see how quickly the political attention span can be diverted."
Some other reforms are under way. Countries already publish far more data than they did before the crisis first hit Thailand in July 1997. The I.M.F. posts some of its conclusions about member nations' debt and economic strategies on the Internet (at http://www.imf.org).
Armed with more information, investors are expected to be far more cautious. But questions remain as to whether the new disclosure policies have prompted the I.M.F. to be less open. "We are clearly less willing to publish something that could trigger investors to panic now that it's clear it may be immediately published," one senior official said recently.
Adding to the diminished sense of urgency is some new thinking that has emerged about crisis-racked nations like Russia and Indonesia: That after awhile, their troubles pose less of a threat to the rest of the world, not more.
Last summer the Clinton Administration scrambled to create a bailout package for Russia, fearing that an economic meltdown would destabilize President Boris N. Yeltsin, threaten economic reforms and perhaps lead to a political breakup.
While the I.M.F. is close to a new agreement to resume loans, it will probably give Russia only enough to pay back the monetary fund and other major debtors, averting the embarrassment of default.
"I would be surprised if Russia gets anything more than just a chance to muddle through the year," said one international official involved in the negotiations. "There is a sense that if you don't give them the money, it would be another sign of Russia's severed linkage with the West, which would put them more and more outside the system." Talk of resuming real economic reform, though, has dissipated.
Similarly, aid to Indonesia is on hold until after elections in June. While its economic woes remain severe, and violence continues around the country, American officials have concluded that the chances are now small that Indonesia's troubles will infect the rest of Asia.
"The new thinking is the old thinking," said Mr. Garten, who left the Clinton Administration for Yale after the President's first term. "And that is that since we still don't really understand many of the forces at work, we should leave a lot of this to the market."

HEADLINE: CULT'S FOLLOWERS RALLY IN BEIJING

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 25

 BODY:
More than 10,000 followers of a religious cult surrounded China's leadership compound today, demanding recognition from authorities who are wary of any group not easily controlled. It was the biggest protest here since the democracy movement in Tiananmen Square in 1989.
Coming as a complete surprise to the authorities, the protest drew followers from all over China. Eerily silent and devoid of banners or slogans, the protesters seemed to materialize out of nowhere, suddenly appearing in large numbers at the seat of Chinese power in the middle of the morning and remaining immovable all day long. 
 Displaying remarkably good organization and discipline, the demonstrators stayed motionless, calm and seated on the sidewalk while organizers communicated by mobile telephones. Many protesters apparently tried to use meditation to persuade leaders to see them in a more favorable light.
The cult, known as Buddhist Law, asserts that it has more than 100 million members in a country of 1.2 billion, the largest among hundreds of cults that have flourished in China in recent years as socialism evaporates as an ideology. Preaching good behavior to win salvation from an increasingly evil world that is headed for catastrophe, followers believe that they can cure illness and eviscerate wickedness from the world.
The cult's leader, Li Hongzhi, 48, moved to New York City two years ago under pressure from the authorities to restrict his activity.
Dressed in simple clothing, followers converged from many provinces of China, sitting on worn squares of cotton padding in long rows that stretched for nearly two miles along two sides of Zhongnanhai, the compound in central Beijing where China's leaders live and work.
The police, apparently eager to avoid a confrontation, did not force the protesters to move, and the gathering dispersed peacefully by 10 P.M.
 The protest came right in the middle of a most politically sensitive time, the 10th anniversary of the student movement that began in April, 1989, and just weeks before the anniversary of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square on June 4. China's leadership is already deeply concerned about the potential for social unrest as a wrenching transition to a market economy is throwing tens of millions out of work.
As China becomes a less regimented society -- with people confused over conflicting laws and regulations at the same time that jobs disappear as state-run industries close -- religious cults with mass followings like this one appear to pose a greater threat to social order than democracy advocates do.
 "The authorities can surgically take out political activist groups, but this is a whole new thing, far harder to control," said Robin Munro, a China scholar who researched Chinese political opposition groups for years as head of Asiawatch in Hong Kong. "Sects are inherently peaceful, but only become politicized, and then potentially explosive, when repressed."
Mindful of the strong role that secret societies played in the downfall of the last imperial dynasty, in 1911, China's leaders are juggling their need for social order with demands for greater religious freedom.
To many Chinese bewildered by a fast-changing society, perhaps the greatest appeal of a cult like Buddhist Law lies in its simplicity.
"What we stand for is good for the nation and good for society, so how can we threaten anyone?" said a 47-year-old woman in a worn green jacket who sat near the corner of Zhongnanhai. "They don't understand us. We want understanding."
Several other followers nodded in agreement as the woman spoke.
"We will stay as long as it takes," said a 52-year-old man in a tattered grey sweater. "A day, a week, a year. We are not in a hurry."
The protesters, wary of giving their names or talking in detail about their organization, said they were demanding a meeting with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji. In the late evening, as the protest dispersed, organizers announced to small groups that they had been promised a meeting with members of the State Council, China's Cabinet. The Government made no announcement, and state-run news media were conspicuously silent.
Buddhist Law is a sect of qigong, a traditional Chinese teaching that incorporates a broad range of healing techniques, martial arts and meditation. An overwhelming majority of Chinese believe in some form of qigong, while some join cults built on the teachings of a particular master, like Mr. Li.
The Communist Party denounces cults as superstitious remnants of an earlier age and asserts that many popular qigong masters fool followers with get-rich-quick schemes and fake medicine.
Many of the cult followers carried a book by Mr. Li. Buddhist Law, founded by Mr. Li in 1992, preaches that evil lurks in the modern appearance of rock and roll music, television, drugs and homosexuality. Although the group is vehemently opposed to modern science and technology, many members use the internet to spread its message.
"Your diseases will be eliminated directly by me," wrote Mr. Li in one of his five books, regarded by followers as sacred texts.
Mr. Li's teachings echo ancient Chinese civilization, asserting the power of healing by using qigong to tap into a person's "inner energy." The cult also uses the Buddhist notion of karma, which holds that people's good and bad deeds determine their fate in the next life.
The origin of today's protest apparently lay in a recent article in an obscure academic journal in the coastal city of Tianjin that warned of the dangers posed by cults in China. Several protesters said they were deeply offended by the article and that a dozen followers were arrested in Tianjin last week after a protest there.
Last year, after Beijing Television broadcast a program critical of Buddhist Law, organizers engineered a protest outside the television station. Two employees of the station were later said to have been dismissed for inaccuracies in the broadcast.
Buddhist Law has apparently earned tens of millions of dollars by selling Mr. Li's books and videotapes of his preachings, meditation cushions and his pictures. But the full size and scope of the operation remains unknown.
The organization, secretive about its operations, has a network of support in the United States, and the followers say that many Communists,senior officials and police officers are among its members.
Mr. Li, who asserts that he has a higher spiritual authority than Jesus, Mohammed or Buddha, teaches that he was sent to earth by a "supreme being" to save mankind from moral corruption caused by consumerism, modern science and technology.
Chinese society has disintegrated so far, Mr. Li contends, that many humans are reincarnated as demons, some of them disguised as monks.
Competing for followers with other cults, Mr. Li has denounced other qigong masters as "possessed with foxes or yellow weasels, and some with snakes."
At today's protest, followers extolled the virtues of their cult.
"I am a better father and husband and citizen," said a 48-year-old man who came from Hebei Province, and said he had been a member of Buddhist Law for six years. "We are making a better society.
"I don't get sick anymore," the man continued. "If everyone is healthy, it will save medical costs and be good for society as a whole."
Today's protest, populated mostly by people from outside the capital, elicited much fascination but limited sympathy from Beijing residents.
"They're crazy," said Li Xiaoming, 27, who works for a transport company. "But there are a lot of them, so the government has to listen."

HEADLINE: 80% of Vote Reported to Back Rewrite of Venezuela's Charter

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 25

 BODY:
Venezuelans today overwhelmingly approved a Government-backed proposal to convoke a national assembly to write a new constitution. The decision signals the disintegration of the political system that has been in place here for more than 40 years.
Less than half of 11 million eligible voters took part in the referendum, called by President Hugo Chavez as part of his plan to install what he calls "a true participatory democracy" in this oil-producing South American country. That immediately led opposition leaders to question the legitimacy of the nearly complete official results, in which more than 80 percent of those who cast ballots favored a new constitution on the President's terms. 
 Nevertheless, the outcome of today's vote, combined with the passage on Thursday of a special "enabling" law that allows Mr. Chavez, a 44-year-old former Army paratrooper, to rule by decree on economic matters, significantly strengthens the position of Venezuela's new leader. His supporters said that was exactly what this country, which has become the principal supplier of oil to the United States in recent years, requires.
"We need to untie the hands of our President and give him the powers he needs so that he can really govern and make the changes Venezuela needs," Pureza Duenas, a 47-year-old nurse, said as she waited to vote this morning. "He can't do that in this fake democracy we have, in which a bunch of corrupt politicians use a flawed constitution to hold him in check."
But opponents of the proposal have expressed concern at Mr. Chavez's behavior since he took office in February, seven years after leading a violent but unsuccessful coup attempt.
That conduct has included making threats to declare a state of emergency that would give him enhanced powers, expanding the military's role and announcing that he intends to seek a second consecutive five-year term of office, something the current Charter prohibits.
"The President is right in wanting to correct the many shortcomings in our institutions, but no single person should be given absolute power," said Luz Marina Rondon, a 42-year-old engineer.
"We need gradual change, not a radical change, and it needs to be carried out within the existing system so that the economy and stability of the country are not damaged."
Because the attributes and powers of the Constitutional Assembly have not been clearly detailed, political turbulence seems likely to increase, not diminish, as a result of today's vote. Last month, for instance, the Supreme Court ruled that the assembly will not have the power to dissolve Congress or the court system, as Mr. Chavez had originally proposed.
Mr. Chavez has given strong indications, including during a victory speech tonight, that he intends to defy the ruling, which he dismissed last week as meaningless. "It would be the same as me decreeing that the sun will not rise in the morning," he said last week.
Under the procedures approved by voters today, the Constitutional Assembly will consist of 131 members to be chosen in a special election, likely to be held late next month, in which candidates apparently will not be allowed to run under party banners.
Counting from the day it is sworn in, which Mr. Chavez suggests should be July 5, Venezuela's Independence Day, the panel will have six months to draw up a new charter, which will then be put to a popular vote.

HEADLINE: New York Teachers Have a Pretty Good Deal

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine is right in saying that any future salary increases for New York City employees should come only in exchange for greater employee productivity (news article, April 21). 
 In contrast, Randi Weingarten, the United Federation of Teachers president, asserts that teachers and other city workers have not been "partners in prosperity," with labor leaders emphasizing the two years in which there were no base pay increases.
In fact, over the contract's five-year span, the salary of a teacher who started in September 1995 will increase 22 percent, while the salary of a teacher with a master's degree and three years' experience will increase 41 percent.
This certainly compares favorably with a projected 12 percent total inflation over the life of the contract.
 
DIANA FORTUNA
Pres., Citizens Budget Commission
New York, April 22, 1999

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE EMBARGO;
Setting Up a Blockade Is Simple, but the Risks Are Many

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
The mechanics of imposing an oil embargo against Yugoslavia enforced by NATO warships plying the Adriatic Sea should be fairly straight-forward, military officials said today. The legal, political and diplomatic risks are far greater, particularly with Russia, which has furiously denounced the plan and thus raised the specter of clashes at sea.
Between 1992 and 1996, allied vessels carried out such a ban on arms to all six republics of the old Yugoslavia in the same Adriatic waters. Some 6,000 ships were boarded and inspected, and only six were caught trying to smuggle weapons. Arms shipments overland still found their way into the hands of the warring factions -- as did oil shipments to Serbia and Montenegro, despite comprehensive United Nations sanctions that virtually barred all foreign trade with the oil-starved republics. 
 But the ban on oil shipments to Yugoslavia that NATO has now authorized is trickier to enforce. And stopping oil tankers from countries not party to the agreement, like Russia, is an expansion of the monthlong war with Yugoslavia.
NATO Secretary General Javier Solana today sought to dismiss the Russian threats of war with a verbal wave: "The Russians, every now and then, they make phrases which go a little bit beyond where they should go."
Just as forcefully, Mr. Solana said on ABC's "This Week" program that Gen. Wesley K. Clark, NATO's military commander, was writing a draft plan that considers "all the possibilities so that the embargo can be guaranteed not only by NATO and NATO-friendly countries, but also for others. If it's an embargo, it will apply to everybody."
The goal of the embargo is to dry up the flow of oil into ports on the coast of Montenegro, the small republic that supplies its only partner in Yugoslavia, the far larger Serbia. The blockade could further undermine the democratic government in Montenegro by introducing more tensions into its relations with Serbia. NATO has also ordered heavier air strikes against overland roads, pipelines and railroads that carry the fuel to Serbia. "Without oil, the Yugoslav military machine will come to a halt and very quickly," said the NATO spokesman, Jamie P. Shea.
Indeed, NATO officials say that with Serbia's two main refineries knocked out of operation, Yugoslav military officials are so desperate for fuel that they are siphoning gas out of abandoned cars belonging to refugees, and using it for tanks and other vehicles.
American intelligence analysts estimate that Montenegrin ports have unloaded 40,000 to 45,000 metric tons, or about 300,000 barrels, of oil in the past month, undercutting the air campaign's goal to cut off Belgrade's ability to resupply the 40,000 Yugoslav troops in Kosovo who are expelling ethnic Albanians and destroying their villages.
France and Italy, in particular, have raised questions about the legal justification for mounting a blockade against third-party countries, as distinct from an embargo restricting only shipments from cooperating nations. Mr. Solana's scenario would cover countries that do not belong to NATO or the European Union, like Russia and Ukraine, whose tankers have unloaded oil in Montenegrin ports since the air war started on March 24.
"If we make the choice of a blockade, then we have to recognize we risk war with a third party who hasn't agreed to the blockade," said one French diplomat. "For that you need a U.N. mandate."
The Italian Prime Minister, Massimo D'Alema, explained to Italian journalists today that the embargo can be carried out with on-board searches and inspections. But a blockade, as such, does not exist, he said.
And Norway's Foreign Minister, Knut Vollebaek, said in an interview, "As for third parties, we would like to see a U.N. Security Council resolution in order to make this binding."
But a senior Pentagon official said that while there may not be a specific Security Council resolution authorizing the ban, "the laws of armed conflict" justify such an embargo.
Mr. Shea acknowledges that "there would have to be a political discussion as to who is covered by such a regime." And Mr. Solana, in his closing briefing today, made light of objections to the embargo, asserting that all 19 members will be in agreement on General Clark's draft plan. The North Atlantic Council, NATO's political arm, is expected to review that plan this week, military officials said.
As outlined now, American and other NATO officials said, the embargo would not try to exclude all ships from Yugoslav ports. Instead, NATO would create a kind of seaborne police force to check manifests and board selected ships to investigate cargo.
Ships caught carrying contraband oil would be turned back or diverted to other ports, but NATO military officials said the legal consequences of interdictions have not been worked out. "There are some legal questions that have to be answered," the Dutch Defense Minister, Frank de Grave, said in an interview.
Other military experts said the issue could be rendered moot simply by the stated purpose of the naval armada. "The very presence of NATO ships would be a deterrent, and would induce ships to go back," Senator John W. Warner, a Virginia Republican who heads the Armed Services Committee, said in an interview.
"We cannot tell our pilots to fly high-risk missions against petroleum storage facilities in Yugoslavia, and then let this other oil creep in through the back door," said Senator Warner, a former Secretary of the Navy.
At General Clark's headquarters outside of Brussels, top aides are pouring over the details of the operation. Military officials said they must define where the NATO interdiction force will operate in the Adriatic and Ionian seas.
General Clark must also determine how many ships, helicopters and surveillance planes, like the United States Navy P-3's, the operation will need. Navy officers said that a dozen ships, rotating duty, would likely be sufficient. Eight NATO ships are assigned to the region now.
A delicate part of the mission would be the actual rules of engagement. Once NATO affirms a specific plan, a notice would go out to all international mariners with the rules. NATO warships would likely establish checkpoints off the Montenegrin coast for checking vessels.
If ships were suspected of carrying contraband, they would be boarded and inspected. Allied ships could fire on any vessels that refused to comply, first as a warning, and then to disable violators. Navy officers say there are also nonlethal means of stopping a rogue tanker dead in its tracks, including devices that would entangle a ship's screw or rudder.
"In a tactical sense," Adm. Luc Kroon, the Dutch chief of defense staff, said in interview, "it's no problem to execute this."
