HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton and Yeltsin Agree to Share Ideas on Kosovo

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia agreed in a telephone conversation today to work closely together in the search for a solution to the conflict in Kosovo. They spoke as leaders of NATO concluded a summit meeting with pledges to intensify their air campaign against Slobodan Milosevic.
White House officials said Mr. Yeltsin initiated the call and asked Mr. Clinton to place the next one after doing "some thinking." 
 The Russian leader's thoughts were not fully clarified in the 90-minute conversation, the officials said. But after the call they said that Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott planned to leave for Moscow on Monday to consult with Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, Mr. Yeltsin's envoy to the Balkans.
The three-day NATO summit meeting, originally called to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the alliance but largely overshadowed by Kosovo, concluded with bold expressions of solidarity in the struggle to halt the Yugoslav President's assault on Albanians in Kosovo.
"What NATO did here this weekend was to reaffirm our commitment to a common future rooted in common humanity," Mr. Clinton said in his closing statement. "Standing against ethnic cleansing is both a moral imperative and a practical necessity."
The leaders went away declaring they would succeed against Mr. Milosevic by sticking to their original strategy of an air campaign. They vowed to escalate the attacks and expand the targets.
But they acknowledged that they did not know how long the air campaign would take to reach their goal of "degrading" Mr. Milosevic's military forces in Kosovo and making him capitulate.
The British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, declared that NATO would continue "for as long as it takes."
 The air campaign went into its 33d night late Sunday. The Associated Press reported that the official news agency Tanjug said explosions rocked the northern Serbian city of Novi Sad and destroyed the last remaining of three bridges over the Danube.
 Tanjug said a fuel depot was targeted near the central Serbian town of Valjevo early on Monday, Belgrade time. Nine NATO missiles also hit an airport in Sombor on the border with Hungary, Belgrade's Studio B radio reported, the A.P. said.
The summit meeting had opened with talk about when and how ground troops might enter Kosovo. But by the end the talk faded away, a casualty of opposition within the Clinton Administration and a recognition that the stability of several European governments, especially Germany and Italy, would be shaken by open discussion of ground troops.
Reaffirming the primacy of the air assaults, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said: "What I think has really come out of this session here at the summit is a really genuine support for an intensified air campaign."
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany said: "It's not going to be easy. It's going to take longer than we would have originally hoped for, but we shall win."
But behind the tough public statements, aides to European leaders said there was an acute awareness that the escalation of the air strikes had to bring better results soon. Public support in NATO countries could easily erode if the war drags on, they said.
Further, if the alliance wanted to get the more than 500,000 ethnic Albanian refugees now camped in Albania and Macedonia back into Kosovo before the onset of winter, the military campaign against the Serbs in Kosovo had to speed up, several European officials said.
But at the same time that the alliance was stressing military victory, NATO leaders were also trying to find a diplomatic track.
Speaking about Mr. Yeltsin's telephone conversation with Mr. Clinton, White House officials described Russia's efforts to deal with the Serbs as being in "good faith." They said that Mr. Talbott would try to learn more about what Mr. Chernomyrdin had accomplished in Belgrade during a visit there last week with Mr. Milosevic.
"The President made the point to Yeltsin strongly that he very much wants to keep the lines of communication open at the highest level," said Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman.
During the telephone conversation, the Russian President described some of the elements of a possible peace deal that Mr. Chernomyrdin brought back from Belgrade, according to a White House official who listened to the call.
"Yeltsin told us there was a commitment from the Serbs to allow the return of the refugees and for the Serbs to withdraw their forces from Kosovo," he said.
But there was "not a great deal of clarity" on what the withdrawal of Serbian forces meant. On another key point, Mr. Yeltsin said that Mr. Milosevic had agreed to the deployment of an "international presence" run by the United Nations with Russia as a key element. It was also not clear whether the "presence" meant inclusion of police, armed observers or soldiers, the White House official said.
The deal described by Mr. Yeltsin fell far short of the five principles that NATO had laid down as the basis for an agreement, the White House aide said. They include an international military force, with NATO at its core, that would escort the ethnic Albanian refugees home once the conflict was over.
An important task for Mr. Talbott is to try to determine from Mr. Chernomyrdin how much Mr. Milosevic is "hurting" from the air strikes, the White House aide said. This was a key factor in figuring out how far the Yugoslav leader is from accepting a diplomatic solution on NATO's terms.
Other NATO leaders also stressed the need for Russia's help in finding a solution.
The German Chancellor said he was meeting with the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, in Berlin this week to talk about a Kosovo solution and that he understood Mr. Annan will then fly on to Moscow.
"I invite the Russians to resume their role in putting pressure on the Serb side to come to a political solution of the conflict," Mr. Schroder said today. Mr. Annan was on the verge of appointing a personal envoy for the Kosovo conflict, and Austrian officials said it would probably be Franz Vranitsky, the former Austrian Chancellor.
In Belgrade, a member of the Milosevic Government, Deputy Prime Minister Vuk Draskovic, said Russia and NATO could come to an agreement at the United Nations soon, and urged his Government to accept it.
As it had during the first two days of the summit meeting, the Kosovo conflict served as the constant current on the last day.
At a special session devoted this morning to the seven states that surround Serbia, President Clinton praised Albania and Macedonia for bearing the burden of more than 500,000 ethnic Albanian refugees expelled into their countries by Mr. Milosevic.
"The people of Albania and Macedonia have welcomed almost a half a million refugees to their countries -- often, literally, into their homes," President Clinton said. "You have shared what you have, through the strains are immense."
The well-being of all Europe, Mr. Clinton said, rested on the ability of NATO and other Western organizations to rebuild southeastern Europe. After the the Kosovo conflict ends, the region should aim for similar democratic and economic standards as Western Europe has, he said.
There were few details about how this would be accomplished, although several countries in the region called today for measures on the scale of the Marshall Plan. In Mr. Clinton's closing remarks this afternoon, he tied together the idea of a new Europe with the conflict in Kosovo and its refugees.
"Our vision of a Europe undivided, democratic, free and at peace depends upon our constructive commitment to the hundreds of thousands of poor refugees, so many men, women and children with no place else to turn, who have been made pawns in a power struggle," he said.
The delegations of all 19 countries included defense ministers. In interviews today, half a dozen of the ministers said an important outcome of the summit meeting was the decision to step up the air campaign with a goal of turning the Serbian people against their leader.
"People are looking at how their positions will be after this is all over," said Hans Haekkerup, the Defense Minister of Denmark. "People are not going to believe in this myth of Milosevic much longer."
The summit meeting's communique embraced the idea that NATO remained open to new members but did not give a timetable for when they could join.
The communique listed groups of possible new members. In the first group were Romania and Slovenia, which almost made it into NATO in 1997 when Hungary, the Czech Republic and Poland were selected as new entrants.
In the second group, the communique listed the Baltic states Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. Bulgaria and Slovakia were listed together for "positive developments," a reference to their moves toward democratic standards. And finally, Albania and Macedonia, which are bearing the burden of the ethnic Albanian refugees but have little hope of meeting NATO's standards, were listed as long-shot contenders.
The Macedonia President, Kiro Gligorov, criticized NATO for not extending an invitation to his country to join NATO and showing little appreciation for Macedonia's efforts with the refugees. "Macedonia has been circumvented and has again been put in last place," he said.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
They Call It the Blues, but They Sure Look Like They're Having a Ball

 BODY:
"It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues," which opened for a limited run at the New Victory Theater in Times Square on March 26, has reopened at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center. Following are excerpts from Lawrence Van Gelder's review, published on April 1.
Looking for a sure cure for the blues? Just latch on to a ticket for "It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues." 
 Now that title bears some parsing because this rich, evocative, rousing show, with some 50 musical numbers ranging from African chants and spirituals to Delta and Chicago blues, with plenty of stops along the dusty roads, river banks, broken country hearts and juke joints in between, is more than a musical feast.
Besides its cornucopia of splendidly interpreted song, "It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues" is a potent blend of visual eloquence and historical sweep that engages the eye and touches the heart while its songs soothe the ear, occasionally work mischief on the funny bone and always raise the spirits.
As the splendid cast assembled by the much-praised Crossroads Theater Company of New Brunswick, N.J., applies its individual and collective vocal, musical and acting talents to songs like "I've Been Living With the Blues," "Blues Man" and "St. Louis Blues," photographs projected onto screens behind the performers brim with history.
Here are sketches of slave auctions and pictures of thirsty women working the fields with their little children nearby, a black man dangling from a lyncher's noose, rural poverty, country churches, the great blues man Robert Johnson and changing fashions in clothes and entertainment, as well as the economic, social and cultural upheaval surrounding the great black migration from the South to Chicago.
"It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues" is based on an idea by Ron Taylor, who wrote it with Randal Myler, its director, and Lita Gaithers, Charles Bevel and Dan Wheetman.
Mr. Taylor, Mr. Bevel and Mr. Wheetman, with Gretha Boston, Carter Calvert, Eloise Laws and Gregory Porter, constitute the powerhouse lineup of singers who step up, step out and put over one number after another. Depending on the song, they can be heartbreakers, heartbroken, sexpots or absolute rapscallions. And after intermission, when they trade their simple attire, rustic airs and simple instruments for shapely gowns and stylish suits, each seems good-naturedly determined to outdo another as they make their way with the backing of an enhanced band through pieces like "I'm Your Hoochie-Coochie Man," the sly, slinky, humorous "Crawlin' King Snake," "Walkin' After Midnight," the bitter "Strange Fruit" and "Let the Good Times Roll."
By this time the band is making the floor vibrate, and the cast and audience are raising the roof.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 470 words

HEADLINE: Kosovo Strategies

 BODY:
Like President Kennedy's naval quarantine of Cuba during the 1962 missile crisis, NATO's planned embargo on oil shipments to Serbia is not called a blockade by diplomats, for fear that term of war could widen the conflict. But the intent is clear -- use a naval armada in the Adriatic Sea to deny Slobodan Milosevic's forces the fuel they need to operate in Kosovo. If executed with a healthy regard for Russian sensibilities, it can sap Serbian strength and speed the way to a political settlement.
As the war in Yugoslavia enters its second month, NATO is searching for a combination of force and diplomacy that will induce Mr. Milosevic to reach for a peace deal. Last weekend's NATO summit meeting in Washington endorsed several potentially productive steps in that direction, including the naval action, intensification of the air war and a subtle but significant shift in the alliance's conditions for a cease-fire. All of these can support a critical round of diplomacy that will begin today in Moscow, where Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott will meet with Russian leaders. 
 The interdiction of oil tankers will not cut off petroleum supplies to Serbia. Smugglers will be eager to collect the premium fees that come with running a blockade, and some overland shipments are likely to continue. But after bombing Serbian refineries, it would be a mistake not to try to limit the flow of oil through Yugoslav ports.
Russia has been sending oil to Serbia, and NATO must work with Moscow to avoid a confrontation with tankers carrying Russian fuel. The alliance cannot afford to provoke military tensions with Russia or drive the Kremlin from the peacemaking role that Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov said yesterday his country is now playing. The best way to avoid either possibility is to persuade the Russians not to send further shipments to Serbia. The subject should be on Mr. Talbott's agenda.
Though Mr. Ivanov made clear in an interview that NATO and Mr. Milosevic remain far apart on peace terms, Mr. Talbott is carrying an important concession from the alliance. NATO is now prepared to suspend bombing when Serbian forces begin to leave Kosovo, rather than waiting for a withdrawal to be completed. NATO also signaled some flexibility over the weekend about the composition and command of an international peacekeeping force in Kosovo, saying it would seek a United Nations Security Council mandate for the troops. That would require Russian assent.
It is unfortunate that the NATO meeting dodged whether to start assembling ground forces in the Balkans to keep open the option of a land campaign. The additional pressure might help move Mr. Milosevic. For now, the best strategy is to press ahead with bombing, organize the blockade and be imaginative in the pursuit of diplomacy.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Joseph R. Gregory

 BODY:

ASIA
 
CHINA: TRADE MEMBERSHIP TALKS -- China and the U.S. extended talks in Beijing over China's proposed entry into the World Trade Organization. Working to preserve momentum that almost sealed a deal during Prime Minister Zhu Rongji's trip to the U.S. earlier this month, American negotiators delayed a scheduled departure on Sunday and met again yesterday. The organization's Director-General, Renato Ruggiero, said he believed that China would join before November. Seth Faison (NYT)
 
CHINA: DISSIDENT ON TRIAL -- A prominent dissident, Fang Jue, went on trial on fraud charges that human rights organizations say were fabricated. The trial, delayed so it would not coincide with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji's American trip, went into recess after four hours. Mr. Fang, 44, was arrested after he called for elections at all levels of government. Seth Faison (NYT) 

THE PHILIPPINES: PEACE TALKS REJECTED -- Communist rebels rejected an offer by President Joseph Estrada to resume talks following the release of the last of five hostages the rebels had been holding since February. A rebel spokesman said conditions demanded by the President showed that he was not sincere about negotiations. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
SOUTH KOREA: SUBWAY STRIKE ENDS -- Subway workers in Seoul ended an eight-day strike called to protest layoffs, even though the Government met none of their demands. The development dealt a serious blow to plans by the militant Korean Confederation of Trade Unions to escalate protests over layoffs in bloated private and Government-owned industries. (AP)

THE AMERICAS
 
VENEZUELA: PRESIDENT'S POWER EXPANDED -- President Hugo Chavez approved a special "enabling law" that will allow him to rule by decree on economic and social matters for the next six months. He had rejected an earlier version of the bill three weeks ago, saying it imposed too many restrictions on him, and then threatened to dissolve Congress if it did not make the revisions he wanted. The new, more sweeping version of the law also raises the value-added tax and places a new levy on financial transactions. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
MEXICO: FIGHTING OVER LICENSE PLATES -- Gov. Patricio Martinez of Chihuahua is locked in a battle with federal authorities over the provisional license plates his government has issued to thousands of automobiles imported illegally from the United States. Treasury officials fear that the provisional plates extend a measure of legality to the illegal cars and encourage smugglers to import more vehicles without paying taxes. Mr. Martinez, who is from President Ernesto Zedillo's governing party, says federal authorities do not respect the needs of Mexico's 31 states. Sam Dillon (NYT)

URUGUAY: PRIMARY RESULTS -- The ruling Colorado Party and the country's left-wing opposition leader, Tabare Vazquez, both emerged strengthened by primaries on Sunday to choose presidential candidates for October. More than 37 percent of those who voted in the party primaries took part in the centrist Colorado Party's contest, which was won by Sen. Jorge Batlle, according to Interior Ministry figures. Another 30.5 percent voted in the leftist Progressive Encounter primary, which was won easily by Mr. Vazquez, a former Mayor of Montevideo. (Reuters)
 
ARGENTINA: SEEKING NAZI GOLD -- A panel investigating Argentina's links to Nazi Germany said it believed that it has proof that the country's central bank held Nazi gold after World War II. Peron, in which Mr. Bramuglia said he asked Swiss officials in 1946 to deposit gold they had held for the German Embassy in the central bank. Mr. Klich said the letter did not specify the amount. HEADLINE: Time Warner To Shut Down Its Pathfinder Site on the Web

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
In a move that symbolizes a passage from the early experimental era of the World Wide Web to a mature publishing platform, Time Warner will shut down Pathfinder, its pioneering outpost in cyberspace.
During the last five years the company's Time Inc. unit has lumped together all of its magazines, including Time, Fortune, Money and Entertainment Weekly, in Pathfinder, a single, huge Web site. 
 The site will be phased out over the next six months, to be replaced by so-called hub sites that combine related magazines, features and links with the Web sites of other Time Warner properties like CNN, CNNfn and other information and entertainment properties. Each new hub will go after a more precisely targeted audience.
The magazines will retain their individual home pages.
"This is an evolution, and it follows the way consumers have been using our sites," said Jeffrey Coomes, vice president of marketing at Time Inc. New Media. Mr. Coomes said that the decision to dismantle Pathfinder was based on the fact that most consumers went directly to the individual magazine sites and skipped the Pathfinder home page, and that the move was part of a long-term strategy. "Now we're working on promoting individual brands, like Time.com and Fortune.com, and their features and functions," Mr. Coomes said.
But the move, first reported yesterday on CNET's News.com Web site, comes late, industry analysts said. Lisa Allen, a senior analyst at Forrester Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass., said that Pathfinder's demise was about two years overdue.
"It's about time," she said. "It is repurposed print content on line, and that just doesn't work. The success of a site like Pathfinder is about creating a specific on-line entity. It doesn't mean throwing up a group of magazines on one home page and having people drill down to the magazines."
Founded in 1994, Pathfinder was one of the first corporate sites to open on the Web. But it was dogged by problems, from the merely technical -- such as the initial lengthy download time that users found frustrating, and a cluttered layout -- to the problems of a constantly shifting management.
Like any pioneer, Pathfinder bore a number of scars as the first major publisher to face issues like intellectual property rights in a free-for-all medium and the gamble of offering content from print publications on line at the risk of hurting newsstand and subscription sales.
In 1997, Pathfinder underwent a flurry of changes in management and focus when it named as president Linda McCutcheon, a Time Inc. vice president for sales and marketing. Ms. McCutcheon resigned earlier this month.
Time Warner spent more than than $15 million a year in developing the site, according to a former staff member. It was unclear how much, if any, of that investment was recouped. No one at Time Inc. would comment on the costs or cash flow, said Graham Cannon, a spokesman for Time Inc. New Media.
Mark Mooradian, a senior analyst at Jupiter Communications, said Pathfinder had made a number of missteps.
"One of them was burying all those wonderful consumer brands like Time magazine and Fortune magazine under the U.R.L. Pathfinder," he said, referring to the Web address pathfinder.com. "That was a terrible mistake, because people had to learn what Pathfinder was."
The bright side, he said, was that the demise of Pathfinder "is paving the path for much more editorial control and the empowerment of the individual properties."
One way in which that individual empowerment may come about is through electronic commerce. Most of the success on the Web is attributed to sites that offer a combination of content and commerce -- for example, when a user can read about the new Britney Spears CD on the Teen People Web site, then click on a picture of the album cover and purchase it.
To that end, Time Warner announced in January the formation of Time Warner E-Commerce to consolidate the company's current direct-marketing efforts on the Web and introduce other programs.
Michael Pepe, the former president of the Time Inc. Business Information Group -- which includes Fortune, Money, Your Company and Mutual Funds magazine -- was named president of the E-commerce unit. At the time, Mr. Pepe said he expected the magazine group's growth in E-commerce to be big. "We're beginning to create parallel, complementary Web sites for our magazines that will provide new ways to talk to our consumers," he said.
The Web audience, Ms. Allen of Forrester Research said, has "a different set of expectations: they look for utility and convenience and savings, as well as content." She said that Time Warner had recognized that the old publishing model of magazines was different on the Web.
"On-line publishing blends content and commerce increasingly, as if the old lines between editorial and advertising are disappearing," she said.

HEADLINE: Border War Over the Peace Bridge

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, April 22

 BODY:
Since the days of Prohibition, the Peace Bridge has been the infrastructural equivalent of a warm handshake between Canada and the United States: an economic, recreational and cultural lifeline for people on both sides of the Niagara River.
Because of the bridge, Canadians do not think twice about crossing over to Buffalo Sabres hockey games or buying winter homes in the Cattaraugus Mountains. Americans routinely hop over to Toronto for dinner, and stay in summer cottages on the Canadian side of Lake Erie. 
 Indeed, people here probably see the other side as less of a foreign country than, say, some Manhattanites view New Jersey or Queens.
But these days, there is anything but peace at the Peace Bridge.
The bridge, a 3,600-foot steel truss built in 1927, is past its prime, barely adequate for the traffic that has surged in recent years at the crossing, where the wait can exceed an hour and a half on summer days.
The Canadians are pushing to build a three-lane bridge next to the existing one, a mirror-image "twin span" that they say would honor history and symbolize American-Canadian friendship. The Americans, though, want to demolish the old bridge and build a six-lane structure that they envision as so impressive that they are calling it a "signature bridge."
The clash over the Peace Bridge is not just a battle of function versus form, engineering versus esthetics. It has become a political football in Ottawa and Washington, with Canadian officials accusing the Americans of Manifest Destiny arrogance, and American officials dismissing the Canadians as parochial.
"It's not an American bridge; it's an international bridge," sighed John D. Maloney, who represents the Fort Erie district in the Canadian Parliament. "The Canadian interests and desires appear to be ignored. It's very disappointing, and quite frankly, very difficult to believe that this could be happening."
To which James W. Pitts, president of Buffalo's Common Council, sniffed, "I think the problem now is that they're trying to make this an international incident, when in fact it's nothing more than sitting down rationally and trying to do something better for both sides, and create a new symbol with binational cooperation."
More than just political bickering, though, the clash has been transformed into a fight of millennial magnitude -- a fight over how to build the best bridge for, well, the 21st century.
The new bridge, quite simply, is the biggest project to come down the pike in many years, a huge public works endeavor that could cost $90 million and take more than six years.
The fear, on the Canadian side, is that diplomatic squabbling may delay other economic projects. But the hope, on the American side, is that the authorities do the right thing -- finally -- for a city and a region that have long been mired in self-doubt and economic quicksand.
"While nobody thinks that a bridge will revitalize a city, public symbols are important, especially here, because a lot of people feel beat up," said Bruce Jackson, a professor of American culture at the State University of New York at Buffalo.
The debate is now at a crucial stage. With the support of the Buffalo and Fort Erie Public Bridge Authority, the quasi-public binational authority that operates the bridge, Canadian officials have approved all of the requisite permits to begin work on the twin-bridge proposal. All that remains is a decision by the United States Coast Guard on whether the project has any negative impact on the Niagara River.
But already, Buffalo's Mayor, Anthony M. Masiello, has threatened to sue if the Coast Guard approves the permit. And with the exception of Gov. George E. Pataki, who has sidestepped the issue, all of New York's major politicians, including Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Charles E. Schumer and Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, have thrown their weight behind the signature bridge.
There is, however, one point of agreement: something must be done to improve the flow of traffic on the existing bridge, which resembles, with its dollar-green paint and asymmetrical truss, a scaly aquatic monster burrowing into the American side.
Encouraged in large part by the North American Free Trade Agreement, commercial traffic via the Peace Bridge has skyrocketed in recent years. In 1991, $23 billion worth of goods passed through; now, the annual figure is $40 billion to $45 billion, said Stephen F. Mayer, the bridge's operations manager on the American side.
The number of commercial trucks, meanwhile, continues to break records with as much nonchalant regularity as the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Last year, 1.381 million commercial vehicles crossed the Peace Bridge, up 62 percent from 1991.
Yet for years, truckers, commuters and vacationing motorists have complained about the lack of customs agents and immigration officials at the border, creating bottlenecks that are especially pronounced during the summer.
So in the early 1990's, the bridge authority began studying options for a new bridge.
"The approach was, 'What are the options that allow us to avoid impacts?' " said Deborah J. Chadsey, an American lawyer for the bridge authority. "Don't disrupt the lake. Don't disturb the archeologically sensitive areas. Don't move the footprint."
For a while, it seemed that the twin bridge, combined with a plan to renovate the existing one, would be a fait accompli: the authority's 10-member board of directors, comprising five Canadians and five Americans, all political appointees, unanimously approved the project, which would be financed by bonds, not taxes.
But at the latter stages of the process, particularly after the winning bid came in at $90 million, much higher than previously projected, public opinion on the American side began to shift from indifference to indignation, led by Mr. Pitts of the Common Council, Senator Moynihan and a citizens' group of mostly young professionals in Buffalo called the New Millennium Group.
They said the bridge authority did not make the process as open as it should have been for so monumental a project. Then, as an alternative, they unveiled a concrete cable-stayed bridge, in which cables flare out from a central tower, sketched by the noted bridge designers Bruno Freschi and T. Y. Lin, that they said would be better, cheaper and faster to build than the authority's $90 million twin bridge.
If adopted, their bridge plan would restore land to a Frederick Law Olmsted park along the waterfront and help revitalize a downtown that is now a shell of its proud industrial past, said Bill Banas, 28, a software engineer who is the group's director.
Their bridge, they believe, would also help convince outsiders that the city is not just a dumping ground for blizzards and the birthplace of chicken wings, but also a culturally vibrant place with a fine natural harbor and architectural feats by Wright, Sullivan and Richardson.
It has become so personal, so emotional, an issue that some people are saying they will take their civic energy elsewhere should the twin bridge be hatched.
"If they build that ugly, mismatched companion bridge, we're going to spend the next 100 years apologizing for it," said Jeff Belt, 36, an entrepreneur who lived and worked all over the world before returning last year to Buffalo, his hometown. "That's why so many of us say, if this thing comes to pass, we're going to leave. We're not going to bear with the heartbreak, again."
The bridge authority itself was until recently a relatively anonymous entity best known for collecting tolls ($2 for cars; an average of $10 to $12 per truck) and plotting small-bore projects (repaving the bridge; repainting the bridge).
In an interview, bridge authorities vigorously defended the twin structure, saying they had studied about a dozen options, catalogued all the environmental permutations and spent more than $10 million in the process.
Their mandate, they said repeatedly, was to collect tolls as efficiently as possible to compete with the top border crossing, Detroit and Windsor, Ontario. It was, Mr. Mayer said, asking perhaps just a tad too much of the authority to "hang the economic rejuvenation and renaissance of Buffalo on the appearance of this bridge."
Or, as Roderick H. McDowell, a Canadian board member and a lawyer, framed it: "We're responsible for assuring a safe, economical conduit of public transportation. Cinderella's castle won't work here."
But even on the bridge authority, there are signs of strain. In a recent vote on whether to delay the project for further study, the tally was a 5-to-5 split along national lines, with the Americans saying yes to the delay and the Canadians saying no.
There are few signs that the issue will fade any time soon. In Fort Erie, almost every person interviewed seemed to be reading from the same script, saying that it was most important to "get on with it," that their American counterparts were acting selfishly.
The twin bridge, the Canadians added, could be built more quickly, pumping life into Fort Erie's sagging economy and attracting more Americans to a planned casino at the Fort Erie race track. It would also preserve a beloved symbol.
"The Peace Bridge in Fort Erie is significant because many of us grew up in the shadow of the bridge," said Wayne H. Redekop, the Mayor of Fort Erie, population 28,000. "For many of the people in Buffalo, the Peace Bridge has no real emotional connotation. For them to suggest, 'Well, just tear it down,' doesn't respond to the sensitivities on this side of Buffalo. For them, Fort Erie is an afterthought."
In Buffalo, meanwhile, almost every person interviewed endorsed the signature bridge. Some even pulled out postcards printed from the New Millennium Group's Web site -- with its striking computer-generated image of Tampa's Sunshine Skyway Bridge superimposed over the Buffalo skyline -- as a possible vision of the future.
But the fact that Canadians are not seeing things their way remains a source of bewilderment and bitterness.
"When people are frustrated, they look for a bad guy," said Mr. Jackson of the University of Buffalo, speaking, of course, about the American perspective. "So all of a sudden, Canada became the bad guy to people."

HEADLINE: U.S. Tells Global Partners That It Can't Be Sole Engine of Growth

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
The United States told Germany and Japan today that the world economy could not run for long on only one engine: an American economy that keeps expanding as Europe slows and Tokyo prays that a seven-year recession is ending.
But after a daylong meeting of the finance ministers and central bankers of the world's seven largest industrialized economies, it became clear that even two years of global financial turmoil had done little to forge a consensus about reviving economic growth. In fact, several participants in the meetings described the return of an atmosphere of calm about the state of the world economy, a calm that one official said "might make you think we had not just been through a devastating world economic crisis." 
 Most of the meetings were filled with talk of a modest agenda of changes for the International Monetary Fund and its member states, mostly requiring greater disclosure by countries about their finances, in hopes of preventing the kinds of surprises that fueled the Asian economic crisis.
But there was no urgent talk, as there was six months ago, about the risks of deflation. European officials offered no new agenda for turning around a slowdown that has already led to a slide in the value of the new European currency, the euro. And a clear divide emerged between the United States and Japan over whether Tokyo had already done enough.
No sooner had the Group of Seven nations issued their traditional communique this afternoon than Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his Japanese counterpart, Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, began to interpret the deliberately vague wording about Japan's economic strategy in strikingly different terms.
The communique, agreed upon by all of the nations well before the start of today's meeting, stated that Japan should "implement stimulus measures until growth is restored, using all available tools to support strong domestic-demand-led growth." Mr. Miyazawa, a former Prime Minister and one of Tokyo's canniest politicians, told a news conference here this evening that the wording "has nothing to do with anything new." It should not be read to suggest, he said, that Japan was ready to take further steps to stimulate its economy. The I.M.F. predicts that Japan's gross national product will shrink 1.4 percent this year, while the Japanese Government officially says that there will be modest growth.
Mr. Rubin appeared to have a different view from that of Mr. Miyazawa. Speaking at the Treasury, he insisted that the communique, in his interpretation, committed Japan to "continue to take important measures" until "solid, domestic-demand-led growth is resolved."
There is an enormous political gap laid bare by their statements. Mr. Miyazawa knows that the Government of Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, who visits here next week, has no political capital left to persuade Japanese lawmakers to spend more on stimulating the economy and bailing out failed banks. But Mr. Rubin has repeatedly said that the United States cannot continue to soak up exports from Japan and the rest of Asia, sending the American trade deficit soaring.
"This is not indefinitely sustainable economically," Mr. Rubin said today, "and certainly not politically." He referred to the divergent positions as a "slight difference of emphasis." But it was a difference that had been kept well below the surface for nearly a year.
Throughout 1997 and the first half of 1998 Mr. Rubin rarely missed an opportunity to criticize Japan's slowness to react to its troubles, despite overwhelming evidence that the country's recession was worsening the angst in Asia. But after the Japanese protested that he was undercutting confidence, Mr. Rubin muted those comments and often praised Prime Minister Obuchi for pushing through bailouts of Japanese banks.
But the fear now is that Japan is not ready with a second phase of measures if the first run out of steam. That is what happened three years ago, when Japan briefly showed signs of recovery only to fall into its deepest recession since the end of World War II.
Japan, though, was hardly the only shrinking economy that commanded the group's attentions today.
The finance ministers stopped well short of publicly endorsing new loans to Russia to keep the country from defaulting in coming months. Nonetheless, officials say they expect a $4.2 billion loan will be delivered by June, the first aid to Russia since it devalued its currency and President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed an economic reform team last August.
In their communique, the ministers said that they remained "concerned about the country's ongoing financial and macroeconomic instability," and, in the typically understated wording of such documents, urged Russia to adopt "a credible economic program." But Mr. Rubin clearly remains skeptical about the ability of Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov to deliver on Russia's commitments.
"Assuming that the actions agreed to are real," Mr. Rubin said, referring to Russia's promises to the I.M.F. to rein in its government spending, "then I think that would be a substantial fiscal accomplishment." But he quickly warned that "agreement is one thing; implementation is another," a clear reference to Russia's past promises.
Mr. Rubin said that the ministers spent very little time discussing exchange rates. There was some discussion of the economic impact of the air war in Kosovo, but no agreement on how the cost of rebuilding the region might be shared. Most of the session was devoted to questions of increased financial disclosure, with hints that all the countries would soon adopt new rules regarding hedge funds, the huge pools of money that some blame for accelerating the Asian crisis and the flight of cash from Russia and Brazil.

HEADLINE: Power Plants Lure Investors, And Critics

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
For the first time in more than two decades, companies are asking permission to build large power plants in New York City and the Hudson River Valley, all spurred by the deregulation of the electric power industry.
Eight proposals have been filed with the New York State Public Service Commission since August. They include plans for a 520-megawatt, 800-foot-long floating power plant to be moored along the waterfront in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, two separate 1,100-megawatt plants in Ramapo, in Rockland County, and -- furthest along -- a 1,080-megawatt plant in Athens, 30 miles south of Albany. 
 A 1,000-megawatt plant produces roughly enough power for one million small homes. The plants, to be built with money from private investors instead of ratepayers, are projected to cost from $350 million to $500 million each.
Proponents say the plants would cut power bills by increasing supplies of electricity and generating it more efficiently, fueled by natural gas, which produces little pollution, instead of oil or coal, the dirtier fuels burned at the state's older plants.
But opponents of the Hudson Valley plants say the power is not needed, the giant structures would mar the landscape, and cooling systems would threaten water supplies and fish in the river.
At the same time, as part of the statewide restructuring of the industry over the past few years, existing older power plants are being sold by utilities like Consolidated Edison Company and Central Hudson Gas & Electric to independent companies that plan to compete with the new plants.
Some environmental groups say that by modernizing or expanding the existing plants, the air and water would be protected without pocking the horizon with new smokestacks and steam plumes.
All this activity is part of a broader effort to encourage competition in an industry dominated by local monopolies for a century. While little competition has been seen so far in New York in the retail end of the business -- the companies that sell power directly to homes and businesses -- the proposals for new power plants indicate that at the wholesale end, some companies feel there is money to be made.
"While not trying to pre-decide the environmental issues involved in some of these sites, I think having eight plants here with applications to build is very good news for customers," said Frank Herbert, the director of the office overseeing the restructuring of the power industry in the state's Department of Public Service.
There are similar flurries of proposals for new plants in New England, Texas, California and other areas with big electricity markets and lagging supplies. The Public Service Commission opened the wholesale power market in New York state to competition in 1996.
New York's new plants could eventually offer consumers the ability to choose a power source based on considerations besides cost -- for example, buying power generated with the least pollution, a choice already available in California.
But there is no consensus on whether the new plants would lead to lower prices or less pollution.
"It's kind of a wild West out there," said Mark Stultz, a spokesman for the Electric Power Supply Association, a private group in Washington representing independent power-producing companies. "All these guys are gambling they can do it best."
Some of the confusion stems from new questions about a state power plant siting board created by the State Legislature in 1992 to streamline the process of seeking permits.
In February, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency ruled that the state board lacked the authority to issue permits for discharges to the air and water. New state legislation will probably be needed to fix the problem, environmental experts and state officials say.
In the meantime, the first proposal under consideration is by US Generating Company, an arm of Pacific Gas & Electric, to build a plant powered by natural gas in Athens. The site was chosen, company officials say, because it lies at the confluence of the Iroquois gas pipeline, the river, and power lines that can carry electricity to New York City, New England, and other power-hungry markets.
A series of state hearings on the proposal ended earlier this month, and two "examiners" -- state officials assessing the plans -- are to issue a recommendation to the siting board this summer. By law, a vote of the board, an arm of the Department of Public Service, must follow by October.
The final decision is largely controlled by Gov. George E. Pataki, who appointed the four state agency commissioners who sit on the six-person board for each application. (The other two board members come from local governments, and are also appointed by Mr. Pataki.) The decision on the Athens plant is bound to be a particularly sticky one, given Governor Pataki's eagerness to spur economic growth and his strong ties to scenic and environmental preservationists in the Hudson Valley.
The plant is supported by most elected officials in Greene County, who say it would be in a lot zoned for industrial use and would generate taxes and jobs. It is opposed by private historic preservation and environmental groups, who say it would ruin the view from several parks and historic homes across the river in Columbia County.
One view that would be affected is that from Olana, the ornate Moorish mansion built by Frederic E. Church, a 19th century artist whose work epitomized the Hudson River School of landscape painting.
Citing the proximity of the plant to the state-owned mansion, the State Parks Commissioner, Bernadette Castro, wrote a letter in February to the Public Service Commission opposing the plan.
The company says the plant, set back two miles from the Hudson, would be largely hidden from view and many times cleaner than nearby oil-fired plants. The plume of steam from its cooling systems would be limited with special equipment, said Daniel J. Whyte, the director of government relations in the Northeast for US Generating.
He said the plant would help improve both the river and the air. Niagara Mohawk, a power company with older plants nearby, projects that it would have to reduce the amount of power generated at its plants because of the cheaper power coming from the new competitor. Earlier this month, the finding was used at the hearings on the proposal to show that building the plant would help cut air pollution.
Mr. Whyte said the proposed plant also would use 150 times less cooling water per kilowatt than neighboring older plants, meaning that it would result in far fewer fish being sucked into equipment and killed.
Scenic Hudson and Riverkeeper Inc., two environmental groups, dispute the predictions of cuts in pollution and say the plant has the right technology, but is planned for the wrong place.
Theresa Rose Hanczor, a lawyer for Riverkeeper, said that in the new free market for electricity there was no way to predict how the arrival of a cleaner power plant would affect decisions at neighboring older power plants.
The result could be that demand for power would be high enough that all the plants would keep running, she said. "In the case of Athens, then, you've got this plant in a prime shad-spawning and nursery grounds," she said. "Once it's there, it's there for good and the area is degraded forever."
Ms. Hanczor and other critics also say that the state's process for deciding whether to permit new power plants moves too quickly and does not provide enough scrutiny of proposals.
Company officials expressed frustration with the continued opposition on environmental grounds.
"If there's not a problem with the air and not a problem with the fish, you've got to find a problem," Mr. Whyte said of the environmental groups.
Earlier this month, the state examiners viewed the proposed plant site from the grounds of Olana. Daniel P. O'Connell, the associate examiner, marveled at the sweeping panorama from the mansion.
"It's clearly the most gorgeous view of the Hudson Valley," he said, but quickly added that this in no way meant he had made up his mind: "We'll have to wait and see until all the comments are in."
The idea of a floating plant on the Brooklyn waterfront is so new that it has not become an issue yet. It is being developed by Sunset Energy Inc., a Manhattan company that is also building a small gas-fired plant at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
The decision to put the power plant on huge barges was easy, said Jerry Montrose, chairman and chief executive officer of Sunset Energy. There are simply no tracts of industrially zoned land inside the city big enough to house a plant, he said.
The Sunset Park site is also important, Mr. Montrose added, because it would supply electricity to a part of Brooklyn that is starved for electricity because of limited transmission lines.
Officials at companies that are buying some of the old power plants say they should not be counted out in the race to sell power.
Why pay for something flashy and new if a well-maintained but older alternative gets you where you are going, said David Mould, a spokesman for Southern Energy Inc., an Atlanta-based power producing company.
For around $480 million, Southern Energy is buying a group of old Hudson Valley power plants totaling 1,776 megawatts in generating capacity from Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc. -- a cheaper investment for more power than the money proposed for the new gas-powered plants in the region.
The company is going to spend $390 million at the existing sites to increase efficiency, cut pollution and add more natural-gas generators, Mr. Mould said.
He would not predict which strategy would win, saying that they were all experimental.
"They're different paths to the same end," Mr. Mould said. "Price will drive everything."

Clinton Cautions Arafat
President Clinton warned Yasir Arafat against declaring Palestinian statehood next week, but he edged toward support for eventual independence for the Palestinian people. The President also set a one-year target date for completion of Israeli-Palestinian negotiations. A8
 
Indian Parliament Disbanded
President K. R. Narayanan dissolved the lower house of Parliament, making way for India's third general election in three years. The election, which has not been scheduled, must take place within six months. A14
 
World Bank Poverty Warning
A World Bank report warned that a generation of improvements in the plight of the poor was in danger of stalling. It also said it was becoming increasingly difficult to meet goals set for 2015 at a series of United Nations conferences. A14
 
BBC Host Is Found Slain

NATIONAL A16-21
 
Police Say Gunman's Diary Envisioned Wider Mayhem
Police investigators in Littleton, Colo., said a diary kept by one of the two gunmen who killed 13 people and themselves at Columbine High School included visions of killing 500 students, attacking neighboring homes and hijacking a plane and crashing it in New York City. Detectives questioned an 18-year-old girlfriend of one of the gunmen in an effort to determine her link, if any, to a pistol found at the scene and whether anyone knew of the plot. Funerals were held for 4 of the 13 victims. Toxicology tests on the bodies of the gunmen did not show evidence of drugs or alcohol, officials said. A1
 
President Clinton plans to announce a package of gun-control proposals today. They will include measures to halt the importation of clips that allow assault weapons to fire more than 10 shots at once and to charge parents with a felony if their children commit crimes with guns. A20
 
Court Enters Tobacco Fray
The Supreme Court said it would decide whether the F.D.A. has authority to regulate tobacco products as drugs and cigarettes as "drug delivery devices." The Clinton Administration is appealing a lower-court ruling striking down extensive F.D.A. regulations issued in 1996. A18
 
Weight-Loss Drug Approved
The F.D.A. approved orlistat, the first in a new class of anti-obesity drugs that work by blocking the body's absorption of dietary fat, as opposed to tricking the brain into ignoring hunger. The drug is intended for use by obese people or overweight people with certain other health problems. A1
 
More Delay for New Air Radar
The F.A.A. said a new traffic control system for lower-altitude aircraft, already several months behind schedule, still could not run fast enough to serve in busy environments. The agency's existing screens are so old, with spare parts scarce, that the F.A.A. had been trying to rush the new equipment into service in busy radar centers serving New York City, Washington and Dallas-Fort Worth. A19
 
New Fishing Restrictions
The National Marine Fisheries Service unveiled new fishing restrictions for the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts to try to rebuild stocks of shark, Atlantic tuna and marlin. Conservationists said the measures, which take effect on June 1, were insufficient to stem the severe decline of swordfish. A18

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
Tagliabue Fakes Out the Patriots

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
From November through last week, the National Football League did nothing publicly to upset the proposition that the New England Patriots would move from the team's creaky old home in Foxboro, Mass., to a $375 million stadium in Hartford that would be fully subsidized by Connecticut taxpayers.
But on Friday, Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner, met in Boston with Massachusetts business leaders, now energized by the urgency of the Patriots' situation. Tagliabue said he wanted to take a look at how the team might remain in Foxboro, in a new $225 million stadium paid for by the league and the team, with up to $75 million being provided by Massachusetts for roads, exit ramps and parking lots. 
 What a fancy stutter-step executed by the commissioner, letting Hartford think it had snagged the Patriots with a giveaway so rich that it made sweetheart deals nationwide seem modest by comparison. In fact, the timing of Tagliabue's trip to Boston seems calculated to stir up a crisis: on the day of his visit, the Patriots filed an official application to move to Hartford, which owners will consider at N.F.L. meetings in Atlanta on May 25 and 26. Approval of the move requires a yes vote from three-quarters of the 32 owners.
By resurrecting Foxboro as an option, the league has set the stage for the possible undoing of a signed agreement between Robert K. Kraft, the Patriots' owner, and the State of Connecticut.
"When the league makes its presentation about the Patriots to the owners, we have to be able to say that we've explored every alternative in Massachusetts," said Joe Browne, a league spokesman. "We have to be able to tell owners, even if they don't like it, that there is no option but Hartford. We're doing what the owners authorized us to do."
The league did not consult Kraft about Foxboro, Browne said. "Kraft can't talk about anything but Connecticut," Browne explained. "He has an agreement."
Kraft can escape his Connecticut deal if he does not sign a site status report by Sunday. But Dean Pagani, a spokesman for Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, said, "We've been assured it's not an out option."
Kraft surely knows what is cooking in Massachusetts, but how can he not have developed a deep affection for Connecticut, which presented him with a deal he never asked for but would have been crazy to reject? In an era of whopping government subsidies for privately owned teams, Kraft won the lottery.
Except that now, maybe he hasn't, because the N.F.L., after focusing on the still unfinished Washington Redskins sale and the potential placement of a new franchise in Los Angeles, has clearly lost its shyness about intervening in the Patriots' move. What happened?
Blame it on Dan Rooney, the Pittsburgh Steelers' owner. Last December, Rooney and Paul Kirk Jr., the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, were at a reception honoring the Irish winners of the 1998 Nobel Peace Prize. They spoke about "what a tragedy it would be if the Patriots left the area," Rooney said.
"I said it didn't look like anybody was doing anything," he added, "and Paul said it looked like a foregone conclusion that they're gone. I said, 'They still have to take it to the league.' Paul took it from there."
Browne said, "Kirk had a job to do to gauge enthusiasm and to question whether the Patriots' move to Connecticut was a bluff or not."
Kirk knew Tagliabue and once worked with him on antitrust legislation. Kirk assembled a group of business leaders who went public with their Foxboro plan on April 16, after which Tagliabue's public enlistment was made possible.
"It made very clear our seriousness of purpose," Kirk said. "Many people feel it's very helpful if the N.F.L. commissioner says what he hears is good. The timing of his visit was great. I feel it made a big difference."
But there would be a difference between how much richer Kraft would get in Hartford than in Foxboro. "We're not coming up with a plan with the same economic benefits for the owner," Kirk said.
You never know what owners will do at an owners' meeting. Will they vote for what Kraft wants, which is Hartford? Will Kraft, a league insider and chairman of its finance committee, surrender his fight for Hartford if Tagliabue twists arms to consider Foxboro? Are owners truly fearful of losing another large-market team, after losing teams in Los Angeles and Houston?
Rooney showed little awkwardness in having laid the early groundwork that might undo the Patriots' deal in Hartford. "I'm not saying it's easy, but we have to do the right thing and what's in the best interest of the N.F.L. and our television partners," he said.
With 2.2 million television households, Boston is the sixth-largest television market in the United States. Hartford, the 27th-largest market, has 909,930 TV homes.
Tagliabue's Boston visit fostered a public-perception problem for Hartford, not a real one, Pagani said. The burst of positive talk in Massachusetts is no different from what Kraft heard in the past, Pagani said, while there is legislation and site preparation going on in Hartford. "Our deal hasn't changed," he said. "In Massachusetts, it's all talk."
But when Tagliabue is the guest emcee of the talk, Hartford cannot feel entirely safe.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;
KREMLIN SAYS NATO AS WELL AS SERBS MUST COMPROMISE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 26

 BODY:
As an American envoy arrived here for talks on Kosovo, Russia's Foreign Minister said today that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia was prepared to make concessions, but that NATO would also have to bend if the conflict was to be brought to an end.
The remarks by the Foreign Minister, Igor S. Ivanov, came a day after President Boris N. Yeltsin telephoned President Clinton about Kosovo, and coincided with the arrival of Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott to pursue the possibilities of Russian mediation. 
 Though Mr. Ivanov, in an hourlong interview, did not proclaim any major breakthrough, he laid down the cooperation that Russia expected from both sides if it was to proceed as interlocutor. With Mr. Milosevic still unbowed after more than a month of intensive bombing, NATO and the United States have been trying to involve Russia, a nation with traditional links to Yugoslavia, in the search for a diplomatic solution.
"We won't serve as a postman," Mr. Ivanov said. "We won't deliver NATO's ultimatums to Belgrade. That is not our mission. If there is an ultimatum from one side and then an ultimatum from the other side, there is no maneuver for negotiation. There should be cooperation on both sides."
Offering a preview of what Mr. Milosevic was prepared to concede, Mr. Ivanov said the Yugoslav leader was ready to reduce his forces in Kosovo to the level they were at in October, before the Serbian military began preparing for its offensive against ethnic Albanians there.
Mr. Ivanov said Mr. Milosevic had also agreed in very general terms to allow an international presence to police a settlement in Kosovo, though crucial details remain to be worked out.
The Foreign Minister acknowledged that the Yugoslav proposals, which were made in recent talks with former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, Russia's special envoy on Kosovo, fell well short of NATO demands.
But he said they represented a starting point for serious discussions on ending the Kosovo conflict, and warned that a political settlement would not be achieved if the Western alliance refused to negotiate on its demands.
The Yugoslav proposals outlined by Mr. Ivanov today suggested that there is still an enormous gap between NATO and Belgrade. Negotiations to bring the fighting to an end appear to be at a very early stage, and it remained far from clear that Russia would prove to be the successful mediator the West is hoping for.
The West's decision to welcome Russia's diplomatic involvement stands in sharp contrast to the 1991 conflict in the Persian Gulf, when Yevgeny M. Primakov's efforts at shuttle diplomacy were regarded by Washington as a meddlesome effort to protect President Saddam Hussein of Iraq from defeat. Mr. Primakov, now Prime Minister, was then the Soviet special envoy to the gulf.
This time, NATO seemed eager to give the Russians a chance.
Mr. Talbott's mission, American officials said, is to learn the details of the proposals Mr. Milosevic made to Mr. Chernomyrdin. It is also, they say, to explain NATO's demands to the Russians so they can continue their mediating role with a better understanding of what the Western alliance can and cannot agree to.
President Jacques Chirac of France telephoned Mr. Yeltsin today and urged him to keep up the political pressure on Yugoslavia, French officials said. The United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, is also scheduled to arrive this week for talks with Russian leaders on Kosovo.
For all the diplomatic movement, nobody denied that NATO and Yugoslavia were far apart. Belgrade's offer to slash it troops is a case in point.
Mr. Ivanov portrayed Mr. Milosevic's readiness to reduce his forces in Kosovo to their October level as a significant concession, hinting that Belgrade might we willing to make still further cuts. According to NATO estimates, Yugoslavia had about 22,500 military and Interior Ministry troops in Kosovo in October, compared with some 40,000 now.
The Yugoslav proposal, however, does not come close to meeting NATO's demands. The alliance has insisted that Yugoslavia withdraw virtually all its forces from Kosovo, saying ethnic Albanian refugees will never return as long as the Serbian units that attacked them remain.
"The idea that those Serb military forces, police or paramilitary units who are responsible for the ethnic cleansing and war crimes in Kosovo can stay is a non-starter," said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman.
The issue of an international force is even more difficult, the Russian official said.
"We started from a position where Belgrade refused to accept any foreign military presence, including a Russian one," Mr. Ivanov said. "After our official talks, Belgrade has officially confirmed its readiness to accept an international presence under the auspices of the United Nations. For now, this question has not gone any further. Talks are under way about its composition and other things, but this work is in progress."
Mr. Ivanov said that Russia was prepared to send peacekeeping troops, but that it would be very difficult for Mr. Milosevic to accept a force that was essentially under NATO's control.
"Put yourself in the place of Yugoslav's leaders," he said. "Would you allow the same people who destroyed your country to carry out the peacekeeping operation?"
In contrast, NATO has insisted that it play the major role in any peacekeeping operation. Thousands of British soldiers are now assembling in Macedonia for that mission, and Britain's Defense Minister has said it is just a matter of time before they are deployed. Lightly armed United Nations peacekeepers, NATO says, will not do.
Mr. Rubin said: "In the absence of a credible military presence, Kosovo refugees cannot come back, and we are determined to create the conditions for them to come back. A force with NATO at its core will provide the magnet for them to return."
Beyond negotiating proposals and tactics, Russia and NATO have issued wildly divergent accounts of how the war is going.
NATO officials have insisted there are signs that political and economic elites in Belgrade have grown unhappy with the war and that the Milosevic Government might crack soon under the strain. Senior British officials have even argued that the air strikes are so punishing that an allied ground force might be able to move into Kosovo in several months against minimal resistance.
Mr. Ivanov, however, insisted that this is a misreading of the situation. He said Moscow had warned alliance officials that its air attacks would plunge the region into chaos and asserted that a ground war would have horrific casualties for both sides.
"We warned that as soon as the bombing started there would be a flow of refugees," Mr. Ivanov said. "It was also clear that the strikes wouldn't undermine Milosevic's position. On the contrary, his position has strengthened."
"And we still warn that if the ground operation begins, it will lead to large casualties, including on the side that carries out this operation," he added. "You should know the history of World War II. There won't be a quick ground operation just as there has not been a quick air operation."
NATO officials argue that they put off air strikes for months as they pursued a diplomatic solution. They say the conflict in Kosovo might have been avoided had Moscow had more leverage over Belgrade and been willing to use what leverage it did possess to induce Mr. Milosevic to agree to the autonomy accord for the Kosovars.
Mr. Ivanov, however, argued that Russia can cajole and press, but not force Mr. Milosevic to agree to a settlement.
"As for whether Russia can persuade Milosevic, I must ask another question: Can the United States persuade the Israeli Government to implement what was signed in Washington in the presence of the United States President," he said.
"Russia has done nothing to bring the situation to what it is today," he added. "Russia is ready, not alone but together with others, to solve this political conflict. Everybody must participate in the process."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE BLOCKADE;
Proposal For Cutoff Inflates Oil Prices

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

 BODY:
NATO's planned oil embargo of Yugoslavia has already created a black market in which Serb-backed buyers pay up to a 50 percent premium for gasoline and other refined products, European petroleum traders and other sources said yesterday.
Although the embargo is not expected to stop the flow of petroleum to Yugoslavia, it has greatly aggravated what was already a grave supply crisis. China, one of Yugoslavia's main providers of fuel and an opponent of NATO's campaign, recently terminated its oil contract with Yugoslavia because of $195 million in delinquent bills. And since practically all of Yugoslavia's refineries have been bombed, it has no use for crude oil and must now import all fuel in refined condition. 
 Russia, which last year supplied 40 percent of Yugoslavia's oil needs, is its only major remaining source of petroleum, said Chris Kushlis, an analyst with PlanEcon Inc., a Washington-based energy consulting firm that monitors Eastern European countries.
Unlike the Chinese, Mr. Kushlis said, the Russians are willing to sell Yugoslavia oil even though the country has not paid $170 million in overdue Russian bills. Traders reached in Europe today said Lukoil, one of the biggest Russian suppliers, has extended new lines of credit to Yugoslavia.
How much fuel the Russians will be able or willing to sell to Yugoslavia remains unclear.
But the embargo, which is expected to be enforced starting this week, means that deliveries by sea could stop.
"I think the biggest volume of smuggled oil will come over land," said Milan Vego, a former Yugoslav naval officer who is a professor in the operations department of the Naval War College in Newport, R.I. "Air power is good for some things, but surveillance of smugglers operating at night is not one of them," he said in a telephone interview.
A Geneva-based banker who extends credits to oil traders said he and other bankers had been contacted in recent days by wealthy Serbs, whom he declined to identify, who are opening letters of credit to finance purchases of petroleum.
Traders in Europe said smuggled petroleum cargo can change hands many times during the course of shipment so it would be difficult to tell where the cargo originated. But they said some of it could easily come from refineries in countries that have pledged to honor the embargo, including the United States.
Some traders said they had already seen evidence that buyers acting on behalf of Yugoslavia are purchasing refined petroleum at prices 20 percent to 50 percent higher than the market price.
"Anytime you have an embargo, you have a lucrative business," said the president of a middle-sized oil trading firm in London, which until last week was involved in selling to Yugoslavia. "All you can do is make it expensive to get the stuff."
This executive, who did not want to be identified because of the subject's sensitivity, said: "There are a lot of Yugoslavs among traders who have been doing this for a long time and they are everywhere in Europe. They are very good at it, particularly now that their mission is to get the oil at any cost."
Besides Russia, Yugoslavia has purchased oil from Croatia, Bulgaria, Libya and Romania. Yugoslavia had produced 20,000 barrels of oil a day at home, equivalent to a third of its daily consumption in normal times.
The NATO embargo was not a surprise to Yugoslavia, which had already taken measures to squirrel away supplies of refined petroleum for its tanks, armored vehicles and transportation system.
"Remember, the Serbs were among those who built many of Saddam Hussein's deepest underground bunkers and storage facilities," said another London-based oil-trading industry executive who has done extensive business with Yugoslavia.
By all accounts, Greece remains the weakest link in the NATO alliance. There is is great sympathy for the Serb cause in Greece, which has one of the biggest tanker fleets in the world. Although the embargo could stop them from supplying Yugoslavia by sea, traders said, it was likely that at least some Greek vessels could be the conduits for smuggled oil that eventually makes it into Yugoslavia.
"I think it would very difficult to supply them with enough oil to run the economy," said Andrew Avramides, an independent London-based oil consultant with extensive experience in the Balkan region. "But a small tanker here and a few trucks there will keep the army going if the will to fight can be maintained, which is a big if."

HEADLINE: New York's Vital Patches of Green

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was wrong to reject the Trust for Public Land's recent offer to buy more than 100 community gardens in New York City and to establish a permanent land trust for them (news article, April 23). In a city that is woefully lacking in neighborhood open space, these community gardens offer a welcome relief.
The Mayor mistakenly believes that the city would reap enormous economic benefits from auctioning these sites to the highest bidder. Unfortunately, history shows that most of the auctioned sites will end up as parking lots, storage sites for construction debris and other things unlikely to make money for the city. 
 A recent study by the Brooklyn Borough President's Office found that of the more than 400 sites auctioned in Brooklyn from 1990 to 1995, only six were being used for housing.
 
RICHARD KASSEL
New York, April 23, 1999
 
The writer is a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Fitch Agency Raises Malaysia's Credit Rating

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Malaysia's sovereign credit rating was raised to investment grade yesterday by Fitch IBCA Inc. The action may accelerate the nation's plans to sell $2 billion in bonds to recapitalize its banks and expand its economy. Fitch, a New York-based credit rating company, raised the rating two notches, to BBB-, the lowest investment grade, from BB, just below investment grade. It said Malaysia's widening current account surplus had bolstered foreign reserves. 
 Fitch also said that it might raise Thailand's rating to investment grade and raise South Korea's rating, which is already investment grade. Higher ratings make it less expensive for countries to borrow overseas.

HEADLINE: A Concert On the Web For Poverty

BYLINE: By KATHRYN SHATTUCK 

 BODY:
The organizers of two benefit-concert extravaganzas, "Live Aid" and "Farm Aid," are turning to the Internet for their latest fund-raising effort: three simultaneous benefits to combat world poverty that are to be broadcast live over the World Wide Web.
The promoters say they have verbal commitments from Sting, U2, John Mellencamp, Celine Dion, Lauryn Hill and Jewel to perform in the concerts, which will take place at Giants Stadium in New Jersey, Wembley Stadium in London and the Opera House in Geneva, Switzerland. The concert event, to be called "Net Aid," will be broadcast live at the Web site www.netaid.com., along with information about poverty relief organizations and other ways to help the poor. Other, shorter concerts are planned at world landmarks, with the Great Wall in China, the Great Pyramids of Egypt and the Eiffel Tower under consideration. 
 The plans are to be announced today at the United Nations today. The United Nations Development Program is a co-sponsor of the effort with Cisco Systems Inc., the Internet communications equipment company.
"The overarching idea," said Doug Wills, a spokesman for Cisco Systems," is to educate people about how much extreme poverty exists, poverty that isn't seen on the nightly news, and to provide a rallying point for individuals, companies and even countries to offer aid."
"Live Aid" and "Farm Aid" have raised $80 million for famine relief in Africa and to help American famers. The organizers will be working with Ken Kragen, Jeff Pollack, Don Mischer and Harvey Goldsmith, producers whose credits include several music-based benefits in addition to "Live Aid" and "Farm Aid." 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: April 28, 1999, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about three benefit concerts to be held in New Jersey, London and Geneva, for awareness of world poverty, included an erroneous reference, supplied by a sponsor and a publicity agent, to the series producers' past credits. The producers -- Ken Kragen, Jeff Pollack, Don Mischer and Harvey Goldsmith -- were responsible for "Live Aid," "We Are the World" and "Hands Across America" but not for "Farm Aid." (The coming series, to be broadcast live on the World Wide Web, is Net Aid.)
