HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
Barolos Put on a Friendlier Face

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
I HAVE to confess it had been a long time since I'd had anything to do with Barolo, a treasure of Italian winemaking. You know how it is: so many wines, so little time.
Besides, there had always been an excuse to drink something else. Barolo had something forbidding about it. The Italians call it the king of wines and, in fact, there is a regal quality to it: words like monumental and powerful are used to describe it. The wine writer Hugh Johnson once complained that Barolo "gives the palate a wrestling match." 
 To me, Barolo was a powerful, astringent wine, like Hermitage and some old-fashioned California cabernets, that required years of tasting to understand. It was also one that was expensive and needed aging, usually about 10 years, to be drinkable. All reasons to put it on the back burner.
Then recently I heard that one of the better-known Barolo winemakers, Pio Boffa, was coming to New York from the Piedmont region to be the host of a tasting of the Barolos produced by his family's company, Pio Cesare. It seemed a good time for a reassessment.
First things first: Barolo is named after a town in the hills southwest of Alba. Turin, some 45 miles to the northwest, is the nearest big city. The official Barolo district covers 3,000 acres in and around Barolo and includes communes like La Morra, Castiglione Falletto and Serralunga d'Alba, whose names will show up on Barolos made within their borders.
Barolo is made exclusively from nebbiolo, a Piedmontese grape of ancient heritage. Once, Barolo was a sweet wine. In the 1840's, the French wife of a local nobleman hired a French winemaker, Louis Oudinot, to transform Barolo into a dry wine in the French style. The new style soon became the only style.
Pio Cesare started his wine business in Alba in 1881, making Barolo, Barbaresco, barbera and dolcetto. Mr. Boffa, his grandson, is head of the firm now and considers Barolo his signature wine. While respecting the traditional methods, he, like most other Barolo producers, has introduced some major changes over the last 20 years to make his wine somewhat easier to drink.
The results were clearly evident in the wines he opened here last week, which began with the 1955 vintage and included 1964, 1974, 1979, 1982, 1985, 1989 and 1990. There were also samples from the yet unbottled 1995, 1996, 1997 and 1998 vintages, plus four examples of Ornato, his single-vineyard Barolo, from 1988, 1989, 1990 and 1995.
In the old days, Barolo was made in large Yugoslavian oak casks, some of them at least 40 years old. The grapes and their skins were allowed to ferment in these casks for up to two months to extract every bit of fruit, and tannin, which gives wines backbone. The wines were aged in these casks for eight years, then transferred to large glass jugs to age further on the roof, in the sun.
The resulting wines were inky-dark monsters. The winemakers realized that changes had to be made if they wanted to attract more customers. By 1978, the Pio Cesare firm had begun installing stainless steel fermentation tanks and cutting the amount of time the juice and the skins were in contact, to reduce the amount of tannin. Eventually, all the old Yugoslavian casks were replaced by small French oak barrels.
In an article last year in International Wine Cellar, a consumer newsletter, the wine broker Marc de Grazia said winemaking in Barolo had improved so much in recent years that "for the first time, we can taste Barolos from 20 or 30 producers that are all carefully crafted and taste radically different."
Certainly Mr. Boffa's wines varied considerably from the older to the younger vintages. Both the 1955 and the 1964 showed a freshness and vibrancy that few Bordeaux of the same age could ever muster. They are exceptional wines. The control of tannins in the younger ones produced richer, sweeter wines with none of the harshness once associated with Barolo.
Oak was evident in the Ornatos, but it was hardly intrusive. In fact, it helped fashion wines that combine unusual smoothness and elegance with the dark, smoky character typical of good Barolos.
Mr. de Grazia and other experts say that consumer interest has been shifting away from Tuscany and the so-called super-Tuscan blends of sangiovese with cabernet and merlot to the wine of the Piedmont. If true, this is good for the Piedmont winemakers, but less so for wine enthusiasts, because the Piedmont produces far less wine than Tuscany: fewer than 600,000 cases of Barolo are produced in a good year.
Barolo may be more approachable than it once was, but don't be fooled: it's still not a wine for casual drinking. Still, that shouldn't scare you away from what could be a great experience.
Other well-known Barolo producers to be found in the American market include Aldo Conterno, with his magnificent Gran Bussia Riserva; Bruno Giacosa, with his Falletto di Serralunga Riserva; Angelo Gaja, with his Barolo Sperss, and Bruno Cerretto, known for his Barolo Zonchera. There is also Elio Grasso, known for his Barolo Vigna Casa Mate; Luciano Sandrone, for his Barolo Cannubi Boschis, and Alfredo Prunotto, for his Barolo Monte Stefano, among others.
Pio Cesare Barolos range in price from around $35 for the regular 1993, now in stores, to around $90 for the 1993 Ornato. Many of the best Barolos, made in tiny quantities, sell for well over $100 a bottle, but for a newcomer to the wine it makes sense, both economically and enologically, to start with a simple example, like Grasso's Vigna Casa Mate 1993, at about $30.
 
TASTINGS
Out of a Blend
Trefethen Vineyards Cabernet Franc 1996, Napa Valley, Calif. About $20.
 A LITTLE less fruity, a little lighter-bodied than cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc has made a name for itself in the Loire Valley and in St.-Emilion, where it is the major component in the wine of Chateau Cheval Blanc. In the Medoc and in Northern California, it's often blended into cabernet sauvignon to add complexity and structure. In Chinon and Bourgueil, in the Loire, it produces a red that is both fruity and lean at the same time.
The Trefethen displays some of that restraint, but the 10 percent merlot and 7 percent cabernet sauvignon that have been added tend to soften it a bit. A good wine and a nice break from cabernet sauvignon, but it would nice to taste the cabernet franc strictly on its own.

HEADLINE: Ejido Pino Gordo Journal;
All Across Mexico, a Chainsaw Massacre of Trees

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: EJIDO PINO GORDO, Mexico

 BODY:
The shepherds of this remote mountain settlement till the earth behind oaken plows and grind their corn between smooth stones. They have no television, telephones or electricity. Yet by one standard, the village enjoys vast wealth: it is surrounded by magnificent forests.
So when outsiders recently bulldozed a logging road and began applying chainsaws to hundreds of 200-year-old trees, villagers panicked. Men, women and children walked for 36 hours across a canyon to board buses for the Chihuahua state capital, where they held a sit-in at the Governor's Palace this month. 
 "We don't want our forests felled," a Raramuri-speaking Indian leader, Francisco Ramos, told authorities through an interpreter in negotiations that followed. "We didn't plant the trees, God did, to collect water from the rain and give homes to the animals. The trees are not our property. We're just taking care of them."
Government officials were stunned by the Indian protest and the news coverage it prompted, and Chihuahua state officials recently announced a halt to the illegal logging around the village in the Sierra Madre, about 850 miles northwest of Mexico City, at least for now. But a federal official denied that any decision had been made. Conservationists said they hoped for an environmental victory, but it was only one skirmish in a war for Mexico's beleaguered forests.
All across Mexico -- from Chihuahua in the north, to the central woodland preserves that are wintering grounds for North America's monarch butterflies, to the tropical jungles of Chiapas in the south -- timberlands are being cleared at a devastating rate. Poachers are even cutting the few surviving forest preserves around Mexico City.
"Deforestation is pushing us toward environmental collapse," said Senator Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, who has proposed legislation to create a National Forestry Commission with broad powers to confront what he calls an emergency. "The Government should declare a national forestry disaster."
The country has destroyed half its forests in four decades and, unless the devastation slows, will finish them off in half a century, Senator Aguilar said in an interview. Mexico's forests still cover an area larger than California. But since it is mountainous, Mexico needs extensive timberlands to capture rain water and prevent flooding, he said.
One year ago, wildfires that sent smoke clouds drifting into Florida and Texas focused American attention on the crisis. But far more trees are lost every year in Mexico to timber clearing or to the cultivation of crops than are lost to fires.
"Illegal logging is out of control," said Leticia Merino, an anthropologist at a branch of the Autonomous National University in Cuernavaca, south of Mexico City, who is studying timber poaching.
Some trees are felled by poor farmers who use the timber to build homes or to sell to firewood vendors. More destruction is caused by companies who engage in large-scale illegal logging, often in collaboration with corrupt officials, she said. Sometimes drug traffickers muscle in, using sawmill operations to launder drug profits.
Mexican forest policy has been marked by zigzags. In the 1930's, land reform gave 9,000 Indian and farming communities control over 80 percent of the country's forests, a higher percentage than anywhere else in the world. The communities, called ejidos, took on the role played by the Forest Service in the United States: fighting fires, planting trees and managing the harvest of timber.
But successive Governments encouraged thousands of rural poor people to clear forests for the grazing of cattle. The most damaging of such projects were abandoned in the last decade, but one farm program still pays rural people an annual subsidy for each acre of forest cleared for farming.
Currently, Mexico's entire budget for all forest-related programs totals only about $90 million, Senator Aguilar said. Responsibility for enforcing forestry laws across Mexico lies with just a few dozen inspectors.
Forestry laws passed in recent years encourage ejido communities to divide forests into plots and to sign timber-harvesting deals with logging companies. But many forest communities that sign timber contracts end up in peonage, owing increasing sums to logging companies each year, despite the harvest of entire forests.
In one Chihuahua village, for example, a logging company harvested 103 million cubic feet of lumber in 1992, yet at year's end the village owed $16,000 more than when the year began, according to village records.
David Barton Bray, an environmental studies professor at Florida International University in Miami, said that 17 million people still live in Mexico's woodlands. Policies should help them earn a livelihood from the forests even as they manage and conserve them, he said.
"For many peasant and indigenous people, forests are not only an economic resource, but also a spiritual wellspring and a source of ethnic identity," Mr. Bray said. Such is the case of the Chihuahua Indians who speak a language called Raramuri. They are often called Tarahumara by outsiders.
"Forests are fundamental to their cosmic vision," said Isela Gonzalez Diaz, an anthropologist who helped advise the Pino Gordo villagers during the recent negotiations.
Pino Gordo lies next to Coloradas de los Chavez, a rival village of Spanish-speaking people. Coloradas leaders are privatizing their village forests, and last year the federal Government issued a permit allowing the village to sign contracts with a logging consortium.
But the loggers soon jumped the boundaries of Coloradas, cutting roads into Pino Gordo's forests and felling trees there. Pino Gordo villagers complained to authorities, but got no response until the recent protest.
During the negotiations, one Indian leader asked why the Government would issue a permit to Coloradas de los Chavez to cut forests that are habitat for endangered fauna, including the thick-billed parrot and the jaguarundi wildcat.
"If we were to restrict the cutting of forests wherever there is fauna in danger, we'd risk being in the same situation as the United States, where most forest lands are now off limits to logging," responded Leonel Iglesias, an official from the federal Environment Ministry based in Chihuahua. "Mexico has economic needs that are different than the developed countries. We need greater flexibility in our forest management."
The authorities insisted repeatedly that there was no illegal logging in the Pino Gordo region and that the Indians were simply confused about their village boundaries.
But as the talks proceeded, journalists and environmentalists who traveled to Pino Gordo found men with chainsaws and hydraulic winches felling trees on Pino Gordo's hillsides. One logger, Curberto Bustillo Acosta, said each man in his crew had been cutting 200 trees a day in the area.
As the Indian protest drew news coverage, Government officials eventually agreed to send surveyors and other state and federal officials to Pino Gordo. By the time they arrived, the loggers had fled. But, seeing hillsides covered with stumps, state officials said they had ordered the suspension of logging that had already stopped. Federal officials said they were still studying the dispute.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 511 words

HEADLINE: China's Muffled Protesters

 BODY:
The large, silent demonstration in Beijing last Sunday by members of a spiritual sect was the biggest protest in China's capital since the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square 10 years ago. Yet China's leaders allowed the peaceful sit-in to go on all day right outside the top leadership's compound, and there are reports that Prime Minister Zhu Rongji met with several members of the group. The Government has responded cautiously because the group represents a popular social movement. China's leaders are hoping to control a phenomenon whose ancient antecedents brought down several Chinese dynasties, and which presents a challenge of uncertain dimensions to Communist Party rule.
The Government estimates that Buddhist Law, the nonviolent sect that staged the protest, has 70 million adherents in China. Members practice a form of qigong, an ancient Chinese belief in the healing and even supernatural powers of harnessing a specific bodily energy. The Buddhist Law sect mixes qigong with Buddhism and opposes consumerism, rock music, television, extramarital sex and use of alcohol. Its leader, Li Hongzhi, was pressured to leave China and now lives in New York. 
 Qigong has not always been associated with nonviolent activities. In the third century a qigong-style movement that used faith healing and predicted the end of the world took over a fourth of the country and helped bring about the fall of the Han dynasty. Similar movements in the Middle Ages and late 18th century led to violent upheavals. Qigong was also central to the Boxer Rebellion against foreigners early this century, as the fighters believed qigong protected them from bullets.
Today, in a time of rapid modernization, unemployment, mass migration to the cities and a relaxation of Communist Party control of people's private lives, qigong is once again growing. It is so popular, and such a part of Chinese history, that many party leaders themselves practice some form of it. They cannot simply dismiss it as foreign, their typical slur on the democracy movement.
In the 1980's, the Communist Party began trying to attract support by adopting aspects of popular ancient doctrines, like Confucianism and qigong. The party endorsed the ancient notion that qigong beliefs were part of Chinese medicine. The leadership's strategy this week seems to be similar. It wants to avoid responding harshly, which could alienate millions, and is trying to befriend the sect's leaders and use its support to increase the party's legitimacy.
While normally any organized challenge to the Communist Party is something to applaud in China, students of Chinese history are wary of Buddhist Law. Hundreds of qigong organizations have sprung up around China in recent years. Some are simply health and exercise groups, but others are being used by demagogues. Especially if the economy slows, China can expect even more rapid growth in a movement symptomatic of people's search for meaning in a time of uncertainty. Whether it will be constructive for China remains to be seen.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE;
Immigrant Planning a Window Factory in Queens

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
In 1982, when he was 27, Thomas Chen arrived in New York from Taiwan, looking for opportunities and planning to bring his wife and young son over to join him when he could afford it. He settled in Elmhurst, Queens, and found a job in a sweater factory.
He knew something about ironwork and soon he was making window guards in the basement of his building and installing them for homeowners. Then he rented half a floor in a factory building on Bergen Street in Flatbush, Brooklyn, to make aluminum windows with two brothers and an employee. 
 Now he finds himself running Crystal Windows and Door Systems, which is in 100,000 square feet of rented space at 131-10 Maple Avenue in Flushing, Queens, and will end the current fiscal year on Friday with $24.5 million in sales. Mr. Chen founded the company in 1990 to make aluminum windows for commercial buildings and apartments, and later expanded into vinyl windows. With a work force of 160 in Flushing, the company makes 200,000 windows a year. Mr. Chen's wife, Anna, arrived in 1983 and helped him build the business, he said. A friend in Taiwan, Kay Hsieh, is a partner.
Last June, Crystal bought a 174,000-square-foot site along 31st Avenue in the College Point Corporate Park in Queens, and he plans to start construction next month on a new manufacturing plant with 144,000 square feet of space. That a new manufacturing plant of that size is being built in New York City is unusual enough. That it is happening in the College Point park is particularly notable since it represents precisely the type of land use that city officials thought they would get when they designated 550 acres of land as the College Point Industrial Park in 1974.
Instead, despite the construction of a printing plant by The New York Times and one or two small buildings, it has seemed that retailing and office uses have become the chief elements in private development in the park. The word "industrial" has been excised from the name and replaced with the more general word "corporate."
Some of the more recent projects are more specifically retail- or entertainment-oriented. Last year, the Related Companies completed a 330,000-square-foot building for four retail chains -- Target, B.J.'s Wholesale Club, T.J. Maxx and Circuit City -- plus a Boulder Creek restaurant. It is on 20th Avenue, the main commercial thoroughfare through the park, running from the Whitestone Expressway across the flat development zone to the eastern boundary of the older industrial neighborhood of College Point at 130th Street.
Earlier, Waldbaum's built a supermarket on 20th Avenue, along with a training center for employees, and last year a new Staples store opened on part of the Waldbaum's site.
Now in construction on 20th Avenue is a retail building of 74,000 square feet, which will have several stores. The developer is Triangle Equities, a seven-year-old development company based in the park. Its president is Lester Petracca.
At another location -- the Whitestone Expressway at 28th Avenue -- Triangle Equities is developing the College Point Family Entertainment and Retail Center, a two-story building with 140,000 square feet that will have a 12-screen multiplex theater operated by National Amusements Inc. It will open next month. The retail component of the project, at street level, will have Toys "R" Us and Kids "R" Us stores. The architect is Angelo Francis Corva, of Manhasset, N.Y.
Development companies have been acquiring sites in the corporate park through the city's Economic Development Corporation. The largest undeveloped site is the former Flushing Airport, 75 acres of soggy land requiring deep piling, at a high cost, for new construction. Development prospects there are least hopeful. But negotiations are in progress on four more-promising sites, covering 17 acres, said Charles Millard, president of the development corporation. Ron Brill, who acts as a liaison for the corporation between park users and city agencies, is expected to have a permanent office there by the end of the summer.
The Crystal Windows land was bought from City Gates Manufacturing, a College Point maker of steel doors, which bought it 15 years ago intending to build, said Vincent Greco, the president. But City Gates ultimately chose to sell.
The irregularly shaped property stretches 946 feet along 31st Avenue between College Point Boulevard to the north service road of the Whitestone Expressway, where it has 233 feet of frontage. The architect, Raymond Chan of Queens, said the exterior would be metal-clad panels and the signs would be in English.
Since a sewer easement runs through the center of the land, Crystal plans to build separate structures, one on a single floor and the other on two, each one totaling about 70,000 square feet of space. They will be separated by a driveway over the sewer easement. Half the space will be devoted to manufacturing and the other half to warehousing and offices.
"We'll be able to meet our goal of doubling or tripling our production within five years in the new plant," said Robert E. Nyman, vice president for sales and marketing. The site was chosen because it is close to the main customer base in New York City and has excellent access to the highway system. The company sells to installers, contractors, window dealers and distributors, rather than consumers, Mr. Nyman said.
Crystal Windows is not alone among businesses that were founded by Asian immigrants in Queens and have expanded there. George G. Sirras, principal in Major Development Inc., a commercial and industrial brokerage in Flushing, said that his company has dealt with several hundred such businesses over 20 years.
Of those several hundred start-ups, "about a hundred companies survive in one form or another after five years," Mr. Sirras said. He added, "Crystal Windows is remarkable for getting to a sales level that it usually takes a family business two or three generations to reach."

HEADLINE: Home Resales Set Record Pace; ConsumerConfidence Up Again

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes unexpectedly rose to a record pace in March, industry figures showed today, and consumer confidence in the economy increased in April for the sixth consecutive month, suggesting economic growth could accelerate in coming months.
"Consumers continue to remain optimistic, jobs remain plentiful and wages continue to rise," said Brian Wesbury, chief economist at Griffin Kubik Stephens & Thompson in Chicago. "All of which is good news for the economy as we move into the future." 
 Home resales increased six-tenths of a percent last month, to an annual rate of 5.05 million, topping the previous record of 5.04 million set in January, the National Association of Realtors said. Analysts had forecast that March sales would register a 4.93 million rate.
Consumer confidence also rose more than expected, with the index rising to 134.9 this month from 134 in March, according to the Conference Board, a research group based in New York. The index is now at the highest level since last July.
Consumer spending has been the driving force behind the current economic expansion, the nation's longest in peacetime. Unemployment fell to a 29-year low of 4.2 percent last month, while inflation was running at a 1.5 percent annual rate -- the lowest in 13 years.
"When jobs are strong and consumer confidence is high, that puts people in the buying mood," said Joel Rassman, chief financial officer of Toll Brothers Inc., a builder of luxury homes.
Prices of existing homes rose 2.5 percent in March, the biggest gain since June, the realty group's report showed. The median price of a previously owned home was $132,700, up from $129,500 a month earlier. Existing-home prices have risen 4.4 percent in the last 12 months, mostly because of a 9.5 percent surge in the West.
In March, the average rate on a 30-year mortgage was 7.04 percent, up from February's average of 6.81 percent, according to Freddie Mac, the mortgage-financing giant. In April, the average weekly rate has fallen back below the 7 percent mark, suggesting that the market may strengthen further.
Separate indexes in the Conference Board's report showed that consumers remained confident across the board. The index that tracks expectations for the next six months rose for the fourth consecutive month. The index gauging whether consumers thought jobs were plentiful rose for a second month and was near the high set in February.
Indexes measuring consumer plans to buy houses, cars and major appliances stayed in the ranges they have been in all year.

HEADLINE: AT&T Profit Surges 42% On Cost Cuts

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Even as it continued its flurry of deal-making, the AT&T Corporation reported strong financial results for the first quarter yesterday, exceeding analysts' expectations. But investors did not rush to buy AT&T's shares as uncertainty continued about the company's unsolicited $58 billion bid to acquire Mediaone Group Inc., the big cable television company.
Earnings for AT&T, the nation's biggest communications company, rose 42 percent from the first quarter of last year, largely because of an aggressive cost-cutting campaign by C. Michael Armstrong, the company's chairman of 18 months. More important, AT&T showed signs of finally emerging from the revenue funk it had been stuck in for years, increasing sales by more than 6 percent over the corresponding period of 1998. 
 As expected, AT&T also announced a partnership with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the world's biggest phone company, to provide comprehensive packages of communications services to multinational corporations in Japan and perhaps other parts of Asia. AT&T has formed a separate joint venture with British Telecommunications P.L.C., and if AT&T can work well with both partners, it will have gone a long way toward realizing its global ambitions.
But it is AT&T's ambitions in the United States that continue both to excite and worry investors.
One of the main questions facing Wall Street, not to mention the board of Mediaone -- which had already agreed to sell the company to the Comcast Corporation -- is how feasible AT&T's offer really is from a legal and regulatory perspective.
Naturally, those are questions that also preoccupy Comcast, which needs to gauge AT&T's offer before deciding whether to make a serious counterbid of its own. Executives close to Comcast said yesterday that while the company had weighed a variety of options, it had not yet decided quite how to respond to the AT&T bid.
The ideal development for Comcast would be for William E. Kennard, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to denounce AT&T's plan to take over Mediaone as "unthinkable," just as Mr. Kennard's predecessor, Reed E. Hundt, did when AT&T tried to merge with SBC Communications Inc., one of the Bell local phone companies, in 1997.
But that seems unlikely, and not just because Mr. Kennard is more diplomatic than Mr. Hundt. The regulations on concentration of ownership in cable television are in limbo, and it is not clear that anyone in the industry, even Comcast, necessarily wants the situation resolved in a way that would prevent AT&T from acquiring Mediaone.
In 1992, Congress directed the F.C.C. to draft rules to prevent the cable television industry from becoming an oligopoly. In response, the commission issued regulations generally stating that no one company could own cable systems that covered more than 30 percent of homes in the United States in which cable television was available. These days, cable is available to about 95 million of the nation's roughly 100 million households.
A loophole in the rules said that a company could expand its stake to 35 percent if it did so by acquiring cable companies controlled by racial minorities.
The commission's rules were challenged by Daniels Cablevision Inc., which persuaded a Federal judge in Washington to declare that the law requiring the F.C.C.'s concentration rules violated the First Amendment rights of the cable carriers.
In response to that decision, the commission suspended its rules. Since 1993 the case has been sitting before a Federal appeals court in Washington, where it could drag on for another year.
No one really knows what, if any, restrictions on concentration will eventually be adopted and upheld. And that makes it difficult to determine the relative regulatory merits of the AT&T and Comcast bids for Mediaone. In fact, both bids might be in violation of the original rules.
Comcast, factoring in its deal to acquire Jones Intercable, owns systems offering service to about 9.4 million homes. Mediaone offers service to about 8.5 million. Together that is about 18 million homes, considerably fewer than the 28.5 million that would constitute 30 percent of the 95 million cable-accessible homes.
The potential problem is Mediaone's 25.5 percent stake in Time Warner Entertainment, a venture that includes most of the cable operations of Time Warner Inc. The stayed F.C.C. rules state that any active investor that owns more than 5 percent of a cable operation must count all of the homes potentially served by that operation in calculating the 30 percent limit. Time Warner systems may be available to as many as 18 million homes. Including those systems would raise Comcast's reach to as many as 36 million homes, far above the old limit.
For AT&T, the potential numbers are much higher. With its purchase of Tele-Communications Inc., AT&T already owns cable systems available to 18 million homes. Add in Mediaone and its Time Warner interest and the figure becomes as high as 44.5 million. And that does not even include TCI's numerous affiliates, which are available to another 13 million homes.
So in the battle for Mediaone, both AT&T and Comcast need whatever new rules that emerge to be quite a bit more lenient than the current regulations. For Comcast, the trick is to have the rules relaxed a bit, so that it can acquire Mediaone, but not enough to enable AT&T to do the same thing.
As complex (and potentially moot) as the stayed cable rules are, Time Warner Entertainment could pose yet another problem for AT&T.
When Time Warner acquired Turner Broadcasting System Inc., John C. Malone, who was then the chairman of TCI and who had a big stake in Turner, agreed not to acquire any more Time Warner stock. Comcast could contend that Mr. Malone's agreement now applies to AT&T and that AT&T would violate that deal by acquiring Mediaone and assuming its stake in Time Warner Entertainment.
AT&T's response to that possibility is that the Malone agreement applies only to Liberty Media, the programming operation that is publicly traded as an AT&T tracking stock but in which AT&T has no economic interest. That leaves AT&T itself free to invest in Time Warner Entertainment (or Time Warner Inc., for that matter), AT&T says.
Concerns about AT&T's Mediaone bid (which also include concerns about the deal's dilution of AT&T's future earnings) may have obscured a robust quarterly financial report for AT&T.
Including the effects of a recent 3-for-2 stock split -- but not including one-time charges and the effects of the TCI acquisition, which was completed last month -- AT&T earned $1.78 billion, or 67 cents a share, up from $1.25 billion, or 46 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. That beat the 63-cent average estimate of analysts polled by First Call, a research firm.
Including the effects of the TCI deal and special charges, AT&T earned $1.08 billion, or 38 cents a post-split share, down from $1.3 billion, or 48 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1998.
Propelled by strong gains in the wireless unit and in sales to business customers, AT&T's revenue, excluding TCI, increased 6.1 percent, to $13.61 billion, from $12.83 billion in the corresponding period last year. Including TCI, revenue increased almost 10 percent, to $14.1 billion from $12.83 billion.
AT&T's stock closed yesterday at $53, up 6.25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
